PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Environment and Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, wish to record our support for the One World Declaration:
to focus Australian aid, and policies at the World Bank, IMF and Asian Development Bank, on fighting poverty and protecting the environment,
to restore Australian aid to 0.5 per cent of GNP, cut military spending by 1 per cent and work for a fairer international economic system,
to promote human rights through aid and a code of conduct for companies.
Your petitioner humbly pray that the House of Representatives call upon the government to implement the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann (from 263 citizens), Mr Aldred (from 262 citizens), Mr Bilney (from 90 citizens), Mr Blanchard (from 100 citizens), Dr Blewett (from 223 citizens), Mr Braithwaite (from 28 citizens), Mr Ian Cameron (from 31 citizens), Mr Cobb (from 461 citizens), Mr Dobie (from 48 citizens), Mr Fife (from 129 citizens), Mr Fitzgibbon (from 587 citizens), Mr Griffiths (from 545 citizens), Mr Hand (from 781 citizens), Mr Hawke (from 161 citizens), Mr Hawker (from 121 citizens), Mr Hollis (from 74 citizens), Mrs Jakobsen (from 119 citizens), Mr Barry Jones (from 25 citizens), Mr Kerr (from 810 citizens), Mr Lindsay (from 59 citizens), Mr McArthur (from 154 citizens), Mr Macphee (from 130 citizens), Mr Millar (from 72 citizens), Mr Milton (from 112 citizens), Mr Rocher (from 218 citizens), Mr Scholes (from 500 citizens), Mr Sharp (from 116 citizens), Mr Simmons (from 213 citizens), Mr Taylor (from 28 citizens), Dr Theophanous (from 98 citizens) and Dr Wooldridge (from 327 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987-88 taxpayers' funds through Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State public hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt (from 56 citizens), Mr Cadman (from 374 citizens), Mr Ian Cameron (from 16 citizens), Mr Cobb (from 43 citizens), Mr Connolly (from 13 citizens), Mr Dobie (from 21 citizens), Mr Dubois (from 739 citizens), Dr Harry Edwards (from 24 citizens), Mr Ronald Edwards (from 235 citizens), Mr Hicks (from 37 citizens), Mr Hollis (from 19 citizens), Mr Johns (from 29 citizens), Mr Katter (from 24 citizens), Mr Kerin (from 22 citizens), Mr Martin (from 50 citizens), Mr Rocher (from 108 citizens), Mr Ruddock (from 293 citizens), Mr Simmons (from 122 citizens), Mr Snowdon (from 33 citizens) and Mr Tickner (from 239 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they:

1. Deplore the changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme ``Authority only'' drug list and the delisting of frequently prescribed drugs without ensuring that alternative products are readily available.

2. Deplore the proposed restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which will reduce both remuneration to pharmacists and the standard of professional service and counselling provided by pharmacists to ensure that patients follow appropriate medication usage regimes.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House do everything in its power to call on the Minister for Housing and Aged Care and the Minister for Community Services and Health to reconsider the restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hicks (from 94 citizens), Mr Kerin (from 120 citizens), Mr Pratt (from 99 citizens) and Mr Spender (from 166 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they:

Deplore the proposed changes to the method of Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration which will affect the quality of service and counselling the pharmacist will be able to provide to the public and which could force the closure of up to 30 per cent of Australia's pharmacies.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House do everything in its power to call on the Minister for Housing and Aged Care and the Minister for Community Services and Health to reconsider these proposed changes to the method of Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration.

PETITION.TITLE: International Earth Repair Action Decade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives assembled:
The petition of concerned Australian citizens respectifully points out that:
our total global environment is rapidly deteriorating;
important natural rsources vital to human life and livelihood such as ozone, trees, soil and the purity of air and water are being depleted at an increasing and alarming rate;
there is an urgent need to educate all people in conservation skills and the responsible use and maintenance of natural resources;
the United Nations Association of Australia (the peoples' arm of the UN), has proclaimed an Australian ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade from 1988:
Earth Repair Action will unite people, communities, religions and nations in the productive purpose of greening and repairing our Earth for a safer and more peaceful future.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:

Propose that a world-wide ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade begin on World Environment Day, June 5, 1990 with FIERY, the First International, Earth Repair Year, and that this be proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly. This ten-year plan will ignite the spirit of local and global co-operation to stop the current destruction and start repairing our Earth by: growing billions of trees to replace forests lost and to replenish the atmosphere; hygienically composting all presently wasted bio-degradable materials into humus to revitalise soils; establishing globally, economically viable, permanent self-sustaining organic agriculture to end world hunger.
(See Draft Resolution to the United Nations)
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bilney (from 10 citizens), Mr Dobie (from 12 citizens) and Dr Harry Edwards (from 24 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Community Pharmacists
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

That the proposed reduction in pharmacists' remuneration under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme will be such as to produce severe cutback in the provision of services by community pharmacy in this country and will, therefore, cause unnecessary hardship and anguish to the sick and aged of this country.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House:
Takes all action within its power to bring about significant and decisive consultation between the government and pharmacists of Australia so as to produce:
A resolution of the matter which maintains both high quality health care for the community and equity for the community pharmacists of Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann (from 630 citizens) and Mr Moore (from 40 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their patient's particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to seek permission from a bureaucrat from Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman (from 108 citizens) and Mr Tickner (from 27 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Chlorofluorocarbons and Halons
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
This petition of certain students, citizens of Australia and stewards of the earth draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned about ozone depletion.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his Government to:
change our legislation in the Spring Session of Parliament this year to enact a total phase-out of consumption of CFCs and halons by 1994;
reduce our export quotas immediately and then phase-out exports by 20% per annum, with a complete phase-out of production and export of CFCs and halons by 1995;
support the above phase-out schedules at the Montreal Protocol in April 1990.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Charlesworth (from 24 citizens) and Mr Peacock (from 13,437 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.

This petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the House to the Government's actions in relation to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of service to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the House to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, so as to guarantee the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
We, the undersigned residents of Western Australia, draw the attention of the House to:
(a) the decision of the Government to increase the rate of the social security pension by $2 for single rate and $3.30 for married pensioners;
(b) the fact that this increase will not be received by pensioners until the pension payday in April 1990 at which a Consumer Price Index adjustment will also occur;

(c) the fact that this increase will raise the rate of the pension to a level at least equivalent to 25% of male employees' average weekly earnings, in fulfilment of a promise made by the Prime Minister in 1983.

We therefore pray that your House will urge the Government to increase the pension as indicated on the pension payday in November 1989 at which a Consumer Price Index adjustment will also occur, in view of the delay in fulfilment of the Prime Minister's 1983 promise.

PETITION.TITLE: Disposable Nappies
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the House's attention to the presence of the cancer-causing waste product, dioxin, in babies' disposable nappies which can be in direct skin contact for 2 years.
Your petitioners respectfully request the House to urge the Government to:
(1) Initiate independent research into the precise levels of dioxin in disposable nappies.
(2) Legislate to force nappy manufacturers to remove dioxin from these products.
(3) Place pressure on nappy manufacturers to produce these products from unbleached paper therefore eliminating a significant cause of the presence of dioxin.
(4) Place pressure on nappy manufacturers to produce bio-degradable disposable nappies which will be less harmful to the environment.

PETITION.TITLE: Tampons and Sanitary Products
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the House's attention to the presence of the cancer-causing waste product, Dioxin, in tampons and sanitary products.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully request the House to urge the Government to-
1. Initiate independent research into the precise levels of Dioxin in tampons and sanitary products.
2. Legislate to force paper manufacturers to remove Dioxin from these products.
3. Place pressure on paper manufacturers to produce these products from unbleached paper therefore eliminating a significant cause of the presence of Dioxin.
4. Place pressure on paper manufacturers to produce biodegradable sanitary products which will be safe for women.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortion Funding Abolition Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1988-89 the Federal Government paid $6.9 million from taxpayers' funds for 64,788 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by supporting the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1989 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights: Vietnam
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
That the Australian Parliament expresses its repugnance that the Socialist Republic of Vietnam has kept imprisoned, 47 Buddhist leaders since 1984.

And further, that the regime in Vietnam has recently tried and sentenced to death: Thich Tri Sieu and Thich Tue Sy, two distinguished scholars from amongst the 47. Both of these religious academics are intellectuals of the highest order, being scholars in Buddhist Scripture.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to denounce the intentions of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam and to call on the Vietnamese Government for clemency and a remission of the death sentence as being barbaric.

PETITION.TITLE: Brain Injury Therapy Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that there is a need for continuing research into the problems of patients, following brain trauma, assessed `comatose', or `vegetative', and for all such patients to have Brain Injury Therapy readily available to them immediately following the Intensive Care Unit, in a special Coma Care/Brain Injury Therapy Unit, such therapy to involve paid Health Care Professionals, family members and volunteers, and later, where possible, on home based programmes, with daily access to the facilities of the Unit; hydrotherapy an essential component.

The aim is to assist each patient to attain his/her individual maximum potential, and reach the greatest degree of independence possible; a cost effective alternative to long term nursing home and terminal care centres.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will take action:
To ensure the continuation of the Brain Injury Therapy Centre at Eastwood NSW;
To enable a research programme to be carried out at the Brain Injury Therapy Centre with twenty `warehoused' patients for a minimum period of twelve months;
To have brain injury rehabilitation funded through Medicare;

To establish Coma Care/Brain Injury Therapy Centres in each major centre, providing intensive therapy of up to eight (8) hours on at least five (5) days of each week, involving paid Health Care Professionals, family members, and volunteers;

To provide adequate support to families who are willing to provide a home based Brain Injury Therapy programme for a patient who would otherwise be hospitalised. (Adequate support to include Respite Care of six (6) weeks per year, Attendant Care, and a patients' bed linen and napkin service).
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement: Saving and Investment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Represenatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain electors of the Division of Mitchell draws to the attention of the House:
The constant changes to retirement and veterans' benefits.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
Reject the Federal Government's punitive treatment of those who have prepared for retirement by careful saving and wise investment.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens respectfully draws to the attention of the House:
`the inability of State and Local Government to meet satisfactory road maintenance and construction programmes due to chronically inadequate Federal Government funding'.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled, urge the Government:

`to recognise the threat to human lives from Australia's inadequate road system and increase significantly the existing 23% of present Federal fuel excise now available for road and widen the categories of road now entitled to assistance by measures to be included in the 1988-89 Federal Budget.'
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Antarctica
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by proposed mining activity to the ecological integrity and wilderness values of the Antarctic continent.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his Government to:
withdraw from the signing of the Convention for the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activity (CRAMRA) and extend the moratorium on mining;
take a leading role in preparing a Conservation Convention, that will preserve Antarctica as a World Park and the last wilderness continent on Earth untouched by human exploitative activities;
Continue its high emphasis on environmental protection for the Australian Antarctic Territory.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that major reforms be made to Australia's Retirement Income System. These reforms are earnestly sought by retired Australians and those facing retirement.
The reforms are:
That the pension be increased to 30% of average weekly earnings (i.e. increasing the basic pension to $146 p.w.)
That the pension become tax exempt.
That the pension be adjusted so that it keeps pace with price rises rather than falling up to 12 months behind.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray that your House/Parliament will see that our requested reforms are implemented.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House, that pharmacists, in Australia, have had their very livelihood placed in jeopardy, by the totally unreasonable decisions, of the so called ``independent'' Pharmaceutical Benefits Tribunal, in drastically reducing the remuneration paid to pharmacists for dispensing of prescriptions under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
As a result of these decisions, the essential primary health care functions and services provided (largely free) by pharmacists to the public, have been seriously put at risk.

The replacement of such services could only be fulfilled by an already overtaxed medical profession and at a financial cost that would be virtually impossible to be funded by the Government or the Community.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to, as a matter of extreme urgency, negotiate with the appointed representatives of Australian pharmacists, to ensure that an equitable financial remuneration is granted to these pharmacists for dispensing prescription under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and so protect the essential services now provided by these pharmacists to the Community.

PETITION.TITLE: Breast Cancer Screening
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament, this petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the house that:
about 1 in 16 Australian women develop breast cancer, that 1 in 45 risk dying from it, and that about 2200 actually die from it each year;
while diagnostic mammograms requiring a doctor's referral are covered by Medicare, breast scanning mammograms for women who have no symptoms, or who are in a low risk category, are not.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the House require the Government to:
implement a breast cancer screening programme which is fully covered by Medicare;
make such a programme for routine and expert mammographic examination readily accessible to all women throughout Australia; and

ensure that a suitable education programme offering specialist professional information and advice in regard to this important women's health issue is conducted in conjunction with the screening programme.

PETITION.TITLE: Breast Cancer Screening
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House, that-
about 1 in 16 Australian women develop breast cancer, that 1 in 45 risk dying from it, and that about 2200 actually die from it each year;
while diagnostic mammograms requiring a doctor's referral are covered by Medicare, breast scanning mammograms for women who have no symptoms, or who are in a low risk category, are not.

Your petitioners therefore ask the House to request the Government to implement a breast cancer screening program which is covered by Medicare, and which enables all women throughout Australia to readily access facilities for routine and expert mammographic examination, in conjunction with a suitable education program offering specialist professional information and advice in regard to this important women's health issue.

PETITION.TITLE: Environment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully point out that:
our world environment is rapidly deteriorating,
the irresponsible attitude of our governments, industries and ignorant citizens has seriously threatened out future survival on earth.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
re-educate the citizens of Australia and encourage a more responsible and considerate attitude towards our environment,
communicate this urgent need to all nations of the world and seek an immediate and co-operative response.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now therefore your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating Government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian homeseekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain electors of the Division of Wannon draws to the attention of the House the following:
1. In 1987/88, Australian motorists paid in the order of $6.5 billion in fuel taxes to the Federal Government.
2. In that same year, the Federal Govenment allocated some $1.25 billion for expenditure on roads-less than 20 cents of each $1 collected from fuel taxes.
3. In the past 120 years, only during the two World Wars has investment in road formation in Australia been lower, as a percentage of Gross Domestic Product, than it is at present.
4. Since 1960, vehicle density per kilometre of Australian roads rose from 0.95 vehicles to 2.7 vehicles in 1985-a rise of 184%.
5. In the same period, investment in roads as a proportion of GDP fell from 2.7% in 1960 to slightly more than 1% in 1985-a fall of 61%.
6. In 1987, local government expended more on roads than either the Federal Government or the combined State Governments.

7. The road system is failing in many areas. Many roads are well overdue for reconstruction. Some roads in rural areas cannot be maintained in a sealed state due to funding constraints and are being reverted to an unsealed surface.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to raise the priority listing of roads in the Government's expenditure programmes to ensure that sufficient funding is allocated to:
(a) redress the backlog of road works required to raise the Nation's road network to a standard consistent with that or a progressive, developed country;
(b) ensure that Australia's road network is able to be maintained to a standard acceptable to a country so dependent on road transport; and
(c) permit the progressive improvement and upgrading of the road system so as to keep pace with the demands made upon it.

PETITION.TITLE: New Schools Policy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House that the Government's New Schools Policy unnecessarily restricts the non-Government school sector.
Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives to:
recognise the right of every child to a reasonable level of Commonwealth support for their education;
recognise that parents should be provided with real choice in the schooling they choose for their children;
call upon the Government to abolish the New Schools Policy

PETITION.TITLE: Breast X-Ray Program
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens, electors of the Division of Wannon draws to the attention of the House the following facts about breast cancer in women.
(i) One if fifteen women in Australia get breast cancer.
(ii) 2,500 Australian women each year die of breast cancer.
(iii) the chances of dying of breast cancer can be reduced by 70% by early detection.
(iv) Early detection is best done by regular breast X-rays or mammograms.
(v) Women in Sweden and other developed countries have breast X-rays every 18 months. This service is provided by government medical services.
(vi) Australia has one pilot project in providing regular breast X-rays.
(vii) The failure of the government to introduce a service for regular breast X-rays for all Australian women is taking the lives of 1,750 Australian women each year.
Your petitioners implore the House to implement a programme for regular breast X-rays for all Australian women as soon as is humanly possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Low Interest Housing Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the increase in metropolitan house prices, which, together with the escalation in interest rates, is causing great hardship for many Australians attempting to provide housing for their families.

The petition also draws to the attention of the House the widely expressed need for a higher level of saving in Australia and the fact that the savings of ordinary Australians are currently penalized by taxation.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to enact legislation to provide for:

(a) the establishment of a savings fund open to all Australians but directed to young people for the deposit of a fixed percentage of their income from the time of their entry into the workforce until the age of 25 or earlier marriage;
(b) The exemption from income tax of interest earned on money invested in such a fund; and
(c) The provision by the fund of low interest housing loans to contributors to the fund.

PETITION.TITLE: System of Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of this concerned citizen of Australia respectfully draws to the attention of the House that;
for 2 hundred years we have been governed by a system not of our own choosing but by one that firstly, was by proxy, (as a colony) then, by a modified adopted system;

citizens of Australia are denied the democratic right to change the system of government and economic management that has failed to establish social and economic structures to provide a secure future for all Australian citizens;
citizens of Australia should be given the opportunity to select an alternative that is geared to Australian needs and conditions.

Your petitioner therefore requests that the House enact legislation and establish facilities to enable the ``New Alternative'' to challenge the present system of government at the next federal election.

PETITION.TITLE: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by logging to the integrity an continued existence of what remains of the forests of south eastern Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his government
(1) to phase out woodchipping for export;
(2) Not to renew a long-term export licence to Harris Daishowa;

(3) to ensure that sensitive environmental areas, and specifically the proposed national park and wilderness areas of Coolangubra, Cathcart, Egan Peaks and the Tantawangalo catchment, are protected and excluded from the proposed woodchip licence, and
(4) to promote ecologically sound and sustainable forestry practices including:
re-afforestation and plantation of native hardwoods and already cleared land to reduce pressure on native forests; and
minimisation of wasteful uses of forest products.

PETITION.TITLE: El Salvador
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia humbly pray that:
1. The Parliament heeds our profound concern regarding the Penal Code Reforms of the ARENA Government in El Salvador.

2. We request that as these reforms breach the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and in consideration of the escalation of human rights violations by El Salvadoran Armed forces, the Australian Government convey to the United States that all forms of military aid to the Salvadoran Government should be suspended.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that
the high level of services currently offered by my pharmacist, a frontline provider of medicine, would be threatened if the Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme (PBS) is cut back.

the PBS is one of the most essential and enduring elements of our health care system and its future must not, and should not, be sacrificed by the Government's failure to recognise the extent to which it has placed the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) in jeopardy.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Members of the House of Representatives assembled undertake an urgent reconsideration of efforts to cut expenditure on the PBS by means of reducing pharmacists' remuneration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Pharmacists
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they:
(1) Deplore the changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme drug list and the delisting of frequently prescribed drugs without ensuring that alternative drugs are readily available.
(2) Deplore the proposed restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which will jeopardise the health care of Australians and force many pharmacies out of business.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House do everything in its power to call on the Minister for Housing and Aged Care and the Minister for Community Services and Health to ensure that the viability of community pharmacists is maintained and that people continue to have ready access to the supply of pharmaceuticals and the professional services provided by pharmacists.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Pharmacists
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that we deplore the Federal Government's proposed `restructuring' of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which will jeopardise the health care of Australians and force many pharmacies out of business.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will call on the Government to ensure that the viability of community pharmacists is maintained and that people continue to have ready access to the supply of pharmaceuticals and the professional services provided by pharmacists.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising by Political Parties
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the House to the threat to free speech contained within the recommendations of the majority report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.

We believe that all persons have the right to express their views through paid commercial advertising on television and radio and that any limitation on that right constitutes a threat to the people's freedom of speech and to the Australian democratic system.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Parliament rejects the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and preserves the right of all persons and political parties to exercise their right to free speech through any media they choose.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Investment in Australian Property
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the State of South Australia, draws to the attention of the House that there is increasing levels of foreign investment in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will limit foreign investment in Australian homes, business enterprises, resorts, farms and basic resources to 45% of each purchase.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I present the Committee's report entitled The restless years-Inquiry into Year 12 retention rates, together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The restless years is the fourth report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. It is the result of a comprehensive, year-long inquiry conducted by a subcommittee chaired by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price). The inquiry examined the factors that influence year 12 retention rates in Australia-that is, the factors which determine whether or not students stay on at school and complete year 12. In essence, the report concludes that if more young people are to realise their entitlement to a complete secondary education, governments-both Commonwealth and State-must encourage schools to improve both the relevance and quality of senior secondary education.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the report's 25 recommendations are directed towards improving the educational opportunities and outcomes for all young people, the report focuses in particular on the opportunities and outcomes for young people from educationally disadvantaged groups in our community. For example, we refer particularly to students whose parents may be employed in jobs which have a low social or economic status, to students living in country areas and to students from Aboriginal or non-English speaking backgrounds.

I very briefly draw the House's attention to three of the report's key recommendations: employment, education and training options for young people; basic learning in primary schools; and teacher retraining. In relation to employment, education and training opportunities for young people, the Com- mittee has recommended that the Govern- ment introduce what we term a youth guarantee, which would be provided to every young person in Australia. It would guarantee them the opportunity of participation in secondary education, an apprenticeship, a traineeship or some other form of education, training activities or employment. That is a key recommendation.

The Committee's second key recommendation relates to the role of primary schools. In this report we have said that Government should adopt a national strategy to ensure that all young people achieve proficiency in mathematical, reading and writing skills in their primary school years. In that respect we refer to the very successful basic learning in primary schools program which operated in Australia in the early 1980s.

The third key recommendation relates to teacher retraining and professional development. In this report, as in our previous report entitled An Apple for the Teacher? Choice and Technology in Learning, we re- iterate that improving Australia's teaching force is an essential prerequisite to strengthening our schools. We recommend the development of a national retraining strategy.

Many members of the subcommittee wish to speak in this debate today. Therefore, in conclusion, I would like to express my appreciation for the significant contribution to this report made by all of the subcommittee members, particularly the honourable member for Chifley, who chaired the subcommittee. They have all worked very hard on the report and I believe it is an excellent one. I place on record my thanks to the Committee secretariat for the time and effort it has put into the report, particularly the subcommittee's secretary, Grant Harrison, who has worked tirelessly. I also thank the House of Representatives duplicating section for producing copies at short notice. I commend the report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report, entitled The restless years-Inquiry into Year 12 retention rates, is dedicated and mainly addressed to Australian students and their parents. The subcommittee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training had the opportunity to meet with students, parents, teachers and school administrators in each State and Territory. Whilst many of these meetings were informal, much of what was said has been incorporated into and forms the basis of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee believes that every Australian has a basic right to an education to year 12. The objective of all governments-Commonwealth and State-should be to ensure that this is a real option for all young people. The last decade has seen a dramatic increase in the number of young people staying on. In 1978 only 35 per cent of students stayed on to year 12 and by 1988, 58 per cent. The national goal is to have 65 per cent of students stay on to year 12 by 1992. This goal is on line to be achieved. While this increase is welcome, there is still a long way to go before the aim of year 12 for all is met.

Success at school too often depends on where students live, the income of their parents and what type of job they do. At a time when the level of one's education is still the best determinant of whether one gets a job and the type of job, too many young Australians are missing out. Why should young people's chances of successfully completing year 11 or 12 depend on whether they are attending a government or private school, whether they live in the western suburbs of Melbourne or Sydney, whether they live in the city or country, whether they have parents who migrated to Australia, or whether they are Aboriginal? It is towards improving the educational opportunities and providing equal opportunities for young people from these backgrounds that national attention must now be urgently directed. Renewed joint effort is needed to ensure that the momentum that has been built up is increased and better focused.

The Committee believes that schools must be held accountable for the educational outcomes of their students. Schools have the responsibility for educating our young Australians. They should also have accountability and should be accountable. Students and their parents should not be blamed. At a time when more young people are staying on and still more are being encouraged to do so, schools and teachers are facing new challenges from a majority of their students who are not tertiary bound. In many cases, old education policies and practices often tailored by inflexible tertiary institutions can no longer be expected to meet the demands of an increasing number of young people, whose wide range of interests and abilities I never doubted.

Schools must be encouraged to improve both the relevance and quality of senior secondary education. In The restless years, the Committee identified a number of ways of improving the educational opportunities and outcomes for young people, such as providing adequate financial support for young people from low income families; introducing more programs to involve parents and the community in schools and their learning programs and to involve the schools in their community; empowering parents and developing and adopting a charter of parents' rights and responsibilities; offering a broad range of courses in years 11 and 12; developing public awareness campaigns about the value of staying on and finishing school; introducing more appropriate forms of assessment and more comprehensive records of achievement; establishing more year 11 and 12 senior secondary colleges, sometimes called senior high schools; and giving better information and counselling about course options, job opportunities and avenues for further study.

Some schools and school systems have already taken steps such as these to encourage more young people to complete secondary school. Much more needs to be done. The Committee urges governments to support and build on these initiatives by ensuring that a more coordinated and consistent effort is made. If governments do not act promptly, a large number of young people will continue to be denied their basic right to a complete and relevant secondary education. In this event Australia will be the poorer socially, culturally and economically. To students and parents, the challenge is now theirs to see the recommendations implemented-it is their schools; it is their education system.

Finally, I add my thanks to those expressed by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) for the support, hard work and dedication of my fellow members of the subcommittee, which are reflected in this important report. My thanks also go to the Committee secretariat for their sustained efforts-Grant Harrison, Bob Dupree, Louise and Laura, without whom this report would not have been possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Deputy Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I am delighted to speak to the tabling of this report on year 12 retention rates. I would firstly like to congratulate and express my appreciation of the tireless work of the staff of the Committee and, in particular, the subcommittee's secretary, Grant Harrison. The subcommittee travelled widely and took evidence in every State and Territory in many different areas-rural and urban, rich and poor. I would especially like to congratulate two schools which we visited in the inner west of Sydney-Domremy College and St Patrick's College. Both the staff and, in particular, the students that we met made invaluable contributions to the Committee's deliberations. Those associated with these schools should justly be very proud of them.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of retention rates is one of the most important in secondary education in Australia today. It is vital to the future of this country that all who want years 11 and 12 education and would benefit from it should have access to it. It is vital not only from a functional point of view in regard to training for a job or a trade but also for increasing the depth of knowledge and cultural understanding that should be present within our community. It is also vital to the individual that he or she should have access to years 11 and 12 education regardless of background, financial situation, area of residence or race. Australia has always striven to be a fair and just society with opportunity for all, and access to education is a vitally important part of this society.

It was clear time and time again from evidence given to the subcommittee, both formally and informally, that the single most important factor regarding whether children stay on at school is the involvement, encouragement and motivation given to them at home by their parents. Unfortunately it was also clear that, while many parents were very involved with their children's education, a large number were not. In some cases this was probably due to apathy on the part of the parents, but in many cases it was clear that parental involvement was actively discouraged by some school authorities. For example, one woman in Darwin who tried to become more involved with her child's school was put off and told that, after all, she was only a mother. Lack of information about the activities and progress of children at school, and lack of consultation with parents during the formation of education policies were complaints which were all too common.

It is clearly necessary not only to encourage parental involvement but also to make parents aware of both their responsibilities and their rights in regard to the education of their children. Accordingly, in this report, amongst a number of other recommendations which have been touched on by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), the Committee has produced a draft charter of parents' rights and responsibilities which we hope will be adopted as a national standard. It states:
(a) Parents have the primary responsibility to educate their children.
(b) Parents may be aided by governments or accredited education authorities in the education of their children but this does not usurp the primary responsibility of parents.
(c) Parents are entitled to be consulted and involved in the formation of education policies.
(d) Parents are entitled to be considered by school principals and teachers as equals and partners in the process of schooling.
(e) Parents are entitled to be treated by school principals and teachers with respect, courtesy, honesty and openness.
(f) Parents are entitled to full and frank information about the activities and progress of their children in schools.
(g) Parents are entitled to hold schools accountable for their actions and outcomes.
(h) Parents are entitled to play a greater role in the selection and appointment of principals and key teaching staff.

I believe this is a landmark development in secondary education. If we are able to in- crease the involvement of parents and produce better motivation of our children then Australia will be the beneficiary. I commend this report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to speak on the tabling of this report by the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled The restless years-Inquiry into Year 12 retention rates. I thank the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), for his comments. I particularly thank the Chairman of the subcommittee, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), for the great zeal, imagination and skill that he brought to his task. I am sure that my comments are supported by the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods) and the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), who worked with us on the subcommittee. I extend my own thanks to them for their commitment, co- operation and comradeship in the course of the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member of the subcommittee which took evidence in a number of States during the inquiry, I am delighted with the content of the report and the relevance of its recommendations. I believe that it will be a useful addition to the body of information which already exists about teacher, parent, student and community attitudes to staying on at school for the senior high school years and offers some constructive suggestions for change.

Because the Committee was determined that its findings should take proper account of the views of all groups of people involved, it went to considerable lengths to ensure that evidence was specifically sought from people who might not normally respond to advertisements, and consultations were often conducted in an informal manner, aimed at putting witnesses at their ease. In particular, we made a point of visiting schools to talk to students and teachers and held special public meetings with parents to ascertain their views. These ventures proved to be very successful, with the comments and opinions obtained being refreshingly frank and relevant additions to the more considered evidence received in the form of written submissions and formal public hearings.

At one school the Committee was provided with the opportunity of speaking to a student who had decided to leave high school and ascertain his reasons for doing so. He wanted to undertake an apprenticeship the following year and was taking a job in an unrelated area of activity in the interim. School was no longer relevant to his life and his aspirations. Both the school and the Committee realised that this situation was not right. It should have been possible for such a student to pursue a course at the school which would help his transition into his chosen trade. However, another student provided the Committee with an example of delayed good sense. She had been restless and decided to leave school to take up a relatively unskilled job. It was a salutary experience for her. Realising that this would continue to be her lot without the benefit of higher education, she quickly returned to school and proceeded to tackle her studies with vigour, at the same time advising her friends of the merit of the lesson she had learned during her short time in the work force.

I would like to take this opportunity of thanking two schools in my electorate for their hospitality during the inquiry. Both Girrawheen and Morley senior high schools hosted a visit of the subcommittee, the former for a discussion with teachers and students and the latter for an inspection of its alternative upper school program. Like the honourable member for Lowe, I think these schools should be congratulated on their contribution to the Committee and for the way the students, in particular, responded to our questions. Their evidence and experience contributed to the Committee's conclusion that the environment in the school was as important to senior students as was course choice and credential recognition. The importance of parental factors in encouraging students to remain at school was also recognised. I also endorse the draft charter of parents' rights and responsibilities outlined by my colleague the honourable member for Lowe.

Before concluding, I would like to put on record my thanks for the subcommittee's hardworking and competent secretary, Grant Harrison, who was ably assisted by Laura Gillies, Bob Dapre and Louise Carney. The latter two are no longer on the Committee. They performed their duties admirably in a competent, cooperative and amiable fashion. I think that this report will be of interest to many people in the community and trust that the Government will choose to implement the majority of its recommendations in pursuit of our national goal of increasing the number of young Australians staying on to year 12.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to speak briefly on the report by the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled The restless year-Inquiry into Year 12 retention rates. Before doing so I congratulate the chairperson of the Committee, the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), and the subcommittee chairperson, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), for their astute stewardship. I also thank members of the subcommittee for their valued contribution and our most supportive secretariat for the professional attentiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: I will confine my comments to three aspects of the report: the role of primary schools; the resource implications for State governments; and the need for the Commonwealth Government to continue to take the lead in developing national strategies for education. In chapter 6 the Committee affirms the contention that the role of primary schools in ensuring that students acquire basic skill levels is paramount, and also states:

. . . if primary schools are unable to impart basic skills and capture the interest and imagination of students from an early age the education future of young people thus affected will be severely limited.

In Chapter 13 the Committee acknowledges that there appear to be no clear reasons, other than historical, why quite large cost differentials exist between senior and junior secondary schools in the provision of educational services. The Committee recognised the importance of early intervention in the learning process. The very real possibility was raised by the Committee that a reallocation of resources to the earlier years of schools-years 1 to 7, my emphasis-may be more cost effective. Reports are not merely ends in themselves; they should identify future directions. Recommendations 24 and 25 of the report point the way for the Commonwealth to assume a more substantive leadership role with the States.

The report recommends that a study be sponsored into the cost implications of increasing year 12 retention rates and the nature and extent of additional resources required to provide for increased retention. The report further recommends that a major study be sponsored into the economic and social implications of achieving universal retention to year 12. It is significant to note that the Inner London Education Authority's major longitudinal study of the mid-1980s found that schooling between the school years 3 to 7 is the most significant factor in determining the future success of young people, and that schooling is a far more significant determinant of success than race, religion, socio-economic background or gender. Unfortunately, that message has not yet reached educational bureaucracies, especially when it comes to allocating the educational dollar.

The primary sector of this nation's schools, government and private, is very much under-resourced when compared with other sectors of education where the elite decision making power lies. As preventative health measures are in the long term more cost effective and beneficial than curing illnesses, so too will it be proved that preventative education measures are also more cost efficient and beneficial to the nation. It is interesting to note that 40 years ago only 8 per cent of our students completed year 12; 20 years ago it was 25 per cent; and now it is almost 60 per cent. The Committee's aim of universal retention is attainable before the turn of the century. I endorse the recommendations of the Committee and commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time allocated for this report has expired. Does the Chairman wish to move a motion in connection with the report to enable it to be debated on a future occasion?

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House take note of the report.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Fin- ance and Public Administration, I present the Committee's report entitled There's no place like home-A review of an efficiency audit of the Department of Community Services and Health: Home and Community Care Program, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report I have just tabled is the third report of the Committee to be presented this year, and the eighth report of the Committee for this Parliament. It is perhaps fitting to follow on from the restless years and now look at the resting years as far as people's lifestyle is concerned. The report reflects the longstanding interest of the Committee and its predecessor, the Expenditure Committee, in the care of the aged. It was the two reports of the Expenditure Committee that led to the establishment of the home and community care (HACC) program. The first report-In Home or at Home: Accommodation and Care for the Aged, with which you would be most familiar, Mr Speaker-had a major impact on thinking about care for the aged. Too often people were consigned to a home when, with some support services, they could have continued to live in familiar surroundings.

SPEECH.PARA: In the report there is a quote from the Department of Community Services and Health which sums up one of the major achievements of the HACC program:
Assessment teams are probably proposing for nursing homes about 50 per cent of those who previously would have been recommended for nursing homes by the Department's Commonwealth medical officers.

Our report, There's no place like home, is a review of an efficiency audit of the program by the Auditor-General. It draws to the attention of the Parliament one of the problems faced by the Audit Office in the audit of joint programs. The auditors cannot go out and question State officials; they are forced to rely on written reports. This problem has also been commented on by the Public Accounts Committee. The Auditor-General in his response noted:

The history of the issue is being researched as a preliminary to exploring with State Auditors-General whether there is a role for the Commonwealth Auditor-General to play. If so, it would then be necessary to examine the resource and mandate implications.
The Committee has suggested that the Auditor-General pursue those investigations. The audit identified a number of problems with the home and community care program. It suggested:
After more than two years operation of the program, the Department has been unable to find details of specific service being provided, who is being serviced and to what extent.

Not surprisingly, the Department of Community Services and Health did not accept that statement. It suggested that the program was in the early stages of development and more recognition could have been given to the progress made with assessment and co-ordination. The Department of Community Services and Health was not alone in the criticism of the audit. There was much concern about the timing of the report. For example, the New South Wales Government said:
. . . it was a very unfortunate time to undertake an audit that was as far reaching or sweeping in its scope and at a time when the program had really only commenced.
According to the Queensland Government:

The commissioning of an efficiency audit less than two years after the national starting date of this relatively large and complex joint Commonwealth-State programme did not allow adequate time for Commonwealth-State relationships to develop and for the development and smooth functioning of networks between service providers. This was unrealistic and could only have been expected to find fault in the administrative processes of the programme.

There was also concern about the focus of this report. The South Australian Government acknowledged that the report has high-lighted a number of legitimate concerns with the current operations of the program, yet it was critical of the conduct of the audit as `it fails to provide a balanced view of the program from the State's perspective'. The re- port criticises the Commonwealth Depart- ment for its perceived inadequacies in ensuring the fine print of the agreement is complied with.

At the same time as the Committee was conducting the inquiry there was a working group of Commonwealth and State officials reviewing the program. The report of that review has been made available to the Committee and it appears to have addressed the problems raised in the audit report. It remains to be seen whether the problems will be overcome. A second triennial review is proposed for 1990 and the Committee has recommended another efficiency audit after the completion of the second review. However, it was the comments in the audit report about meals on wheels which generated the most interest. The audit report included a section on delivered meals. It noted that it is Meals on Wheels that has the largest voluntary component. It went on to suggest:
Departmental documents record that meals are one of variable quality, often poorly prepared and lack nutritional value.
This comment was not accepted by those organisations involved in that delivery of meals. The South Australian association said:
We were well aware of the unjust attack made in the audit report on meals service nationally.
The Tasmanian association said:
Any attempt to reduce the number of delivery days for any reason, economic or otherwise, would destroy a very important and distinctive component of the Meals on Wheels service.
The Queensland association said:

This association is extremely concerned at the adverse publicity generated by the press printing criticism from the report regarding the delivered meals services. This publicity has resulted in unwarranted anxiety and anger in both recipients and volunteer workers.

The members of the subcommittee met with Meals on Wheels volunteers in Adelaide, Brisbane and Sydney during the inquiry. In fact, we assisted in one delivery service in Sydney in appalling conditions. This gave us an opportunity to see first hand the importance of a service of this nature.

The report concluded that the Meals on Wheels service makes a significant contribution to the home and community care program. It also noted that a feature of the Meals on Wheels service is the daily contact that it provides for the recipient of the meal. It also provides an acknowledgment for the volunteer. While the efficiency aspect might be worthy of further investigation the Committee, because of the wider social issues, would be reluctant to endorse such a proposal for a weekly delivery unless there were special circumstances.

The report also recommends that the Department of Community Services and Health facilitate the establishment of a national Meals on Wheels organisation. Such an organisation would facilitate the exchange of information and the sharing of experience. The home and community care program is a community program and involves the three spheres of government. The level of involvement of local government varies significantly from State to State and the Committee has suggested that the involvement of local government be encouraged.
The Committee has also commented on accountability, as there were accountability problems identified in the report. Other issues covered include data collection, assessment teams and consultation.

The report is not a sensational report; it is a positive one. It is a commendation to those in the community who give up some time each day to care for others. In caring for other people they also help reduce the costs of caring for the aged. But there is more than just the costs involved. There is also the time taken to talk, to listen and to respond to other's concerns.

I thank the committee secretariat who worked so diligently on this report: Monica Teleseny, before leaving the secretariat; Phil Bergin, the Secretary; Sharon Fisher and Amanda Garlick, who worked tirelessly on the preparation of the manuscript. I extend a vote of thanks particularly to the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) and the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), who made up the subcommittee and gave of their time in the course of the subcommittee's deliberations on this report.

I conclude by stating again that, although this is not a sensational report, it clearly identifies that the home and community care program is making a valuable contribution to our society and to the care of the aged. It indicates that there are intrinsic matters that need consideration more than simply looking at the dollars and cents aspect of the provision of care for the aged, including the fact that people go and talk to these elderly people in their homes. The aged look forward to those visits in their homes and the visits make their days go a lot more quickly. I commend the report to the house

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a lot of pride to be able to speak on this report and also to join the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) in extending our thanks and appreciation to the secretariat, who served the subcommittee and the Committee itself in bringing forward this report. As important is the efficiency audit conducted by the Auditor-General.

SPEECH.PARA: It is great to be able to focus on some of these programs even in their infancy. While there has been criticism of the timing of the Auditor-General's report, I believe that, in the short and long term, the report will be beneficial because it allowed our Committee to look at it and to bring forward certain recommendations which I believe will be of benefit to the scheme. The recommendations or criticisms contained in the efficiency report have already been outlined in a fair amount of detail by the Chairman of the Committee. It is then very important to look at our recommendations concerning those criticisms and, as the honourable member for Macarthur said, the positive nature of them.

I wish to include in the report the fact that the review was conducted by the old House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, which has been subsumed, I suppose, by the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. It is interesting to note that the review in connection with aged care, In a Home or at Home, was commissioned back in about 1981. I had the pleasure of being a member of that previous Committee, under the chairmanship of Stephen Lusher, and of the subcommittee under the chairmanship of the present Speaker. Having gone through the list of names of the people on that Committee at that time and those on the present Committee, I am the only continuing member.

I have a lot of pride in the home and community care (HACC) program. Nothing can be perfect after a trial of only three years, the first years of the legislation. But it appears to have been able to deliver on many of the recommendations included in the McLeay report In a Home or at Home presented in this Parliament in October 1982. That report was probably unique in that it never received a response from the Government of the day. But there was a response in a following report, in the present HACC program and the aged care program.

This is a very important issue. Ten per cent of Australians are in their greying years. According to the statistics, by the year 2021 that percentage will have increased measurably to the extent that it is suggested that over 15 to 16 per cent of the population will be in that age group. So, by tackling the problem now and putting programs in the right perspective, we are going a long way towards fulfilling the ambitions of government not only now but through to the years 2000 and 2021. By that time I will certainly be one of those aged people. The honourable member for Macarthur should not smile because by the year 2021 he will be well advanced in years, too. The Minister at the table, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), need not smile at that prospect either because he is three days older than I am.

The October 1982 report was a very significant one in so far as we have acted on the recommendations and dealt with care for the aged. Those recommendations included a reduction in the number of programs and concentrating them on an extended care program both within the community and within nursing homes, to provide home care and accommodation. That is what the HACC program is about. It also recommended extended care, which is now delivered by domiciliary nursing services, meals on wheels and home help.

The other important issue is that I remember from those inspections that quite a few things came vividly to light. We heard about the open manner in which deficit funding and other funding was available to the private centres participating and also how the building of institutions-hostels and nursing homes-was sometimes inappropriate but encouraged by the availability of money. As we went around the country we saw many such inappropriately placed homes. We saw many institutions inappropriately delivering services that could have been provided back in the community. We mentioned in the report that such constructions should be on the basis more of need than of population. It is interesting to note that now the need is determined by the percentage of frail people aged over 70 in the community. Ten per cent are being catered for in institutions, nursing homes and hostels. We want to keep the other 90 per cent at home with the proper services available to them.

It is with some pride that I look back on the recommendations of that report and see what has happened as a result of them. I do not know whether any other report presented to parliament has had such success. Other recommendations concerning residents' rights are included in legislation to be introduced this afternoon. When inspecting some homes back in 1981-82, we were very concerned that residents' rights were not being properly addressed. There was a lot of regimentation, residents' needs were not being met and their rights were not being respected. The legislation being introduced this afternoon will address the issues in that report.

I want to pay tribute to the volunteer services. Basically, the HACC program has a high percentage of voluntary workers and these services can only be delivered by encouraging these volunteers. The unfortunate part about the efficiency audit is that we have to come back to having in place a good, flexible program but we have to have accountability. Over the last three years a lot of comments have been made about the HACC program and it has been subject to that review. But, as the Auditor-General has suggested, the most difficult part is to try to be accountable where funds are incorporated with State funds and delivered on that basis. While that is a difficulty, the flexibility that allows the States to deliver these programs is indicated in Victoria. The Victorian Government, in order to divest itself of the people in hospitals who could be cared for at home, has given a grant to one of the domiciliary nursing services in Melbourne to extend that care at home.

I think it would be of interest to every member of this Parliament to go out on a Meals on Wheels delivery and on a domiciliary nursing service-whether it be the blue nurses, the white nurses or the district nurses. It is a tremendous experience to go out and see how these people are working and delivering these services. They are doing a great job. They are changing their methods and they are innovating.

I pay a particular tribute to the deliverers of those services in my electorate of Dawson. They are doing a first-class job in a voluntary capacity and are putting in a tremendous amount of effort. I hope that the Committee's report and recommendations, following on the Auditor-General's report, will provide a flexible program within the community, one that is accountable and, more importantly, one that delivers services to that 10 per cent of aged people in the community.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 17 August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I rise to speak in one of those rare parliamentary debates which bring before us, as law makers, the question of first principles. I rise to speak on and support the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1989. In making my comments today I am conscious, to quote a well-known theologian, John Stott, that the debate over abortion is complex. It has medical, legal, theological, ethical, social and personal aspects. It is a highly emotional subject and involves acutely painful dilemmas. I have presented this Bill, however, and sought to have it debated, because for too long the Parliament has avoided the issue of abortion precisely because of its complexity. In that regard, I thank the Selection Committee of the House, under the Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), for its decision to allocate time for this debate.

In presenting this Bill in this place on 17 August this year, I outlined both the reasons for and the objectives of the Bill, but it is appropriate now briefly to summarise both. The Commonwealth's main involvement with abortion is through Medicare subsidisation of abortion procedures. The Bill, therefore, addresses the Medicare subsidisation of abortion and seeks to allow Medicare funding only for abortions performed to avert the death of the mother or in cases where the procedure is for a different purpose and where the doctor was unaware an abortion would occur. The Bill also requires doctors to certify that the reason for any abortion was to avert the mother's death or it occurred indirectly.

Honourable members will recall the extent of the Commonwealth's involvement with abortion through Medicare: an allocation of around $7m each year via Medicare involves honourable members in the abortion each year of nearly 70,000 unborn babies. I ask honourable members to reflect on what I have just said: they are and I am, through the policy and legislation of the Government and the Parliament, involved in the abortion of tens of thousands of unborn humans every year.

The Bill before us today presents honourable members and me with an opportunity either to end that involvement or, by opposing and defeating the Bill, to reaffirm that involvement. It seems obvious to me, then, that each of us is faced with the task, first and foremost, of settling in our own minds and hearts, according to our own consciences, the basic moral questions inherent in this debate.

In the eighth century BC an unknown peasant named Micah, angered by injustice and by contempt for the weak and defenceless in his country, put this simple question to the leaders of the land: Is it not your duty to know what is right? We face today the same question, the same duty, in this place. Let us first ask whether there is one question, among the many in the abortion debate, the answer to which will place all the others in context and order. I put to the House two claims: first, that what is called scientifically the embryo and foetus is an individual human being; and, secondly, that abortion is therefore the denial of the most basic of rights, the right of life. These two claims constitute together such a primary question. People are saying to us that abortion is murder. Others are saying that the foetus is not a person, has no rights and is, as part of a woman's body, her property and business. We have a duty to decide which of the claims is right, relating as they do to an assertion of the denial of basic rights.

I have tried over many years to give this question the consideration it is due.
