As I said in this place on 17 August and 26 October, I feel compelled by scientific and medical evidence and by moral logic to conclude that an individual's antenatal and postnatal development constitutes a single process of becoming what she or he already is-an individual human person. I am yet to see that evidence and logic discredited by opponents of this Bill or by pro-abortion advocates. I am therefore compelled to provide that unborn individual protection under the law. Let no-one enter this debate who is not willing to address this fundamental question. Let no-one avoid the duty he or she has to tell us whether he or she accepts or rejects the existence of two sets of rights in an abortion situation. Let no-one deny the humanity and rights of the foetus who will not also show at which point-two months, three months, eight months-the foetus suddenly becomes human, or show why a two-day-old child has rights that the two-month-old unborn baby does not have. The questions are those that I put to honourable members last week: Is the embryo-foetus a human person some of the time or any of the time before it is born? If only some of the time, what is the suggested non-arbitrary marker point? Why is it right for the community to involve itself in the affairs of a seven-month pregnant woman but not a two-month pregnant woman? If the foetus is worthless and a woman's property, what would be wrong with women falling pregnant with the intention of having an abortion for the purpose of selling foetal tissue to transplant or research clinics?

Those who have followed the debate outside the House over this Bill will know that its opponents wish to focus not on the primary question of rights recognition for the unborn, but on the question of whether the Bill will have a greater impact on low income women than on high income women. I acknowledge that there are many compassionate men and women in this place whose concern for the poor, and poor women in particular, and whose anger at the capacity of the rich to buy their way around their moral and legal obligations blind them to the question of first principles. In failing to focus on the primary question, however, their response to the Bill is misdirected.

I do not deny that in this instance, as in so many others, the rich have the capacity to cushion themselves against the impact of the law. State tobacco and liquor taxes, levied to pay for health programs, hurt the poor more than the rich. The abolition of slavery hurt poor farmers more than it hurt rich farmers. The rich will always have the capacity to act above and outside the law. That is one of the reasons why Jesus said that it would be very hard for the rich to enter heaven. To those, however, who use a woman's poverty to justify government subsidisation of abortion, I say this: know that, in aborting the children of the poor, you not only add to the litany of tragedy in a poor woman's life, you actually oppress the poor. You say to the poor woman, `My heart goes out to you, your poverty is a scandal, but I will not free you from your poverty, I will relieve you of your child'.

I say to those who see their opposition to this Bill as an act of solidarity with the poor that the problem facing a pregnant poor or dependent woman is not the pregnancy but the poverty and the dependency. It is the poverty that is unwanted, not the child. Just as I can understand but never institutionalise desperate acts of infanticide by poor women, I understand but cannot institutionalise abortion by poor women. I do not deny that a society marked by inequality will place unbearable burdens on many women facing parenthood, but I say to honourable members: let us not take the easy and cheap path of paying Medicare money to suppress the problem on an abortion clinic table. Let us develop families policies that sustain a woman in pregnancy and parenthood. There are those who speak mindlessly of unwanted pregnancies leading to abused and neglected children. To those people I say: look at the staggering growth of abuse and neglect and at homeless youth in a society with free and legal abortion. Is it not possible that the subversion of respect for life by the abortion industry and abortion philosophies is responsible for the increasing violence against children? It is not likely that there is some deeper spiritual problem in our society at the root of violence against both the unborn and children?

There are some who raise the questions of rape and incest. The reality is that pregnancy after rape or incest is very rare indeed. In South Australia-the only State to publish reasons for abortions-abortions due to rape or incest represented zero per cent in 1985 and 1986 and 0.1 per cent in 1987. It is not clear, in those very few cases of pregnancy after rape or incest, that there is less risk of emotional stress if an abortion is performed than if the pregnancy were allowed to continue, especially where support and counselling services are made available. I am not convinced, therefore, that there is a case for subsidising abortion after rape or incest, which again, I believe, would represent the easy, violent social response to an already tragic situation.

Many other arguments have been put against the Bill. Some argue that we should look towards education and family planning to stem abortion, oblivious to the evidence that substantial funding for sex education and family planning services has had no impact on abortion figures. Some play on the fear that women will be forced into backyard abortions. What they will not admit is that the legalisation and provision of free abortions has not lowered the incidence of maternal deaths at all; nor will they acknowledge that in the United States of America the predicted boom in backyard abortions failed to occur after subsidies were removed. Some critics argue that the Bill will only lower, not eliminate, abortions. The evidence in the United States is that withdrawal of subsidies will lower significantly the incidence of abortions. It seems that the necessity of having to fund one's own decision does make an impact on a woman and her partner; they reflect on that decision and reconsider their circumstances. Nevertheless, the critics are correct that the Bill will not eliminate abortions altogether. It will fail to do so because abortion is allowed under, or in spite of, the law in every State. It will fail to do so because, notwithstanding talk about poverty, an abortion costs less than most poor women will spend on cigarettes in a year. It will fail to do so because some doctors will perform abortions free of charge.

Is the Bill worth the effort then? If it will save thousands of lives, thousands of unborn babies-and it will; there is no doubt of that-of course it is worth it. Let me finish my remarks on that point. This Bill will significantly lower the incidence of abortion in Australia. It will ensure that at the Federal level the relevant legislation embodies what is right and just. The Bill, if passed, will free up funds which could be used for pregnancy support rather than pregnancy termination. This Parliament should be about saving lives, or at the very least doing no one harm and minimising evil. This Parliament should be about wisely weighing and balancing competing sets of rights. It should be willing to affirm that some rights are basic and carry more weight than others, no matter how difficult the politics of explaining our judgment. The right to life of the unborn is one such right. This Parliament's laws should reflect what is right and its Budget should not fund what is wrong or harmful. This Parliament should not, therefore, fund abortion.

In considering the Bill, we have before us, individually and as a parliament, two choices: we can choose life, or we can choose death. I urge honourable members to choose life. I urge honourable members to support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very controversial issue. The views held by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) no doubt are well considered, sincere and honest. It is a question that one looks at from a number of different angles-scientific, religious, moral and legal. But, in the end, it is moral differences which distinguish this issue and which are often aligned to political and religious views. Generally, the law in this land operates on a moral consensus. If one places abortion with issues such as contraception and divorce, one finds that many people find those things morally reprehensible. Indeed, our democracy allows those people to preach and try to persuade those who undertake those practices to change their mind. We have the freedom of conscience in those issues.

SPEECH.PARA: In placing abortion with issues such as robbery, rape and murder, one puts it with issues where there is a universal belief in the law that those activities are reprehensible. Indeed, the law provides for sanctions and prohibitions against them. If abortion is to be put in with those categories we should not be talking about removing funding for Medicare: we should be talking about the main game, if that is what we think it is. If one in five pregnancies terminates spontaneously, how do we decide which of the cases are those of murder and which are the ones where there would have been spontaneous termination anyway?

When we debate this issue we have a tendency to look for scientific solutions. However, science cannot offer a solution here. It is just a debate about when an acorn becomes a oak tree. There is no clear evidence about that and about when life begins. I draw the House's attention to a submission in the Webster case which was heard in the United States Supreme Court last year. A total of 167 eminent scientists-11 of them Nobel laureates-summarised their view thus:

There is no scientific consensus that a human life begins at conception, at a given stage of fetal development, or at birth. The question of `when human life begins' cannot be answered by reference to scientific principles like those with which we predict planetary movement. The answer to that question will depend on each individual's social, religious, philosophical, ethical and moral beliefs and values.

The point I am trying to make is that if we can have no confidence in the scientific community-and it has no confidence-about the definition of when life begins then what the honourable member might say is that we ought not to interfere with the chance of a human life eventuating. If one takes that to its logical conclusion, one says that there can be no contraception and family planning. If that is the issue, perhaps we should be debating it, but certainly not Medicare funding. If that is the issue about contraception and whether we ought to allow the chance for human life to eventuate, it is not an issue on which I could support the honourable member. So we look for religious guidance and again we find that there is no consensus.

We have a system of government in Australia which provides for secular government-a division of powers between the state and religious organisations and a freedom of religious expression. Taking the views of those who most strongly hold the view that the honourable member puts-the Catholic Church-again there is division. Any theological discussion within the Church about when ensoulment takes place will cause division. There is no certainty about when ensoulment takes place and theologians will tell you that. The pro-life people would say that they want the foetus to have some superior right, or at least the same rights as the mother, on this issue. However, when a miscarriage or even a stillbirth occurs, the Church rarely performs baptism and it rarely performs a funeral mass. So it does not place the same status on the miscarried foetus, or on the stillborn, that it does on other human life. That distinction exists in the Church. The second Vatican Council refused to make a judgment on the question of ensoulment. So even within the Catholic Church there is division. McBrien, in his book Catholicism, talks about individual conscience and states:

If, after appropriate study, reflection and prayer, a person is convinced that his or her conscience is correct, in spite of a conflict with the moral teachings of the Church, the person not only may but must follow the dictates of conscience rather than the teachings of the Church.
Thus, if one looks at the scientific evidence and asks for religious guidance, one finds there is no consensus on the moral position on this issue.

The Abortion Funding Abolition Bill relates to the abolition of Medicare funding. If I put the best complexion upon it and the motives of the Opposition and the honourable member opposite, I would say that the honourable member's intention is that there should be fewer abortions. Such a proposition would have my support. I have no difficulty with that because I too would like to see it occur. I think that it is desirable. However, Medicare benefits do not underpin abortions. Medicare benefits do not cause abortion. It will not go away if we remove the benefit, just like unemployed people will not disappear if we remove the unemployment benefit. That is something which the honourable member has to understand.

Why are abortions necessary? Why do we have unwanted pregnancies? There are many causes. I admit that rape and incest account for very few. They often occur due to ignorance, lack of sex education, poor sex education, failed contraception or just because of a mistake of judgment. An unwanted pregnancy is never deliberate. Whether a Medicare benefit underpins it or not, the choice remains for the woman involved: she has to make a decision. That needs to be understood very clearly. I suggest that it is a gut-wrenching decision for that woman. For some the consequences must be overwhelming into their future lives-in the weeks and years afterwards-just as the suggestion that adoption is the answer produces gut-wrenching problems and overwhelming guilt. That is not the answer.

The best way of reducing the number of abortions is to have better sex education, better and more family planning and, indeed, more support for those who find themselves in these circumstances. That support should come from the partner, who is often forgotten, and, I suggest, it should come from us. Tolerance and compassion are necessary. I do not think that fixing the blame solves the problem in any way. Removing the benefit clearly does not.

I suggest that the legislation will not change the number of abortions but will change the nature of the available treatment. We will see a return to the backyard abortion, which is undesirable. One has only to look at mortality rates in developing countries where abortion is illegal to see that that procedure is very dangerous. It is a women's health issue and we, in this Parliament, need to consider it in that light.

If there is to be real freedom in our country-freedom and rights are words that we throw around in this place-we need the freedom to differ on the big issues; not just on whether someone wears a seat belt and matters such as that, but the big issues that are matters of human conscience. To say that we do not want a portion of our taxes going to things that we do not like is a facile argument. Many people in our community decide not to have children. According to the same argument, why should they be supporting child-care funding or schools funding? There are people who do not drive cars. Why should they be funding roads? That is a facile argument and it does not stand up.

This argument is about individual choice. It is about the person who is in the best position to make that choice. The mother has to weigh the consequences; she has to weigh up the effects. I support her right to do so. In the end, any of us who thinks deeply about this issue and other issues is left with the lament of Shakespeare's King Lear, who said, `Who is it that can tell me who I am?'. Indeed, in the end, it is individual conscience that must make this decision. I support the right of people to make that choice. I reject the Opposition's legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill I wish to pay tribute to the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) for the courage he has displayed over a period in bringing this Bill before the national Parliament. The honourable member is highly respected and has been at pains not to turn his Bill into a partisan debate. He, as have others in this chamber, has always conducted the debate in a very measured way. For that reason, I will not analyse point by point the matters raised by the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth). In the very limited time available to me in the House to debate this issue this morning I would much prefer to put my views on record, except to say that I do not think it is incumbent upon the honourable member for Perth to represent the Catholic Church in the fashion that he has. The Catholic Church has unambiguously stated time and again its total and unreserved opposition to abortion. Whatever individual theologians may claim, Catholic bishops, even in recent days, have again stated their total opposition to abortion.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe, as I know other members believe, that this debate is long overdue. It is well past the time when the Parliament of this nation should be discussing the issue of funding for abortions. Surely no-one would deny the validity of the debate if, for no other reason-leaving aside the moral and ethical questions-than the fact that about $7m of taxpayers' funds per year is involved. After all, if the cosmetic surgery aspects of Medicare funding were to be abused they would be the first thing discussed by this Parliament. This debate will allow honourable members to let the electorate know where they stand on this issue. We are accountable to our constituents on any number of issues-tax, social security and immigration-surrounding government administration. But too often we duck for cover on the issue of abortion. Frankly, there is nowhere for honourable members to hide from their constituents when answering questions on abortion. They cannot hide behind party affiliation because it is a matter of conscience.

There has been an unstated conspiracy of self-interest to keep abortion off the political agenda. It is regarded as too hot an issue to handle: it is all too hard. It is an emotional issue which fires up people both ways-it is unpredictable and difficult to control in political terms. It is far better for governments and oppositions alike to fight elections on tried and true issues. This is too great an issue for too many people for legislators to ignore. We are accountable, not just as members of a political party but as individual legislators. Economic issues dominate the political debate-tax, balance of payments and foreign debt. The standard of living of Australians occupies most of our thinking and working hours.

One of the very few quality of life issues debated in this chamber is the environment but rarely, if ever, do we debate the morality of our society. As honourable members would appreciate, morality is defined in a very subjective manner. There would be almost as many definitions of morality as there are members in this place. Yet surely there is a base which should be commonly accepted, namely the Judaeo-Christian ethic. The cornerstone of the Judaeo-Christian morality is the sanctity of life. If one believes that life begins at the moment of conception, what choice does one have but to oppose abortion? To do otherwise would be to repudiate the notion of morality, to abandon one's faith. It only becomes a question of how one opposes abortion: to what lengths does one go?

The most obvious expression of opposition is not ever to have an abortion. For many people opposition is expressed in private prayer but for others opposition takes a more public form ranging from letter writing to parliamentarians to demonstrations and incarceration. Scorn is poured on these people; they are frequently ridiculed by the proponents of abortion in a compliant press. Yet those who lie in front of bulldozers or cling to the bow of an American naval ship are elevated to sainthood. The double standards are breathtaking. There is a kind of religious fervour amongst many of the fanatics who demonstrate about trees and animals but those who oppose abortion are so often dismissed as cranks. Yet the issue of abortion-the issue of life itself-is infinitely more important than the popular causes that dominate our society today.

The scientific evidence establishes beyond doubt the commencement of life at the moment of conception. The destruction of that life through abortion is murder. No matter how one talks around the issue, the inescapable truth is that the taking of life is murder. There are those who do not accept that life commences at conception; rather, they believe that life commences at a later time. Abortion to them is therefore not murder. I do not agree and believe that such a judgment is not substantiated by medical or biological knowledge. If that judgment is a matter of conscience, as with the honourable member for Perth, for example, obviously it is a matter for the individual. No-one can see into the soul of another person; only God can do that. I do not stand in judgment. But all human beings, to one extent or another, shape their consciences to their convenience. This is the weakness of man flowing from original sin. Any person who reaches a deep and abiding conviction that life commences at the moment of conception cannot stand idly by as more than 80,000 lives are aborted every year in Australia-more than 70,000 at the taxpayers' cost.

We have often heard the argument that it is the right of a woman to control her body. Is that right so supreme that it extends to the destruction of a life? Examples are also given of the terrible hardship and sadness, even tragedy, that result from unwanted pregnancies. They are emotional and at times superficially convincing arguments but, nonetheless, as the honourable member for Macquarie has laboured, one has to measure any rights in our society against others. Like it or not, we deem some to be more compelling, more superior than others. The right to life is the most basic, the most important and the most honourable. As has been said in this debate and often at other times, pregnancies resulting from incest or rape should be terminated; but as a percentage of the 80,000 abortions every year, such pregnancies are infinitesimal. Overwhelmingly, the majority of abortions are of convenience. We have to ask: What is more horrifying-an unwanted pregnancy or the taking of a life?
I endorse the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill and commend it to the House. There is no more important issue that this House could consider than the legislation before it at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the compelling realities of this debate is how different it is in this chamber with the emotion certainly real and yet constrained. The sort of debate we are having here could well be a way of showing leadership to those in the community who have erred on both sides of this debate to extremist positions on occasions and, very often, extremist actions. For my part, I do not demur at the comments of my colleague the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) in relation to understanding the position of the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster). I believe that he has genuine views in relation to this issue, as do most members of this chamber. It has been interesting in the past to me to see how, on a bipartisan basis, the views in relation to this issue and related issues can go far beyond party-political positions. Many people have in the past adopted non-partisan positions based on their own ethical and moral understanding of these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: I do have one significant problem, however, with the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill. To me, it seems a backdoor route by which to come to the issue of abortion when this Parliament has, as we all know, discussed the merit or otherwise of abortion per se in considerable detail. I know that the honourable member for Macquarie did not argue this, but those who argue that the end result of the acceptance of this sort of proposal would, because of its moral dimensions, be acceptable, accept that we do discount the very real impact of poor women in our community. There is a coalition of women. It is interesting to see that it is four males talking about this issue in this chamber. Perhaps we ought to regret that.

This debate will be adjourned at 11.27 a.m. I know that some of the previous speakers went a little over time, so I will not have time to touch in very great detail on most of the points that I wish to raise. But let me list some of the organisations which have expressed genuine and very real concern about this particular proposal. I have correspondence from the Young Women's Christian Association, expressing very serious reservations about this proposal, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, the National Society of Community Based Children's Services, the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled, the Australian Women's Health Network, the Australian Women's Educational Coalition, the Campaign for Economic Justice, the Women's Electoral Lobby, the Catholic Women's League of Australia, the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia, the Association of Non-English Speaking Background Women of Australia, and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, amongst numerous others. Every member of parliament, conversely, has received representations from those who very strongly supported this legislation. But it is incumbent upon everyone in this chamber to reflect for a moment on two matters. First, if we are going to have a debate about abortion, let us all have the guts to debate the issue of abortion. This Bill seems to me to be just so obviously a backdoor method that will lead to backyard abortions. One needs only to look at some of the statistics in terms of the deaths resulting from backyard abortions. They are not matters of assertion; they are based on empirical data. The end result of this decision would be-I do not believe that there is any way that people can argue against this-the rise of backyard abortions and all the corollaries that go with that in terms of increased deaths for women who participate. The criminal element has not been adverted to here, but anyone who has an understanding of how crime has developed in this country will be aware that the genesis of many organised crime groups was money derived from backyard abortions. It corrupted our police forces in the 1960s. Again, that is a matter on the public record. Everything that flows from that has been debated in this chamber on numerous occasions.

Certainly the Commonwealth has a responsibility to maintain funding through the Medicare system for medical procedures which meet State prescribed legal criteria. I ask the honourable member for Macquarie: Has he debated this proposal in the councils of his Party? Has he consulted his colleagues? What is his attitude to the New South Wales Government, which continues to conduct the laws as they are at this moment? If the issue is one of such great moral dimensions for him, there are many other actions he should be taking. He has been a member of this chamber now for some five years. This move seems to be a little late in the day, if I may respectfully say so.

In terms of women's rights, I think that it is fundamentally a woman's basic right to choose in relation to this issue. That does not discount the responsible role of men in our society, but it is fundamentally a woman's right to choose in consultation with her medical practitioner. I feel entirely discomfited in contemplating the adoption of a position that seeks to impose on that fundamental right. Were I a woman, I would not accept an argument whereby someone could seek to impose his view on me in a similar regard, and I do not expect women to take the same position from men in our community in that absolute assent. As I have indicated, the proposed change to the system would openly discriminate against the less well-off and the young females in our community. That is a position I would not countenance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:

(1) notes the focus of the One World or None Campaign, initiated by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid and 85 aid and development organisations together with other community groups, on the issues of environment and development, global economy and the fight against poverty, disarmament and development, and protecting human rights;
(2) calls for community debate on these vital issues of our time; and
(3) calls on governments to initiate policies to contribute towards the advancement of these goals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member. These are truly issues of our time. They are critical issues which confront not just the Australian people but the people of the world. The One World or None Campaign does focus on those four interconnected issues. I think it is important that I emphasise what they are, because it is clear to me and, I think, ought to be clear to all of us, that these four issues are absolutely interrelated and are questions which we ought to address as a parliament, as a nation and, indeed, as part of humankind.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of those issues is environment and development. The issue here is how to achieve sustainable development; that is, development which meets our needs while leaving resources for future generations, and the need for development to be in harmony with the environment. The second major issue is the global economy and the fight against poverty. The issue here is how to get more aid for those who need it, how to develop further fairer trading practices, and how to lift the burden of debt repayment from developing countries.

The third major issue is disarmament for development. That involves redirecting global arms expenditure for food, shelter, health care and the education of the world's poorest people. The fourth and final interrelated strategy is for the protection of human rights, to ensure that people all around the world have a right to participate in decisions affecting their lives.

The purpose of introducing this motion in the Parliament today is not to engage in partisan debate but, hopefully, to raise the public profile of the important campaign One World or None, sponsored by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid. The Council is supported by its 84 member organisations, which include a wide diversity of organisations in Australia: the Association of Apex Clubs in Australia, Australian Baptist World Aid, Australian Catholic Relief, the Australian Teachers Federation, the Federation of Australian Jewish Welfare Societies, World Vision and the Young Women's Christian Association, to mention just a few. A wide cross-section of Australians are prepared to lend their names to this campaign.

Fundamental to the campaign is the proposition that we, as individuals, are not powerless, that we are not able to turn our backs on the rest of civilisation and that each and every one of us in this chamber and people listening to this debate has a positive role to play in lifting public awareness about these crucial issues. These issues, of course, have been on the international agenda for some considerable time. Even comparatively recently, in 1983, in response to the concerns of nations about the future of the world's environment, the United Nations brought together some 23 experts from around the world. That Commission on Environment and Development was chaired by Norway's Prime Minister Brundtland. It brought together the world's attention, focusing on the urgency of global degradation and its impact on the poor. The report, called Our Common Future, is popularly referred to as the Brundtland report. It was published in 1987. Our Common Future highlighted the need to put environmental concerns at the centre of all decisions made about development. Unless we have a healthy environment we will have no basis at all for our requirements.

A number of issues are involved in this campaign. The limited time for this debate precludes me from making more than a brief reference to some of those crucial issues. To address the world's environmental crisis, as recognised by the Brundtland Commission, the poverty crisis must also be addressed. The tragedy is that the world's poorest people live on land which has been most seriously environmentally degraded, that is, land which has often been stripped of trees, which is overused, which has lost its topsoil and, with that, the capacity to grow trees or healthy crops to feed the poor.

The issue of energy conservation is one which we all have to address because in Australia we consume 80 times as much energy as a person in sub-Saharan Africa. The reality is that Australia's population of 17 million has the same impact on the world's resources as 1,280 million Africans. The consequences of that unrestrained energy utilisation include many things: the greenhouse effect, the growing urban industrial air pollution and the high incidence of acid rain, to name just a few. I remember being on a parliamentary delegation to Poland and seeing in Krakow buildings that had stood for centuries and that had never been subject to destruction and erosion literally beginning to crumble because of the effect of acid rain.

We have now entered a new dimension of world history. It is very important that we respond as a civilisation to those things. The issue of the loss of forests has been mentioned before in this House but we need to be reminded of a simple fact. Imagine 43 football fields with trees standing and then imagine those same football fields with no trees standing. That loss is occurring every minute of every day. The loss of trees means loss of life in a very direct way. In 1988, de-afforestation in the catchment areas of the Ganges and the Nile turned heavy rains into catastrophic floods. In Sudan, the floods left 1 1/2 million people homeless and in Bangladesh the Ganges floods left 25 million people homeless. There are many other environmental problems which I do not have time to refer to in detail.

Let me turn to some other important issues, such as foreign aid. The Australian Labor Party Government's record on foreign aid is not a good one. I am not proud of my Government's record. I am an outspoken critic of the failure of the Government to do more. I want to place this on the record in a bipartisan way. I say to the Opposition that the proposals to cut foreign aid recently announced by the Opposition are wrong; they are in the wrong direction. It is very easy as parliamentarians to go for the cheap option, the easy way, to play on public prejudice. How much more important it is that we as parliamentarians take the high moral ground, that we try to educate Australians about the importance of being good international citizens. I call on the Opposition to reverse its stand on aid.

Another important matter is the integration of environmental concerns into our aid program. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a major statement on the environment. Some important initiatives have been announced in relation to the integration of environmental protection in Australia's aid program. I welcome those recent developments. The issue of poverty is almost beyond comprehension for us as Australians. The statistics are absolutely frightening. The 1989 report of the World Bank estimates that 950 million people in the developing world live in conditions of poverty. They are not statistics that we, as global citizens, can afford to ignore. Another issue of integral importance in the One World or None campaign is the issue of disarmament for global development. Again, some statistics need to be drawn into this debate. Simply, three weeks of global spending on arms would pay for primary health care for every child in the developing world. That would include their access to safe water.

The time available to me in this debate has run out. My purpose has been to put these issues on the agenda of the Parliament and to say to my fellow parliamentarians that we are not neutral, that history will judge our contribution to raising public awareness about these important issues. I urge the support of all members for the propositions that I am advancing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the House is very wide-ranging and encompasses many interlocking issues. The One World or None Campaign is a challenge for us all. In its campaign for One World, the Australian Council for Overseas Aid draws the attention of the Australian public to four matters to which it can make a contribution and commitment: firstly, the environment; secondly, economic problems, with a view to reducing poverty, hunger, malnutrition and diseases; thirdly, protecting human rights; and, fourthly, disarmament, with the intention to guide the world away from its massive expenditure on weapons.

SPEECH.PARA: India, a regional neighbour of Australia, is a recipient of a significant amount of both government and non-government aid from Australia-deservedly so, some would say, as India is a country with great economic problems that have seen a large number of her people languishing in a seemingly hopeless poverty trap. Yet, despite the terrible conditions of many of her people, India's expenditure on her huge rearmament program has more than doubled since 1983. It is the equivalent of $US8,300m in 1988-89, or about 4.2 per cent of gross domestic product. In marked contrast, Australia's defence spending in terms of gross domestic product is only 2.3 per cent. Instead of concentrating on the basic social needs of its population, India has chosen to pour billions of rupees into both her rearmament program and her nuclear weapons program. Indeed, such is the scale of India's military expansion that signs of a regional arms race are now evident. It is an arms race provoked by India and is entirely at odds with the aims of One World.

Let me illustrate the obstacles posed to One World by India. On 27 September 1989, barely a month ago, Admiral Nayyer, recently retired from the Indian Navy, gave a most interesting address to the United States Global Strategy Council Forum in Washington, DC. The Council has a set of rules for such addresses, the most notable being that `it is off the record-no one can be quoted directly'-and one can use the content as long as the speaker is not identified. I have been provided with a certified transcript of Admiral Nayyer's address which should be compulsory reading for the Australian Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and particularly his Department, given its pitifully poor submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which is currently examining Australia-India relations.

It appears that Admiral Nayyer was in Washington as part of a delegation sent by the Indian Government to explain its policies, but he was not an official spokesman. Admiral Nayyer also describes himself as follows:
. . . involved with a lot of organisations which deal with national security concerns outside the Government, and my views reflect the concern of a large number of Indians.
In his address Admiral Nayyer, referring to the 1978 Carter initiative for the United States and the Soviet Union to demilitarise the Indian Ocean, said it is:
. . . in the interests of unilateral states that there is an indigenous power in the area which can ensure stability.
He goes on to say:

I'm not suggesting that we . . . want to dominate the countries in the region, but what I am saying is this, that any hope of stability in our region, negative India stability and India power, is rusery.

This statement lends yet further credence to the belief that India's advocacy of the Indian Ocean zone of peace is nothing more than a blatant attempt to ensure that the only significant and thus dominant naval presence in the Indian Ocean is the Indian Navy. This hardly fits in with the objectives of the One World campaign if for no better reason than to maintain a navy sufficient to dominate the region, India's defence expenditure will have to remain high, which is to the very great detriment of its impoverished people.
Admiral Nayyer's vanity got the better of him at one stage when, talking of India's naval expansion, he said:
For almost 30 years I have provided the philosophic rationale for India's maritime power . . . it is not India's fault that the rest of the world refused to recognise it.

That is, recognise India's expansion and not his vanity. However, Admiral Nayyer's observation that the rest of the world refused to recognise it is a condemnation of the Hawke Government's strategic assessment, because the period of greatest acceleration in India's naval expansion has been in the 1980s. As far as I can discover, the Government's official position remains one of being `intrigued'.

In justifying India's acquisition of a nuclear submarine force, Admiral Nayyer advanced an argument that has ramifications not just for the stability of Australia and the Indian Ocean region but also the stability of the world as a whole. Admiral Nayyer said:
We-
that is, India-

should have an indigenous capability of serious production of nuclear submarines and not just staying with propulsion, but that we should propose the whole strategic spectrum of fitting them with missiles and all that.

Even taking into account that India regularly engages in bluff and that its missile program is very much in its infancy, the fact that an unofficial spokesman of the Indian Government is canvassing the development of nuclear ballistic missile submarines is, I would have thought, a quite significant point.

Of special interest to Australia is that Admiral Nayyer was tackled on the issue of Indian intervention outside of India and its sphere of influence in cases where an ethnic Indian population was perceived to be threatened, and Fiji in particular was raised. Given the fact that Admiral Nayyer's views present us with a window into current thinking in respect of the Indian decision making elite, his response deserves mention. He said:
I am glad that the Fijian problem has occurred before India had the military capability to do anything.

I should add that Admiral Nayyer presaged his response by indicating that he would answer `lightheartedly', but this does not detract from the fact that such an opinion was voiced. He then went on to describe the application of military power in varying degrees and talked of exercising restraint of power, but there is a none too thinly veiled threat in his remarks that needs to be seriously heeded. Indeed, that threat fits in with the current strong belief that India has set about pursuing its pre-Mogul destiny. It is a destiny wherein India regards itself not so much as a country but as a civilisation-a civilisation not constrained by the present man-made borders of India or other regional countries, and a civilisation that embraces the numerous overseas Indian populations that are to be found around the Indian Ocean littoral.

The Hawke Government's total inability to come to grips with the changed strategic situation in the Indian Ocean region is, to a large degree, illustrated by the fact that it was only in May this year that the position of military attache in New Delhi was reinstated after it was abolished three years ago. Lest anybody be in any doubt that the Hawke Government has entirely misjudged the strategic environment, I will quote a remark by a senior Defence bureaucrat to the Senate Standing Committee investigating Australia-India relations. He said:

I would not like the Committee to think that you have a team of experts on India before you . . . in some respects that is illustrative of the nature of defence concerns about India that we could not put together a team from Defence of experts on India. I would doubt that we would be able to do so in the foreseeable future, nor would we see a need to do so.

That is a very disturbing quote. It is little wonder then that the Minister for Defence is in a position only to describe himself and therefore the Australian Government as `intrigued'. In conclusion, I seek leave to table the certified transcript of Admiral Nayyer's address to the United States Global Strategy Council.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate quite readily. I was approached only two weeks ago by some women who work with the Australian Council for Overseas Aid. They presented me with a number of petitions in support of the One World Declaration which is the end point, in a sense, of the One World or None Campaign. I was pleased to receive that declaration, and I will mention the six points that these people seek to impress upon the Australian Government. They are:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Focus Australia's aid program on fighting poverty and protecting the environment.
2. Restore Australian aid to 0.5 per cent of GNP by 1992 and work for a fairer international economic system.
3. Cut military spending by 1 per cent and allocate the savings to overseas aid.
4. Ensure that aid promotes human rights.
5. Develop a code of conduct for Australian businesses investing in countries where serious human rights abuses occur.

6. Develop new policies for Australia's representatives to the World Bank, International Monetary Fund and Asian Development Bank that give top priority to fighting poverty and protecting the environment.

I might say in the spirit of this debate that I cannot agree with all of the six points that they present for consideration by the Australian Government. I can agree with most of them but, for instance, a great deal of complexity lies behind what they ask of us.

I refer to the third point-`Cut military spending by one per cent and allocate the savings to overseas aid'-and I say this especially to the younger ones who are listening: I suppose it is obvious to suggest that we should shift spending from military purposes to overseas aid. I would hope that at some stage we will do that but we cannot do it simply in one step or two steps. We have to ask ourselves what is the apparent situation in which Australia-and the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) was talking about India-finds itself in the real world. In other words, if a nation is to feel secure it must spend a certain amount of money on military hardware. Unfortunately, that is a fact of life. The real question is not the simple one of `Let's transfer money from military expenditure to overseas aid', but the more complex one of how we achieve security between nations such that we can lessen our expenditure on military hardware. That is the key question. I guess this debate allows us to raise the more complex things that lie behind the One World Declaration.

I find it most encouraging, for instance, that in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) at present there are two events taking place. The first is an attempt to reform the USSR economy and the second is an attempt to reform its political life through some sort of democratisation. It seems to me that the USSR has been forced into a revamping of its economy simply because that country is going broke. There are both wins and losses in this process. We might find that the USSR reforms its economy and integrates itself into the Western economy, thus lessening its need to invest in military hardware. In other words, to the extent that it can reform and integrate its economy with the rest of the world it might feel less out on its own and will not have the need to spend so much on military hardware.

I am fairly hopeful that what is happening at present in the USSR might be the first step in the cutting of military expenditure in that country and in the whole of the Eastern bloc, that it will follow to the United States of America and so forth. The steps are not simple. We do not just make a neat accountant's transfer from the defence budget to overseas aid. Let me go through this once again. It is possible that the reforms taking place right now in the eastern European bloc will mean a greater integration between that bloc and the Western world. If that greater integration occurs there will not be the need to spend so much on military hardware. That is what I am hoping for.

The second thing that is happening in the USSR is that there is now an ability to speak out and tell the rest of the world what happens in that country. I was speaking recently to an eminent biologist from the University of Queensland who had visited the USSR in the last couple of years. He said that just three or four months ago he found that Soviet scientists for the first time were able to speak out not only about some of the scientific achievements of that country but also about some of the crises that had occurred in the industrialisation of the USSR. For the first time we will learn about some of the awful environmental and pollution problems within the Eastern bloc. He tells me that every press conference to which a Soviet scientist goes now is sold out because they are so interesting. For so long we have heard little about what is happening in the USSR, but now journalists are asking question after question of Soviet scientists about what happens in their country with respect to environment destruction and industry.

I find that a positive thing too. It is possible that while Soviet scientists can now speak out our scientists can speak to them. Our biologists and environmentalists can go to the USSR and debate with them the best ways of promoting new technologies that will mean a safer and better environment in the USSR. These joint movements for reform of the Soviet economy and reform of its democratic process will, in the first instance, reveal in the next decade an awful picture--

TALK.START.PARA: —There are four speakers. Your time is up.

—There are only three debaters. It will reveal an awful picture of environmental destruction in the Eastern bloc but a real possibility that there will be a lot more integration between the science of the Eastern bloc and the science of the Western bloc. We might now find that USSR industry will be able to achieve a far cleaner and far less destructive degree of output. I believe I still have a couple of minutes left.
—No, you have not. You have gone two minutes over. There are four speakers.
—I understand there are only three speakers.
—Order! The honourable member for Petrie will resume his speech or his seat.

—I will finish off. I am sorry that we were not given the same information. The One World Declaration raises a great number of debates in this whole topic of environment and aid. I am glad that today part of that debate has commenced here and will be boosted. I look forward now to hearing the next speech on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns). He was not necessarily to know what the arrangements were. Like other members of this House, I received a delegation last week in my electorate office in relation to the One World or None Campaign. I spent an hour and a half with that delegation discussing some of the issues it raised. Inevitably everybody agrees with the basic motherhood propositions it put forward-that is, that we all want peace, we all believe in the importance of human rights, we would like to have a sustainable long-lasting environment and we all want to destroy poverty. There is no argument with any of that. I think it is important to recognise that just about everybody I have ever met in my life would agree with those particular propositions.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating how we achieve these sorts of objectives. For example, let us take the issue of poverty, in particular poverty in the developing world. The solution to the problem of poverty in the developing world is not a constant flood of aid to those countries, although emergency relief aid is fundamentally important in certain circumstances. The solution to the problem of poverty lies in domestic economic policies, the generation of investment, including foreign investment, and responsible land policies, and also the opening up of international trade to developing countries. If we want a sustainable environment we have to introduce the concept of polluter pays and ensure that environmental degradation is properly recognised in national accounts. If we want peace and disarmament we have to be realistic and move towards that objective in the context of multilateral disarmament, not through unilateralism, as is suggested but not spelt out in the One World or None Campaign. Unilateralism will lead to instability. Multilateral disarmament based on trust is something that is fundamentally achievable.

When we talk about moving towards alleviating poverty, when we talk about moving towards a sustainable environment, when we talk about peace and disarmament, we must try to achieve these things in practical and constructive ways. There is no point in going around with beads and flowers hoping that people will sit down and be kind and loving to each other. Even in a peaceful place such as this Parliament not everyone agrees with everyone else and there is scope for very fierce debate. That applies worldwide. It applies between nations. It applies within nations. The resolution of these debates will always be a constant struggle for mankind. But if we move towards intelligent solutions to those problems, not wishful thinking, then we can indeed achieve one world and we will not have to confront future generations with the prospect of none.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time alloted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day of the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of the focus on the environment that has been so much a part of the nation and the Parliament in recent years, and in the light of the comments attributed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) over the last 24 hours, I move the following motion appearing in my name on the Notice Paper:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:

(1) recognises the importance of the Murray-Darling Basin in the economic development of Australia and its continuing contribution to the nation's primary production, industrial and recreation activities; and

(2) calls on the Federal Government to give a higher priority to salinity mitigation schemes in south-eastern Australia and to foster greater cooperation between the State Governments involved in the Murray-Darling catchment areas in order to ensure that the long-term interests of river users are met.

Thanks to the generosity of the Opposition Whips and the fluctuating fortunes in Parliament House, my office in this building is located in the northernmost room in the north-eastern wing. It has a particular advantage. From my office desk I can look down into the courtyard which is used by the parliamentary staff to obtain access to the staff dining area. In that courtyard there is a rather magnificent fountain arrangement. It comprises a slated area with a 3-inch PVC pipe gushing water vertically into a reservoir. The water overspills into what from my point of view very much resembles an irrigation channel, which runs for 25 or 30 metres and then makes a right-angled turn into an even wider area.

With my background, sitting at my office desk in this place I am very much at home. I spent my first 40 years, either as a child or as a practising irrigator, on irrigation properties in the Riverland area of South Australia. The presence of a 3-inch pipe gushing water into what appear to be irrigation channels is something with which I am very familiar. With the boyish exuberance of all Riverlanders, I have, as you would not be surprised to hear, Mr Deputy Speaker, had an illegal swim or two in an irrigation channel and even accepted a challenge to swim across the river. So I suspect that in my veins I have more than my fair share of muddy River Murray water.

From that perspective, I have a great deal of sensitivity about what is happening to the Murray-Darling basin. The importance of that basin to Australian agriculture cannot be overstated. The basin provides something like 40 per cent of Australia's total agricultural production. The area from Murray Bridge in the electorate of Mayo to Toowoomba in the electorate of Groom, and from Canberra where we are at present to the South Australian gulfs, one-seventh of the land mass of Australia, is caught up in the catchment area of the Murray-Darling Basin. Relying on this water resource for domestic water are 1.25 million Australians; and half of our sheep, a quarter of our cattle and three-quarters of our irrigated land depend on the Murray-Darling catchment area.

As a South Australian I am acutely aware of its importance to that State. In a normal year, more than 50 per cent of the water requirement in South Australia is met from the Murray River. In a drought year, that rises to 70 or 80 per cent. In the electorate of Grey, 90 per cent of the Iron Triangle depends on the River Murray for its water supply. It is an ecological feature without parallel in Australia. It is an ecological feature on which I have been totally dependent for my livelihood. I use the motion before the House this morning to emphasise the point that I am irritated by the underlying impression abroad in the community that the ecological problems of the River Murray result from irrigation and that the irrigators are principally to blame.

The facts do not underscore that point. History shows that this huge south-eastern area of Australia was once a great inland sea. Under this catchment area lies a basin of saline water which is constantly flowing into the Murray-Darling system. The Murray-Darling system never comprised sparkling freshwater streams fed from snow-covered mountains. That is true only of the uppermost regions of the River Murray. Only in the electorate of Farrer has that any semblance of reality. The River Murray is a very low flow river by world standards. Its flow is only 16 per cent of the flow of the Nile River, 3.5 per cent of the flow of the Mississippi River, and 0.25 per cent of the flow of the Amazon River. The River Murray flows over a huge salt underlay which is constantly making its way naturally into the Murray system.

Members of this Parliament have heard me say before that, if I were to sit with the Berri hotelier, Mr Malcolm Hill, at the front bar of his hotel and look at the River Murray as it flows past that hotel early on its entrance into the South Australian system, every 12 minutes the equivalent of a semi-trailer load-24 tonnes-of salt would flow past my nose, borne from the eastern States and through South Australia to the sea. My point is that not all of this salt is irrigator-induced. The Murray-Darling Basin Commission statistics show that the maximum amount of irrigator-induced salt in the Murray-Darling system is about 31 per cent, with 69 per cent coming from natural inflows that existed before white man occupied that area. In the 1860s, before irrigation was even dreamt of, Salt Creek, which flows into the Murray River, was aptly named by early explorers because it was so saline. In 1914, a drought year, the salinity levels at Morgan in South Australia, where the River Murray turns dramatically south towards the sea, were recorded at 10,000 EC units. Salinity, whether it is man-induced or naturally induced, has to be dealt with.

For the Parliament to act as if irrigators were guilty of the ecological damage done to the Murray-Darling Basin area is quite wrong. It is an area of enormous natural inflow which has gone on since well before white man occupied this continent. The truth remains that the cost to irrigators of rising salt levels in the Murray-Darling catchment area is calculated at $65m a year and $37m is the cost to urban users as a result of industrial corrosion, hot water services not lasting as long as they should, and other difficulties that urban users in South Australia face because they are dependent on Murray River water. If nothing is done to address the problems of the Murray-Darling Basin it is calculated that, by the year 2015, the cost to irrigators, in today's dollar terms, will be at least $95m a year and the cost to urban users will be closer to $60m a year. The cost will accelerate, and the additional and unforgivable cost will be the loss of up to 500,000 hectares of presently irrigated or occupied farm land because of encroaching salinity.

I concede, as would every member of the Opposition, that the Government is well aware of this dilemma. The reports on the Murray-Darling Basin would make a pile so high that even you, Mr Deputy Speaker, could not jump over it. What is needed is not more reports but action to address this problem. I am also prepared to concede-and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) will be anxious to correct me if I am wrong-that the Government is taking action, but it is too little, too late.

Upstream from my property is the Woolpunda area. Through the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, the Government has introduced a salt interception scheme which is designed to pick up the natural underground inflows of often unseen salt coming into the Murray-Darling system and transfer them to evaporation basins located somewhere in the Cadell area. It is a great idea. The construction is in place and we look forward to the scheme working. It is estimated to cost $29.9m. That money is being spent, but it is only a drop in the ocean.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you do?

—What we need are further Woolpunda schemes to get the mean salinity level at Morgan down by at least 80 EC units. These schemes will cost money. The Minister asked, `What did you do?'. I suspect that is a classic interjection from Ministers in any political party. What the Minister cannot lose sight of and what the Government must not be allowed to lose sight of is that the Opposition, when in government, had committed itself to a $600m program to address the problems of water reticulation around Australia.
—In a Budget of minus $9 billion.
—Frankly, I am not saying that money is not being spent but that insufficient money is being spent to avoid what could be an ecological disaster for which future generations would condemn us all.
—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a brief contribution to the debate on this motion from the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and to pick up on a couple of his comments. It is time that everyone in Australia came to understand that in the Government's view soil degradation-salinity is one of the principal issues-is the major problem facing Australia and has been identified as such. One can take lots of approaches to these sorts of things. The honourable member for Wakefield takes the practical approach of someone who comes from the land and has seen the effects of soil degradation.

SPEECH.PARA: When, in the late 1960s, I was first posted to northern Victoria with my work, to a little place called Pyramid Hill, I just could not believe what I saw around the area in sloppy watering practices and just sheer ignorance. I guess that over time that caused me to reflect on the wisdom of such things as soldier settlement and other schemes that we have embarked on to open up irrigation. We have taken what we now understand to be a very fragile aspect of this continent-the crust of the soil, the balance that nature had evolved over time. When we do things such as turn the Murray River into a 50-mile wide lake using irrigation and take flat land that has a very delicate crust and start to water and overuse it-using it for all the things we have managed to do in that region in the last 150 years-we produce very dramatic outcomes very quickly. It is a bit like computers: they are terrific when they are working well but when the darned things start to go wrong they go wrong in such a hurry that it takes a lot of time to backtrack and fix them up.

What has happened with the proliferation of subdivisions, dairy farming and all the other things, particularly in the Murray-Darling Basin, has been that we have taken something and started to change it at such a rapid rate that the damage has been major. Farmers understand this. Nothing that I say here now is critical of the future approach of farmers and people in general. I know that the honourable member for Wakefield is sensitive about governments and other people saying, `You are the ones who have caused it; you are the ones who are guilty'. I agree with him that no one sector of the community is responsible; we are all responsible.

Many people have been questioning these things for a long time in places such as the Murray Valley, up around Kerang. I am sure that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is at the table, would have seen these things for himself when he went around the area as a union official in the old days. In such places one sees water lying around and the sun beating down on it. The water table comes up to about one foot from the top and six months later it is just salt. One can see it happening very dramatically and very quickly before one's eyes. To turn all that around does not involve just turning around practices; it involves turning around attitudes.

The Minister's interjection was a valid one. I know that the honourable member for Wakefield was sensitive to the Minister's saying, `What did you do about it?'. But it is all very well for the honourable member to say that the Opposition when in government was going to throw money at this problem. It threw a lot of money at a whole lot of things, but we finished up with a minus $9 billion Budget to deal with. What we have managed to do-this ought to be kept in perspective-is not only to take the Budget from minus $9 billion to plus $9 billion and deal with all the other things associated with restructuring the economy, but also to fund the things that the previous Government would have liked to fund. It would have liked to fund these things but instead it threw around all that money and got us nine billion bucks in the red.

We have also introduced the environment statement handed down by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in July this year entitled Our Country, Our Future. Australia is the first nation in the world to accept the United Nations' global approach to the environment and other such issues. I know that the Opposition agrees with and welcomes that. We all welcome that approach. This is a government of action. The approach involves a land care program and a national soil conservation program. The Murray-Darling Basin is a key feature in these programs. Only last week we had in Parliament House the national launch of the land care program. This is an historic occasion because it is the first time that organisations such as the Australian Conservation Foundation and the National Farmers Federation have taken a cooperative approach. The Opposition, to its credit, has agreed to work in cooperation with the Government on the issue so that people in the structure that has been set in place know that it has a budget and a direction and that, irrespective of which government is in power-I do not see any prospect of change-they will at least have an assurance that it will be able to continue with its priority and direction.

I welcome the chance to speak this morning to the motion on the Notice Paper from the honourable member for Wakefield. Any attempt by anyone in this place to raise the profile of these environmental issues, and particularly to focus on the issue of soil conservation and land degradation, must be commended. To the extent that the honourable member's motion raises even more awareness and commitment to these issues in the community in general, it is certainly worth supporting.

But I have to take issue with the second part of the honourable member's notice because it actually calls for the Government to give priority to these issues. I simply have to point out to the honourable member that we finally do have a government in Australia that is giving priority to these issues and that has actually adopted a comprehensive environment statement which has been recognised around the world as the leading position of any government on the environment in general. A key feature of the statement is the commitment to this issue of the Murray-Darling Basin. That commitment is matched with the dollars necessary to make it happen. The real test of the Government's commitment is that those dollars have been provided from real money in a real Budget and not from a minus $9 billion, `hope we could, wish we could, wouldn't it be nice if we could' Budget. This money has actually been provided and it is committed from a real Budget with real dollars. It will really happen, and everybody in this place ought to applaud that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of pleasure that I second the motion moved by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), which recognises the importance of the Murray-Darling Basin in the economic development of Australia and its continuing contribution to the nation's primary production and industrial and recreational activities, and calls on the Federal Government to give a higher priority to salinity mitigation. Very few Australians today would not be aware of the environmental problems that this nation faces. In particular, very few would not be aware of the real problems we face in caring for and in rehabilitating Australia's greatest environmental resource-the Murray-Darling Basin. As Malcolm Fraser once said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Murray-Darling Basin is Australia's greatest natural recurring resource.

It has been claimed that its resources are worth $10,000m annually to the nation's economy. The Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council, an intergovernmental body that met formally for the first time in August 1986 to promote and coordinate effective management and planning for the basin, brings together 12 Ministers from the Commonwealth and three States. Queensland, which contains one-quarter of the basin, currently holds observer status. One of the first fruits of the Council is the new Murray-Darling Basin Commission, formed by the Commonwealth, Victorian and New South Wales governments to have a coordinated management approach to the resources. This caretaker organisation is aware of the many problems facing the basin, but is frustrated by inadequate funding and long term financial commitment.

It is estimated that $100m annually is required over the next 10 years to help rectify the problems of salinity, both man made and naturally occurring. The honourable member for Wakefield referred to that when he said that there was just not enough funding for this valuable resource. As a South Australian member of parliament, Peter Arnold, has stated, in broad terms the problem can be rectified by means of on-farm improved irrigation practices, engineering works and reafforestation of the Murray-Darling Basin, both on and off the farm. There is a strong argument, in coordination with the works that I have mentioned, that the residual saline effluent should be piped to the sea. It is the dream of many irrigators, farm users and the general public along the river that this pipe will take the effluent to sea and, therefore, allow the Murray to run free, at least of some of the salt.

As with most environmental issues, we have instant experts on everything. When I first went to the bush, which is many years ago, I travelled throughout the grazing and irrigation areas. I, like the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), would have looked at those areas and said, `These people are doing something wrong here', or `They are providing too much water. They are sloppy in their attitudes'. But I am not an expert on farming or irrigation. I think the problem we have in our country today is that we have too many instant experts. Certainly we have researchers and people who are looking into these problems and I think we should be advised by them. But people should not go into an area and say, `This farmer is doing it wrong', although he might have been there a lifetime and have made a living from it. Farmers-I include amongst them irrigators-are very environmentally conscious because they have to make a living out of the soil on which they live.

I believe many civilisations-we all know of them; we have read about them in ancient and modern history-have risen and fallen on their irrigation practices. Some have lasted for thousands of years and others have not lasted very long at all. Egypt, the Nile delta and the Nile River are good examples. Those who have been to Egypt would realise just how important irrigation is to that nation, having only a narrow fertile plain along the Nile River on which to grow its crops. Of course, Australia is a much newer nation and we have a lot to learn. In the main, we have adopted European practices and perhaps those practices have not been as good as we would have liked them to be.

Referring to what the honourable member for Wakefield said, I know that when Deniliquin and north of the Murray were in my electorate of Riverina-Darling some problems were faced there. Great work has been done to overcome those problems. What the honourable member for Wakefield has said is right: the whole Murray-Darling Basin contains what we call prior streams-salt streams-which continually feed salt into the main river system, particularly in times of drought. If anyone travels through those areas in times of drought he will be able to see in some areas exactly what I am talking about. But certainly irrigation enables a fair amount of salt to go into the rivers. We now have to worry about how to contain that.

I have a particular interest in this because in my electorate I have the Murrumbidgee and the Coleambally irrigation areas. In those areas, as in most irrigation areas, we have a rising water table which we have to do something about. Most of what we have to do will be on-farm. We will have to try to stop the problem there by putting in tillage and by trying to keep the salt levels down. Of course, the overall problem we face is that what we intend to do will require a great deal of money. As I have said, a South Australian member of parliament, Peter Arnold, stated that the whole problem will have to be controlled by improved on-farm irrigation practices; probably large engineering works and reafforestation of the Murray-Darling Basin, both on and off the farm.

I have spoken about the River Murray Commission but many organisations will have to be involved in controlling not only the salt menace but also many other pollution problems that we will face. One of the organisations that I wish to speak of today is the famous Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). All honourable members are aware of the CSIRO. They would also know that, over the past few years, it has come upon hard times due to a lack of funding and we are losing some of our best scientists. But, if we are to do something about this water problem in the Murray-Darling Basin, the CSIRO has a major role to play. The CSIRO Division of Water Resources pamphlet states:
In January 1988, CSIRO, Australia's national research organisation, established the division of Water Resources. The Division will play a major role in research into the use and management of water.
The objective of the Division is:

To carry out research that will enable public agencies and the private sector to develop improved methods for the definition, use and management of Australia's water resources. Of particular importance is the maintenance of the quantity and quality of urban, rural and industrial water supplies.
The Division has a total staff of 230 including 56 research scientists and operates from four sites across Australia-Perth, Adelaide, Griffith-
which is in my electorate-

and Canberra. As well, it has strong links with the Murray-Darling Freshwater Research Centre at Albury-Wodonga where it has several staff seconded. One of these, Dr David Mitchell, is Director of the Centre.

Dr David Mitchell is a well-known scientist who was once stationed in Griffith where I met him and got to know him and respect the work he was doing. Recently I attended the CSIRO establishment at Griffith and met Dr Wayne Meyer, the principal research scientist and crop physiologist, and Kathleen Bowmer, program director of ecology and management of surface water. They have a very responsible job in carrying out research into water not only in the Murray-Darling area but also in other areas.

I have a list of the accomplishments of the CSIRO in the 1980s. In the irrigation system management area it introduced water-run urea for efficient nitrogen fertiliser application; developed aquatic weed control practices in irrigation channels and paddocks; identified crop losses due to waterlogging; and improved soil drainage using gypsum enriched slots. Of course, in all its research it is trying to make the most efficient use of our freshwater supplies and it is trying to stop pollution and salinisation. In the area of environmental and community issues it heightened the awareness of potential water table and wetland salinity problems; identified the cause of odours in drinking water from the Murrumbidgee River; reported on the hazards associated with water recycling following herbicide application; and used aquatic plants for industrial, mining and community waste water treatment. In the area of farmer education-I spoke earlier about how important it is for farmers to be educated, particularly in irrigation areas-it introduced quantitative descriptions of crop growth stages; identified limitations to potential crop productivity; and made estimates of crop water use readily available.

We all know that the CSIRO makes a great contribution to the world development of science. Its world scientific contributions were: to develop the use of current weather information for agricultural decision making; to release disease resistant safflower varieties and sunflower breeding lines; to develop systems to study root growth in real world soils; and to improve the understanding of ways to reduce nitrogen fertiliser loss in rice.
