In the time that is available to me I would like to reiterate just how important the CSIRO will be if we are to save the Murray-Darling Basin and if we are to make a good and proper use of the limited water resources that we have in this great nation of ours. I believe that our development will depend on the availability of fresh water and the use we make of it. As honourable members who spoke earlier said, we are not endowed with a great deal of fresh water compared with the Americas, Africa, China and places like that. So let us make the best use of our water. I call on the Federal Government to make sure that the CSIRO gets the funding it deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 104a. The debate will be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Tasmania: Pilots Dispute-Conservation Movement-Media Ownership-`Our Common Future'-Capital Gains Tax-Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd-Member for Wentworth

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is very nice to see a former Tasmanian in the chair, even though sometimes he does not acknowledge it.
—Order! I ask the honourable member not to reflect on the Chair.

—I am bubbling with enthusiasm after that. At the outset let me say that I will take it easy and keep my blood pressure down because I am told that that is the normal thing to do. My good friend the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is at the table, walked across to me earlier and said, `Bruce, take it easy and don't get stuck into us too hard'. I do not intend to do so. About a month ago I received a box-not a five-foot seven-inch one-containing very nice brochures on Tasmania. The brochures described Tasmania as `an island so much a part of Australia yet so very different' and `rich in heritage and wild in natural beauty'. The contents were all about Tasmania-north, south and west-and all the beauty of Tasmania.
—What about east?

—And east. They depicted Tasmania's wonderful tourist industry. Alas, things have gone radically wrong since I received that box. For the first time in my life I have been too embarrassed to hand out in Parliament House brochures on Tasmania and to talk about Tasmania. Every time I go to the airport I see a line of taxi drivers who say to me, `Bruce, what are you going to do about the strike?'. They tell me that they are battling to pay their mortgages and get wages. They say, `What are those fellas up in Canberra going to do about it?'. Fortuitously, today Mr and Mrs Keith Farrell from Tasmania and their in-laws from Canberra, Mr and Mrs Burton, joined me for morning tea. I am not lousy. I always give Tasmanians a cup of tea: they deserve it. Those people said to me, `Bruce, the front page of today's Mercury says that the strike is over'-or Mr Hawke said that it is over, which is rot-`Planes are back to normal in Tasmania. Ansett is flying normally'. I spoke to Keith at the airport the day he left Tasmania. It took him seven attempts to leave. The planes were cancelled seven times. Tasmania is going down the tube. Regrettably, we are allowing it to happen. I will not start allotting blame. It would be stupid to do so at the moment because there is so much blame that one could allot it for a fortnight.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the other day I read an article in the Launceston Examiner, which is not my local newspaper; it is the Hobart Mercury. After being a member of this place for close on 14 years I find that I like some journalists and some do not like me, but never mind. In that article the journalist criticised politicians. He did not name them; journalists never do. They never say, `Goodluck', `Kerr', or whatever. They always say the politicians are not doing enough to solve this strike. I rang the journalist and said, `Why don't you name the politicians that you think are not doing enough to solve this strike?'. The journalist replied, `No, no, no. Everybody is suffering in Tasmania'. I said, `You are not helping matters, you know, by demoralising politicians like me who are trying to get people from Tasmania, who are trying to get sick people back to Tasmania, and who are doing their utmost to achieve the impossible and overcome this strike'. I sent the journalist a white feather in an envelope and he said to me, `Why did you do that?'. I replied, `Because you do not have the guts to tackle me face to face. You have to do it by pen'. I thought that that was the best way of tackling him.

The point I am making is that this very serious strike is a national disaster, and regrettably the island of Tasmania, which is so dependent on tourism, is suffering badly as a result. I have mentioned the taxi drivers. Motel proprietors keep ringing me saying, `Bruce, what are we going to do about this?'. Hotel proprietors say, `We are not getting the people into the hotels'. The casino is not just important to the people who stay there; it is important to Hobart's economy in terms of the food that is provided and all the other things that go on down there. I cannot give these people a definite answer. For the first time in my 14 years in political life I feel helpless in overcoming the problem. Many honourable members are in a similar position. Creeping into this is a bit of politics. I do not want to criticise anybody-the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) and Michael Field--

TALK.START.PARA: —But you will do it, anyway.

—I will do so. The other day after an Australian Labor Party conference they went on television. Looking as angelic as they normally do-they were beautifully garbed and ready for the fray-they said, `Robin Gray is going to Canberra with a group of Hobart dignitaries-the Mayor of Clarence and the Lord Mayor of Glenorchy-and a few business people to try to draw attention to Tasmania's position, but they will not do any good because they will not be able to see Mr Hawke or whoever'. That is typical of what is occurring at the moment. People are trying to be political without getting to the root evil of solving a strike which is having a devastating effect, particularly on Tasmania because we cannot swim across to the mainland or drive our car across. The ferry service is inadequate. We need another ferry. The present one is overloaded to billyo. We depend on planes coming in and taking our people across and we depend on people coming to Tasmania to stimulate our only economy of importance at present-that is, the tourist industry. Christmas is approaching and everybody is worried. They are ready for the peak season. They want to get a bit of money back into their till during a boom Christmas. But regrettably many people have cancelled their visit to Tasmania. Many people are hesitant to go there. That will have a devastating effect.

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody knows that I do not like the greens. I do not like single-issue politicians. I do not like somebody who sticks to the birds and the bees and forgets the people. At the moment I am worried about the ordinary people of Tasmania who are battling to make a dollar. I am not so worried about the greens. When all this was at its height-when everybody was talking about the strike and worrying about it-the greens and the Australian Labor Party in Tasmania, because they are in cahoots, were talking about locking up 20 per cent of Tasmania by making it a national park. They were not worried about what was happening to the tourist industry. They were not worried about what was happening to the taxi drivers and the ordinary people involved in hotels and motels-the ordinary people making the beds and doing the little jobs. They are the people I am worried about. They are being laid off. They do not have a voice. They are the ones who are always discarded. I said openly to the greens, `Why don't you start worrying about the ordinary people of Tasmania instead of worrying all the time about wilderness and preserving Tasmania as a park? You are always talking about trees. Why don't you start talking about the people down there? Why can't you, for once in your life, all come together in a conciliatory way and work on overcoming this problem?'.

I know that the Labor Party has a dilemma. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was the great conciliator previously. He seemed to be able to overcome strikes after they had done all their damage, but this time he is unable to do so. I say to him-and many people are saying the same thing-`For God's sake, try to overcome this, even if you have to give an inch'. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who is at the table, nods his head. This important matter is affecting many people. It has got past the laughing point. I know that the Minister is not laughing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk to the pilots.

—We have talked to the pilots. Anybody who puts people at a disadvantage, who hurts ordinary people and creates this sort of problem, irrespective of their case, does not come into my category at all. All I am concerned about is what is happening in Tasmania. All I am concerned about is the consistent phone calls that I receive from people who are being devastated by this problem. Honourable members should remember that the tourism industry employs about 19,000 people in Tasmania, directly and indirectly. We have about 10 per cent unemployment. It is about time the greenies woke up to that, too. This is much higher--
—It's the Government.
—The honourable member should not worry about blaming governments.
—Robin Gray.

—And he should not blame Robin Gray; we will watch Mr Field. Nineteen per cent, or probably even more, of our young are unemployed. That position is being aggravated by this problem. It is a massive problem. Tourism generates about 10 per cent of Tasmania's income. It is probably our biggest industry.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—I want another 10 minutes. It will be worth it.
—The honourable member will resume his seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) on that masterly exposition of the problem. A little attention to some possible solutions may have been a little more useful.
—I got only 10 minutes.

—That was more than enough. I want to talk about the environmental movement today. I have been critical of the media in this country because I believe they have been very slothful in the way they have reported on the environmental movement. But I would like to congratulate the Melbourne Herald for an article it published today. The article was written by Dr Rolf Gerritsen, a very good friend of mine. In fact, he was a foundation member of my faction within the Australian Labor Party. He has had a longstanding association with the Labor Party, having worked for the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) for some time. Dr Rolf Gerritsen is now the senior lecturer in public policy at the Australian National University. I will read this article because it is very good. Hopefully, it will be read by many people. Dr Gerritsen says:

SPEECH.PARA: Wilderness conservation has assumed increasing importance on the political agenda over the last two decades. Following the Franklin Dam issue in the early 1980s, conservationism has gradually achieved a dominant influence on government policy. Indeed, since Senator Richardson's conversion to its nostrums, the conservation movement has become seemingly invincible in the making of resources policy. In part this is because it has managed the media's presentation of environmental and resource management issues better than the advocates of development.

But the ``greenies'' have also had the considerable political advantage of controlling the moral high ground of ``principle'', while successfully labelling any opposition as inspired by venal self-interest.

In reality, of course, many conservationists do have vested interests which are well served by their movement. For example, biological and environmental scientists are advantaged by governmental regulations requiring environmental assessment for large-scale development projects.

That illustration provides one clue about the distributional implications of wilderness conservation. For in practice conservation measures, like any other governmental interventions, create advantages for some people and disadvantages for others-in other words, winners and losers.

These redistributions occur in a variety of ways, some not immediately obvious. For example, wilderness conservation can see the imposition of a particular aesthetic of recreation. Restricting access to a wilderness area mostly favours those persons (usually tertiary educated and from leafy suburbs!) who prefer to walk through it communing with nature, as against those persons (most likely neither tertiary educated nor from leafy suburbs) whose preferences lean to challenging nature by traversing bush on a trail bike or in a four wheel drive vehicle.

More serious than such ``social'' redistributions are the economic redistributions following unbridled conservationism. The Commonwealth government's enthusiasm for preventing development projects is threatening, if not Australia's economic future, certainly that of a large segment of our population.

Thus, if we persist in preventing export income-generating projects, unemployment will be an eventual consequence. And it will not be greenies from the urban professional classes that suffer that unemployment but predominantly rural and blue collar workers.

The greenies argue that tourism to these wilderness areas will replace the employment effects of mining and forestry. Even if this were true it requires the present generation of workers to sacrifice their employment prospects for the next generation. In addition the tourism job market is a very different one from that of Australia's extractive industries. Skilled jobs would be replaced by unskilled jobs. Should our future lie in our children being waiters and cleaners rather than skilled tradespeople?
I think not. Dr Gerritsen continues:

There are other economic consequences from shutting down projects such as the Wesley Vale pulp mill and the Coronation Hill mineral prospect. Initially they come principally from the diminution of our future foreign exchange earnings. That means future redistribution of income from the marginal and insecure working class to the educated, secure middle classes.

From the point of view of social equity this Government's obsession with conservation is paradoxical. Further foreign exchange constraints must eventually be met by extra fiscal restraint by government. Given that governmental transfer payments are most important to the living standards of less privileged Australians, this coming restraint portends decreasing living standards for the weakest in our society. These are the very people the Labor Government has thus far devoted much effort to protecting.
And that is an effort that I certainly applaud.

This paradox should not surprise, merely replicating the vacuity of a Commonwealth government ready to give Kodak a $40m production bounty, because it will earn Australia export revenue, while at the same time preventing the paper pulpers and miners from doing the same.

Another monetary consequence of continuing current account constraints will be the relatively permanent imposition of historically high interest rates. This is okay for the middle-aged ``baby boomers'' and the comfortably off. They have houses either with controlled 13.5 per cent interest rates or most of the principal repaid. Their life cycle has reached the capital gains period of home ownership. But for young couples who wish to enter or have recently entered the housing market, high interest rates are crushing their standard of living. They are paying disproportionately for Senator Richardson's sellout of working people's interests to middle-class consumers of conservation.

The intergenerational implications of untrammelled conservationism are similarly inequitable. Shutting down the Australian economy to preserve the rustic romanticism of the urban middle classes is going to be paid for by the next generation of taxpayers who will be saddled with the burden of increasing numbers of welfare beneficiaries. This intergenerational effect is exacerbated by the growing antagonism to population growth by the environmental militants. They propose, in effect, that today's numerically smaller generation of children shall bear disproportionately the taxation burden of funding the ``baby boomer'' generation when it becomes aged.

The greenies have legitimate desires to preserve Australian landscapes unspoilt. But this is achieved at a considerable cost to all Australian citizens. Whether or not we share their preferences we are forced to pay equally for them. So the greenies are obtaining a transfer of economic goods to themselves from the generality of taxpayers.

The ``me-too'' generation is forcing its aesthetic and physic preferences on this and future generations regardless of the economic costs. Militant ``greenies'' are really individualistic ``greedies'' who threaten the economic future of Australia's children.
Mr Deputy Speaker, that quote is from an article in today's Melbourne Herald entitled `Behind the trees: greenies or greedies' and I think it gives a lot of food for thought.

This sort of concern has recently prompted me and a few of my colleagues here in Parliament to launch a coalition for sustainable development. We believe that the environment must be protected, but we recognise that environmental protection costs money. It just cannot happen for nothing and it has to be paid for by industry. Industry is generally prepared to pay and I might add that today some of the best conservation efforts are found in the private sector. For instance, in the State of Western Australia, Alcoa of Australia Ltd is now recognised worldwide as being a very good regenerator of forest. The work that the company has done is certainly a pleasure to the eye and will establish for future generations the sort of environment we all like. Similarly, the regeneration work done by APEA, the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, is superb. In many cases one simply cannot see where it has been, and in some cases I would say that the environment has been restored to a condition better than that which existed before its efforts.

We really do have to come to grips with this as an issue because it afflicts all political parties in Australia, not just the Australian Labor Party or the Liberal Party of Australia. The greenies have managed to create the illusion-and I believe it is an illusion-that they have disproportionate political power and they can guide and control the destinies of governments. If the Government were to change nothing would change as far as they were concerned. They would simply transfer their pressure to the incoming government. Until we get a bipartisan agreement across the political field in Australia that they are just one other competing influence, we will not get any rational debate. The truth is that these people have an open-ended agenda and any compromise that they reach today, they will repudiate tomorrow. One sees examples of this: they make allies when it suits them. For instance, they told us that in Tasmania tourism would replace the blue collar jobs. This was never true. Tourism does provide jobs but they generally tend to be low paid jobs for women and kids; not the skilled blue collar jobs that existed before.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As this Government decays, its lack of principle becomes very clear. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised to abolish child poverty by 1990. He has failed to do so and he now says that he did not mean to use the words he did when he made the promise. The Government has no difficulty whatever in deciding to subsidise a multinational company so that it will remain in Australia. It has no difficulty whatever in subsidising the airlines in order to prolong the pilots dispute. Had it not so subsidised the other employees' wages, the dispute would have been resolved by now. As it is, the dispute could go on indefinitely. The Prime Minister, of course, says that there is no dispute. Well, tell that to anyone trying to run a tourist industry dependent on air travel. Tell that to anyone trying to travel by air in Australia today. Of course there is a dispute and the dispute is compounded by the Government itself.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has adopted outrageous policies regarding the media. It gives me no pleasure to say this but I must say that I have been warning of this to a point where some people have said I am obsessed. But I cannot be obsessed about something as important as free speech, and the concentration of media ownership in the hands of very few people threatens our capacity to get information and to make judgments about matters that are important to us. As a result of these polices, we have not only a threat to our right to know, but also hundreds of people out of work and the prospect of thousands of others losing their jobs. They will not be subsidised by the Government.

Tomorrow is the fiftieth anniversary of Actors Equity. I hope that its members have a wonderful party in Sydney because its fifty-first year looks very bleak indeed. Hundreds of people are being retrenched from the television networks now and the prospect is that those who work in support industries, such as production houses, will lose their employment as well. Very probably thousands of people will be affected by the absurd policy of this Government, which forced through the Parliament an audience viewing reach in television of 60 per cent. That meant that increased prices were paid for licences because if one managed to get hold of 60 per cent then it seemed that one had the world at one's feet. Massive borrowings were made in order to pay these highly inflated prices. Some of that was made overseas, worsening our balance of payments and, of course, all the borrowings were really subsidised by the taxpayers because the interest is tax deductable.

The result is that the same taxpayers who subsidised the policy are now suffering from limited programs. The services are being reduced, there is a real prospect that we will have only two networks in the next 12 months and there will be, of course, a loss of Australian content because Australian programs are costly to make, even though they can be sold overseas. We will be virtually deprived of free-to-air television. The networks are afraid of these `people meters' because they will show that sets are not being turned on-there will be a big turn-off. In dozens of speeches I warned of these and other consequences. I also warned of the loss of local programs in regional areas by this absurd policy of aggregating markets.

One of the most distinguished television executives in Australia, Mr Nigel Dick, said the other morning on AM that regional stations were going broke as a result of this policy; they were reducing local programs because these are costly to make; they were even unable to pay the networks the prices that the networks needed to recoup their program costs when the programs were sold on to the regional stations. Mr Dick estimates that by the year 2000 the stations in the four aggregated regions of Queensland, northern New South Wales, southern New South Wales and Victoria, will have lost $800m-that is in current terms.

What about the print media? The Trade Practices Commission, of course, needs more power. Its recently released report on the lack of competition in Adelaide and Brisbane is very disturbing. The so-called competition is so friendly as to be virtually non-existent. What it amounts to is `warehousing'-that is, where an alleged competitor actually appears to operate as a warehouser for the Murdoch newspapers in those two cities. The report also revealed that originally the Trade Practices Commission had refused Mr Murdoch the right to buy the Canberra Times, but it is now widely believed in the industry-and I certainly believe it-that the Canberra Times is effectively owned by Mr Murdoch. It was of course, we recall, bought by Mr Packer, who had got out of newspapers. He has no interest in newspapers now; he runs magazines very successfully and he loved running television. He did not want to run newspapers at all. He bought the Canberra Times when Warwick Fairfax was obliged to sell it. Then, of course, when Mr Stokes bought the Canberra Times he flew to the United States to talk to Mr Murdoch about the purchase. Mr Murdoch is, effectively, the owner.

It is very interesting that one of the most senior executives of the former Fairfax empire, Mr Fred Brenchley, who was a distinguished member of the Press Gallery here, has written in a very widely circulated trade magazine that he asked a number of direct questions to the people involved in order to ascertain whether indeed the Canberra Times is effectively warehoused by Mr Stokes for Mr Murdoch. I wish to read part of what he wrote. He said:
. . . if Kerry Packer wasn't warehousing the Canberra Times for Rupert, and if Rupert has no hidden deals over the paper, these should be easily denied by those involved.

Not so. Direct questions to Trevor Kennedy, managing director of Consolidated Press, Ken Crowley at News Corporation and Kerry Stokes brought forth a fusillade of no comments, but no direct answers to questions.

The questions to all three were framed in a brief, direct manner to avoid innuendo. They queried some of the financial stratagems for a third-party involvement in a financial transaction, including put and call options, non-competitive clauses, and profit top-ups, some of which Murdoch used in the sale of his Brisbane and Adelaide afternoon newspapers. All questions could have been answered with a simple ``no''.
Of course they were not. He went on to say:
While there would be many business people and politicians who wish Kerry's journalists-
that is, Kerry Packer-
were as passionate about their privacy as he is about his own, Trevor still could have protected that privacy better by ticking off ``no'' to the six questions asked.
Instead of that he said he was protecting the privacy of Mr Packer. Mr Brenchley continued:

At News Corp, Ken Cowley was equally adamant on not responding to market rumour. ``The reasons for this policy are purely pragmatic, and include the fact that we are not prepared to waste resources which would be involved in responding to all the questions we receive,'' he said. ``Having this policy, it is obviously better for us not to make exceptions . . .
Mr Brenchley went on to say:
I put straight questions and straight answers from Mr Cowley would have saved resources all round and killed the rumours that indeed News Limited is the ultimate owner of the Canberra Times.

At Kerry Stokes' Australian Capital Equity, spokesman Andrew Cohen said that while it was not company policy to respond to rumours, ``We depart from our well-founded custom so as to stem the irresponsible propagation of rumours''. He said:
1. The acquisition of the Canberra Times from Consolidated Press Holdings was a cash deal with no unusual conditions.
2. The Canberra Times was 100 per cent beneficially held by entities associated with Stokes.
3. All powers of management and control of the Canberra Times were exercised by Stokes as chairman and the other directors on behalf of the company, the staff, and the readers of the paper.
Fine, Mr Cohen, but these were not the questions which were asked; and once again a straight ``no'' would have been sufficient.
It's quite odd that media companies with the scar tissue of News Limited and Consolidated Press can't summon up a straight no to a question.

My own guess is that if Murdoch ever had any ambitions of owning the Canberra Times they were ended by Paul Keating's warning that he should not acquire any more newspapers . . . Still, it would be nice to know . . .

I believe that the policies of this Government have been absolutely outrageous in all of these fundamental ways and history will damn it for them. The Government can talk of its big pictures, but it is letting Australia down in so many fundamental ways that it is truly outrageous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak today about a debate that is going on in the community around Australia on the compelling prospect of `one world or none' and its relationship to the Brundtland report, Our Common Future. I was recently approached by some of my constituents about this campaign and have lodged a number of petitions calling on the Government to take specific forms of action. The people who approached me included representatives of a local church congregation and an urban environmental group. They are concerned citizens who have a commitment to securing the future of their children and who sincerely believe that many young people are in danger of having their natural optimism stamped out by the gloom which tends to pervade our own comments on the future of our world environment. Some of these people have already written to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), voicing their belief in the need to conserve our environment.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to quote from one of these letters in order to provide the House with an idea of the genuine feeling for humanity and the environment that they convey. My constituent says:

I am aware of the need to make changes in lifestyle and outlook in order to reduce pollution and other waste, and to ensure as much material is recycled as possible. But there is a limit as to what individuals can achieve. It seems to me that it is also the responsibility of government, as the voice of all Australians, to encourage a clean and healthy environment through the preservation of our forests, the reduction of industrial and other waste and encouragement on a national basis of a reduction in energy consumption via an associated recognition of the need to preserve energy resources . . .

I recognise my, and my family's position, from a global viewpoint, is an economically-privileged one, and that it is on this basis that I am able to concern myself with this issue. However, that is by no means to lessen its importance. Instead, it highlights the extent of the problem of achieving environmental aims since it is only through addressing the issue of poverty both in an Australian and a world context that awareness of the needs of our planet, and thereby the means of our survival can be achieved.

The letter ends by asking what our Government's position is with regard to Our Common Future-the report of the World Commission on Environment and Development-whether a full study of it is under way and whether a formal response will be made to it in this Parliament.

As well as a brief response from the Prime Minister's office, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has replied to my constituent referring to the Prime Minister's statement on the environment and the consequent fact that the Federal Government is committed to the principle of sustainable development, at both the national and international level as outlined in the Brundtland report. The reply goes on to say that many Government policies and programs are already consistent with the major principles of the report and the specific recommendations are taken into account as relevant issues arise.

My constituents do not take issue with any of these claims and I am sure that they acknowledge our Government's excellent policy on and work towards conservation of our environment, including a number of decisions which will aid the preservation of important areas of our natural heritage, both nationally and regionally. However, they remain concerned that we, as a Government and a nation, should make a considered response to the content and recommendations of the Brundtland report, given its implications for the international community's attitudes and actions for the future of our world. I concur with this view and believe that the excellence of our Government's record on many aspects of conservation make this response all the more necessary, as it will be useful to other countries in the world.
I would like to put the Brundtland inquiry's findings into context now by reading from page 3 of the report, which refers to the time at which the Commission was considering its report. It says:
The World Commission on Environment and Development first met in October 1984, and published its report 900 days later, in April 1987. Over those few days:
The drought-triggered, environment-development crisis in Africa peaked, putting 35 million people at risk, killing perhaps a million.
A leak from a pesticides factory in Bhopal, India, killed more than 2,000 people and blinded and injured over 200,000 more.
Liquid gas tanks exploded in Mexico City, killing 1,000 and leaving thousands more homeless.
The Chernobyl nuclear reactor explosion sent nuclear fallout across Europe, increasing the risks of future human cancers.

Agricultural chemicals, solvents, and mercury flowed into the Rhine River during a warehouse fire in Switzerland, killing millions of fish and threatening drinking water in the Federal Republic of Germany and the Netherlands.
An estimated 60 million people died of diarrhoeal diseases related to unsafe drinking water and malnutrition; most of the victims were children.
I also believe that the findings of Our Common Future deserve a hearing. It is only a short quote. The findings are summarised in this way:
We must all adopt a policy of sustainable development-wherever we live. This means development which does not degrade and destroy global resources.
We must meet our needs without wiping out the possibility of future generations meeting their needs.
We must leave behind us forests, soil, clean air and clean water-without these resources future generations will be unable to live.

I think those are very important recommendations. In her foreword to the report the then Prime Minister of Norway, Gro Harlem Brundtland, indicated that the Commission was addressing governments, but most of all it was addressing people `whose well-being is the ultimate goal of all environment and development policies'. The Commission also calls for `a common endeavour and for new norms of behaviour at all levels and in the interests of all. The changes in attitudes, social values and aspirations that the report urges will depend on vast campaigns of education, debate and public participation'.

The people are certainly responding with campaigns, contacts and debate. A specific response from the Government would assist in focusing some of this activity, as well as providing them with encouragement and information on the immense undertaking they have begun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) has raised a number of points concerning the environment, and basically I want to raise a matter today that I believe will certainly assist the Australian environment. I refer to the use of the growing number of farmlets that we have in our countryside. My electorate is on the New South Wales coast between Newcastle and Port Macquarie, and that is an area in which, over the years, quite a number of larger properties have been subdivided. Most of the land that has been subdivided is not good agricultural land, yet there are certain areas that would be most productive if they were treated properly. There are many of these areas-hundreds, in fact-within my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that in those geographical areas of Australia where it is convenient to subdivide land and it is possible for people to live, there will be many property subdivisions in the years ahead. Basically, this depends on the ordinance of the local government body concerned, and the policies of the various State governments throughout the Commonwealth. There has been a tendency, though, to allow people to subdivide land because of the way of life that most Australians want. It has been most noticeable, particularly in the last few years when the price of real estate has risen in the Sydney metropolitan area, that many Sydney people, particularly those who are retiring, have moved to other parts of the State or to Queensland, seeking a better climate and a better way of life generally. Many have had a particular desire throughout their lifetime to move on to these smaller farmlets.

When I speak of smaller farmlets, I speak of areas from 10, 20, 30 or 40 acres up to 100 acres or even more, depending upon the quality of the soil. As time goes on, it concerns me more that these lands are getting rather run down in some instances. If we look at our farming production within Australia, we have to appreciate that there are a lot fewer farmers today, occupying our rural lands. I do not say that production has fallen overall, particularly in the wheat, sheep, beef and fruit industries, but over the years there has been a decline in the numbers. The family farm has tended to disappear and bigger corporations and more moneyed people are occupying many of the properties.

Australia itself is looked upon as a country that will be responsible, and is responsible now, for supplying much of the food needs of the world. Many countries want to buy from us and I am very optimistic about the future of primary industry, irrespective of the droughts and the vagaries of the market that occur in this country all the time. I would like to see a close examination, undertaken in company with many of these people and the various agricultural departments. I know that this is primarily a matter for the States but the Commonwealth is involved, particularly in relation to the taxation aspects. I would like deeper thought to be given to the way in which we can make these farmlets productive.

On 17 November there is to be a seminar at Taree in my electorate when officers of the Australian Taxation Office will address the farmers. We have asked them to attend; it is not a political matter, it is aimed at giving advice to people. We are emphasising the fact that we would like the owners of these farmlets to come along. If they are working in town, their wives may be available to attend. We want to encourage these people to make greater use of their soil. When I say `make greater use of the soil', I refer to the planting of trees. The idea of this seminar arose when I was approached by a farm machinery representative who said that he mixed with the farmers and many of these people would like to know what possible taxation concessions were available for them for the growing of certain crops. Some of them have spoken to me as well.

This is why I mentioned the environment. If we want to improve the environment we have to look at the best way of using soil. Much of the country that these farmlets are on is rather poor; they might be situated on iron bark ridge country; they might be on heavily timbered land; they might be on land that is basically clear of timber. Most of those that come to mind immediately are smaller properties that have very little timber on them. We have to encourage people to plant trees on these small properties. Trees need a lot of care; I have planted a lot myself. I find that rabbits, hares and vermin around the place tackle them and the seasons also, of course, have a big effect on them.

We must encourage these people to care for their properties. They are living on the spot; they want to improve the look of their property and if there is a possibility of commercial advantage we should encourage this too. That is why I raise specifically this tax issue. The owner of the farmlet might be a person who works in town; he might be a retired person; he might be a pensioner. But the fact is that that land is there and we want to see some use made of it which is of benefit to Australia.

I wish to speak not only of growing trees but also of growing vegetables. Not enough people today are growing their own vegetables and fruit in their own backyards and I think that this is a great shame. Perhaps we are too lazy. I have a little plot myself and I like to see my beans, lettuce and potatoes growing. Why not utilise a 10-, 20-, 30- or 40-acre piece of land? Even if a person has only an acre, he or she should be encouraged to develop a small amount of that, to cultivate the land and sell the product in the market. Vegetables and fruit today are pretty expensive. That opportunity is there. That is why I wanted to raise the matter today in the House, to draw attention to a matter that is very important for Australia.

As I said earlier, although many people have left the industry, principally for family and economic reasons, we have, coming up behind them, a multitude of smaller property owners. Some of us worry about them because we feel they regard their farmlets as `only a hobby'. Some people come from the metropolitan area, find that they have not got the health or the funds to develop the property and they sell again. We should encourage a certain number of these to recognise the potential of that small amount of land, that they can farm it for their own interests which will, I am sure, keep them in better health. Then, perhaps, they may be able to produce commodities which others can buy. We will have to look very closely at the situation with a view to giving them some encouragement which will then benefit our nation as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is only the second time in seven years that I have participated in a grievance debate. I do so because of my concern about the Liberal Party's action plan. The part of the action plan that I want to discuss is the proposal to scrap the capital gains tax. I believe that the Labor movement throughout Australia should be outraged by this proposal because workers have to pay tax on all of their income; yet the Liberal Party's proposal is that those people who make a capital gain and can get around the loose taxation laws that will replace the capital gains tax, will pay no tax on that income. It is a step backward-back at least five years into the sort of situation we had before where people could shuffle paper and arrange their affairs in such a way that they paid no tax at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose what is really galling about this is Mr Elliott's-and I will only refer to Mr Elliott once-statement that the action plan was `taking money off the bludgers and giving it to the workers'. In this case, the removal of a capital gains tax, exactly the reverse would be true. The Liberal Party proposes to take money off the workers and give it back to the bludgers, the tax bludgers who are always in the system.
I would like to refer to a couple of statements made in the press and elaborate somewhat on them: What is in a name? `McCrann on Sunday' in the Sunday Herald said:
. . . the Libs have called it a speculative gains tax.

I can only guess they chose the title because there would be considerable speculation as to whether anyone in Australia would be dumb enough to ever pay it. As well, we could all start `speculating' on how much income tax it enabled people to avoid.
I will touch on that a little later because people can avoid it and the sums are quite staggering. Ken Davidson in the Age asked, `Who will get the windfall profits from this?'. He went on:
If the coalition wins the next election, the capital gains liability on asset appreciation between 1985 and now will be retrospectively abolished and the windfall of $450 million-
those are the Liberal Party's figures-

in the first year will go virtually exclusively into the pockets of the richest members of society who have been notorious in escaping from wage restraint, have benefited greatly from the property and share boom and have received the biggest marginal tax rate cuts from what used to be laughingly called, the Hawke Socialist Government.

The abolition of the capital gains tax would once more open up the tax avoidance industry. Creative accountants and lawyers will market schemes to the rich to turn taxable income into non-taxable capital gains.
In my State of Western Australia we know all about that with the bottom of the harbour schemes that flourished during the previous Liberal Government.

I spoke before about who will benefit. There is just one statistic that will show who does benefit from this action plan. In the 1987-88 financial year, the take from capital gains tax for those people earning $50,000 and over-not the poorest people, but those in the top income bracket-was $78.5m. A total of 9,963 individuals collectively paid $78.5m in capital gains tax. On average, that works out at $7,900 per annum for each individual, or $150 a week. So the abolition of the capital gains tax really means a cut in tax of $150 a week for those people earning $50,000 and over who are subject to the tax. One does not have to be Einstein to know that they are the richest people in society. They are the people who will benefit from the action plan. While the Liberals might throw a few crumbs to the middle income earners, overwhelmingly it is people on high incomes who will gain from the abolition of the capital gains tax-and that is only for the 1987-88 financial year. What we are really seeing is a dramatic build-up because over time it will escalate quite rapidly as more and more assets get caught up in the capital gains tax net. To do away with it and retrospectively take the situation back to 1985 is, in my view at least, criminal in the extreme.
Daryl Dixon, writing in the Sydney Morning Herald, points out, quite rightly, that the rich will not only get the benefit once, but they will actually get it twice. He goes on to say:
Apart from the ill-considered capital gains tax proposal (estimated to cost some $500 million annually), the Opposition has not exposed itself to obvious criticism.

If one looks at the action plan in detail, one sees that perception meter politics has taken over. One does not have to be an Einstein to know that putting the boot into the disabled and the poorest members of society-Aboriginal people, the long-term unemployed and recently arrived migrants-gets some votes in some parts of Australia. That is what the Liberal Party is counting on. As the Canberra Times headline said, `Appeal to greed by Coalition'. It really is. Putting the boot into those sorts of people will always get a few votes. Daryl Dixon, of the Sydney Morning Herald, said:
The capital gains tax proposal will involve a much higher cost than that revealed by the Opposition and opens avoidance opportunities.
I have touched on that. He went on:
The Opposition proposes to replace the present capital gains tax by a speculative gains tax, which exempts all gains on assets owned for longer than five years.
He then made this point:

The proposal will open negative gearing opportunities for taxpayers owning assets for five years or longer. Such investors will be able to get tax deductions for investing to obtain tax-free capital gains, a clearly inequitable situation.

Quite right. On the way through one is getting a tax deduction in buying the asset; when one sells the asset one gets it tax free again. Any money one takes out to buy the asset is tax deductable, and so is the asset when one finally gets rid of it.

It seems to me that the Labor movement must act. What I propose to do today is this: I am organising a drive across Australia for signatures on a petition to keep the capital gains tax. I believe that this is one area where this Government can be clearly seen to be a government that cares about the average family, those who are never touched by the capital gains tax. The capital gains tax is paid by 0.8 per cent of the taxpaying public-less than one per cent. Put another way, 99.2 per cent of people never pay it. I believe that with odds like that on our side we can mount a substantial case against the Liberal Party's proposal on the capital gains tax. I will be circulating the petition, not only to back bench members of this Government, but also to back bench members across Australia and those in the Labor movement. What the Liberal Party has not realised is that there is no great push in the Australian community to get rid of the capital gains tax. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) quite rightly referred to this in Question Time earlier in the week. People out there are not calling on us to get rid of the capital gains tax. The Australian Financial Review, quite rightly, says:

In Australia, whatever the outcry, particularly from rural areas, people have come to accept the Government's existing capital gains tax. If the Opposition had not chosen to make it one, it would not have been a political issue.

By putting it on the agenda, the Opposition has created a political issue by proposing a weak and philosophically unconvincing proposition. Its policy response, instead of showing some fiscal spine, lacks philosophic coherence and will harm revenue.

Amen to that! Through the petition on capital gains tax that I am organising and circulating throughout Australia, the Labor Party can mount a massive campaign against this proposal by the Liberal Party to take from the workers and give to the tax bludgers, to bring back the bad old days of tax avoidance and to bring back the sort of paper shuffling bottom of the harbour schemes that we saw not so many years ago under the Liberal Government.

I believe that when we present these petitions to the Parliament, we will have collected hundreds of thousands of signatures from people across Australia. This will enable us, as members of parliament, to make sure that the Australian population knows just what will happen if the Liberal Party were ever to sit on this side of the House again and implement a silly proposal to get rid of the capital gains tax. We will wipe the floor with the Opposition on this one. It just shows how sophisticated the Australian people have become in just eight short years, because the Liberals used to scare them with the spectre of a capital gains tax, but not now. That tax has now been in place for four years and the people out there know what it is all about. The Opposition will not get away with this again; it has made a major slip on this one. I believe that if the petition I am organising is as successful as we can make it, then Opposition members will have egg all over their faces and in the end they will have to back down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the voice of fear from the Labor Party which sees electoral disaster looming. I want to address a question which arises in the pre-election crisis that that Party is going through-that is, the bail-out of Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd by this Government. Some $36m of taxpayers' funds are being committed in this pre-election period to bail out a wholly-owned subsidiary of a United States corporation. The questions that arise are: What is the deal? What is the Government's economic track record? How does it relate to this deal? What about the position of ordinary people under this Government?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at the deal with Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, which is the second largest manufacturing exporter from Australia. That tells one a great deal about the state of Australia's manufacturing industry-the fact that, after seven years of this Government, the second largest manufacturing exporter is a foreign-owned corporation. That corporation is going through a rationalisation process, As part of that rationalisation process, Kodak intends to close plants in different parts of the world and Australia has been selected as one of those to be closed. There are no prizes for guessing the reason. The reason is, of course, that Australia is not regarded as a good place in which to invest.

We are not talking about the subsidiary of a small company. Let us have a look at the track record of the US parent company, Eastman Kodak over the last five years. Between 1984 and 1988, there was a 15.2 per cent sales growth on average. What were the sales? Sales for the last financial year were just over $US17 billion. In this same period there was a 12.8 per cent growth in net income-that is, after taxes. Its pre-tax income for 1988 was $US2.236 billion, and its post-tax income was $US1.397 billion. This is the owner of the subsidiary that we intend to bail out. Its pre-tax income for 1988 was greater than this Federal Government's forecasted spending on housing and community amenities, culture and recreation, transport and communications, law and order and public safety, foreign aid or general scientific research. In 1988 Eastman Kodak paid $US5.1 billion for an acquisition. This company should be able to look after itself. Certainly, its subsidiary did not need the hand of the Australian taxpayer to reach out and help it. But it is said that Kodak has fallen upon hard times; its recent figures have been bad, so the decision has been made to rationalise.

Let us look at the Australian subsidiary, which has been here for a long time. According to the Australian Financial Review of 30 April 1984, an investment in plant and machinery in previous years has paid off. It noted that:
Profits before tax for the 14-month period to December 31 of $32.8 million are double the previous 12 months' earnings . . .

Kodak says that in 1985-86 another $100m was provided by the parent company as an investment in the Australian subsidiary to fund export expansion, capital investments and working capital needs. Why close it down? The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has praised Kodak. He said in a statement on 30 October 1989:
We had to recognise that we were at a major turning point. Either Kodak's successful Australian manufacturing operation be closed or it could become a major on-going export earner.

He also said that the $36m that we are to provide in bounty payments `will be invested by Kodak in further improving the competitiveness of what is already a world class operation'. We should note those words, `successful Australian manufacturing operation' and `competitiveness of . . . a world class operation'. Why has this competitive, world class operation been closed down? Let us look at some of the answers.

The Coburg plant, which is the headquarters of the Australian operation, has 18 unions and 18 awards. According to the corporate affairs manager, who was reported in an article in the Australian Financial Review of 22 September this year:

The thing that makes the difference from country to country is the costs from the factory gate, infrastructure, freight and how much support can be given to location including export support . . . That is where Australia is presently disadvantaged.

We should note the opening words, `the costs from the factory gate'. Let us now look at a Kodak issues paper, which tells us about Kodak's situation and why it needs help. One of the things said in it is this:
At alternative sites, Kodak's manufacturing exporters enjoy benefits not available in Australia such as special economic zone, tax advantages, freight subsidies and better work practices.
To cap things off, the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) has looked at Kodak. Its report is referred to in the article in the Australian Financial Review to which I referred, and this is said of it:
The BIE found the Australian plant had the highest wastage figures as a proportion of input, while Brazil had the lowest . . .

The cost of labour also differed significantly. Australia had both the shortest working week and the lowest number of standard working days-the number of working days before overtime was paid. Australia had 206 working days, following by Britain with 210, Canada 233 and Brazil 235.
Brazil also had the lowest rate of absenteeism with 2 per cent compared to Canada and Australia at around 4 per cent.

Those are the answers, the reasons. Kodak has gone to the Government, knowing that the Government is in political difficulties and an election is coming up in a few months, and has said, `Give us the money or we will close down the plant and reveal the shambles of your economic and industrial policies and what a shambles and a disastrous state the country is in'. We all know that is what has happened. It did not say, `We have to consider this on a rational basis and we would like some help'. It knew it had the Government over the barrel.

When we hear a subsidiary of a foreign company speaking about work practices and costs at the gate, we know it is saying, `This country, in which we have invested for many years, is uncompetitive and cannot compete with other countries'. That is a verdict on us. It is saying, `Liquidate and perhaps we can screw some money out of the Australian taxpayer'. This company certainly screwed some money out of the Australian taxpayer-$36m.

I wonder how my electorate would like to see that money spent. I wonder how that reflects the concerns in my electorate-not at all. People in my electorate and every electorate around this country are concerned about interest rates on homes and businesses. What has this Government done? It has jacked them through the roof. People want a chance to get ahead. The Government has given them no chance to get ahead at all, given inflation and interest rates of 22, 23, 24 or 25 per cent. Those are the rates people in small businesses are paying for overdrafts. People want a real economic future for their kids. Kodak tells us there is no economic future for Australia so long as the country is run by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, run by a crowd that has learnt nothing and forgotten everything.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the more interesting things about being a member of parliament is to discover the hidden talents of fellow members. The other night I had the great pleasure to see an article about the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt), in his role as an actor, starring in a play in South Australia with the wife of the Premier of South Australia, Mr Bannon.
—Is he a thespian?

—He may be. I am not quite sure what that means, but I am sure that the honourable member for Adelaide knows what it means. Another talent that was revealed earlier in the week was that of the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), the shadow Treasurer. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) pointed out that the honourable member for Wentworth had a great talent for fantasy, being creative and dreaming of other worlds which are far nicer and better than the one in which we mere mortals have to reside. The Treasurer referred to an extract from an interview that the honourable member for Wentworth gave, where he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . because we are moving across the board into my different sort of world, and I am asking you to accept the fact that there is a different world apart from the one that you think about and live in all day.

The Treasurer referred to a rather nice song by Sam Cooke, called What a Wonderful World. Of course, the member for Wentworth and I-this may not be well known to my colleagues-were both elected at the election in July 1977 and we attended together the seminar for new members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nineteen seventy-seven or 1987?

—My apologies-1987. I know that he is a very creative fellow, and he has written a song about the wonderful world that he would like to see, but he is a little too modest to make it public; so I will overcome the problem. The lyrics are set to the tune of What a Wonderful World. I will spare the House by not singing it, but I will recite the lyrics.
—Order! The Chair would remind the honourable member that singing is not part of the normal process of the House.
—I would not wish to offend the Chair on these matters, and I realise that it would be an offence. The lyrics go something like this:

SPEECH.PARA: Don't know much about tax policy
Don't care much about child poverty
Don't want Paul to call me a yuppie sook
Don't remember the economics I took
But I do know how to bribe you
And I know that if you're fooled by me too
What a wonderful world this would be
Don't know much about productivity
Don't know much health policy
Don't like much about this wages accord
Don't know what capital gains tax is for
But I do know if wage growth don't stall
Then interest rates and inflation won't fall
What a wonderful world this would be.
I try to be an `A' student
But I'm not proving to be
Cause maybe if I was an `A' student, Australia
I could win your vote for me.
Don't care much about the working bloke
I don't care if I send him broke
Don't know nothin' 'bout no rise and fall
Don't know nothin' 'bout nothin' at all
Voters it's you I've been thinkin' of
And if I could only win your love
What a wonderful world this would be.

That is the wonderful world that the honourable member for Wentworth would bequeath to Australia. The honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who is holding up a piece of paper on which is written `3 out of 10', is being very cruel.

The world of the honourable member for Wentworth is based on the quaint notion that, despite 89 years of industrial history in this country, despite the presence of very strong trade unions in various sectors of the economy and despite the fact that we are enjoying record employment growth and large periods of demand, somehow we could have a system of enterprise wage bargaining which would result in wages falling, not rising. We would not have the situation where metal workers or building workers would go to their employers and say, `The employment growth is strong and there is a shortage of skills, so we expect, in return for those shortages, to have our wages increased'. That would not happen; what would happen is that the Builders Labourers Federation and the Building Workers Industrial Union and their respective employers on individual job sites would agree that the wages should be linked to gains in productivity, and that would put a good clamp on the level of wage increases. When that magically happens, inflation will fall and the floor under interest rates also will fall.

This is the magical, wonderful fantasy world that the Opposition and the honourable member for Wentworth want Australia to believe in. It may be a wonderful world or a perfect world, but it is not the real world. The real world is where trade unions play a legitimate part in negotiating positions for their members and, where they are in a strong industrial position, they can extract-and have extracted in the past-large wage increases.

That only has to be examined against the recent past in 1980-81 and 1974, when we had a wages free-for-all and collective bargaining. The centralised wage system was ignored and abandoned for the idea of collective bargaining and face to face negotiations at the work face, without any overriding central system to control it. Did wages simply go up in terms of productivity? Did wages magically trend down, so that inflation and interest rates fell? Unfortunately for the honourable member for Wentworth and for those who have to live in the real world, such as the Government, the Treasurer and my colleagues, that did not happen. We had a wages explosion, and interest rates and inflation soared.

If we are serious about our economic direction and grappling with our very real problems, we must face up to the realities; not the fantasies and hopefulness of magical, marvellous different sorts of worlds in which the honourable member for Wentworth would like us to believe.

We find ourselves in the real world of industrial relations, and we need a real practical solution to control wage pressures. That practical solution is provided by the wages and incomes accord worked out between the Government, the trade union movement and most of the employer organisations throughout Australia. The system protects those in weak industrial positions, restrains those in strong industrial positions and delivers to our nation and economy a level of wage growth below the inflation rate which is enabling productivity to increase through negotiation at the work face, and also is improving the profit shares of businesses to enable them to improve employment prospects.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Community Pharmacists-Taxation-Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme: Advertisement-Mr Ian McLachlan-One World Declaration-Ringwood Skillshare Program-Taree Quota Club: Life Education Van-Unemployment Benefit-Airline Pilots Dispute-Australian Council of Trade Unions

Mr McLachlan . . . made flying visits in a chartered aircraft to several towns in and around Flinders, including Port Lincoln.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to lend my support to a motion that was moved this morning by the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). TALKER.NAME: Mr HAWKE
TALKER.ROLE: Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, is addressing the Australian Society of Corporate Treasurers in Melbourne this afternoon. This is an engagement which was accepted by the Treasurer on 29 August. It is an invitation from a group of people which the Leader of the Opposition is very unlikely to receive, I would suggest.
