—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. On the Pru Goward program this morning, the Minister said that there was some evidence that people within the Government were cynically exploiting the environment for votes, and criticised the anti-development part of the Government and others who think there are votes in it. Would the Minister name those who are cynically exploiting this issue? Does he include the Prime Minister among this lobby he referred to? Is the Minister intending to resign from the Cabinet in protest at this deliberate and cynical economic irrationality which he finds not only offensive, but also contrary to the economic interests of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apparently on the back of the hand of the Leader of the National Party is, `Call for a Minister to resign'. This is absolute hypocrisy from the Leader of the National Party. This is the National Party that talks about bringing back the gallows. Part of the reason why Ahern went was the move by the National Party to bring back the gallows. The National Party's policy is: if it grows, chop it down; it it moves, shoot it. That is what it is on about. The difference between this Government and the National Party is that after decades of neglect this Government has given the country the Decade of Land Care. The National Party has never focused on the environmental issues of this country.

ANSWER.PARA: The point I have been trying to make is that nearly every area of industry under my control, in my portfolio, is under attack by various environmental movements. There is a lot of misrepresentation. I think it is a very good thing if there is a healthy debate, but someone has to balance the whole question out.

Let us look at the question of green consumerism. In Europe we face hormonal growth promotion bans on our meat. There is very little scientific fact in that at all-the European Community even said that there is no scientific fact in it-but because there is a green consumerism movement, our meat is banned. Unless someone takes a stand against some of these movements, we will lose more trade because some of the green issues will be used as trade barriers to our goods.

The problem we face all the time is that our fruit and vegetables have to be chemically free. This is the latest call. Again, the whole question of chemicals is being misrepresented. If a store has some crook apples, it puts a sign on them saying they are organically grown, doubles the price, and it has solved its problem. This is the sort of thing we have to deal with.

There are people within the Australian Labor Party, as there are people within the Liberal Party, who share those views. There is a very active green network within the Labor Party and I think it is a very good thing because there have been years of neglect in this country. Decisions were taken in the interests of the `develop at all costs' crowd which was most represented by the National Party. There is only one banana republic in this country and that is Queensland, where the developers were on the roll for 32 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Community Services and Health been drawn to reports that hospital charges in New South Wales are to be reduced? Can he inform honourable members of the implications of this decision for privately insured people in both New South Wales and Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the New South Wales Government has backed down on its decision to force private patients in public hospitals to pay a $10 a day out-of-pocket surcharge. I welcome this as a victory for the privately insured and for commonsense. I think we need to look at the background to this decision. Hospitals have now reduced their charges from $170 to $160 a day. That means that they have effectively abolished the surcharge that they have applied for the last four months. I am delighted that sanity has prevailed in New South Wales and that the Government has finally accepted, after four months, my original compromise proposal that the increase in public hospital private in-patient charges should be held down to $10 a day, which was roughly equivalent to the rise in the consumer price index (CPI).

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members will recall that I refused to accede to the New South Wales Government's request to approve health insurance benefits to cover the proposed new day charge of $170 from 1 July; that is, I was not prepared to endorse a 13 per cent increase in charges from $150 to $170 a day, almost twice the rise in the CPI, particularly as this was the second increase of that magnitude. Hospitals in New South Wales have had a 31 per cent increase in 12 months. I informed the New South Wales Minister that the increase was unjustified and had the potential not only to force private insurance premiums up, but also to force people out of private health insurance. I told the New South Wales Minister that we could approve only $160 a day, in line with the CPI. Nevertheless, he went ahead and charged $170 a day and private in-patients had to pay the extra $10 out of their own pockets.

The decision was unpopular with patients. It was disapproved of by the funds and their organisation, the Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia (VHIAA). I would like to thank both the funds and the VHIAA for making their views forcefully known both to the New South Wales Government and to private patients. It is a pity that the Federal Opposition, which prances around here pretending to be interested in the privately insured, never made a single statement supportive of the Government's stand. Nevertheless, the New South Wales Minister has admitted that he was wrong and that my prediction was accurate; that is, that if he went on with this policy it would simply force privately insured patients to opt to be public patients in the public hospitals. Of course, like many people forced to admit the error of their ways, the Minister scuttles out casting excuses and claims that the Commonwealth had cut funding to the New South Wales hospitals. That was his excuse for putting on the charge. That is utter rubbish.

Under the new Medicare funding arrangements this year New South Wales hospitals received $1,200m from the Commonwealth-an increase of 8.7 per cent in front of the rate of inflation. As the honourable member for Forde knows, while sanity prevails in New South Wales, the Queensland Government, which just simply copied the New South Wales procedure and raised its charges to private in-patients in public hospitals to $170 a day-a rise of 30 per cent in 11 months-is continuing to force patients to pay a $10 out-of-pocket surcharge. The Queensland hospitals are experiencing the same difficulties as the New South Wales hospitals as a result of this policy-indeed, the issue was discussed in the Queensland Cabinet this week-but unlike New South Wales the Queensland Cabinet has stuck with a policy which is absurd in its own interests and in the interests of private patients. I am confident that that will be one further reason why the people of Queensland will reject the Queensland National Party Government at the coming election.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. What steps is he taking to resolve the open conflict between the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say it comes as more than passing strange for the Leader of the Opposition to be asking me what I am doing about reported divisions on my side of the House. When I have a newspaper headline like this one--
—Order! I remind honourable members on both sides of the House that it is considered to be disorderly to read newspapers in the House.

—I was not reading it, Mr Speaker. When I have a situation where a senior Minister of my Government, whom I have been forced to return to the front bench, gets up and tells the people of Australia that there is no trust between Andrew Peacock and John Howard, then I might have something to worry about. But I do not have that situation.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question directly at issue let me say this: it is no secret that, on some of the issues that have been considered by the Cabinet that concern the environment, there are differences of emphasis not only between Mr Kerin and Senator Richardson but between other Ministers. Every Minister supports the decisions that have been taken by the Cabinet--

TALK.START.PARA: —Except Kerin.
—Including the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—It is very wordy evidence.
—Order! If the Leader of the Opposition continues to interject I will deal with him. The House has a right to hear the answer in silence.

—Not only in my Party, but throughout the country and in the Western countries generally, on this issue of the environment and development there are perfectly legitimate differences of emphasis. There are those who, in regard to a particular issue, would see that the emphasis should come down in terms of a particular development, while others would say that environmental considerations should outweigh the particular developmental considerations on that issue. This is not something of which we should be afraid or about which we should be surprised. Indeed, it is the very essence of sensible government, as indeed it is the essence of sensible debate in a democracy. Where people rigorously hold particular emphases they should express them. And so it is in my Cabinet. When an issue like, for instance, the development of Coronation Hill was before the Cabinet there were differences of emphasis as to what the proper approach should be. But, intelligently, we allowed debate and discussion on that issue, a decision was taken and every Minister of the Government supports the decisions that have been taken.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to the very significant decline in the number of unemployment beneficiaries-down from 635,000 in 1983 to 363,000 now-and to the equally significant decline in the number of people unemployed for nine months or more, which is down from 257,000 in 1984 to 159,000 now. I ask the Minister: What do these numbers indicate about the Government's approach in this area? Could the Minister explain the deficiencies of alternative approaches?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Bendigo for his question, knowing his concern about the issue of unemployment, particularly the issue of long term unemployment as it affects rural and provincial areas. The numbers mentioned by the honourable member indicate that integrated income support and labour market programs get people back to work. The numbers also indicate the results of rebuilding the integrity of the social security system and the need to continue with policies that are demonstrably working, driving down levels of dependency and exclusion.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a simple fact that should not be forgotten: there are now 100,000 fewer people on unemployment benefit for more than nine months compared to four years ago. One alternative approach suggested by the Opposition is to remove people from unemployment benefit after nine months and to leave them with nothing, or special benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or a job.
—There is nothing about that in Opposition policy.
—That would not even enter your mind.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—There are a number of questions or deficiencies involved in the Opposition's approach.
—Order! The honourable member for Canning!

—Firstly, what criteria will apply to special benefit? The Leader of the Opposition says, `Exactly the same criteria as now'. But the honourable member for Wentworth, after questioning, says, `Whatever criteria are needed to effect the saving--
—Why do they call you Lee Majors.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo. If the honourable member for Mayo interjects again I will name him. The House will come to order.

—We are talking about people who the Leader of the Opposition suggested would need to be impoverished to be eligible for special benefit. I ask: What would the honourable member for Wentworth do if the Administrative Appeals Tribunal said that it was illegal to administer special benefit in the way he suggests-that is, illegal simply to make the amount of money fit the number of people one wants to pay-and started exercising its legal powers to grant benefits to people who the honourable member says should not get them? Remember that the Leader of the Opposition has made it perfectly clear that the criteria will not change. But what the honourable member for Wentworth says is, `If, under the criteria, we are spending too much money, we will make the money fit the number of people'.

ANSWER.PARA: Thirdly, I ask a question in relation to people who qualify for special benefit. It is a serious question and one that goes to the interjection of the Leader of the Opposition. Have the people to be demoted, if you like, to special benefit by the honourable member for Wentworth been classified as people no longer of interest to the labour market? For example, would it be mandatory-as it is under this Government-to register with the Commonwealth Employment Service for someone transferred to special benefit? Would it be mandatory actively to seek work each fortnight, as it is for someone on unemployment benefit but certainly not for someone on special benefit? Would it be mandatory personally to lodge an application to have unemployment benefit continue each fortnight-again, as it is under our administration? Would the benefit be cancelled if a person moved to a low employment area? Or would all those current controls on unemployment benefit be dropped, or not relevant, as currently they are not relevant to the criteria with respect to special benefit?

Fourthly, what would happen to the Newstart strategy described last week by the honourable member for Bradfield as `spectacularly successful'? Would the employment entry payment be abolished? Fourteen thousand people have taken up the employment entry payment so far this year. Would it be abolished? Would the joint Social Security-Commonwealth Employment Service interviews be abolished? Would the provisions for long term unemployed people to receive benefit while undertaking approved training or voluntary work be abolished? In other words, would the links between this system of benefit and the possibility of re-entry to the labour market be smashed and broken, and those people sunk in the sink of the poverty trap of special benefit?

It is extraordinary that this Opposition should put a proposition to this Parliament with respect to unemployment benefit regarding those people who have been unemployed for more than nine months as the centrepiece of its savings strategy, supposedly to assist families, and not ask itself quite fundamental questions-questions, for example, about individual people.

We on this side of the House are going to do what needs to be done, that is, we are going to ask questions, not in the abstract; we are going to ask questions about individual people. We will go to electorates in which there will be, for example, a 44-year-old widow whose children have just finished school, and who has not had a job since she was married 25 years ago, and we are going to say, `Does she get special benefit?'. Is that all the Opposition can offer-special benefit? The Leader of the Opposition can laugh, but I do not laugh about the unemployed and I do not laugh about the poor. I ask the members of the National Party, those who still have some lingering compassion, about the options for the 40-year-old ex-farmhand who lives in a small town and whose back can no longer handle heavy work. Is he to be written off? Is he to go into the sink, into the scrapheap?

Essentially, the Opposition argues that $1,145m can be taken out of social security and transferred to some of the wealthiest people in the community. The Opposition asks this Parliament to believe that an error of something of the order of half a billion dollars in the estimate of those savings is to be disregarded. The Opposition asks us to believe that somehow there is some fairness and equity in what it proposes. More importantly-and I end on this point-the Opposition asks us and those who observe to believe the incredible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting.

—I well remember the Leader of the Opposition from the Liberal Club when I was attending university. It is all very well for one to succeed socially, but in terms of social policy there are hundreds of thousands of people--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Menzies.

—who have suffered from a massive recession, and it requires a little more than social skills and, I would say to the honourable member for Wentworth, it requires a little more than analytical skills that cannot square up a saving with the Department of Finance before the money is spent on his mate.
—Mr Speaker, my question is to the Prime Minister--
—Order! I have not yet given the honourable member for Wentworth the call. The honourable member for Wentworth.

—Order! If members on my left continue to interject so that the Chair, the House or the Minister cannot hear the question, I will not call the questioner until the House comes to order. The honourable member for Wentworth.

—My question is to the Prime Minister, in view of the answer to the previous question. I refer the Prime Minister to a statement issued today by Australian Workers Union General Secretary Errol Hodder that the Minister for Social Security was right in wanting to repeat the $5.8 billion tax and family package next year. Mr Hodder argues that there is a need to respond positively to the coalition's recently announced Economic Action Plan because, according to Mr Hodder, `there are many aspects of the policy which will appeal to workers and their families'. Will the Prime Minister inform the House what formal or informal discussions he or his Ministers have had with the trade union movement in view of Mr Kelty's reported remarks that it already had been agreed that there would be a wage-tax trade-off next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as the Government is concerned, the position is quite clear. If one looks at the way in which the formulation of economic policy has been followed in the period since we have been in government, one will see that a centrepiece of the formulation and the execution of that policy has been the very sensible concept of having detailed discussions with the trade union movement in this country. That has enabled an outcome of which this country is entitled collectively to be proud. I remind the honourable gentleman who asked the question just what has come out of this process in the past. As a result of giving ourselves an arm of policy which in government members opposite completely eschewed, that is, a wages policy, we have been able, firstly, to turn around the most massive recession in the history of this country-a recession we inherited from members opposite.

—It is no good members opposite ahing and umming and hawing and carrying on and making unintelligent noises. The answer is directly relevant to the question that I have been asked. Because members opposite did not have a wages policy, they gave this country simultaneous double digit unemployment and double digit inflation-a unique achievement never before experienced in this country. We promised this country that we would move away from that negative growth situation that members opposite gave us-simultaneous double digit unemployment and inflation-and that we would do it on the basis of an accord with the trade union movement whereby we would say to it that it made a great deal of sense that, rather than making its claims on employers for excessive money wage increases, it should exercise considerable restraint in its money wage claims and, in return for that restraint, the Government would undertake expenditures in the area of the social wage.

ANSWER.PARA: So that the shadow Treasurer can understand just what this has meant, I ask him to look at the graph on page 235 of this year's Budget statement. What I am about to say is directly relevant to the question that has been asked in respect of how we will conduct the economic policy of this country next year. If one looks at that graph one will see what has happened as a result of the discussions with the trade union movement. Whereas in the past economic growth as measured by the overtime rate was going up with wages following it and then the country moving straight into recession, under this Government the growth has gone right up in record terms and wages have remained flat. That has happened because at the appropriate time in the formulation of economic policy we sat down with the trade union movement and said that there was an alternative to excessive money wage increases. That approach has been spectacularly successful in getting the country out of the worst recession in 50 years.

I remind the House that the average annual rate of economic growth has been twice as high under this Government as was the case under the previous Government, and the rate of employment creation has been five times faster under this Government than it was under the previous Government. That has not been achieved by accident; it has been achieved by making the decision at the appropriate point to talk with the trade union movement about what the wages policy will be for the next 12 months and what the relationship of that wages policy will be to what happens in the areas of taxes and social wages. As we have been spectacularly successful in the past in having these discussions and producing these economic results, at the appropriate time next year we will again have similar discussions with the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has the Minister seen reports that reform on coastal shipping has stalled? Will the Minister advise the House what progress is being achieved in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the honourable member, I point out that I have seen such statements, particularly from the Opposition and most notably in its so-called Economic Action Plan, where it is stated that there has been a stalling of reform on coastal shipping. Such statements are totally off beam. The fact is that coastal shipping is going through a program of substantial structural change and over the next three years there will be the most wide-ranging reform of the coastal shipping industry in its history. It will result in the crew sizes of Australian ships being at Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development levels by the middle of 1992.

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to the program of reform that we have implemented. The brief has been, firstly, to give effect to the Crawford report, which provided for some reduction in crew numbers. We then established the Maritime Industry Development Committee, which came up with a further reform package to modernise the industry, and particularly to reduce further crews on new ships. We then established the ship reform task force, which reported to the Government earlier this year. It proposed further reforms not just to reduce further crew sizes on new ships but for recrewing existing ships.

I am pleased to say that I can now advise the House that, under the auspices of the Shipping Industry Reform Authority, the industry parties have now agreed on the recrewing program to apply over the next three years. For pre-Crawford ships-that is, ships that came in before the Crawford reforms-there will be an average reduction of four in crew size from the end of this year and a further reduction of two by the middle of 1992. For ships which came in under the Crawford program, there will be an average reduction of six in the next three years, most of which will occur in the next 12 to 18 months. Altogether, the reforms will reduce crew numbers in Australia by 640, and half of that number will be from the end of this year. This means that in the Australian fleet the average size of a crew, which was 33 when we came into office, will fall to 25 by the end of this year and is well on track to be 21 by the middle of 1992 as a result of the introduction of lower crewed ships and the conclusion of the recrewing program. In relation to the tug industry, which was not affected by the shipping reform task force, we now--

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought members of the Opposition were interested in coastal shipping. They are always saying that we are not doing anything about it. Now when I tell them what we are doing they do not want to listen. They cannot take it. I have a report from the towage industry review committee. It recommends reducing the maximum crew size in a tug involved in harbour work to five and for those on open sea operations to nine by the end of this year. That will reduce crew numbers on tugs by 145, or 13 per cent, by the end of next month. There will be a further reduction in the maximum crew sizes to four by the end of 1992, reducing crew numbers by a further 190, which will bring about overall reductions over the three-year period of 335, or 29 per cent, and reduce the total towage industry costs by 15 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: It is quite clear that, far from progress being stalled in relation to coastal shipping, or the shipping industry in its broader sense-because this relates not just to coastal shipping but to our overseas ships as well-we are seeing a dramatic program of reform. As distinct from the previous Government, this Government has taken a number of steps to bring about substantial reform. As a result, by the middle of 1992 we will see Australian ships operating with crews at the same level as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average, which is something that the previous Government could never have hoped to achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement on tourism promotion and relief moneys in Question Time yesterday, following his pronouncement that the pilots dispute had ended. Will the Prime Minister confirm industry reports today that the $30m promised by the Government will be provided to a new industry group headed by the honourable member for Parramatta with Sir Peter Abeles and others who will be responsible for the tourism rehabilitation campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is quite clear. In the early stages of the airline industry problems we had a meeting with representatives of the tourism industry, which at that stage was generally through the auspices of the Australian Travel Industry Association. In recent weeks there has been a move in which the honourable member for Parramatta has been associated which has led to the establishment of an industry group. I am sorry that I do not have the list here of those who are involved.
—Mr Cowley.

—Mr Cowley is certainly involved, so is Mr Haddad. Is it significant that Mr Haddad is involved? He has an association with a casino. Is there something sinister about that? This is the most representative body of people that has ever been brought together representing the tourism industry in this country.

—I warn the Leader of the Opposition. I have asked the Leader of the Opposition to cease interjecting on three occasions during Question Time today and I ask him to ensure that he does cease interjecting.

—The body that has been brought together is without any question the most representative body representing the tourism industry in the history of this country. That can be tested very simply. I suggest that those who are interested should look at the list of people who are involved in this group that has come together. Let them examine--
—Order! The honourable member for Fadden will resume his seat.

—The opportunity is there for the Opposition to examine that list. First, if members of the Opposition wish to challenge either the integrity or the relevance of any individual or group that is represented, let them do so. Secondly, I challenge them to show me any other time in the history of this country when such a representative group of the tourism industry has ever been brought together. If in regard to those two challenges they can then bring into question or into doubt either the integrity or the representative nature of that body, then that is something that I would need to deal with. I am satisfied that members of the Opposition will fail on both challenges. There is no question about the integrity or representativeness of the people in that group, and I have no doubt that the Opposition will not be able to point to any other group ever assembled that is more representative of the tourist industry. That is point one.

ANSWER.PARA: We welcome the establishment of that body and as a government we will be more than happy to receive representations from them. When we draw up the considerable package of assistance to the tourism industry that the Government will make available, I have no doubt that the Government and the tourism industry will be singularly assisted by the emergence of this group.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker. I want respectfully to ask the Prime Minister to provide a list of those people to the Parliament. Or should we ring Ansett?
—There is no point of order. If the honourable member for Fadden uses that mechanism to make a point again, I will name him.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. What restructuring of family assistance has there been under this Government? Can the Minister inform the House of what support exists for the maintenance of adequate assistance to low and middle income families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question.
—Money speaks all languages, even Hungarian.
—If the honourable member for Menzies interjects once more, I will name him.

—The system of family payments which the Government inherited from the conservatives was one that was poorly targeted. It was set without reference to the cost of caring for children, particularly for low income families. It was certainly not indexed. The result was that the payments declined over time. Arising from the very detailed and rigorous analysis of the Social Security Review, the Government has been restructuring family assistance arrangements. We have introduced the family allowance supplement. In each year that we have been in government we have raised the additional pension and benefit rates for children, substantially increased family allowance rates, met standards of adequacy central to our fight against child poverty and introduced for the first time ever the indexation of family payments, including the family allowance.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has given a great deal of thought to issues relating to family assistance and has placed the issue of child poverty squarely on the political agenda. That policy had generally been supported by the Opposition. It is particularly difficult to get much sense of Opposition policy when there are so few questions directed to these matters. The family allowance supplement, the honourable member for Bradfield said recently, provides significant support for Australian families. He also said that the coalition, when in government, would continue to provide indexation for those payments. Senator Chaney, in an interjection the other week, confirmed that that indeed was the Opposition's view. However, last Friday, a spokesman for Mr Peacock was reported in the Australian Financial Review. The article stated:

. . . the Opposition would maintain the Government's programme in its first years of Government . . . However, he said `We have not, as yet, made any decision on the details of expenditure in our second and third years, including any decision not to maintain indexation on family allowances.

The previous day, Senator Chaney was saying, `There is no problem. We are right behind you'. The day before that, Mr Connolly was not only congratulating the Government but also saying that indexation was part of the Opposition's policy. Mr Peacock set the issue straight on Thursday night and his spokesman's remarks were published in the Australian Financial Review on Friday. In a real sense this is a crucial issue that needs to be addressed in terms of the policy of the Opposition. We hear a great deal of cant from the Opposition about the Government, the Government's attitude to families and what the Government has or has not done.

What the Government has proceeded to do fundamentally is to achieve reform. Reform is not only about achieving a fairer distribution of income and recognising families; it is also about sustaining those reforms. That is why I do not think it would cause any great surprise that Bishop Hollingworth of the Brotherhood of St Laurence was prompted to produce a statement last Thursday headed `Coalition economic package will divide nation'. I conclude by quoting from that statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean it is right?
—I do not know that he was speaking ex cathedra, nevertheless--
—Order! The Minister might try not to encourage the honourable member for Menzies.
—He said:

ANSWER.PARA: There is a real risk that the coalition's proposals will not only reverse the progress made in recent years to reduce child poverty, but also fail to provide lasting help for the children of middle income families . . . in the end, the extent to which individual families benefit from the tax rebates will be something of a lottery, depending on their ability to achieve wage rises which keep pace with the cost of living, the speed with which inflation erodes the child rebates, and the degree to which other costs rise.

Before the Opposition clarified its situation, Bishop Hollingworth said that it was something of a lottery and depended on inflation. The following day, the Leader of the Opposition made it clear in the Australian Financial Review that we should forget about indexation because it has no reality in Opposition policy. Incidentally, it is not only families with young children but also the aged in Australia who need to worry about the mob opposite. It has no backbone, no principle, no policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. During the Western Australian election in January of this year, the Prime Minister predicted that interest rates would fall by the end of the year. Will the Prime Minister give a similar guarantee to the people of South Australia, namely, that interest rates will fall in the next 12 months or, failing that, will not rise in the next 12 months?
—Within the last week or so I was asked a question on this matter, almost in the same form. I have nothing to add to the answer I gave then.
—I ask the Attorney-General whether there are any Commonwealth powers which prevent a non-corporate body from passing on the proceeds of any tax deduction for increased fees charged?
—This is not a dorothy dix question. I am not supposed to give judicial advice. I doubt very much what powers the Government would have over a non-corporate body.

—I refer the Minister for Housing and Aged Care to the advertisements in newspapers throughout Australia yesterday headed, `How to make the Australian Government pay for your medicine'. Is it not a fact that this advertisement is wrong? Is it not a fact that the so-called yellow book referred to in the advertisement has been superseded by the so-called white book, which contains revised and in many cases higher prices for some pharmaceuticals? Is it not a fact that, when one rings the 008 hotline and points this out, as several honourable members on this side of the House have done, a person at the other end admits this error but excuses it by saying that the Minister's office lodged the advertisement, not the Department, and that the Department is very cross about it?
—Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of all the issues in Australia today and in the areas covered by my portfolio, this is the best that the shadow Minister can come up with! The term `yellow book' is the colloquial reference to the document in which this information has been provided for many years. I do not know what is said to people who ring on the hotline. The prices for pharmaceuticals are available in both books.

ANSWER.PARA: Right throughout Australia, people are concerned about the prices that they are paying for medication, and quite rightly so. Under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, Australians have the right to receive medication at the appropriate price; that is, free for pensioners, $2.50 for concessionary card holders and up to $11 for general patients. People have a right to know the price they should be charged for medication, particularly if the item is to be included on their prescription record form, the safety net card. That has not always been the case and ordinary Australians need to have that information. To carry that information from chemist to chemist would be very difficult, considering the number of items covered by the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The hotline is provided to give people that advice. Judging by the genuine calls, people are quite happy with the advice that they are receiving.

While we are talking about the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, let me outline what the Opposition has not yet proposed in relation to its health policy. This year, the Government has provided more than $1,200m to fund the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to ensure that people get access to the medication they deserve, but nothing has been heard from the Opposition. It is afraid to release its health policy because it would diminish its very low to minimal changes in the Queensland and South Australian elections.

When the Opposition was in government millions of people were left without effective health cover and people are not prepared to allow that situation to occur again. The success of the Opposition's health policy can be gauged by the number of former Ministers and shadow Ministers littered around the back benches. It is about time that the Opposition had a health policy and, if it believed in it, stood up and brought it to the attention of the Australian population, but the Opposition is afraid to do that. As the honourable member for Tangney knows, the honourable member for Wentworth and Senator Stone are having great difficulty in supporting anything that he puts forward in a politically credible way. Because of the failure of the Opposition to evolve a health policy and the failure of the many former Ministers and shadow Ministers who litter the back bench, the people of Australia do not trust the Opposition's health policy, whereas they trust the Labor Government's health policy. They know that under this Government wealth does not determine health.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my contribution today under private members' business, I indicated that I had received correspondence from a number of sources on the issue of anti-abortion funding. I indicated inadvertently that I had received correspondence from the Catholic Women's League of Australia. In fact, I had received correspondence from the Young Women's Christian Association and from the National Women's Consultative Council.
