SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAWKE
TALKER.ROLE: Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to report to the House on my attendance at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM), held in Kuala Lumpur from 18 to 24 October.

SPEECH.PARA: En route to CHOGM, I made a brief visit to Singapore on 16 and 17 October, where I had discussions with Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew and, separately, with several other Commonwealth leaders, including Prime Minister Mulroney of Canada, President Vassiliou of Cyprus and Prime Minister Fenech-Adami of Malta.

In Kuala Lumpur, in addition to representing Australia at CHOGM, I called on Her Majesty, who formally opened the meeting. I also had separate discussions with, amongst others, Prime Minister Mahathir of Malaysia, President Kaunda of Zambia, Prime Minister Namaliu of Papua New Guinea, Prime Minister Thatcher of Great Britain, Prime Minister Palmer of New Zealand, the Rev. Dr Boesak representing the Mass Democratic Movement of South Africa, Mr Thabo Mbeki representing the African National Congress, and representatives of the Commonwealth Trade Union Council.

I table the following documents: the CHOGM Communique, issued on 24 October; the Kuala Lumpur Statement on Southern Africa, issued on 22 October; and the Langkawi Declaration on Environment, issued on 21 October.

The Kuala Lumpur CHOGM was attended by representatives of 46 countries, including 35 at head of state-government level. The meeting, most ably chaired by Dr Mahathir, was significant in a number of respects: it marked the fourtieth anniversary meeting of the modern day Commonwealth; it saw the most welcome return of Pakistan, under the leadership of democratically elected Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto; and it provided a valuable opportunity for wide-ranging and productive discussions on global political, economic and environmental issues between the leaders of one-quarter of the world's population.

Looking ahead to the l900s and beyond, the meeting agreed to establish a high level group to oversee a review of Commonwealth institutions and activities to ensure the Commonwealth's continued important and constructive role in international affairs. The group, to be chaired by Dr Mahathir, will consist of a number of heads of government, including me. A report will be submitted at the next CHOGM, to be held in Harare in 1991.

Consistent with the active and constructive foreign policies pursued by this Government since 1983, Australia played an energetic and positive role in the discussions at CHOGM and in contributing to the thrust and direction of the final outcomes. In doing so, concrete and important Australian interests were further advanced, both globally and regionally, and in areas as diverse as southern Africa and the environment.

Honourable members will note from the Communique the endorsement and encouragement given to the far-reaching changes under way in East-West relations. This is, of course, very much consistent with Australia's own approach, as evident in my discussions with Presidents Gorbachev and Bush and in my announcement on 15 October of our positive response to the current needs of Poland and Hungary. These issues will also be the subject of discussions I will be having tomorrow morning with the United States Secretary of State, James Baker, and the Secretary of Defense, Richard Cheney. In the context of their concerns about the need for continued progress in arms control and disarmament, Commonwealth heads of government welcomed the positive contribution to the elimination of chemical weapons made by the government-industry conference hosted by Australia in Canberra in September.

Other global political developments discussed included the Middle East, especially Lebanon, Cyprus, Afghanistan, Central America, Cambodia, Hong Kong and the South Pacific. Heads of government acknowledged the concerns of the people of Hong Kong and stressed the importance of Hong Kong's continued success as an international trading and financial centre. They welcomed the reaffirmation by China and Britain of their commitment to the full implementation of their joint declaration on the future of Hong Kong, the success of which is vital to the maintenance of international confidence in Hong Kong. I also had the opportunity to discuss Hong Kong with Mrs Thatcher during our separate bilateral discussion.

On Cambodia, Commonwealth leaders urged the continuation of efforts to intensify dialogue and promote negotiations to achieve a comprehensive settlement. In this context, they welcomed the various initiatives, including those of the Association of South East Asian Nations countries, to achieve that objective. Noting the continuing flow of boat people from Vietnam, heads of government welcomed the progress towards a comprehensive solution to the problem, made at the International Conference on Indochinese Refugees held in Geneva in June. Australia does, of course, support the comprehensive plan of action agreed at Geneva, including the screening of boat people to ensure that only those with a genuine claim to refugee status are resettled in third countries. For its part, Australia has accepted over 120,000 Indochinese refugees since 1975, and this financial year will take some 6,000. Certainly, this Government will continue to play its part in resettling genuine cases. In addition, the Government will continue to give strong support to the bilateral migration arrangements it has with Vietnam.

Heads of government welcomed the positive developments in New Caledonia-a subject which I have discussed directly with Prime Minister Rocard of France in recent months-and again acknowledged the importance of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.

Fiji was not the subject of formal discussion at CHOGM and its possible re-entry into the Commonwealth was not at issue, as no application was before the meeting. I was, however, able to exchange views on developments in Fiji with other South Pacific Commonwealth leaders.

Honourable members will be familiar with the vital role played by the Commonwealth in leading international action against the abhorrent practice and philosophy of apartheid. The Kuala Lumpur Statement on Southern Africa continued that process. I am pleased to inform the House that it was significantly as a result of the contribution made to this meeting by Australia that this further progress was made. I acknowledge especially the important assisting role of the Foreign Minister, Senator Gareth Evans. The task at CHOGM was to decide on the course of action which would maximise the prospect for reform in South Africa. As I said in urging a five-point program of new Commonwealth initiatives to bring pressure to bear on South Africa-it has been said in this House before-`We do not seek to bring South Africa to its knees but to bring it to the negotiating table'.

In considering the appropriate strategy, Commonwealth leaders took into account the fact that all the fundamental and repugnant elements of apartheid remain in place, such as institutional discrimination, epitomised most vividly by the Group Areas Act; and on the other hand, the more positive recent developments, especially the release from prison of eight prominent political leaders and President de Klerk's talk, however vague, of reform. With but one exception-the exception of Britain, to which I shall refer in a moment-the Commonwealth was united in its view that sanctions had begun to influence the policies of the South African regime, a fact acknowledged in South Africa itself.

Where we refer to acknowledgments from within South Africa, that is from within the Government itself and from within the most relevant institutions. I refer to statements by the Minister for Finance, Mr du Plessis, and the late Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr de Kock, both of whom did two things: Firstly, they recognised unequivocally the impact upon South Africa and the constraints on its economic development that have been involved in the imposition of sanctions; and secondly, and most importantly, in acknowledging that effect both of those gentlemen indicated their understanding that those constraints would be removed only if they got their political act together in South Africa. So that acknowledgment has come right from the centre of the Government and of the Reserve Bank.

It was against this background that the Kuala Lumpur Statement endorsed each of the five points I had proposed. The Commonwealth heads of government noted with satisfaction the strong preference for a negotiated and peaceful settlement inherent in the Harare Declaration; and endorsed, with the exception of Britain, the maintenance of existing sanctions and the tightening of financial sanctions. For instance, the statement called on all relevant banks and financial institutions to impose tougher conditions on day-to-day trade financing, specifically through reducing the maximum credit terms to 90 days. The Commonwealth heads of government endorsed, again with the exception of Britain, the establishment of a small, independent agency-the initial funding of which Australia has expressed its willingness to provide-to review and report on South Africa's international financial links; and agreed to ask appropriate international institutions, and in particular the International Monetary Fund (IMF), to examine how resources might be mobilised for South Africa upon evidence of clear and irreversible change.

I wish to give further emphasis to the positive way in which Commonwealth leaders approached this matter. There is a clear understanding that under the present leadership of the anti-apartheid movement within South Africa, including some amongst the leadership of the black trade union movement in South Africa, and including the leadership of the frontline states-it is very important that this should be understood-they are not seeking to see a resolution to the situation in South Africa which involves the driving out of white capital, white entrepreneurial expertise and all the accumulated experience that is represented by white South Africans. Indeed, there is a clearer understanding that a democratic, non-racial South Africa at the end of the apartheid period will be a much better place for all its citizens if the white people who are there now are able to stay on and make their contribution through their capital, their entrepreneurship and their experience.

The great challenge that faces the world at present is that we should take the opportunity while there is that attitude amongst the current leadership of welcoming and wanting to see stay in South Africa all that accumulated experience. If that opportunity is not taken and the sort of leadership that is now there and has that attitude is replaced by a more radical leadership that would rather see the elimination of the white presence and contribution, that would be a tragedy not merely for white South Africans but also, in the longer term, for all South Africans. So when we talk about approaching the IMF to see what sort of package of assistance would be available, that view is consistent with the view of our Government that we want to see a peaceful resolution, not a bloody ending to apartheid. We want to see a peaceful resolution of this matter and we want to see the emergence of a South Africa in which blacks and whites together will be able to cooperate economically, politically and culturally to make South Africa a country of which they can be proud and which is the more likely to contribute to an elevation of the living standards of all people. So that is the sense in which we were contemplating the approach to the International Monetary Fund to see whether some package could be formulated, the implementation of which would be contingent upon the ending of the abhorrent apartheid regime.

The Commonwealth heads of government also agreed, again with the exception of Britain, that the Committee of Foreign Ministers, the CFMSA, should continue to review the situation in southern Africa and should meet again in April of next year, by which time the new Administration in Pretoria will have had six months to demonstrate its commitments to genuine reform. I am proud to say that all Commonwealth Heads of Government at the meeting were not dismissive of the new President and saying that he was just talking empty phrases. In this respect I was personally assisted in my consideration of these issues by a lengthy discussion with my friend President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia, who has had the opportunity of meeting with President de Klerk. My friend Kaunda was generous in his assessment of the attitude of the new President. He thought he was somewhat innocent in terms of his understanding of all the implications of what was involved, but he was prepared to accept that there were signs in the new President that he understood that there was a need for reform.

In that sense, this concept of giving a period of about six months is an intelligent thing to do, to give the new leadership in South Africa an opportunity to translate into acceptable decisions and action the indications of a desire for reform. The Commonwealth heads of government also agreed that, while legislative action progressively to dismantle the legal apparatus of apartheid may take some time to put in place, it is within the executive power of the South African Government to back its words with deeds by, for instance-this does not necessitate waiting for the meeting of the South African Parliament-executive decision, by which the South African Government would be able to release all political prisoners, it would be able to lift the state of emergency, and it would be able to unban currently banned organisations, including the African National Congress.

In essence, the message from CHOGM was that normality can only return to South Africa's economic and financial relations with the rest of the world when the ugly abnormality of apartheid disappears. South Africans cannot ask for and seek normality-because it will not happen-in its economic and commercial relations with the rest of the world while it tolerates the abhorrent abnormality of apartheid.

On other matters relating to southern Africa, Commonwealth leaders identified a continuing need for assistance to the front-line states, decided to examine actively increased special assistance to Namibia and looked forward to welcoming a free Namibia into the Commonwealth.

Much has been made of the differences in Kuala Lumpur between Great Britain and the other Commonwealth members over South Africa. Let me say that at Kuala Lumpur, as at London and Vancouver, the British position was in a minority of one in the Commonwealth. That, of course, disappointed all the rest of us. What sharpened that sense of disappointment on this occasion was the fact that Britain, having initially explicitly accepted the text of the statement, and indeed, having been instrumental in having the statement accepted by other Heads of Government, then promptly issued a unilateral declaration disavowing its entire thrust. I believe that honourable members would understand that if such an approach became the norm at Commonwealth meetings, the whole institution would be undermined. It was not an acceptable course of behaviour. I expressed this view, as did Prime Minister Mulroney of Canada. In doing so, we clearly spoke on behalf of our other colleagues.
Mr Deputy Speaker, it is worth noting that Malcolm Fraser, in delivering the B'nai B'rith Oration last Sunday, said:
There should no longer be a debate about whether sanctions work or not, it is now widely accepted that they do.

I want to say to the Leader of the Opposition and honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) that the remarks I am about to make are made with full sincerity and in the hope that there can be a positive response. I would very much like to see bipartisanship on this important issue. At the moment, unfortunately, we do not have it. The Future Directions document says unequivocally, `We do not support the use of economic sanctions'. The Liberal and National foreign policy statement, issued in April this year, includes a detailed criticism of economic sanctions and states directly that a Liberal-National Government `will not impose any obstacles to investment and to business, commercial and travel links with South Africa'.

These two documents bear the unmistakable imprint of the former Leader of the Opposition and his former foreign affairs spokesman, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). From what one knows of the positions formerly espoused by their replacements, the honourable member for Kooyong and Senator Hill, such views should be unacceptable. They are certainly unacceptable not only to this Government and to the previous Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all entitled to our views.

—I know there is no hope for the honourable member for Maranoa, and I do not look for any hope for him. If the Leader of the Opposition wants to identify himself with the honourable member, that is his choice. But I have a little bit of hope for the Leader of the Opposition in this one area-not in the area of economics-and I do hope that on this issue he has the courage to express what I do believe are his points of view. If, however, he shares the honourable member's point of view, that is a tragedy not only for the Opposition but also for this country because the honourable member is an unreconstructed hopeless case.

SPEECH.PARA: Those views in Future Directions are certainly unacceptable not only to this Government and my predecessor as Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, but also to the Progressive Conservative Government of Canada, to regional neighbours such as the governments of Malaysia, Singapore, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea and India, to the other members of the Commonwealth, to the Congress of the United States and not least to the moderate forces for change within South Africa itself. So I look forward to hearing what the Leader of the Opposition will have to say on where, under his leadership, the Liberal and National parties stand on this important issue of principle, a principle which has the support of the whole of the rest of the Commonwealth except Britain but including the Conservative Government in Canada, as well as the support of Malcolm Fraser and all the countries in our region. That is what the position is, and it is a matter I hope we can get bipartisanship on.

As always, CHOGM paid close attention to international economic issues. Against the background of the Uruguay Round negotiations, which are to conclude next year, Commonwealth leaders issued a strong call for a renewed effort to capitalise on the progress made at the mid-term review in Montreal and, after that, in Geneva. It was noted that substantial and persistent protection, as in agriculture, was particularly damaging and needed to be eliminated.

On the question of regional economic cooperation, CHOGM noted the Asia-Pacific Economic Conference to be held in Canberra next week. Consistent with the aims of the initiative, which I launched in Seoul early this year, heads of government expressed the hope that regional trading efforts would promote an expansion of trade in an open and non-discriminatory multilateral trading system.
As honourable members will note from the documents tabled, issues relating to poverty alleviation, debt and financial flows, and women and structural adjustment, were also discussed in some detail.

At Dr Mahathir's initiative, the environment was a centre point of the Kuala Lumpur CHOGM. Against the background of my comprehensive statement on the environment in July, Australia welcomed the initiative and took an active role in the formulation of the Langkawi Declaration, and in discussion of environmental issues generally. The Declaration is a forward looking document which outlines in clear and precise terms many of the environmental problems facing the world today. It provides a clear-sighted program of action encompassing, amongst other things:
Support for measures to improve energy conservation and efficiency;
Promotion of the reduction and eventual phase-out of substances depleting the ozone layer;
Promotion of afforestation and sustainable forest management;
Support for activities relating to the conservation of biological diversity; and
A strengthening of national, regional and international institutions responsible for environmental protection.
I would draw the attention of honourable members to developments in three specific areas:
Australia's initiative, welcomed by other Commonwealth leaders, to develop a technical assistance program to provide training for assessing the effects of climate change on rural land productivity;

The explicit support in the CHOGM Communique for the Tarawa Declaration on Fisheries and the conclusion of an international convention to ban pelagic driftnetting from the South Pacific, as a first step towards a comprehensive ban on such fishing practices the Tarawa Declaration was, of course, an initiative taken by this Government at this year's South Pacific Forum; and

The explicit recognition in the Communique of the need for `every effort' to be made `to protect and conserve' the unique Antarctic environment, and it is relevant to add that, while Commonwealth heads of government were meeting in Kuala Lumpur, a meeting in Paris of members of the Antarctic Treaty System agreed to convene a special meeting next year to discuss proposals for protection of the Antarctic environment, including the Australian-French proposal for a comprehensive environment protection convention. I am sure all members will join with me in thanking all those who have worked so hard to achieve this significant step towards our goal. For Australia, mining in the Antarctica is simply out of the question and I reaffirm today my Government's decision not to sign the Minerals Convention.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as with other CHOGM, the meeting at Kuala Lumpur covered the full range of practical cooperative arrangements which give substance to the Commonwealth. These arrangements cover education, youth training, science and human rights. In respect of the latter, I am especially pleased to inform the House that, at the request of heads of government, a working group is to be charged with recommending possible areas for enhanced cooperation. Also, there is to be an examination of what might be done within the Commonwealth to strengthen democratic institutions. I mention this, as I know that subject is of genuine interest to honourable members on both sides of this House.

Australian sports men and women will be pleased to know that Commonwealth heads of government reaffirmed the importance attached to the Commonwealth Games. The Secretary-General has been requested to invite sports administrators, representatives of the Commonwealth Games Federation and suitably qualified government nominees, to form a working party to examine issues associated with the Games, including the desire to see all regions of the Commonwealth hosting the Games. It is intended that the report of the working party be finalised in time for the next CHOGM.
Honourable members will be aware that the Commonwealth Secretary-General, Sonny Ramphal, will retire in June next year after 15 years of dedicated service.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to Malcolm?

—If the honourable member keeps his silence for a moment, he will hear. I joined with other heads of government in paying tribute to his contribution with which, I know, many members present are familiar. The Commonwealth was fortunate in having two excellent candidates to replace Sonny Ramphal: the former Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser and Chief Emeka Anyaoku of Nigeria. The Commonwealth is, of course, one of the principal global organisations to which Australia belongs. I was, therefore, pleased to be able to give the Government's full and active support, within the framework of proper diplomatic norms, to Mr Fraser's candidacy. I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his support in that respect. Chief Anyaoku was elected in a close race. It goes without saying that Chief Anyaoku has Australia's wholehearted and unqualified support, which I made clear to him personally immediately he was chosen.

SPEECH.PARA: I made reference at the beginning of my report to my separate discussions with a number of other Commonwealth leaders. These were important in their own right and served to progress matters of common interest. My talks with Mr Lee and Dr Mahathir, for instance, covered both regional economic cooperation and Indo-China. In addition, Dr Mahathir and I discussed ways of strengthening our cooperation in the fight against the illicit drug trade.

My discussions with Prime Minister Namaliu focused on developments in Bougainville. My talks with Mr Mulroney saw significant progress in resolving the problems confronting Australian canned fruit exporters as a result of the United States-Canada free trade agreement. I am confident that, as a result of my talks with Mr Mulroney, Australian fruit growers will retain competitive access to the Canadian market.

As we enter the l990s, the Commonwealth remains a strong and relevant international organisation. The Kuala Lumpur meeting, superbly organised by the Government of Malaysia, addressed substantive issues confronting us all-political, economic and environmental. My Government has maintained an active involvement in Commonwealth affairs. My attendance at the Kuala Lumpur CHOGM was consistent with that involvement and, as is evident from my report, has enhanced Australia's position and interests. I present the following paper:
Visit by the Prime Minister to Singapore and to Malaysia for the 1989 Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting-Ministerial Statement, 2 November 1989.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.
Motion (by Mr Beazley)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition speaking for a period not exceeding 30 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PEACOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on his recent visit to Kuala Lumpur to attend the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM). It comes at an important time for the future of the Commonwealth as an effective international association and raises some serious concerns about whether this Australian Government is at all capable of pursuing policies to help bring about such a future. There are two levels at which I want to direct my comments on the Prime Minister's statement. One concerns the future prospects for the Commonwealth as an organisation; the other is the particular outcome of the Kuala Lumpur meeting and Australia's role in it.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps more so than any other Commonwealth meeting of recent times, the Kuala Lumpur meeting generated extensive criticisms in the Australian media and the community of the Commonwealth as an anachronistic, divided and ineffective organisation, reflecting more on historical coincidence in the national development of its member states than any future potential for effective common action based on shared political ideals, economic priorities or development needs. Let me make it quite clear that the Opposition unambiguously rejects such a view of the Commonwealth. It has always regarded it as an important organisation with great potential for enhancing international cooperation among developed, developing and underdeveloped countries.

The Commonwealth's geographic and cultural diversity should be sources of strength, not weakness. The Opposition remains committed to this dynamic view of the Commonwealth's future. There were aspects of the Kuala Lumpur meeting which provided some reassuring signs of the Commonwealth's continuing growth and potential. The return of Pakistan to the Commonwealth was a most welcome development. The Langkawi Declaration on Environment addresses many of the deeply felt concerns of citizens throughout the Commonwealth about the interaction between development needs and environmental protection.

I raise the point about the growing public scepticism of the Commonwealth's role not to endorse it in any way but to shed some light on its causes. It is interesting to note that the Commonwealth leaders themselves sensed something of the same need. They agreed in their Kuala Lumpur communique to a wide ranging reappraisal of future roles and structures for the Commonwealth to be completed for consideration at their next meeting in 1991. The communique called for this to:
identify possible roles which the Commonwealth might need to play, and to examine whether its institutions, including the Secretariat, are adequately equipped for the task.

This review will be an important process in which any Australian government must be closely involved. One cause of the unfortunate but growing public scepticism about the Commonwealth is that it appears to have lost something of its sense of wider purpose in international events. This is highlighted by the dominance that the issue of South Africa has assumed in recent CHOGM meetings, and the Kuala Lumpur meeting in particular. I will return later to the substance of the meeting's consideration of the South African sanctions issue. The point I want to make is that the issue of South Africa, important as it is, has assumed a disproportionate role at CHOGMs. The effect has been that other issues of very great concern to Commonwealth countries have been either neglected entirely or not accorded the attention they deserve. Issues such as the future of Hong Kong, the situation in Fiji, the fate of Indo-Chinese refugees, resource development possibilities and the implications for small developing states of changes in the global trading system were totally overshadowed at the Kuala Lumpur meeting by the South Africa issue; nor were they the only issues of wider significance for Commonwealth countries to suffer such a fate.

I am not denying the relevance of southern African issues for the Commonwealth. They are, and will continue to be, a subject of concern and, where appropriate, common action. But the Prime Minister's fixation on grand initiatives on major international political issues is likely, in the long run, to serve the interests of the Commonwealth less effectively than carefully targeted and quietly pursued programs directed at specific smaller scale problems. I am concerned that Australia should lead in the Commonwealth's reassessment of its priorities with the objective of giving greater prominence and emphasis to a range of issues in addition to South Africa in which the interests of the Commonwealth countries are also directly engaged and where there are good prospects for effective common action. Australia's involvement in the Commonwealth must avoid drifting into a one-dimensional framework. The Opposition believes that the future effectiveness and viability of the Commonwealth, to which the Opposition is fully committed, demands nothing less.

I turn to the second level at which I respond to the Prime Minister's statement-that is, the principal outcomes of the Kuala Lumpur meeting and the Prime Minister's role in it. We congratulate Chief Emeka Anyaoku of Nigeria on his election to the position of Commonwealth Secretary- General. He brings considerable expertise and special ability to his new position and we wish him well. Of course we were disappointed that Malcolm Fraser missed out. He was a most worthy candidate who ran a good race. I was pleased to be able to support his candidacy in meetings with various Commonwealth leaders, in particular with Margaret Thatcher only a few weeks ago. I join the Prime Minister in congratulating Sonny Ramphal on his tireless service as Secretary-General.

As I stated earlier, the Commonwealth meeting was dominated by the issue of South Africa and Commonwealth sanctions. In fact, it was largely overshadowed by the public dispute between Mrs Thatcher and our Prime Minister. Not being a participant at the meeting and not being privy to all the relevant information, I do not want to comment specifically on this most unfortunate distraction other than to say how regrettable it was. Whatever the real cause, it was a most unseemly and unfortunate occurrence that did absolutely nothing to serve the Commonwealth cause. There is much in the Kuala Lumpur statement entitled Southern Africa: The Way Ahead, with which the coalition is in agreement. Our opposition to apartheid is unequivocal and longstanding. We agree with the statement's condemnation of many of the continuing unjust apartheid practices, such as the detention of political opposition and the banning of organisations. We support its call for genuine negotiations towards a peaceful settlement that safeguards the rights and interests of all South Africans. We agree that opposition to apartheid should be peaceful and not violent. We fully endorse the views expressed in the statement in support of a genuinely independent Namibia.

The Kuala Lumpur statement on South Africa comes at a critical time in South Africa's history. It is a period of significant and hopeful change within South Africa. A new government is bringing a new perspective to old problems. We do not delude ourselves that a new dawn is imminent but we need to take careful account of the changes that are occurring. It is against this background that the Kuala Lumpur statement calls for the maintenance of all the Commonwealth's existing sanctions and measures and, with the British disclaiming, for the tightening of financial sanctions, particularly in the area of trade financing and trade credits for South Africa.

The coalition's view of sanctions against South Africa is clear, and no selective quoting from it by the Prime Minister will change that: we do not oppose sanctions in principle. We have been strong supporters of a range of Commonwealth sanctions against South Africa, such as the arms embargo. We welcome the moves made in Kuala Lumpur to strengthen that embargo but we do not support the use of punitive economic sanctions, which we believe do not advance peaceful reform, the end of apartheid or the transition to full democratic power sharing in South Africa. We believe that punitive economic sanctions increase social tensions, exacerbate divisions, encourage extremism and slow down the internal dynamics making for reform. Time and again I have said this in the past.

The new financial sanctions called for by the Commonwealth would be implemented by the relevant banks and financial institutions. The extent and manner of their implementation have the potential to be punitive, in effect if not in intent. The coalition parties will be carefully monitoring this implementation process and the extent of the punitive impact that these new sanctions exert. We believe that the Kuala Lumpur statement could have been strengthened by a greater recognition of the changes taking place in South Africa and by less emphasis on the stick of punitive economic sanctions and more on carrots to promote a practical program of reform.

A range of issues other than South Africa were addressed in the communique in a very summary way. In the communique and the Declaration on Environment the Prime Minister commits the Australian Government to some positions that are, quite frankly, inconsistent with recent Australian actions and to undertakings which require further explanation and detail, neither of which his statement today provided. A few examples will suffice. The Langkawi Declaration on Environment, which we endorse and which reflects many of the proposals in the coalition's environment policy, commits the Australian Government to a program of `sustainable development' to enhance economic growth. But this Government has no coherent idea of what `sustainable development' is. The open public dispute on environmental and development issues between the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is about the fundamentals of policy. It reveals how deep, irreparable and confusing are the divisions in the Government's ranks over what sustainable development means in practice. The Prime Minister has done nothing to clarify this issue by explaining precisely what Australia's commitment to sustainable development in the Langkawi Declaration actually means.

Additionally, the communique endorses the requirement for a comprehensive political settlement of the Cambodian problem, an objective which the Opposition has consistently and fully supported, but which the Government has not. Only recently, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and our Ambassador in Thailand, the well-known spokesman at Australian Labor Party disarmament conferences, floated the possibility of a partial settlement, which in no way would guarantee democracy and self-reliance for the Cambodian people. I always noted how frequently the Ambassador in Thailand returned to Australia when there was a disarmament conference. It does not reflect badly on his work as a diplomat. I simply note that he seemed to return with regular frequency when Labor Party conferences on disarmament matters were to be addressed.

The communique calls on all States to establish a zone of peace, freedom and neutrality in South East Asia-our old friend ZOPFAN, which has been around for as long as many members have been in this Parliament and which, as Foreign Minister, I described, in diplomatic terminology, as `a noble aspiration'. This Government, however, has agreed to endorse and establish the elements of the zone of peace, freedom and neutrality in South East Asia. But the Prime Minister today certainly failed to spell out how he intends doing so in a way that is consistent with our regional security strategy and our alliance objectives. Furthermore, the communique notes the threat posed by inflation-it reads very well: `to sustain growth in industrial countries and the need to avoid recession'.

But neither the Government's economic policies nor, unsurprisingly, the Prime Minister's statement today, let alone this Government's actions, offer any way out for Australia. We go off to Malaysia; we are opposed to inflation; we are opposed to recession; but we come back and practise the very opposite! Then again, the Langkawi Declaration on Environment commits Australia to:
. . . strengthen and support the development of international funding mechanisms and appropriate decision-making procedures to respond to environmental protection needs . . .
But the Prime Minister's statement provides no details of costings or timings on this undertaking.

I conclude my response to the Prime Minister's statement by reiterating that the coalition's underlying perspective on the role of the Commonwealth is a positive and dynamic one. I look forward as Prime Minister to continuing the long tradition of active and constructive involvement by coalition governments in Commonwealth affairs. I can assure honourable members that I will not be skirmishing and indicating--

TALK.START.PARA: —Pigs might fly.

—And the Minister for Defence shows as much comprehension of international affairs as he does of running this Parliament. That is one of the tragedies: there has never been a Defence Minister with such a lack of comprehension of international affairs as this Minister. He thinks it is all about simply marshalling up the hardware. He is probably looking for a war to happen. If it occurs under him, I hope that it will be only some tiny micro-state, otherwise we will not meet with success.
—That is why you endorsed it.

—The Minister is sounding very agitated. It may be the regular miscalculations he is making as Leader of the House. Something has caused the agitation, and it is certainly not the Government's standing in the polls. As leader of the nation and attending these prime ministerial conferences and Commonwealth Heads of Government Meetings, I can assure the House that I will not be getting into the sorts of skirmishes the Prime Minister did with Mrs Thatcher. It seemed to be quite an obsession with him because he came back here and carried on with his endless criticism about whether she endorsed this program and what she did afterwards. In other words, what he is saying is that Mrs Thatcher is a textual deviate. I would not get into that sort of argument, but that is what he was on about and he is continuing it today.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern we have to have with the recent Kuala Lumpur meeting and the Prime Minister's role in it is that it reinforces the growing perception of the Commonwealth as a one-dimensional body divided against itself. The Prime Minister has shown himself to be too easily tempted to use the Commonwealth as a vehicle for his own brand of moralising, largely for the benefit of a particular domestic political audience. He has done so at the expense of meeting the less spectacular, less grandiose but nonetheless vitally important challenges that confront Commonwealth countries. The future of the Commonwealth depends on a more balanced sense of its priorities and possibilities. By his statement today the Prime Minister has demonstrated that this Australian Labor Party Government is incapable of addressing that historic challenge, but the next Australian Government, a coalition government, will redress that failure.
Debate (on motion by Mr Humphreys) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to determine its environment and development policies based on a rational and objective assessment of both environmental and economic consequences which accepts the principle of sustained development.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BLUNT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today when we awoke we had the spectacle on the front page of a newspaper of two senior Cabinet Ministers brawling. We had quotes from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) which were not even veiled criticisms of his colleague the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). From answers to questions in this place today it is obvious that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is chastened. I might go so far as to say that he is almost emasculated. He would not follow through on his criticisms; he deviated from the question and answered anything but the real issue of the day. That is a great pity because if ever there were a time for a sensible, mature debate in Australia about those issues, it is today. What we need is far more logic, rationality and commonsense in our political debate and a lot less party politics and emotion. The media had blazing headlines, but what Australia needs is that mature debate. We desperately need a consistent and coherent policy from the Government that balances the competing needs of the environment and development.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that Australia's economy is in crisis. The Australian people know the statistics; they know the forecast by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for the current account deficit of $18.5 billion; they know that it is more likely to be $25 billion; they know that our foreign debt is approaching $140 billion; they know that inflation is rising; and they know that the Treasurer's high interest rates are bleeding Australian families and businesses. We need a responsible Australian government that can provide leadership and a clear policy direction. What do we get? We get stunts from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), slander from the Treasurer, and a brawl between two Cabinet Ministers over direction. Where is that leadership? There is not any. We now have one Minister-the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy-belatedly arriving in the chamber. We welcome him. The fact of the matter is that this Government has never accepted--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. There are two Ministers in the chamber, not one. The Leader of the National Party is misrepresenting me; I was here all the time.
—There is no point of order.

—Before I resume the matter of substance, I point out to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs that, technically, when he is over there in the advisers box he is not in the chamber. He ought to read the rules of this place. Mind you, he does not need to because he will not be here for much longer. We also know what is going on out of his office. He ought to read what his obligations are as a Minister of the Crown in terms of the use of government funds. We have a fair sort of file on him.
—Order! I think the honourable member should withdraw that remark. That is an imputation against the Minister.
—What? That we've got a file on him?
—It is not the file; it is the imputation against the Minister unless it is by substantive motion.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I withdraw. What is far more important is the failure of this Government on such a significant issue. This Government has never provided any leadership. What we have seen today is the surfacing of a brawl that has been going on for seven years. This Government has never governed in the national interest. In the seven years that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who is at the table, has been responsible for this portfolio not one major resource project has been approved. All the major resource projects in Australia today were approved under the previous coalition Government and there is not one project valued at more than $500m planned for implementation in the near future. The Minister knows that; he knows that it is a stark condemnation of his administration. There are dozens of examples of the Government's failure to address the real issues that confront Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I could spend literally hours talking about its failure to come to grips with these issues, but today I would like to go very briefly through three significant issues: the ridiculous three mines policy; the way the Government handled the Wesley Vale pulp mill decision; and, of course, the latest fiasco-Coronation Hill. I could talk about Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, about the trauma that the third runway decision presented for this Government, or about dozens of other issues, but I will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the pilots?

—The pilots dispute is over. There is no point in talking about the pilots dispute; it is over, according to the Prime Minister. Let us look at the three mines policy. This policy is based upon the ludicrous proposition that there is good and bad uranium. Good uranium comes out of the mines that the Government has approved; bad uranium is that uranium in deposits that the Government will not approve. It is illogical, it is irrational, it is a sell-out of the national interest, it is a sell-out to the left wing, and it is a sell-out to pressure groups. The cost of that decision-the Government does not worry about the cost-was $8 billion in the 1980s and it is projected to be $10 billion in the 1990s.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us come to Wesley Vale. The blatant politicisation of that decision is amazing. Everybody, including the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on occasions, accepts the need to add value to our primary exports. Everybody also accepts the need to impose controls to limit the impact of pulp mills on the environment. But where are the Government's guidelines for pulp mills? Look at the number of inquiries we had into Wesley Vale. Look at the brave statements that came from the Prime Minister, the Cabinet and various responsible Ministers about commitments to guidelines. What was the deadline for those guidelines? It has come and gone and we have not seen them. Of course, we will not see any guidelines before an election. The reality is that politics have overcome the urgent need in this country to provide business with some sort of framework within which to take decisions.

The last example is Coronation Hill. The estimated value of Coronation Hill is $500m to $700m. The way the Government behaved in that area is amazing. First of all, assurances were given to the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd that the mine would go ahead. The company went ahead and spent $10m on an environmental impact study and all the concerns were complied with. Because we are close to an election, the Government did a backflip-the Minister, who now protests his concern so loudly around this country, conveniently was overseas; he did not even leave a proxy-and reversed its decision.

But even worse in terms of the Minister's statement yesterday was the decision on the conservation zone. On one of the most highly prospective mineral zones in Australia, by the Government's own estimates valued at between $8 billion and $15 billion, a decision was taken arbitrarily to reduce its size and limit access. Let me paraphrase what the Minister said yesterday when speaking about these issues. He said that each proposition should be considered on its merits. What did his Government do? It took an arbitrary decision in globo to sterilise an area, to prevent exploration, to limit even the concept of looking at the area. It was not even prepared to examine whether there was a possibility of developing a resource there without damage to the environment.

What we have in Coronation Hill is sheer tokenism. The Government sought, in the most blatant and obvious way, to do a transparent deal with people who purport to be able to deliver, en bloc, the votes of the conservation movement. Of course, that cannot be done. There is no such thing as a corporate vote for the conservation movement. Everybody in this country is concerned with our way of life. Everybody is concerned to protect the environment. But not everybody will vote the way they are told to by one or two leaders of the conservation group. Only the simplistic and desperate approach of the Prime Minister and his Government would have them believe that sort of vote can be bought. They would earn far more respect and, dare I say it, get far more votes if they had a rational and responsible approach to these issues rather than this craven pursuit of political popularity at any price.

We have a Minister in the other place who by his own words has disqualified himself from participating in decisions on resource development, a Minister who says of the mining industry, `There is no greedier, more impossible to satisfy group in our society than the mining industry. They are unbelievable'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is dead right.

—The honourable member has endorsed it. Well done! I wonder how many other honourable members opposite would endorse it. The Minister, out of his own mouth, disqualifies himself from taking part in these decisions. No wonder the major business organisations of this country are putting out statements saying that because of the Government's inconsistent, unpredictable policy there is a crisis in business confidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Less than a week ago a press release was issued by nine major business organisations, including the Business Council of Australia, the Australian Chamber of Commerce, the Associated Chambers of Manufactures of Australia, the Mining Council and the National Farmers Federation. This press release, which is comprehensive in its criticism of the Government, says in part:

Resource development and business investment are subject to short term political expediency. The uncertainty created by a government which goes back on its undertakings is undermining business confidence. Australia's resource industries are committed to environmental standards that are equal to the best of the world. Australia needs sustainable development which recognises the fundamental link between economic growth and the environment to maintain our living standards.

Where is the Government's response? Where is the response from the Minister? Where is the response from the Prime Minister? I asked him in this place the other day for a response and I got nothing but lunatic ramblings, ramblings that did not address the issue, that carried on about Access Economics and cited statistics that were irrelevant to the issues. That is the response that we get from this Government to the most pressing economic issue that confronts Australia today; that is: how are our resources to be developed? What is going to be the fundamental basis of Australia's economy? The Minister's response has been nothing short of pathetic. He knows the policy is wrong, he knows that he has no influence, he knows that he has been frozen out, and he knows that Cabinet will not listen to his complaints. So we have an angry and public conflict, a conflict which must be an embarrassment to a responsible government, but a Prime Minister who will not act on it. Let me take a minute or two to read out the Minister's comments on radio this morning in answer to questions from Pru Goward:
PRU GOWARD: But are you the only one in Cabinet who is a bit worried that the green debate is going a bit far, and we are losing out on our major developments?
KERIN: I wouldn't know. I've not canvassed it with my colleagues. I suspect quite a few would support what I'm saying. But I haven't done a poll within Cabinet.
PRU GOWARD: What does the Minister for the Environment say to you?
KERIN: Well . . . not much.
PRU GOWARD: You don't talk?
KERIN: (laughs) Well . . . we are both very busy, quite honestly. He wanders around the country bagging the miners and the farmers and all the rest of it.

My goodness! What sorts of Cabinet meetings do they have? They must sit at each end of the table throwing paper balls at each other. One can picture it. This is an absolutely appalling state of affairs. What should be a serious political issue, which is subject to serious and considered debate, is really determined by the political ambitions of this Government. The Government is operating not on an economic strategy but on a political strategy.

The Government has set up something known as the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC). That, in fact, is a lap-dog of the Government, and it has no impact. It could be a first class organisation. It could do the job that so desperately needs to be done, but it has become a dumping ground for difficult decisions. There is no guarantee that any report that comes out of the RAC will be treated any better than the report of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests. The Minister knows that, and he knows that the RAC legislation is flawed. He knows that it is skewed and he knows that recommendations that do not comply with that ridiculous schedule are subject to legal challenge.

In the few moments left to me, let me draw this whole situation together. What we have is paralysis on the part of this Government when it comes to deciding on policy issues, fundamental policy issues that will determine the capacity of this country to survive and pay its way into the future and to sustain a standard of living as well as a quality of life. There is a concept known as sustainable development. The Minister is aware of it. He has taken to speaking of it recently. But when it comes to arguing it forcefully with his colleagues, he is strangely silent. We have a government that has shirked its responsibility. It should be concerned about economics and Australia's future, but it is motivated entirely by politics. Not only does it not have a coherent economic policy-we have not seen one word from the Treasurer about that-but the Government's commitment to the environment is about as deep as the ballot box.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government had no difficulty in accepting the proposition raised today by the Opposition; namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to determine its environment and development policies based on a rational and objective assessment of both environmental and economic consequences which accepts the principle of sustained development.

That is exactly what we are doing as a Cabinet and as a Government. What the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), has just confirmed is basically what we on this side of the House have always said; that is, that the National Party is profoundly anti-environment. There is only one banana republic in this country and that is Queensland. His Party has raped and pillaged the landscape in Queensland. New South Wales gets a new government, and straightaway the Nats are into it. They use the same old rhetoric and have the same anti-environmental approach to government.

I went through the Hansards to look at the Opposition's performance on environmental issues. I went back to 1 April 1987. The drift of one of the questions put to the Government was that mining should go ahead. `World Heritage listing should not go ahead for the Queensland rainforests', `World Heritage boundaries are specious in the Queensland rainforests'. Then there were two questions criticising Minister John Brown because he wanted to build a railway in Uluru. Then there was a question to me about logging. Again, it was pro-logging. Then there was a call for a Helsham-type inquiry prior to World Heritage listing. Then the Nationals wanted the speedy implementation of the Helsham recommendations.

I can go through every question that has been asked in this House that has some vague connection with the environment, and every one was pro-development and anti-environment. That is the reason why yesterday in my speech I mentioned posturing, tokenism, vote chasing and cynicism. They refer exactly to the Opposition. I nearly fell off my perch when I heard that the new Premier of Queensland-whatever his name is, they change them so regularly; Sir Robert Sparkes sees to that-would run on the environment in the election campaign. What a joke! I have dealt with forestry Ministers in Queensland who think that the only good tree is a horizontal one-sheer tokenism.

The Federal Opposition's policy is to establish priority national parks. That is clearly a threat to all the others. It is vote chasing. I refer to the statement of the Leader of the National Party that the Opposition will set greenhouse gas emission targets. He then went on to say:
I should emphasise that this is a target.

In other words, the target does not have to be met at all. I refer to the Opposition's cynicism in respect of its attempts to rewrite history by claiming, for example, that it had a soil conservation program when that was not the case. In that respect the Opposition referred to Mr Fraser's heritage classification of Fraser Island. I can just imagine the brawl that went on in Cabinet about that.

Today the Leader of the National Party also talked about splits between Cabinet Ministers. One of the biggest debates in the community today is about development and the environment, and it is a healthy debate. I will certainly not shirk from putting forward my point of view in this area. It must be one of the easiest things in the world to maintain shadow Cabinet solidarity-there would not be anything easier. The decisions made by shadow Cabinet do not mean anything and, if the Opposition gets into government, it could easily overturn those decisions. Even in this area of shadow policy, it cannot maintain solidarity-it cannot manage it. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) and the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) were in a great mess over child-care last week.

The Leader of the National Party is a genius. He wanted me to spend six weeks in Riyadh drinking coffee while following the live sheep issue. The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd) is another genius, a diplomatic one. He wants me to de-recognise the People's Republic of China and recognise Taiwan in order to reward Taiwan for limiting our beef exports.

The point of my speech yesterday was all about sustainable development. Rational assessments have underpinned all the Government's environmental decisions, and I will go through some of them. The Franklin River runs free. In respect of the protection of World Heritage areas, the most important to my mind is the wet tropical rainforests. Another was my introduction of national soil conservation in 1983. That was not done by the Fraser Government, as the Opposition's Stalinist attempt to rewrite history would have it. The work we have done on fisheries management is an environmental success story of this Government which goes largely unnoticed.

No-one can argue that there was not a very great objective assessment in respect of the Tasmanian forests. There was also the agreement with New South Wales in respect of the south-east forests. That agreement is working well at this stage, partly because New South Wales knows that the Commonwealth will use its constitutional powers to protect the forests if that becomes necessary. We are leading the world in protecting the ozone layer at international conferences, and we are doing more research per capita on the greenhouse effect than any other country.

There is also the work that led up to the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in July on the environment. That is a magnificent document which is well suited to the interests of my portfolio and the concept of sustainable development. The document contains a substantial expansion of the national soil conservation program, a commitment to plant one billion trees, saving remnant vegetation, and expansion of the national afforestation program. The document also deals with expanded work on the greenhouse effect, development of pulp mill guidelines, assistance to local government for environmental management, and the promotion of paper recycling, including the removal of sales tax from recycled paper.

What a record-a record that justifies calling that environmental statement one of the greatest. It is all based on rationality, because we have established the institutions to provide rational, objective advice-the National Resources Information Centre; the Bureau of Rural Resources in my Department; expanded resources for the Australian Heritage Commission; and the most important of the lot-the Resource Assessment Commission, which the Opposition tried to water down out of existence in the Parliament. In fact, the Opposition nearly wiped it out in the Senate. The most important announcement of the lot was the very first in the Prime Minister's statement on the environment: that the overriding objective is ecologically sustainable development. That is why we can accept this proposition.

Let us look at this concept of sustainable development-a concept the Opposition has now started talking about without having a clue what it is talking about. Sustainable development means that we, this generation, must bequeath to future generations a total environment that is at least as good as the one our predecessors bequeathed to us. That is an historic commitment by the Government. It goes beyond `balance' in environmental decision-making. `Balance' can be held to mean that some rate of environmental decay is appropriate-sustainable development means that no rate of decay is appropriate. It goes beyond `conservation', as `conservation' does not allow for restoration. In a whole host of areas, we need to improve the environment we inherited. The most obvious is in the area of land degradation.

As I said in Question Time today, after decades of conservative parties' neglect, we are introducing a decade of land care. It was Prime Minister Whitlam and former Minister Moss Cass who set up the environmental impact process in this country. They were responsible for the study by the States and the authorities on Australia's land degradation situation which eventually came forward during the term of the Fraser Government. What did the Fraser Government do with it? For a while poor old Kevin Newman thought that he was on a goer and he promised that the then Government would bring in a national soil conservation program, but that was all wiped out by the 1980 razor gang affair; it never got up. I recall pointing out in this House that this was Australia's greatest conservation issue, but what was I always told by the then Leader of the National Party and other people? I was told that it was a State matter. It was this Government that achieved it. Members opposite neglected the land.

When I first raised this question as a shadow Minister, the farmers said, `Here is Kerin. He is a bit of a pinko, a bit of a greenie; he should not be talking about these things'. The farmers are now backing this Government on land care, because they know that it is one of the most important issues facing them.

The most important thing about sustainable development is that it recognises that people want improvements to their overall quality of life-including both environmental amenity and material standards of living. Sustainable development means providing both. It recognises that stopping economic growth is not the solution to the world's environmental problems. Indeed, in comparing the environments in rich and poor countries, it is obvious that economic growth is a nexessary part of the solution to those environmental problems. If one is going to talk about the environment, there is also the built environment, the urban environment. To service it and to continue to spend billions of it will require economic growth.

Sustainable development also recognises that the community deserves a decent return from the exploitation of its resources. As I have been at pains to point out recently, the rents belong to the community. That is what the Government is all about. That is what our decisions to date have been about, and it is what all our future decisions will be about. Let there be no doubt that further decisions are required. Our agriculuture is still not sustainable, although it is getting there. Only parts of our forestry-such as those administered by the Victorian Government-are sustainable. I have got fishing to be almost sustainable. But it goes on throughout all industry activities.

That is what we will do, but what will the Opposition do? What will the slash and burn merchants of the National Party do? What will the Liberal Party do with the millstone of the National Party around its neck? We all know the answer. They engage in what I called yesterday posturing, tokenism, vote-chasing and cynicism. There is high cynicism by the Opposition parties as they now claim, because of the opinion polls, that they have the true greenie credentials.

Only this Government is capable of providing leadership and vision to policy-making in this country. We have demonstrated this in many ways: our economic policy, where we have created 1.5 million jobs; our social policy; and our environmental policy. This whole question of sustainable development is going to take a lot of work. Much of that work will be done in my Department as we work with industry on the concepts of sustainable development. If we look at agriculture, forestry and fisheries, the concept is well established. If we look at other areas where we are dealing with finite resources it is quite obvious that a different approach needs to be taken. There seems to be a lack of knowledge in this country about exploration techniques. There is a lack of knowledge about alternatives, substitutes and processes-all of the things that can be incorporated into an approach to sustainable development for the mining industries.

The Brundtland report, the major report in recent times that emphasises the whole concept of sustainable development, has been pushed harder by one group in this country-the Australian Mining Industry Council-than by any other. I was recently in the United Kingdom, where the Government has brought out a report by Professor David Pearce on sustainable development which tries to define the concept in terms that make sense in the United Kingdom. Defining the concept of sustainable development in this country is going to take time but it is the only possible way to work through the dilemma we have with respect to conservation and development. This country has pressing economic problems. We cannot ignore the fact that we need to have growth. Above all, we cannot ignore the fact that the way out for this country is sustainable development.

TALK.START.PARA: —It ain't easy being green, is it?
—Order! I might suggest to honourable members on my left that they remain silent because it is the time of the honourable member for Gippsland which is being taken up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The performance just given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) should remind members of this House of a similar performance. It struck me towards the end of his carefully read speech that it exactly mirrored the performance yesterday of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). So concerned is the Minister under fire not to sway in any way from a carefully scripted performance that he will not answer the central charge. Just as the Treasurer did not answer the charge of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock)-that he had chased the big lie in regard to allegations of John Elliott and the capital gains tax supposed link-up-nor has this Minister answered our central charge, which is that the extremist environmentalists, aided and abetted and encouraged to a wild degree by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, are determining the level of development in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Who is determining development? Is it the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, and the Cabinet, based on rational objective decisions, or is it the Minister responsible for the environment, Senator Richardson, in a cynical ploy with the false hope of winning votes at the next election? The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy gave us a rambling and very carefully worded statement but he backed away in a very obvious manner from his comments of the last couple of days, not least of all on the Pru Goward Australian Broadcasting Commission program this morning. He was asked:
You would also be forced to say that there are people in your own party who are cynically exploiting this for votes, wouldn't you?
The Minister answered:
I think there is evidence of that in some areas, yes. I think the anti-development party of my party sees that this is a new cause . . .

The Minister has been silenced. In the face of provocation from the extremist environmentalists, assisted by Senator Richardson, he has gone to water. When asked in Question Time yesterday to dissociate himself from the outrageous and inaccurate comments of Senator Richardson, as reported in the Illawarra Daily Mercury of 8 October, he certainly gave tacit endorsement. Those comments are almost indelibly etched on the minds of most members. Senator Richardson made a gratuitous and generalised attack on the mining industry when he said:
There is no greedier, more impossible to satisfy group in our society than the mining industry, they are unbelievable.
Moreover, Senator Richardson did not stop there. I quote further from the article:
Senator Richardson said the only reason BHP wanted to go ahead with mining in Kakadu was because of gold, but that tests had shown there was not a scrap of gold in the area.
`There are five or six areas in Australia richer than Kakadu, but money isn't spent prospecting on those, it's only spent in an area that looks like going into a park,' he said.

The stupidity of a remark like that from a Cabinet Minister defies logic. Is he alleging, as the plain words would have us believe, that members of the mining industry get out maps and say, `Let's forget about the resource-rich areas. Let's go straight to a national park where there is not a scrap of resource to be mined in any event. Let's spend $10m on exploration within Kakadu stage 3, but there's not really any gold there?' That is the level of bigotry which it is incumbent on the Cabinet, but more specifically the development Ministers, to counter.

The Minister is utterly powerless. The supposed Hawke of the bush has been reduced to the galah of the Parliament. He goes around muttering under his breath about the cynicism of Senator Richardson and the short-sightedness of his obsession with blocking any sort of development, whatever environmental guidelines can be guaranteed. He always complains that he cannot negotiate with the environment movement because Senator Richardson is forever egging it on. When it negotiaties with Minister Kerin he cannot in any way strike a compromise because it knows that it can get what it wants at any price from Senator Richardson. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy goes around the mining industries and resources sector saying all this, muttering under his breath and trying to make a big man of himself; but when he is asked finally to stand up on a matter of principle he backs away as fast as he possibly can.

The loser in all of this is obviously our nation. The Government has tried to characterise itself as adopting a consenus approach to potentially divisive national issues. It certainly employed that sort of all-econom-passing soothing language when it introduced the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC) which the Minister made great play of, citing it as evidence of his Government's determination to reach balanced and rational decisions on the development-environment debate. The truth is that that Resource Assessment Commission has been gutted before it even gets off the ground. The Government has referred to it for decision, for advice, not the whole of the conservation zone of Kakadu Stage 3 but only that small strip extending from Coronation Hill to El Sherana, a matter of a few kilometres. Cabinet has already made the decision to do away with the potential of $7 billion worth of resources. The RAC is left with only a narrow reference. Moreover, its reference has been delayed many months so that there will be no recommendation derived from the RAC until many months later. So much for the rhetoric of the Government.

The reality is that there is no balance and no consensus; nor is there any rationality to the Government's approach on environment and development issues. There are only winners and losers. The environment Minister is the winner; the development Minister, the resources sector and the nation are losers. Where is the consensus that the Prime Minister promised us in his July supposed world's greatest environment statement? Where are the new mechanisms for an accord process in regard to development projects and the environment? Where is the trade-off and the compromise and the balanced perspective on this issue? The Resource Assessment Commission, which is the only possible example of a government trying to inject rationality into this debate-which to a very large extent has galloped away from it, having been inflamed by Senator Richardson-has failed. It has already been corrupted by high politics. Once we were told that the RAC would remove the divisiveness from the development scene, but now we have seen the RAC turned into the political arm of the Government.

The Cabinet's decision on exploration and mining in stage 3 of Kakadu marked the loss of innocence for the RAC. If the Government had been legitimate in its hopes for the role of the RAC, it would have at least referred the entire conservation zone within stage 3 to the Commission for assessment.

The Government knew that this delay mechanism would enable decisions on crucial development to be deferred until the next Federal election, and all persons within the RAC know it. They know that they have been sold down the drain and now know that their fate is merely to serve as an extension of the Government and not as an arbitrator trying desperately to inject rationality into this debate. The industry knows it also.

So where are these consultative mechanisms about which the Prime Minister has boasted? The Prime Minister has not pursued these initiatives simply because the prospect of a balanced discussion is anathema to the political course that he has charted based on the best advice Senator Richardson can give. How tragically disappointed the Government will be. There is no forum for any consultation or sober discussion, nor any likelihood of reasoned outcomes. The development Ministers within the Government are totally isolated and the anti-development part of the Australian Labor Party, as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy described them this morning on the Pru Goward show, have won the day.

This is the man who has some claim to be the next Leader of the Opposition, so all is not lost. Even now that he has been reduced to irrelevance in the Government, the one bright light is that he will make a better Leader of the Opposition than the Treasurer. So one slight, bright hope may come out of all this. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will make a good Leader of the Opposition because, by heavens, Government members are coming over to this side of the House--
