SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the main planks of what the Opposition has been talking about is lack of investment and development in Australia. I quote, from Access Economics Investments Monitor, a unique listing by sector and State of 500 investment projects worth over $5m each under construction, committed or under consideration in mining, manufacturing, tourism and public sector investment relating to foreign exchange earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: The projects listed have a total value of $90 billion. I will repeat that so that it will sink into some people's heads. There is $90 billion worth of investment in Australia. Do honourable members know how much of that is in the mining industry?-$6,932m on projects under construction or committed. So who said the Government was letting the mining industry run down? We agree with some of the miners and some of the mines going ahead. However, we must ensure that those under construction, committed or under development are environmentally sensitive. I repeat that $6,932m worth of mining is involved in construction and development in mineral sands, gold, iron ore, coal, oil and gas, uranium and others. I correct that. There is nothing in uranium, I am pleased to say. To tell the coalition's environment story, I should like to give a few quotations from Opposition members. The first comes from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), who used to be the environment spokesman at one stage. He said:
The third factor was the extraordinary irony that we were roundly criticised for our decision to abolish the Environment Department.
This is their secret agenda. If ever they get back into power, out goes the environment department. The next quotation comes from Charles Blunt--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to the Leader of the National Party by his title.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. The next quotation comes from the Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Charles Blunt), who warned that the recently announced Decade of Land Care program would be reviewed if the coalition were returned to office, and said:

SPEECH.PARA: We may change the program, but it will be from the day we come in.

That appeared in the National Farmer of 25 August 1989, not that long ago. So obviously, land care is on the skids. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) is referred to in the next quotation as the Leader of the Opposition. It was printed only a couple of weeks ago and he is now the Opposition spokesman on industry. He said:

I don't beat about the bush. I admit that after the election I said we should look at environmental issues and that it was no longer a sufficient response from a Liberal to automatically say `Well, we have nothing to say on that subject because it's entirely a matter of State Rights'.
On 7 November 1986 a journalist interviewed the honourable member for Bennelong at Parliament House. The transcript of the interview read:
Journalist: On Kakadu, will a Coalition Government allow mining of Stage 2 of Kakadu?
Howard: The Coalition Government believes that the proposed plan of management is unacceptable and we will be moving in that direction when the Parliament resumes.
Journalist: But more concretely, does that mean that you will allow mining in Stage 2?
Howard: It could, yes.
All of the Opposition members agree to mining in stage 2 of Kakadu. Again, the Leader of the National Party said:

For us a rational policy for the Government to follow is to take a decision on the development of Coronation Hill project and allow further exploration of the Kakadu National Park with EIS studies for each new proposal as they come in.

The coalition members say all the time that they are environmentally conscious. Judging by the statements made by some of their leaders, it is obvious that they are not. I now quote that great man of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, who was extolling the potential for investment in Queensland. He said:
You can do so much with a bulldozer.

That is certainly the policy of the National Party. Peter Garrett responded to the Opposition's assurances that stages 2 and 3 of Kakadu National Park would remain open to the mining industry under any future coalition government. He said:
If Mr Peacock wants to take two steps back into the dinosaur and destroy path then he will do that at his own peril.
Peter Garret also said:

He, Mr Morgan, claims that environmentalists are the logical successors to communists and socialists. If that's the case, then we're in the same boat as President Bush and Mrs Thatcher and Prime Minister Hawke. The Federal Government's decision about Kakadu was a responsible decision. What it does do is extend the ambit of Kakadu National Park and that's something which all Australians will welcome.
Whilst I am talking about communists I point out that the honourable member for Flinders was mentioned in a recent article in the Independent News, in talking about environmentalists, as follows:
For the former solicitor, now shadow minister for education, and 16th in the queue for the top perch in the Liberal barnyard--

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifteenth now.
—Fifteenth, is it? The article goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: any green candidate in the next Federal election will be `watermelons'. They'll be watermelons because they'll be green on the outside and red on the inside.
He said that as if he had just invented horticultural analogies. The article continued:
Some of the greens people who claim to be green, most likely will be a front for the Labor Party. It's as simple as that.
That reaction created quite a storm in my area and I must say that the Labor candidate for Flinders, Mr Tony Moore, said:
Is Mr Reith saying that anyone who dares vote against him, or dares to have a different opinion to his, is not a conservationist but a communist (a red) in disguise?

That is what honourable members opposite imply. They imply that I am a communist because I stick up for the environment. They are trying to intimidate us once again. I say for the benefit of everyone in the gallery, including all the children in the gallery if they are listening, `Stick up for the environment. It is the only way. Don't be scared when people like members of the Opposition call you a communist or anything like that because you know what you are doing is correct'.

Something I have done recently in regard to the environment was to draw attention to the toxic waste from the BP refinery. For some years I have been trying to learn where it was. On 13 June 1989, I mentioned in this House that some toxic waste was buried. On 4 October the State member for Mornington, Mr Robin Cooper, said that what I had stated was a cynical beat-up about the waste dump in Hastings. He said:
Late last May, Mr Chynoweth grandstanded in Federal Parliament on this . . . then sought out and obtained local publicity which has seriously alarmed local residents.

It is claimed that my remarks were a cynical beat-up. However, on Tuesday, 17 October, in an article in another local paper, I named the location of this dump. Surprise, surprise! Over last weekend the Environment Protection Authority (EPA) went there and put a bulldozer or back-end loader into the ground. What did it dig up? There were 200 to 300 drums, each containing about 200 litres of waste material. They are now being analysed and I am informed by the EPA that it is the largest dump of this type of BP waste ever found in Victoria. The EPA is analysing it at the moment and there seems to be bituminous waste and also some viscous liquid substance.

In addition to the site that I gave the location of, through further digging the EPA has located several other drums. Tom Roper has thanked me for my help in the matter. I would like to congratulate Tom Roper and his Department for the speed with which they acted to investigate this location of waste. The waste is located in the electorate of the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). But what has he done over the last five years that I have been raising this matter? The Opposition has never even bothered to look into it. Opposition members just laugh about it. I would have thought, after I had made a claim such as this, that he would have asked around about it. He knew that the Hastings Council knew about it. He knew that certain people in his electorate knew about it. Maybe we should see who these certain people support in this political game. I want to make certain that this sort of thing never happens again, so I hope that whoever has put this waste there will be penalised severely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the nineteenth report from the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Senate Publications Committee. Copies of the report are being circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Duffy) proposed:
That this House:
(1) absolutely rejects any recourse to chemical warfare and calls for the elimination of all existing stocks of chemical weapons;

(2) views the comprehensive, global Chemical Weapons Convention under negotiation by the Geneva Conference on Disarmament as the most effective, enduring solution to the potential threat of chemical warfare;

(3) believes that an effectively verifiable Chemical Weapons Convention will need to be designed and implemented with the active participation of the international chemical industry and that in this regard it:

(a) welcomes the outcome of the Government-Industry Conference against Chemical Weapons held in Canberra in September 1989, including the industry statement rejecting any involvement with the manufacture of chemical weapons and affirming commitment to the development and implementation of a global ban on chemical weapons; and
(b) encourages the continuing growth of dialogue, stimulated by the Conference, between government and industry on the chemical weapons issue; and

(4) believes that Australia should continue to work with neighbouring countries to foster regional awareness of the chemical weapons issue, with the aims of reinforcing norms with our region against chemical weapons and of strengthening regional support for the Chemical Weapons Convention under negotiation in Geneva.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports this motion relating to the proposed chemical weapons convention which I had assumed the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) would speak in support of. In any event, I understand the matter has been spoken to in the Senate. The Opposition supports this motion basically for two reasons. The first is that the Opposition shares with the Government an abhorrence of chemical weapons. The horrors of chemical weapons are well known, as are the dangers of chemical warfare. I understand that at least 22 countries are known to possess chemical weapons. By the end of the century an estimated 30 developing countries will have ballistic missiles capable of delivering chemical warfare warheads accurately over great distances.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reason we support the motion is that we support any step towards a comprehensive and verifiable global chemical weapons convention that would ban not only the use of chemical weapons but all chemical weapons entirely and in perpetuity. We are well aware that the chemical weapons convention is still being negotiated. It is being negotiated at the United Nations Conference on Disarmament, which has been in progress since March 1968. We support any efforts towards confidence-building measures, the resolution of differences and details of the ongoing consideration of this issue which might assist in the process.

We are in agreement with much of what the Government is doing in relation to chemical weapons, for example, with its participation in the negotiations at the Conference on Disarmament, which predate the present Government. We support the Government's active role in the informal `Australia Group' of 20 Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development nations to monitor and control the export of materials that could be used to build chemical warfare facilities, or what are known as precursor chemicals that could be used as ingredients in chemical weapons production. Certainly, there seems to be a greater international realisation of the horrors of chemical weapons and of the need for a comprehensive global ban. One is aided in this realisation by a vision of what one might call the unthinkable, the confirmed use of chemical weapons by Iraq and Iran in the Gulf war. Indeed, who would forget the photographs of the 10,000 men, women and children in the Kurdish town of Halabja who were wiped out in March last year by Iraqi chemical weapons? In January this year, 149 nations in Paris affirmed their commitment not to use chemical weapons and stressed the need to conclude a chemical weapons convention.

One should note the activities of the Government-Industry Conference against Chemical Weapons (GICCW), which was held in Canberra from 18 to 22 September and which was designed to bring together representatives from government and from the chemical industry to discuss how best to help to bring about and implement a chemical weapons convention. Of course, this is another of those conferences that are described these days as awareness conferences. The earlier regional chemical weapons seminar which was held here was significant and useful in educating regional groups-one which the Opposition supported, although we were never really quite sure why Australia was expected to bear the cost of all participants attending that conference, even those from New Zealand. The ad hoc committee on chemical weapons will be resuming in Geneva next month, as I understand it, and the full conference on disarmament session resumes on 6 February next year.

There is a considerable hope for the conclusion of a chemical weapons convention in two years time. Therefore, we support this motion, but we wonder about the Government's timing of it. Presumably, the Government is looking for a statement of parliamentary support, which we certainly lend our hand to, in view of some concern by the Government that the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) may be proceeding towards a bilateral agreement between them that would set back negotiations for the wider and more effective convention. Of course, the Government knows more of the subtleties of what is under way by virtue of the fact solely that it is the Government and it may well be that this is the reason why the Government is asking for this expression of parliamentary support. We want to indicate our support for it, which we do by my speaking in support of this motion.

There certainly seems to be some uncertainty regarding the intentions of the United States Government. There have been reports that the Australian Government suspects the United States of being more interested in chemical weapons non-proliferation than it is in the conclusion of a chemical warfare convention. This would seem to be surprising as on 4 February 1983 the then Vice-President Bush announced at the Conference on Disarmament that the United States had certain requirements for a chemical weapons convention. On 18 April 1984 he presented the Conference on Disarmament with a draft convention which has since served as the basis for negotiations on the present rolling test and, of course, when he became President, he declared that a ban on chemical weapons would be his Administration's priority.

We must recognise that since the United States and USSR bilateral negotiations started in 1986 they have resulted in much progress in the Conference on Disarmament negotiations. For example, on 6 August 1987, the USSR finally agreed with the longstanding United States position to permit short notice, on-site challenge inspections as a necessary element of an effective chemical weapons verification regime. Since then there has been much progress on procedures regarding challenge inspections, on the destruction of chemical weapons stockpiles and on the destruction of production facilities.

A recent landmark in the bilateral negotiations was the signing on 23 September of a memorandum of understanding between Secretary of State Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze in Wyoming. The memorandum of understanding took the bilateral negotiations further by providing for an exchange of data on stockpiles and on measures to verify that data. A couple of days ago, on Monday, 30 October, the United States and the USSR began their bilateral discussions to develop procedures on implementing the memorandum of understanding. Since the memorandum of understanding, the United States has pledged to destroy 98 per cent of its stockpile in the first eight years of the convention, with the remaining 2 per cent being destroyed in the last two years. The USSR, not to be outdone, has announced that it is prepared to destroy all of its stockpile now, even before a convention is concluded.

On 9 October came what has been regarded by some as a bombshell, with the report in the Washington Post that President Bush had decided that the United States would continue to manufacture what are know as binary weapons, even after a chemical weapons convention was concluded, and that binary weapons would not be included in the program of destruction of chemical weapons stock and facilities under a convention. It is not clear, therefore, what the present situation is and where we are today. Of course, we would welcome some indication from the Government as to exactly where we have got to on this issue and where it is proposed we are all going in the short to medium term in view of these American statements. It was reported in the Age newspaper on 27 October that Senator Gareth Evans wrote to Mr Baker asking for clarification. Of course, a public announcement has yet to be made by the Americans and President Bush has not commented on the matter any further. As I said before, the Government is more in tune with the subtleties of this whole procedure by virtue of the fact that it is the Government. We would appreciate at some stage some indication of just where we stand on the developments in this area.

Presumably, the Government would like some credit for the two conferences that it sponsored in Australia in recent times and we are happy to give this. Of course, they add to what Australia has been doing in the Conference on Disarmament and I think that should be placed on record. Unfortunately, the debate has acquired a bit of unnecessary colour by some of the political statements being made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans. Although we give credit where it is due, we think, nevertheless, he has fuelled unreal expectations, presumably in an effort to gain some domestic political standing. We really need to look through the headlines that he has generated in recent times to see just how true this is. For example, on 22 September the Australian Financial Review offered the following headline, `Evans to secure weapons deal'. In the Australian on the following date, 23 September, we find the headline, `Chemical ban in 1990 tipped'. On 23 September, the same day, the Age newspaper said, `Chemical weapons accord a coup for government'. We have not seen the final realisation of this coup as yet, but we live in hope. On 25 September the Canberra Times had as its headline, `Agreement to ban chemical weapons'.

Probably the most overstated proposition of all time was contained in the Australian of 25 September, `Evans' date with destiny'. That does seem to add unnecessary rhetorical colour. I know that the world is in a pretty bad state and I see that Senator Evans is offering himself as its saviour by being President of the General Assembly, but I do not think anyone would hold the view that the world was in such an abandoned state that it needed Senator Evans to guide its future destiny. However, we have, `Evans' date with destiny'. Just how unrealistic the Foreign Minister was during the GICCW conference last month in pushing for a chemical weapons convention next year can be seen by the fact that we do not have one as yet and we are still somewhat in the dark as to what the progress is, particularly in view of United States developments.

It is clear from the conference that massive problems still remain. There is a great deal of work to be done and confidence building measures are needed before a chemical weapons convention can come about. For instance, there are some articles in the rolling text which are still in their formative stages. It seems from all this that Senator Evans's date with destiny will be put off for some time but we certainly support those steps that have been taken and that are being taken and we certainly lend our support to all right-minded and right-thinking people who are working, as are nations, through the various conferences towards the achievement of the convention that we all hope will come about.

In addition, a number of countries indicated in Canberra that they wanted the inclusion of sanctions against the use of chemical weapons. This is a difficult area because, if the convention is an effective one, there would be no need to include a clause on sanctions. Many countries, especially in the Middle East, want a linkage between chemical weapons disarmament and nuclear disarmament. Third World countries at the GICCW were not happy about the impact of a ban on their own chemical industries. Of course, they are continually concerned about development, as we saw from the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting when Dr Mahathir directed some observations at those people with whom I suppose the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) would find himself in agreement. Of course these Third World countries wanted assurances that a ban would not affect technology transfer.

One can go on in detail, but I do not propose to do that. But it must be said that, while recognising that the recent conference was useful to get together government and industry representatives and representatives of chemical industries to state their opposition to chemical weapons and for some thinking about the national measures that would have to be taken in preparation for the implementation of a chemical weapons convention, we must keep the achievements of the conference in perspective. Certainly continuing high tensions in the Middle East and the latest question mark over binary weapons coming from the United States illustrate the problems that remain to be dealt with before the convention comes about. But we certainly support the Government on this motion.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (TRAFFIC IN NARCOTIC DRUGS AND PSYCHOTROPIC SUBSTANCES) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Simmons, on behalf Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SIMMONS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Crimes (Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Bill 1989 represents a further stage in this Government's strategy to deal effectively with the illicit trade in drugs. All honourable members would have been repulsed by the images of renewed violence and mayhem emanating from the cities of Colombia over the past two months. All members would agree with the messages of worldwide support that have been directed to the Colombian Government in its bid to rid its country of this insidious cancer which threatens the very existence of the oldest democracy in Latin America. However, such moral support is inadequate to deal with the international menace of drug trafficking. What is required is effective, coordinated international action. It is for this reason that the Government has over the past seven years placed the highest priority on providing and securing international cooperation in the fight against the illicit trade in drugs and organised crime which is dependent on it.

Over the past seven years the Government has modernised Australia's extradition laws and negotiated and secured 28 modern extradition treaties. In this period, Australia has led the rest of the world in the development of modern arrangements for mutual assistance in criminal matters, thereby securing treaty backed obligations to assist in criminal investigations, prosecutions, the pursuit of the international criminal money trail and the confiscation of criminally obtained assets. Further, in the international arena Australian model extradition and mutual assistance treaties form the basis of model treaties being prepared by the United Nations Crime Prevention Committee for adoption by the eighth UN Crime Congress next year.

On the domestic legal front the Government's Cash Transaction Reports Act 1987 and the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 comprise one of the most comprehensive legislative packages for following the money trail in the world. Australia's achievements have been recognised in the international community, most recently by our inclusion in the Financial Action Task Force established by the Group of Seven major economic nations to advise on the prevention of money laundering. As the International Enforcement Law Reporter stated in its September edition, `Australia's participation in the taskforce is significant because it has taken a leadership role in international criminal cooperation'.

Because of our commitment to international law enforcement cooperation we have played a prominent role in the development of the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. This new Convention embodies further measures for law enforcement and cooperation between international states.

The Convention was concluded following calls from Latin American states through the 1984 Quito Declaration against Traffic in Narcotic Drugs, the 1985 Lima Declaration, and from Bolivia at the 36th Session of the United Nations General Assembly, for an effective international campaign against traffic in drugs. Some 79 states have signed the Convention, indicating the strong support in the international community for its intent and content. I am advised that, like ourselves, most signatory parties are proceeding to ratification of the Convention through their own constitutional procedures.

This legislation represents the first step in the process of Australia's ratification of the Convention. Ratification will achieve one of the aims of the National Campaign against Drug Abuse, which has the support of all governments in Australia. The States have been aware of the proposed Convention and of the Commonwealth's wish to become a party to it from the beginning of the drafting process in 1985, and their views were sought at each stage of the negotiation process.

I wish to emphasise, however, that this Convention reinforces only one strand in the international drug strategy, which, as the international community recognises, requires a multidisciplinary approach. The Declaration of the International Conference on Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking in Vienna in June 1987 designated four areas for future action:
prevention and reduction of demand;
control of supply (including programs for rural development involving crop eradication and substitution);
suppression or illicit trafficking; and
treatment and rehabilitation.

Although the Convention is, of course, directed at the illicit drug trade, it also touches upon these other important aspects of the problem of drug abuse. This, too, is consistent with the approach adopted in the national campaign against drug abuse. This campaign also takes a multidisciplinary approach with a strong emphasis on education and prevention directed at vulnerable groups, and treatment and rehabilitation of regular users.

There is a degree of misunderstanding about the effect which ratification of the Convention will have on drugs policy. The Convention primarily addresses the question of trafficking in illicit drugs. It includes provisions relating to extradition, mutual assistance, confiscation of assets, following the money trail and questions of jurisdiction. It expressly provides that parties to the Convention will ensure that drug trafficking offences attract the strong criminal sanctions they deserve but distinguishes between possession of drugs for the purpose of trafficking and for personal use. It is in respect of the latter category that the Convention has been seriously misrepresented.

Contrary to some views which have been expressed, the Convention does not preclude the re-examination of policy in relation to personal use of prohibited drugs. It is open to governments, should they so decide, within the context of this Convention, to provide that possession which would otherwise be an offence will not be subject to criminal penalties where the possession is clearly for personal use only. Thus, the Convention specifically states that parties may, as an alternative to conviction or punishment in such cases, provide measures for the treatment, education, aftercare, rehabilitation or social reintegration of the offender.

Additionally, section 17a of the Crimes Act 1914, which provides that imprisonment should be imposed as a last resort, will apply to offences created under this Bill. As a result, when the courts are considering sentences to be imposed on persons convicted of offences in relation to cultivation or production for personal use, they will be required to give preference to alternative forms of sentences which could lawfully be imposed. Such alternatives could include programs of rehabilitation, treatment and education, and the court would need to be satisfied that none of these options is appropriate before they impose a sentence of imprisonment. Thus, sentencing options already available in the case of Commonwealth offenders enable us to take full advantage of the alternatives to sentencing proposed in Article 3 of the Convention.

Many of the obligations created under the Convention which fall within areas of Commonwealth legislative responsibility are already covered by Commonwealth legislation such as the Customs Act 1901, the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, the Extradition Act 1988 and the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987. Other obligations fall within areas of State responsibility, and consultations are under way with the States on action to be taken by them to ensure their laws are in accord with the terms of the Convention. The Commonwealth has been very much aware of the importance of not encroaching on areas of State jurisdiction in this field and fully supports the continuation of the cooperative approach to drug law enforcement with the State and Territory governments and their law enforcement agencies.

The principal area requiring legislation in the Commonwealth sphere relates to the need to create extraterritorial jurisdiction under Article 4 of the Convention. The purpose of the jurisdictional changes envisaged by Article 4 is to ensure that drug traffickers cannot escape justice by moving from one jurisdiction to another-for example, to a jurisdiction which for a valid reason is not prepared to surrender the person to the country the laws of which were infringed.

I will now outline the ways in which this Bill will extend Australia's extraterritorial jurisdiction. The first extension relates to Australian nationals who have engaged in conduct, outside existing Australian jurisdiction, which would constitute an Article 3 offence if it had occurred in Australia. and where extradition of such persons from Australia is not sought or, if sought, is not granted for reasons outside the scope of section 45 of the Extradition Act 1988.

The Bill also establishes a second area of jurisdiction where a person who is not an Australian national has engaged in drug-related conduct outside Australia which constitutes an offence against the law of the country where it occurred and also against the law in force in an Australian State or Territory and the person is subsequently present in Australia; but Australia declines to extradite that person.

Thirdly, the Bill creates jurisdiction over persons who are outside Australia and engage in conduct with the view to the commission of a drug-related offence in Australia; for example, knowingly growing a crop for subsequent marketing in Australia. The Bill also creates offences arising out of drug-related conduct on Australian aircraft and provides for the exercise of Commonwealth jurisdiction on Australian ships in certain circumstances. Another provision creates a Federal offence which has the effect of applying, outside Australia, State and Territory offences of conspiring or attempting, aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the carrying out of drug-related conduct which is an offence against the law of a State or Territory.
I do not anticipate that the proposals put forward in this Bill will have a significant impact on Government expenditure in the foreseeable future.

This Bill is the first step in the process of ratification of this most important United Nations Convention. Further action will be required by the States before ratification can take place. The Convention seeks to achieve concerted international action against those who, for their own gain and at great cost to the community, engage in illicit trafficking in drugs. The cooperative multidisciplinary approach of the national campaign against drug abuse recognises the need to address the problems of addiction with compassion and to offer treatment and rehabilitation to those suffering under all forms of drug addiction. In no way can it be argued that ratification will prevent a reasoned and complete debate on the merits of the present national approach to drug abuse. The Government welcomes such a debate but remains committed, along with our State and Territory counterparts, to the type of tough and thorough measures prescribed by the Convention in respect of illicit drug trafficking. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr N.A. Brown) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Simmons, for Mr Dawkins, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SIMMONS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill represents an important measure in the Government's efforts to strengthen and, where necessary, protect the legitimate autonomy of higher education institutions. The specific purpose of the Bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act to protect the rights and responsibilities of higher education institutions to make their own decisions, independent of government interference, on the provision of services and amenities for their students and the imposition and collection of fees for that purpose.

As honourable members will be aware, student organisations provide a wide range of services to their members from counselling, sporting, health and careers services to the necessary social outlets for young people in higher education. It is fundamentally important that these services and amenities be maintained at a viable level. This cannot be achieved without money. The principal source of that money is services and amenities fees collected from students themselves by the governing bodies of the institutions on behalf of organisations representing the interests of students generally. At present these fees are paid in accordance with provisions made by the governing bodies of the institutions.

It is unfortunate that there needs to be a Bill of this kind at all. However, States have in the past interfered with these arrangements and some are threatening to do so again. We are not prepared to see this happen. This Bill provides that, as a condition of grant under the Act, a State must not interfere with the rights of the governing bodies of institutions to make decisions as to the imposition or collection of fees for organisations representing the interests of students generally. If a State breaches this condition it will be required to make up any consequential shortfall in revenue to those institutions. If necessary this will be achieved by a requirement that the State pay the Commonwealth an amount to make up the shortfall or alternatively, the Commonwealth could reduce the State's general revenue assistance. The Commonwealth will then make payments direct to the affected institutions. The Government encourages any State contemplating such interference in the autonomy of higher education institutions to think again and hopes that the provisions of this Bill will never need to be invoked. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Over the last six years, the Federal Labor Government has reconstructed Australia's social security system. Once regarded as little more than a passive payment agency, the social security system now has strong and active links to employment, training and labour market services. Social security policy has become an integral part of the Government's economic, wages and taxation policies. The social security, wages and tax systems have been restructured to deliver fairer and more adequate incomes to all at every stage of life. Together these systems now provide a solid base of economic security for all Australians. The barriers and difficulties confronting the different groups within the social security system have been progressively identified and tackled. Today's social security system offers incentives and opportunities for those of working age to move from payments designed for short term support back into jobs. Assistance has been targeted to those most in need while administrative procedures have been constantly improved to minimise the risk of payment abuse.

The impetus for many of these changes has been the Social Security Review which last year completed its historic `life cycle' examination of the system-the first time this has been done since World War II. The results of our reconstruction are clear. For the first time ever Australia has a guaranteed level of income support for families with children. Australia now leads the world in providing adequate, secure child support to separated parents. The increasingly strong links between Australia's social security system and labour market assistance for the unemployed and sole parents are setting the pace for reform in Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries.

These links provide opportunities to participate in the mainstream of community life for people at risk of being excluded. They ensure that the community does not bear the cost of unnecessary and counterproductive welfare dependency. This Bill would implement further fundamental reforms to the social security system.

In the 1989-90 Budget and retirement income policy statement, the Federal Government announced a fundamental restructuring of the relationship of the public pension and tax system on the one hand and private savings and support for retired Australians on the other. This restructuring will provide a sound basis of income security for the retired and for those who will retire in the next decade and in the longer term.

These changes, like every element of the Government's social policies, are fully funded on introduction and sustainable in the long term. They complement the Government's reform of superannuation. This Bill would reshape income support to take account of the different forms of savings available to retired people and ensure that they can live with dignity and security in their own home. Our policies will guarantee access to a fair, adequate, secure and sustainable retirement income for all Australians. The most significant reform for older Australians will be a major restructuring of the overlap between the pension income test and taxation. This Bill would implement our promise that, from 1991, the income test free area will be indexed annually. The free area will also be 100 per cent tax free. Further, from 1995 no age or service pensioner-full rate or part rate-will pay income tax. These, plus other significant reforms to date, mean that every major element of the social security system will be protected into the future by guaranteed automatic adjustment for inflation. This Bill also contains carefully crafted and coordinated measures to provide better opportunities and incentives for self-provision for the aged, the disabled, sole parents and the unemployed.

The Bill would overhaul the interaction of private superannuation and the social security system. The treatment of annuities and superannuation pensions under the income test will be brought into line with their treatment in the tax system. The Bill would exempt from the income test that part of the undeducted purchase price which represents the notional return of the after tax purchase price of a superannuation pension or an immediate annuity. These changes would be complemented by exclusion of superannuation pensions from the assets test and by special rules from the treatment of immediate annuities under the assets test. This will ensure the changes have the effect of encouraging the use of private savings to provide retirement incomes, rather than becoming a vehicle for income test avoidance. Labor's better incomes policy acknowledges the wide range of needs of retired and pre-retired people. This Bill would enable people who are disabled or have become unemployed before age pension age to retain the full benefit of their superannuation for retirement. Income which accrues on compulsorily preserved superannuation will be exempted from pension and benefit income tests until the pensioner or beneficiary reaches age pension age, except when the person draws on the superannuation. In those cases, the growth will be treated as income over the 12 months following the withdrawal. Compulsorily preserved superannuation will be disregarded under the assets test.

Mr Deputy Speaker, through our retirement income policy we will provide opportunities for all Australians to provide for their retirement. We will deliver better incomes in retirement to all Australians. When the Whitlam Government was elected the age pension was only 19 per cent of average weekly earnings. In three years Whitlam raised the level of the pension to almost 25 per cent. However, over the next seven years the conservative parties in Government allowed the pension to fall back to about 22 per cent of average weekly earnings. This Labor Government has steadily regained the ground lost under the conservatives. Through this Bill pensions would be lifted to more than 25 per cent of average weekly earnings-in fact to their highest level relative to average earnings in 40 years. From April 1990, single rate pensions and benefits for people with dependants will rise by $2 a week on top of indexation. Pensions and benefits for married people will rise by $3.30 a week on top of indexation. This means pensions for single people will rise by about $11 a week by April next year and the combined married rate pension will rise by about $18. The Bill leaves entrenched our amendments to indexation provisions made earlier in the year, which guarantee twice- yearly indexation rises in line with the consumer price index at the earliest time possible, so pensions will retain their real value. These measures represent an unprecedented commitment to the adequacy of the age pension. But we will go further. Labor, and only Labor, is committed to further increases on top of indexation over time, to deliver better incomes in retirement to all: to those without private means of support as well as to those with superannuation.

This Bill recognises the housing needs and aspirations of retired people and others. The rent assistance measures that would be implemented by this Bill, in tandem with measures legislated following last year's Budget, fundamentally restructure the rent assistance program. Maximum rates of rent assistance for the aged will double-from $15 a week to $30 a week-between December this year and September next year. Assistance to families with children-low wage families, sole parent families, unemployed families-will more than double: up from $15 a week to $35 a week and $40 maximum payment a week for families with three or more children. The Bill also recognises the needs of older home owners who, though not having the costs of private rents, often need to find money for house repairs or alterations. Home equity conversion is a mechanism by which a home owner may convert all or part of the equity he or she has locked up in the family home into cash or a stream of income. The Act at present discourages pensioners from embarking on these schemes because the money raised may be treated as income. This Bill relaxes the income and assets tests to allow pensioners access to home equity conversion products without penalty. They will therefore be able to draw a loan of up to $40,000 on what is probably their most valuable asset to carry out home improvements or to raise their standard of living. The draw downs on a home equity conversion will be exempt from the assets test for up to 90 days.

The Bill acknowledges the extra costs faced by pensioner couples when one of the couple is in respite care for a period of 14 days or more. The maximum single rate would be the maximum rate payable to each of the couple during any such period of respite care. These measures-overhaul of rent assistance, home equity conversion concessions and additional help during respite care-provide a coherent comprehensive basis for addressing the housing needs of the aged and low income families. The Bill would also address the income security needs of people following the death of a spouse or dependant. The bereavement package would replace the current special temporary allowance and funeral benefit with a new, more generous scheme of bereavement payments. The new scheme would preserve for 14 weeks the entitlement of the partner or child who has died in the form of a payment to the surviving partner or parent. This allows a period for readjustment for the bereaved before having to establish a new structure of income support.

The new payment is available to the surviving member of a married pensioner couple, a sole parent pensioner on the death of the only qualifying child and the parents of a deceased dependent child who attracted one or more of the various family payments available. When the Department becomes aware of the death, the balance of any entitlements under these new arrangements would be cashed out, as soon as practicable, to a lump sum to assist with funeral and other costs likely to arise. The legislation would make it clear that where payments continue during the 14 weeks after death to an account in the name of the deceased-whether alone or jointly with the surviving spouse-the financial institution would be entitled to pay those amounts to the spouse. This will address a major practical problem that faces many newly widowed people-continuing access to their bank accounts.

This Bill would dramatically simplify the earnings credit to provide extra assistance to pensioners who undertake short term jobs and to provide a springboard into employment for pensioners seeking permanent jobs, especially sole parent pensioners. From April 1990, earnings credit accrual will be standardised. Pensioners will build up credit at a set rate depending on the income test free area that applies to them. This will be $40 a week for single people, $35 for each of a married couple, plus $12 for each dependent child. The maximum credit will remain at $1,000. This amendment will create a more worthwhile, understandable and efficient earnings credit scheme.

The aged package included in this Bill, and complemented by other measures announced in the Budget, is the most comprehensive, detailed and coherent social policy development in the history of Australian Federation. It is based on the detailed work of the social security review and was crafted following extensive consultations conducted by the Government on the issue. I would like to record in particular the Government's appreciation of the efforts of the members of the task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on retirement incomes jointly convened, by Mr Speaker, Mr McLeay, and the honourable member for Phillip, Ms McHugh. Their efforts and the efforts of the thousands of retired people who spoke with them ensured that this package is a package for the long term. It is with deep regret that I record that the Opposition has still not committed itself to the long term commitments in this policy-the indexation of free areas in 1991 and the removal of all age and service pensioners from the tax system in 1995. A retirement income policy must be stable and long term. If the Opposition is serious about all Australians having adequate incomes in retirement, if it is serious about enhancing our national savings effort it will use the debate on this Bill to unequivocally commit itself for the long term to the national retirement income policy. Its failure to do so, or any qualification of its commitment, will be a clear signal to the retired and pre-retired people of Australia about the priority the Opposition gives to better incomes for all in retirement.

Many provisions of this Bill which address the needs of the aged extend to veterans and their dependants in receipt of a repatriation service pension in the same way as to social security age pension recipients. This Bill also provides for increases in the rates of payment of a number of minor benefits for severely handicapped veterans.

Over the last five years Labor has rebuilt the integrity of Australia's unemployment benefit system. We have fundamentally restructured the system and converted it from a passive payment system to an active system linked to labour market policies and programs designed for the broad range of people dependent on unemployment benefit. This Bill would continue with the reform of benefits entitlements that has underwritten that restructuring. The labour market and income support issues facing older unemployed people are of particular concern to the Government in terms of social justice, economic and retirement income policy objectives. There has been a disturbing long term trend of declining labour force participation by people aged 55 and over. Together with the retirement income policy, this Bill would provide more adequate assistance and better opportunities and incentives for regaining employment to the older unemployed.

First, the work test for beneficiaries aged 55 and over would be restructured-to enable older beneficiaries to retain or regain close attachment to the labour market. The dynamic Newstart strategy-described by the Opposition spokesman as `spectacularly successful'-introduced in February this year allows participation in Commonwealth Employment Service approved training courses and voluntary work while unemployment benefit continues. The strategy helps the long term unemployed to get back to work. This Bill would provide the basis to extend the strategy to all older unemployed beneficiaries regardless of how long they have been on benefit. Further, older beneficiaries on benefit for 12 months or more will be able to engage in training or voluntary work for even longer-for up to 26 weeks in a year. They will also be able to participate in substantial ongoing part time employment as an acceptable alternative to the requirement to seek suitable, full time work. Second, the maximum rate of benefit for people aged 60 or more would be aligned with pension rates after six months receipt of benefit. The 26-week rent assistance waiting period would be abolished for beneficiaries aged 60 or more. Third, people aged 60 and above who have been receiving unemployment or sickness benefit for at least 12 months will become eligible for a health benefit card rather than the less beneficial health care card which they currently have available to them. This new card will provide the full range of Commonwealth fringe benefits.

These measures will be complemented by a hefty boost in availability and appropriateness of labour market programs-such as Jobstart, Jobtrain, Skillshare and the new enterprise incentive scheme-for the older unemployed. Different methods of helping and encouraging older unemployed people back into work are being trialled over the next 12 months. These measures stand in sharp contrast to the Opposition's approach. The Opposition argues that all long term unemployed people should be removed from unemployment benefit and placed on special benefit-or receive nothing. Their position is also that Jobstart, Skillshare and the new enterprise incentive scheme-centrepieces of Labor's approach for the older unemployed-should be abolished. There is no doubt that this Bill-in providing for modifications to unemployment benefit to help people back to work-is inconsistent with Opposition policy. The debate on the Bill provides to the Opposition an opportunity to put down the details of how it would deal with the older unemployed. Over the last four years this Labor Government has completely restructured income support and labour market assistance for the young. The common allowance structure-under which Austudy for young people at school is paid at the same rate as job search allowance-or JSA-for unemployed young people has removed the incentive for young people to leave school for unemployment. The JSA structure has also provided an integrated basis for delivery of income support and labour market assistance.

The results of Labor's approach are dramatic. The numbers dependent on social security have plummeted while the proportion staying on at school has skyrocketed. However, we recognise that some young people have missed out-and so we developed the youth social justice strategy announced in the Budget. That strategy involves an integrated comprehensive $100m program to address the barriers facing disadvantaged young people and to respond to the concerns about youth homelessness highlighted in the Burdekin report. This Bill would implement the social security aspects of that program. Young homeless allowance would be increased on 1 January 1990 by $7.50 a week, bringing the total payment for homeless young people to $95.10 week-and the payment will be indexed every year from then on so that it keeps its value. Young homeless allowance has been subject to a six-week waiting period. To avoid the hardship that this may cause and recognising that delaying payment cannot actually resolve family problems, the Government has decided to reduce this waiting period to two weeks. For those who have faced a history of domestic violence, sexual abuse or other similar serious problems, the waiting period would be abolished altogether.

This Bill would implement an independent rate of job search allowance for young people who are exempt from the parental income test because of their independent status. The rate payable would be $95.10, an increase of over $41 a week. The new rate, which would be indexed every year, would be paid from the beginning of 1990 to young people who have not lived at home for six months, who have worked full time for at least 13 weeks since then and who do not get any financial support from their families. In addition the $25 minimum rate of job search allowance would be indexed on 1 January each year commencing in 1990.

This Bill would reinforce the Government's encouragement for young unemployed people to move back into the labour force or to continue full time studies. An employment entry payment of $50 would be available to people who take up full time employment after being on job search allowance for nine months or longer. Their spouses would be eligible for the same payment which acts as a recompense for some of the hidden costs involved in taking up a job. People who receive job search allowance or junior rate sickness benefit for nine months before starting work would no longer have to serve the normal 13-week waiting period if they need to reapply within 13 weeks of losing benefit. The Newstart work test concession which is currently available to long term beneficiaries would be extended to young people who have been on job search allowance for at least three months. This would enable them to participate for a total of eight weeks each year in Commonwealth Employment Service-approved voluntary work or short training courses. Finally, students who reapply for job search allowance or unemployment benefit within four weeks of attempting a return to study would not have to serve a second 13-week education leaver's deferment period.

In addition to this significant range of reforms for our youth, the labour market package announced in the Budget continues the promotion of a more active unemployment benefit program through several innovative measures. To encourage married beneficiaries and their partners to make the most out of labour market opportunities that come their way through part time work, the Bill would provide for them to earn a further $30 a fortnight between them above the usual $60 without losing any benefit. A sole parent beneficiary whose youngest child receives job search allowance would receive an increase in the rate of benefit to the same rate which is paid to the sole parent of a child receiving Austudy. To remove another inequity in this area, a sole parent pensioner or beneficiary whose only child attracts Austudy or a similar payment would no longer be paid the higher `with dependant' rate of benefit or mother's/guardian's allowance once that child turns 18. To provide appropriate assistance to sole parents, formal training allowance payable for part time training would not be counted as income under the pension income test-bringing it into line with the way formal training allowance for full time training is handled. Recipients of unemployment benefit and job search allowance would be automatically issued with health care cards as from June 1990 without the need to apply a separate income test. Those beneficiaries along with sole parent pensioners who have received payment for at least 12 months would be entitled to health care cards for at least six months after starting full time unemployment. This measure will remove a significant disincentive to regaining employment.

The Government is committed to providing adequate support for Aboriginal people in rural and remote areas. Family payments at present can be made only to the immediate family or sometimes to an institution. More appropriate mechanisms may be available for Aboriginal children living in remote or isolated communities. From next year, bulk payments or family allowance at the higher rate would be available to Aboriginal community organisations which provide services of benefit to the children concerned. This arrangement would apply only with the agreement of the people concerned. These measures form part of a package to lift the standard of service provided by the Department of Social Security to isolated and remote communities.

This Bill contains several other measures in the area of family payments. From next year, parents with a child under 16 earning $100 or more a week would no longer be entitled to child payments for that child. The $100 would be indexed each year. Child payments for a student child would cease when the student turned 16 unless Austudy or its equivalent was not payable. Parents with children who are receiving formal training allowance would no longer be eligible to receive family payments for those children. From April 1990, invalid pension would not be granted to people over age pension age. Currently, infirm elderly people who do not meet the residency requirements for age pension can gain access to the same rate of payment through the invalid pension system which does not have the same residency requirements. The amendment would reflect the clear purpose of invalid pension as a payment related to incapacity for work for people of work force age.

Section 19 of the Social Security Act provides a scheme for the protection of personal information held in the social security system by making it an offence for departmental staff to record or disclose such information outside the course of their duties. Where there is a legitimate public interest reason to disclose information, those receiving it, whether officers or not, are bound by the same section 19 restrictions in passing on that information.

This Bill would close a loophole in the provisions which could allow people who have acquired personal information from officers acting in breach of the section, and who may in turn use or disclose that information, to do so without themselves committing an offence. Receiving, using or disclosing information concerning a client without lawful excuse or authority, or advertising or holding out that one has access to such information would be an offence under the Act.

The Bill would continue Labor's vigilance in guaranteeing the integrity of the social security and veterans systems. It would provide for the imposition of an interest charge of 20 per cent on amounts defrauded from either system through major frauds.

I now refer to the significance of 1990 in the annals of the Anzac tradition and to the Government interest in the commemoration of this historic event which is to include a visit to Gallipoli by a number of World War I veterans. The Government is concerned to preserve the integrity of the significance of this event. Misuses of the term `Anzac' have already taken place. To prevent further misuses and abuses of this sort, this Bill introduced increased penalties for the use of the term `Anzac' without the authority of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SIMMONS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the explanatory memorandum for the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 which I introduced in the House earlier today.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Simmons, for Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SIMMONS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is an omnibus measure proposing a series of amendments to the principal Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901, along the lines of the similarly titled Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bills introduced into this place over the last few years. In addition, this Bill proposes a series of repeals of various unproclaimed sections of early 1980s Customs and Excise Acts, following a recent review of unproclaimed Customs-related legislation.
The main proposals contained in the Bill relate to:
(i) The termination of manufacturing in bond, announced by the Government in the context of the 1988 May economic statement (clauses 7 and 8);
(ii) The amendments to the commercial tariff concession system (Part XVa of the Customs Act 1901) announced by the Government on 14 September 1989 (clauses 18 to 29); and

(iii) The new requirement that all potable spirits imported into Australia in bulk containers be repackaged in licensed premises prior to entry for home consumption (clause 9), and that locally produced spirit be repackaged in non-bulk containers prior to entry for home consumption (clause 37) as announced by the Government on 18 December 1988.
I shall refer briefly to each of those proposals now.
Manufacture in Bond

Manufacture in bond arrangements permit the production of prescribed goods in a manufacturing warehouse licensed by Customs, for both domestic and export markets. The stated objective of the manufacture in bond scheme is to promote local manufacture of goods. The scheme is meant to assist local manufacturers by: allowing them to defer payment of duty on imported inputs used in production until the completed-manufactured-product is entered for home consumption; and allowing goods manufactured in bond to be entered for home consumption at the lesser amount of either the combined duty of the imported components or the duty payable on the finished article if it were imported.

Other inherent benefits of the scheme are that wastages of imported materials and/or components in the production process are not dutiable, duties are not payable on imported inputs used in the manufacture of goods for export and, prior to the May economic statement of 1988, manufacturers were not liable for duty on imported inputs used in the manufacture of goods sold to Commonwealth authorities.

In January 1987 the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) reported to the Government on export concessions, report No. 399 dated 16 January 1987, and recommended, inter alia, that manufacture in bond be abolished. The Commission found that the original objectives of the scheme have not been pursued. At the time of the inquiry the only goods being produced were blended oils (manufactured by one plant) and telecommunication equipment (manufactured by 14 licensed warehouses, which has subsequently been further reduced to only four warehouses). The manufacture in bond scheme has not promoted Australian manufacturing industry and it tends to discourage investment in, and the sourcing of, materials and components from other domestic import competing industries, because with concessional entry under the scheme, it is often cheaper to source materials and components from overseas. The scheme has also not been effective in promoting exports as only a small proportion of the goods produced in bond have been exported. The IAC noted, and the Government accepted, that there are alternative and more effective assistance schemes in existence which provide duty concessions on imported inputs, notably the commercial tariff concession system, and, from the viewpoint of export promotion, schemes such as the duty drawback and by-law for export schemes.

The Government accepted the IAC's recommendation to abolish this scheme and announced, in May 1988 as part of the May economic statement, its intention to terminate manufacture in bond. The proposed amendment in clause 8 of this Bill will terminate the manufacture in bond facility as from 1 January 1990. The activities of blending and packaging, however, will still be permitted in licensed warehouses.
Commercial Tariff Concession System

The main purpose of the amendments to Part xva of the Customs Act relating to the commercial tariff concession system is to overcome the narrow interpretation that has been placed on the provisions contained therein by decisions of the Federal Court such as that in Corinthian Industries (Syd) Pty Ltd v. Comptroller-General of Customs and Others, contrary to the original intent of the Government when the scheme was introduced in 1983. Notwithstanding that the Government has announced that the new Industry Commission will review the overall objectives and operation of the commercial tariff concession system, it believes immediate action is necessary to implement the proposals contained in this Bill in order to restore the original intention of the system, overcome operational problems and provide additional benefits to industry. The changes proposed will enable the system to be effectively administered in the period up to the Industry Commission report, expected in late 1991.

By way of background to the proposed changes in clauses 18 to 29 of this Bill, it is opportune to recall the original purpose and intent of the legislative provisions in this part of the Customs Act. On 2 July 1982 the Industries Assistance Commission reported to the government of the day recommending that a modified commercial by-law system be introduced. The Government accepted the report and introduced the commercial tariff concession system with the clear intention that it would be broad in interpretation and predictable in administration.

The system provides a mechanism to allow the duty free entry of goods, where goods serving similar functions are not produced or capable of being produced in Australia in the normal course of business. Experience with the system has pointed to several changes which could be made to improve operational efficiency. In the May 1988 economic statement the Government announced that it would modify the system to align its operation more closely with the Government's industry and technology policy objectives. Subsequent to that economic statement, decisions by the Federal Court have highlighted restrictive and narrow interpretations to various definitions contained in the legislation.

To restore the Australian Customs Service's ability to administer the legislation in accordance with the Government's intentions it is necessary to make appropriate changes to the legislation and fine-tune operational aspects of the system. The amendments proposed in this Bill seek to achieve this. In particular, it is proposed to delete from the legislation the interpretation of `particular goods', `serving similar functions' and `capable of being produced/repaired in the normal course of business', and the term `particular' from the phrase `particular goods' where it is no longer relevant. I refer to clause 18. These definitions have proven to be a source of contention and have forced administrators to interpret the legislation more narrowly than the Government intended. The removal of these definitions from the legislation and their replacement by principles for the interpretation of key phrases-I refer to clause 19-will ensure that administrators, importers and local manufacturers have a clear understanding of the system's objectives and will provide the flexibility to ensure that the system can be administered as the Government originally intended.

Further, as the Federal Court has determined in Corinthian Industries that the existing legislation limits the scope of a concession order to the particular goods that are the subject of an application, legislative amendments are necessary to enable commercial tariff concession orders to be issued in relation to the relevant class of goods rather than the narrowly specified products sometimes described in applications. This power, contained in clause 20, is necessary because, under the current provisions, neither the applicant nor the Comptroller-General of Customs is empowered to change the wording of an application. In practical terms this means that if, for example, after approaches to local manufacturers, an applicant accepts that a concession can only be issued for a narrower range of goods than that applied for, such a concession cannot be granted unless a new application is made. This results, however, not only in a substantial loss of time but, more importantly, the loss of the original operative date of the concession.

Another proposed amendment concerns section 269e, relating to the national interest discretion, amongst other matters. Currently the Comptroller-General of Customs has the power to refuse to grant a concession order if he considers such a concession is not in the national interest. The Government considers that such power is more appropriately vested in a Minister, and therefore clause 22 effects the necessary amendment in this regard. Finally, amendments are proposed to sections 269n and h of the Act by clauses 27 and 24 respectively to facilitate the granting of specified period concession orders, and simplify the date of commencement of all orders.

Currently, an application can be preceded by a notice of intention to make a concession order which allows the applicant 28 days to obtain and present the information required for a legal application. If the application is received within the 28-day period the date of lodgment of the notice of intention becomes the operative date when a concession order is issued. The Government proposes to abolish this practice and automatically make the date of effect for all concessions 28 days prior to the date of lodgment of the application. Such action will reduce paperwork for clients and unnecessary checking by administrators.

Similarly, under the current legislative regime concession orders cannot be granted for periods during an applications's processing time. The Government believes in principle that in such circumstances a concession should be available, an initiative widely supported by industry. It is therefore proposed to amend the legislation to allow a concession order to be granted from cessation of availability of locally produced goods or from the normal date of commencement to the day local production commenced or a local manufacturer satisfies the capability to produce criteria. I refer to clause 27.
Abolition of Out of Bond Bottling/Packaging

The final matter I wish to address concerning this Bill relates to the proposed amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 in clauses 9 and 37 respectively relating to the new control regime for imported and locally produced potable spirits. The amendments propose that all potable spirits be bottled or packaged into non-bulk containers in licensed premises prior to their entry for home consumption, which is the point at which duty is assessed and collected. The amendments will have the effect of removing the facility which currently exists for such spirit to be entered into home consumption in bulk containers. Such a practice has been identified both by this Parliament's Public Accounts Committee, and by the Industries Assistance Commission in its report No. 408 of 19 November 1987 on the customs and excise bond system, as one which increases the possibility of illicit spirit production via the mixing of duty paid spirit with illicit spirit.

To address the possible risk both to Commonwealth revenue and public health from this practice of bottling or packaging spirit outside of licensed premises, the Government proposes as from 1 January 1990 to effect the change outlined. The remaining provisions in this Bill propose a series of minor policy or technical drafting changes, which are explained in detail in the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. One of the proposed amendments, however, I would like to touch on briefly here. That relates to the amendment in clause 6, which provides a head or power to permit the making of regulation to impose a fee for services to defray the costs incurred the Australian Customs Service in respect of preparing certain kinds of import entries lodged under section 36 of the Customs Act 1901. The Government appreciates the sensitivity which attaches to any cost recovery initiatives, and will proceed with such fees only after suitable consultation with relevant Government agencies and industry bodies.
Financial Impact Statement
The proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the House and present the accompanying explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Simmons, for Mr Staples, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SIMMONS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954, the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Act 1989, the First Home Owners Act 1983, the Health Insurance Act 1973, the National Health Act 1953 and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974. The major purpose of this Bill is to enable the residents' rights initiatives to be implemented in nursing homes and hostels. The Bill also removes the necessity for a medical certificate for nursing home admission; allows for backdating of domiciliary nursing care benefit in certain circumstances; provides for proprietors of nursing homes to be approved operators; provides for lodg- ment and processing fees for reviews of budgets of deficits of certain nursing homes; and includes certain minor amendments consequential to the implementation of new respite care arrangements in nursing homes. These measures are based on the Government's social justice policy and continue the reform strategy in the aged care program with particular emphasis on ensuring access and equity, promoting equality and providing opportunities for full participation in Australian society.

The Bill also includes amendments to: the First Home Owners Act 1983; the definitions of `proprietor of a laboratory' and `officer' of the Health Insurance Commission; restrict entitlement to Medicare benefits of certain diplomatic representatives; the administration of the vocational register of general practitioners; and various arrangements of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The major purpose of the Bill is to introduce new provisions which give effect to the rights and responsibilities of residents of Commonwealth funded aged care facilities. The Bill provides for a `charter of residents rights and responsibilities' and an agreement between a resident and a proprietor of a facility, based on the charter. The Bill strengthens the legislative provisions for preserving those rights by improving access by authorised persons to facilities, residents and staff. The Bill also seeks to make available information about the standard and general nature of services provided by a particular nursing home or hostel to enable consumers, the elderly or their friends or relatives to make informed choices about suitable care and to encourage high quality care.

In 1986 the nursing homes and hostels review recommended a major program of aged care reforms aimed at providing better quality care and a greater range of choices for frail aged people. The first four reform stages were concerned with the rational use of resources, more effective planning, equitable distribution of funding, effective assessment and equity in care provision. The fifth stage of this reform process was heralded by the release of the report Residents' Rights in Nursing Homes and Hostels in July this year. In the minds of many people, older members of our society are seen as a group, rather than as individuals. They are often considered to be without influence and dependent on the goodwill of others. Consequently, they are devalued and may become even more vulnerable to harassment, threats and even physical violence. Older people are also commonly victims of a patronising approach which sees all people over a particular age as unable to make decisions and needing assistance with every task.
