Many older people have accepted this negative view of themselves and have become resigned to being isolated and lonely. We must not accept this situation as inevitable. Government have a responsibility to both enforce rights and educate and inform in relation to those rights.

Residents' Rights in Nursing Home and Hostels was the final report of the consultant commissioned to identify the issues that concern residents of nursing homes and hostels and to examine the attitudes and approach of nursing home and hostel proprietors and staff to residents of those facilities. Four major problems were identified in the report: residents' feelings of isolation and boredom; the lack of control that residents feel they have over their own lives; the absence of information about available services; and the fear of retribution if any complaint is made. These problems are ones which should be of concern both to service providers and to the community in general.

I will not go through the report's recommendations in detail. Instead, I will refer to the major changes flowing from the report which the Government, in the 1989-90 Budget context, has announced as priority initiatives for implementation over the next four years. The priorities in 1989-90 will be to implement: a charter of residents' rights and responsibilities and a resident/provider agreement by 1 July 1990-the standard agreement would be implemented in respect of new residents only from 1 July 1990 and a later date will be negotiated with the industry for completion of agreements with existing residents; the establishment in each State and Territory office of the Department of Community Services and Health of an effective unit to receive and follow-up complaints from residents for their representatives; Commonwealth funding for independent advocacy and mediation services in each State and Territory to take up grievance issues on behalf of residents-it is likely that most will be operational in the latter part of 1989-90; a community visitors scheme to enable residents to have greater access to their local community and to provide residents with information, support and advice-it is anticipated that the scheme will be implemented first in Queensland and Victoria from April 1990; and a comprehensive information strategy to enhance the awareness of residents, potential residents and the community generally, of care options and the key issues to be considered in choosing the right type of care. Before action is commenced to implement these initiatives there will be extensive consultation with the industry, consumers and staff groups.

I would now like to outline the provisions in the Bill to enable the residents' rights initiatives to be implemented. While the residents' rights report makes a large number of recommendations for change, it recognised that it is also critical to change the attitudes of our society towards the aged as well as those of consumers, staff and management. The proposed amendments to the Aged or Disabled Homes Act 1954 and the National Health Act 1953 contained in this Bill will provide the framework within which residents' rights issues can be addressed, and thus continue the process of positive change. The Bill provides the Minister with the power to formulate a statement or charter of the rights and responsibilities of the residents of approved nursing homes and hostels. The charter is a broad statement of principle which will emphasise rights of choice, access to services, rights to independence, participating and involvement in all aspects of daily life, and access of the residents to their own records. It will also state the responsibilities that residents, as adult members of society, should meet in their daily lives, including respecting the rights of others.
The residents' rights report suggested that there are a number of advantages of a charter:

A charter provides residents with a sound basis for any negotiations with management around particular issues . . . also, it provides a sound basis for the quality of care which management are endeavouring to provide. It is a useful tool for informing residents about what they can expect in a facility and for educating new staff members on the nature and type of facilities they have joined.

The charter, along with the proposed agreements, will establish the concept of residents and proprietors being equal partners. The Bill also provides for the adoption of contractual arrangements or agreements between nursing home residents and proprietors, as a condition of funding. The entering into of agreements as a condition of funding has already existed in hostels since January this year and this Bill will simply extend the arrangements to nursing homes. The implementation of a standard residents' agreement between nursing home and hostel residents and proprietors is considered essential. The residents' rights report stated that, currently, entering into formal legal arrangements between residents and management is not a common practice. This means that neither party has a clear definition of their full rights and responsibilities towards the other party and there are no clearly defined paths to protect those rights and responsibilities.

The Bill also provides for situations where the resident either does not wish to enter, or is not capable of entering, into an agreement or is not able to be represented by either a guardian or person holding power of attorney. This is particularly relevant in nursing homes where a significant proportion of residents are unable to manage their own affairs as a result of dementia or similar conditions. These residents are entitled to the same consideration as others, and the Bill provides for them to be cared for in the same manner as those residents for whom there is an agreement in place between a resident and the proprietor. In situations where there is no agreement between a resident and the proprietor, the proprietor will be required to comply with conditions set down by the Minister in a notice in writing. The conditions would be consistent with matters covered in the agreement.

While the proposed amendments provide the Minister with the broad power to determine a common or standard form of agreement to be entered into between residents and proprietors, it is envisaged that the agreement will be consistent with the charter and will cover fees and financial information; service provision; security of tenure; participation in decision making, anddispute resolution. The resident and proprietor may add to this if they so wish, so long as the intent of the standard agreement is preserved.

The Bill also proposes amendments to provide Commonwealth officers and other authorised persons with greater access to nursing homes in the performance of their duties. Currently, Commonwealth officers who monitor standards are authorised under section 42 of the Act to enter the premises and access only the documentation related to the operation of the premises as a nursing home. The proposed amendment will extend authorised access by Commonwealth officers to include residents and staff of the nursing home and to documents related to the provision of care. The proposed authorisation does not imply that residents or staff will be coerced into talking with officers but merely enable officers to have access to such people.

The Bill also facilitates access to residents, staff and documents by those Commonwealth officers who review the degree of care required by residents and verify the level of subsidy payable. At present, access for the purposes of review of resident classifications is not guaranteed. Consequently, if a nursing home denied access, no reviews could be undertaken. This means that, potentially, a nursing home could gain excess benefit by classifying its residents into unjustifiably high categories of relative service need but the Department of Community Services and Health would not be able to challenge these classifications. As a key initiative to provide the more isolated residents of nursing homes and hostels with support, advice and links to the external community, the residents' rights report recommended the establishment of a community visitors scheme. Under this scheme, people in the community with spare time and an interest in aged care will visit an allocated nursing home and hostel at least once a month. For this, they are to be paid a special honorarium-$600 per annum based on $50 per monthly visit. The Bill makes provision for the Minister to designate people as community visitors and to describe their role, and also provides them with access to a nursing home and its staff and residents to perform their function. Community visitors will be selected and trained on the basis of the sensitive and critical function they will be required to perform.

Under another initiative, advocacy services are to be established in each State and Territory. Advocates will be employed by appropriate organisations to speak on behalf of residents and uphold their rights and interests in grievance situations. The Bill therefore makes provision for advocates to have access to nursing homes and their residents to perform their function. A further proposed amendment of the Bill is to give the Minister authority to publish information on specific aspects of a nursing home or hostel. The purpose of publication is to assist residents, potential residents and their representatives to select a nursing home or hostel suited to their needs or wishes. The information itself will relate to the quality of life for residents and to details about the fac- ility's location, size, fees and method of operation. The information relating to residents' quality of life will be based on compliance with standards determined by the Minister. This information will assist intending residents to become aware of the quality and level of support available, will allow the many good nursing homes and hostels to promote their facilities, and serve as an incentive for the few low standard facilities to provide a better service. The legislation provides a time period for proprietors of facilities to comment on the information prior to its being published and it requires the Minister to change the information before it is published where such comments are considered warranted.

The publication of information about residential aged care facilities is a major step forward in promoting the residents' right to know about the facility they live in, the public's knowledge of the care provided for the older people in their community, and the high quality of care provided by most service providers. As I have shown, the residents' rights amendments go a long way towards enabling the frail aged in nursing homes and hostels to be protected and address the major concerns identified by the residents themselves, namely, those of isolation and boredom; lack of control over their own lives; absence of information about available services; and fear of retribution if a complaint is made.

I would now like to outline various amendments to other provisions relating to the residential aged care program. The Bill also makes the provision of a medical certificate optional rather than mandatory for the purposes of considering an application for nursing home admission. Currently, medical practitioners on geriatric assessment services with the delegation to approve nursing home admissions are required to provide the medical certificate required on the application form, as well as actually approve the application. The Bill will allow these delegates to make decisions on nursing home admissions even though no medical certificate is provided, thereby simplifying procedures for nursing home admission. However, where a certificate is provided, the Bill requires that it be taken into account.

The Bill also allows backdating of approval of a domiciliary nursing care benefit (DNCB) application in certain circumstances. Currently, the date of effect of an approved DNCB application cannot be a date earlier than the date on which the application was received in the Department. A number of applications, for reasons beyond the direct control of otherwise eligible applicants, have been delayed before reaching the Department. These delays have disadvantaged some applicants and have occurred for a variety of reasons. For example, completed applications have been mislaid or delayed by medical practitioners or registered nurses, or completed applications have been lost in the mail. Previously, act of grace payments were made in some of these cases. The amendments in the Bill will allow for processing in these circumstances. It is intended that, prior to any decision to backdate an application, supporting statements from the doctor and the nurse will be required, indicating that they had completed the requisite certifications and advising the date or dates on which this occurred.

The Bill also provides for the Minister to approve a person as an approved operator of a nursing home for the purposes of receiving Commonwealth payments under the National Health Act 1953. The Bill also provides for the Minister to revoke approvals. These powers are considered necessary by the Government because of the nature and vulnerability of aged persons. In addition, under residents' rights proposals in the Bill, residents will be entering into contracts with proprietors, who must be acceptable for the purpose of operating a nursing home. Further, the amending legislation will assist in removing underlying concerns about some care providers, particularly former proprietors who, having previously treated residents poorly and failed to meet the required care standards or engaged in fraudulent practices, are now seeking to return to the industry, for example by purchasing an existing approved nursing home. Present Commonwealth approval controls do not provide adequate cover in circumstances involving sale and purchase of nursing homes. The powers provided in this Bill will ensure that Commonwealth funding approvals are granted to persons who will properly meet the responsibility for the care and accommodation of an extremely vulnerable group of people.

The Bill also provides for the Minister, when approving a person as an approved nursing home operator or revoking such approval, to have regard to principles. These principles, which will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny, will cover such matters as the character and reputation of the person; the ability, willingness and expertise of the person to provide adequate nursing home care and meet the special care needs of nursing home residents; the ability to effectively financially manage a nursing home; and the capacity and willingness of the person to comply with conditions of approval of a nursing home for Commonwealth funding. It is provided in the Bill that a person who is dissatisfied with a decision to refuse or revoke approval may seek a review of a decision through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Bill provides for existing proprietors of approved nursing homes and persons who have been granted approval-in-principle to construct a new nursing home or transfer nursing home beds, to become approved operators automatically under the legislation. Such approvals are, of course, subject to the revocation of approvals provisions if a person was found to be unsuitable to be a proprietor.

The Nursing Homes Assistance Act and the common form of agreement authorised by that Act permit proprietors of former deficit financed nursing homes to request the Minister to review the approved budget and operating deficit of a home for a period ending before 30 June 1987. The legislation requires the request in the first instance to be investigated by a nursing homes advisory committee. These committees are established in each State to assist the Minister's investigations by providing a detailed professional and independent review of departmental decisions where proprietors are unable to reach agreement with the Minister's delegate on the levels of approved budgets and deficits.

The Government has become concerned at the escalation in the number of requests for review received since 1 July 1987, the date from which the Government's aged care reforms were introduced. The industry has indicated that the increase in the number of requests is largely an orchestrated form of protest against aspects of the nursing home reforms. The National Health Act was amended last year to introduce lodgment and processing fees for requests by proprietors to review nursing home fee decisions. The provisions of this Bill remove the current inconsistency between the Nursing Homes Assistance Act and the National Health Act in this regard. The process of review is a thorough one involving the gathering and analysis of complex information. The length of time for each review varies but on average consumes almost 100 hours of Public Service time. In the past, the cost of a review, estimated at about $4,000, has been met entirely by taxpayers.

There is a statutory obligation on the Minister to consider these requests for review. However, it is difficult to distinguish between protest or vexatious appeals and those which are genuine. It is in the interests of the taxpayer and nursing home proprietors with genuine grievances to free up the nursing homes review mechanisms by ensuring that only those cases which are genuine become the subject of review and that those appeals are expeditiously handled. There is a further need to prevent the situation from worsening by avoiding future protest or vexatious appeals against fee determinations. The Government considers that the introduction of a lodgment fee of $500, and an additional processing fee of $500 for each half-day a committee meets to consider an appeal, will achieve those objectives. Administration of these arrangements will be facilitated by fees being deducted from payments due to a nursing home proprietor under the common form of agreement or under the National Health Act 1953 on authorisation by the proprietor. To safeguard the position of genuine appellants both lodgment and processing fees will be refunded in full where a request for review is wholly or substantially successful. Provision is also made for the lodgment fee to be refunded in full to a proprietor who withdraws a request within 84 days following a decision.

The Bill also provides some essentially administrative amendments to the National Health Act 1953 which are consequential to the National Health (Nursing Home Respite Care) Regulations. Taken together, these amendments remove the distinction between approvals for short term respite care admission and general nursing home admission. This distinction is no longer necessary since the gazettal of these regulations has removed the need for a separate type of approval for short term respite care. The amendments will tidy up the Act and will remove the possibility of confusion. All approvals for admission to a nursing home, including for short term respite care, now will be made under the same section of the Act.

I turn now to the amendments to the First Home Owners Act 1983. The Government has been concerned that whilst Australian-born citizens are ineligible for the first homes owners scheme if they have previously owned a home in Australia, migrants and also Australian citizens who have owned a home overseas are treated more favourably as any previous overseas home ownership is disregarded. For obvious reasons, it is not practicable to attempt to test for previous ownership overseas. Further, there are difficulties in applying the scheme's income test equitably as between long term residents and those acquiring a home before they have been here for a full year. Clearly, those with sufficient means or prospects to be able to embark upon home ownership soon after arrival are in an already strong position and stand less in need of assistance from the taxpayer. Accordingly, the proposed amendment requires at least one person involved in each application for assistance under the Act to have had his or her principal place of residence in Australia during the period of 12 months immediately preceding the date of home acquisition.

Another amendment to that Act provides for a child under the age of 18 at the date of home acquisition, or a child born during the period commencing on that date and ending at the expiration of the first anniversary of that date, to be treated as a dependent child of an applicant for the purposes of the Act. Additionally, the child must be in the custody, care and control of, and ordinarily residing with an applicant for assistance under the Act at any time during the outlined period. The amendment will simplify administration of the Act as the existing references to the Social Security Act are to be deleted in favour of a test administered by the Department. The last proposed amendment will overcome anomalies in the existing legislation which result in disadvantage to certain persons who purchase their homes under a terms purchase contract.

The Bill also includes amendments to the definitions of proprietor of a laboratory in section 3 (1) and officer of the Health Insurance Commission in sections 3 (1), 23dk (3) and 129aac of the Health Insurance Act 1973. In 1987, new pathology arrangements were introduced to bring into effect a greater degree of accountability of persons providing pathology services by requiring that approved pathology authorities (APA) undertake to maintain certain standards. A failure to maintain those standards results in the possible revocation of the undertaking and the loss of eligibility for Medicare benefits for the services rendered in the APA's laboratory.

It has become apparent that the corporate structure of some providers of pathology services makes it difficult to identify the actual operator of the services. The new definition of proprietor of a laboratory in section 3 (1) of the Health Insurance Act will mean that Medicare benefits will not be payable in respect of services rendered in an accredited pathology laboratory unless there is at least one proprietor who has effective control over the staffing, equipment and the premises of the laboratory.

The Health Insurance Act confers upon officers of the Health Insurance Commission a number of powers and duties in relation to the Medicare program. Legal opinion is that the definitions as they stand could be interpreted to mean the persons actually holding office under the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, that is, the members or commissioners and the general manager. This is plainly not the intention of the original provisions. The proposed amendment to section 3 (1) of the Health Insurance Act more clearly defines officer to specifically represent members of the staff of the Commission.

Section 23dk (3) of the Health Insurance Act requires an approved pathology practitioner to produce to an officer of the Commissioner a written confirmation concerning a pathology service. It is not intended that all officers of the Commission should have this power, as would be conferred by the proposed amendment to section 3 (1), but to confine it to the general manager.

The proposed amendment to section 129aac is intended to give added confidence to medical providers at formal counselling sessions by limiting the applicability of the section to officers of the Commission who are either medical practitioners, dental practitioners or optometrists. This Bill will also insert a new clause which will restrict entitlement to Medicare benefits to those diplomatic representatives, their staff and families of countries whose governments have an agreement with Australia under section 7 of the Health Insurance Act which specifically entitles diplomatic and consular staff and their families access to the health care system of the host country. This amendment removes the anomaly whereby in the current Act the inclusion of `eligible overseas representatives' in the definition of `eligible person' ensures that foreign diplomatic representatives and their staff are entitled to Medicare benefits while in Australia whereas Australia's diplomatic representatives in the other country concerned may not be entitled to reciprocal health care privileges.

The proposed amendments to section 3h of the Health Insurance Act relate to administration of the vocational register of general practitioners. The amendments will require the exercise of ministerial power under that section by regulation, not determination. The changes are in accordance with the commitment made to the Senate on 30 August, and again in the subsequent debate on 7 September, to make this change to the legislation `at the earliest possible opportunity'. (Extension of time granted) The proposal is consistent with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance and will provide for greater parliamentary scrutiny.

The Bill also extends the benefits of a health care card, and thus pharmaceutical benefits at the concessional rate of $2.50, to those persons in receipt of a formal training allowance. This amendment simplifies the administration of the formal training allowance scheme and gives those persons the same entitlement as those receiving either unemployment benefits or a job search allowance. This provision is to apply retrospectively so as not to disadvantage persons receiving this allowance since its commencement in July last year.

Two clauses in this Bill provide for the linking of the relevant secrecy provisions of the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act. These amendments will improve the administration and effectiveness of both the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and Medicare, particularly in the area of overuse and abuse. Officers of the Health Insurance Commission will of course continue to be subject to the secrecy provisions of these Acts.

This Bill also makes a technical amendment to the provisions of the National Health Act that relates to the special patient contribution arrangements under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. There are at present only two drugs subject to this provision, which allows for the payment of an additional charge by the patient when the drug's manufacturer disputes the price determined by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority. Under the present arrangements, if a prescription for any quantity other than the maximum quantity, or a multiple of this quantity, is written the patient has to pay a full special patient contribution. This amendment provides a simple formula for the calculation of a pro rata special patient contribution for any quantity of the drug prescribed by the doctor and thus provides a more equitable method for calculating the special patient contribution in all cases.

The Bill will correct an anomaly in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Under the National Health Act at present, when a prescription is written for a patient who is entitled to free or concessional pharmaceutical benefits the patient must establish to the satisfaction of the pharmacist supplying the drug that he or she is entitled to that benefit by recording the card number on the prescription. This information may of course be recorded by the patient or any other person, including the pharmacist, acting as an agent for the patient. Situations arise where persons fail to establish their eligibility status at the time of supply for a variety of reasons. Sometimes this failure arises not through oversight or carelessness on the part of the person or the agent. It could be caused by an error in the pharmacy or private hospital or because the person involved was admitted in an unconscious state or was suffering from an illness which impaired his or her abilities. It is thought that in these circumstances it would be unjust not to allow for such persons to be retrospectively accorded their correct status and expenses incurred would be correspondingly reduced as a consequence.
There is currently no provision in the National Health Act for such an adjustment to be made. This proposed amendment to the Act provides for such an adjustment on the following conditions:
That whether such an adjustment would be allowed would be at the discretion of the Secretary to the Department; and

That this discretion will be exercised only in relation to cases where the claimant can provide satisfactory evidence that he or she had paid for a pharmaceutical benefit at a level above that appropriate to his or her eligibility status and that this event occurred in circumstances beyond his or her control or that of the agent and was not due to their oversight or other avoidable circumstance.

The arrangements for residents' rights, consequential upon amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 and the National Health Act 1953, are expected to cost an estimated $0.89m in 1989-90, $1.58m in 1990-91 and $1.75m in 1991-92. Expenditures would be incurred in relation to honoraria payable to community visitors' costs relating to the preparation of statements on standards and funding for advocacy services. Consequent upon the amendment to subsection 58e (6) of the National Health Act 1953 there may be a small additional cost estimated at $10,000 in 1989-90 and $20,000 annually thereafter arising from domiciliary nursing care benefits being payable from a date earlier than the date of receipt of the application to eligible applicants whose applications have been lost or delayed through no fault of the applicants. These payments are no more than those to which the applicants are entitled under the eligibility criteria in the existing legislation.

Consequent upon the amendment to the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974, the proposed lodgment fee of $500 and an additional processing fee of $500 per half day will yield revenue estimated at $45,000 in 1989-90, with anticipated revenue of $20,000 and $5,000 in 1990-91 and 1991-92 respectively. The fees are consistent with existing provisions in the National Health Act 1953 for requests for review of nursing home fees under that legislation and will have a deterrent effect on nursing home proprietors lodging non-genuine appeals. Proprietors who have their appeal wholly or substantially upheld will have their lodgment fee refunded and no processing fee will be applied. The main Commonwealth savings will be in avoiding non-quantifiable additional costs in processing non-genuine review applications.

The amendments to the First Home Owners Act 1983 to impose a 12-month residency requirement for recent arrivals before they can qualify for assistance is expected to result in savings of $2m in 1989-90 and $3m in each of the three subsequent financial years. The remaining amendments to the First Home Owners Act 1983 have no financial impact.

There is no financial impact consequent upon other amendments to the National Health Act 1953, the Health Insurance Act 1973 or the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Amendment Act 1989. The amendments relating to pharmaceutical benefits will not result in any financial outlays.
I commend the Bill to the House. I now present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr McGauran) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is an omnibus Bill amending 15 Acts administered within the transport and communications portfolio. The most significant amendments are to the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 to put in place part of the shipping industry reform package announced by the Government on 1 June 1989. Other significant amendments are made to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 to provide for customs clearance of imported vehicles and to enable the determination of testing and record keeping practices for manufacturers or importers of vehicles. The other amendments are mainly of a minor policy nature or correct deficiencies or errors in current legislation. I will now deal with the amendments in detail.
Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987

The amendments to the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 are to put in place the legislative elements of the Government's contribution to the shipping industry reform package announced on 1 June 1989. The amendments extend the availability of the fiscal benefits under the Act to 30 June 1997 for new ships and make grants payable for modifications to existing ships completed by 30 June 1992 which enable reductions in crew levels. The extension of the fiscal benefits to 1997 will provide Australian ship- owners with a stable fiscal environment in which to invest in new tonnage. Already 25 ships with Maritime Industry Development Committee-type crews have been introduced or ordered for the Australian fleet. This represents one-third of the fleet of major trading ships. The extension of the Act will encourage other shipowners or potential shipowners to invest in more modern tonnage, crewed at levels comparable with those applying on ships of Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development nations using national crews.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments are also to safeguard against excessive grant payments possible under ship financing schemes which inflate the purchase price of ships by including financing costs. These changes were announced on 7 September 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989

The amendments proposed to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act demonstrate the continuing commitment by the Government to maintaining that a high level of safety is met by all road vehicles supplied to the Australian market for the first time. The major amendment provides for a proper link between the Act and the Customs Act to ensure that vehicles are not allowed to enter Australia unless they meet the requirements of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act. It ensures that vehicles subject to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act will not be allowed to enter Australia without the specific approval of the Minister administering the Act. In addition, the amendments provide that determinations relating to the testing of motor vehicles be disallowable instruments, thus providing for proper parliamentary scrutiny. The Bill also contains a number of minor amendments that clarify certain provisions and facilitate administration of the Act.
Air Navigation Act 1920

There have been some doubts expressed that the regulation making power of the Air Navigation Act does not extend to aviation security. These doubts arose following the enactment of the Civil Aviation Act 1988 which provides that the Civil Aviation Authority has responsibility for aviation safety but not for aviation security. Prior to the enactment of the Civil Aviation Act, aviation security was considered to fall within the term `aviation safety'. The amendment to the Air Navigation Act will remove the doubt that regulations relating to aviation security may be made under that Act.
Broadcasting Act

The proposed amendment to section 125d of the Broadcasting Act provides for the introduction of charges for the investigation of interference with the reception of radio and television programs. Under current legislation, the Minister for Transport and Communications has an obligation to investigate and make arrangements to correct interference to broadcasting services. This obligation is currently discharged as a free service by officers of the Department who investigate complaints of reception difficulties.

The requirement was initially introduced because knowledge and understanding of interference effects were seen to have an important input to the service planning process. Because of technological development, the provision of broadcasting services is now much more scientific and predictable and the planning information obtained from investigations is negligible. Also, the service industry is now better educated in ways of overcoming reception problems.

In addition, in recent years, there has been a growing tendency for members of the public to rely on this free service. In the overwhelming majority of cases, the reception problems have been attributed to easily detectable factors such as: deficiencies in the receiving installation-for example, an inadequate antenna or television receiver-people trying to tune to stations where they are well outside the station's service area; or unintended radio frequency emissions from the local electricity authority's reticulation system. These complaints are investigated by departmental officers whereas they could, and should, be handled by complainants themselves, television repair services and electricity authorities. Because departmental officers are not in a position to fix these reception problems, this activity represents a waste of highly skilled technical resources. This unnecessary demand is not only diverting valuable technical resources away from other important spectrum management and broadcasting planning functions, but it is also inhibiting the Department's ability to provide timely assistance to people with cases of genuine interference.

It is proposed, through appropriate consumer education, to encourage the public to make their own assessment of any interference problem before calling on the Department for assistance. To assist people to understand what is involved and to know what action is appropriate, a comprehensive information booklet and questionnaire will be sent free to each complainant. Provision will be made for the public to submit, at no charge, the questionnaire without requesting an investigation of their own receiving equipment. By this means the Department will be able to detect and deal with genuine cases of interference, such as those affecting a local community.

The Department will also provide an improved telephone advisory service to help residents deal with general queries and any difficulties that the local repair services or electricity authority cannot resolve. A call-out charge will apply only subject to guidelines and criteria developed by the Minister for Transport and Communications. Until the criteria are developed and approved, charges will not be applied. I wish to emphasise that it is not proposed to terminate the Department's interference investigation service. On the contrary, departmental officers will continue to investigate all cases of interference to radiocommunications services, as well as genuine interference problems involving broadcasting services. This initiative is in accordance with current Government policy to encourage a more efficient and effective public service and will result in a quicker and better service to all users of the radio frequency spectrum.
Interstate Road Transport Act 1985

The Bill also amends the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 in three respects. Firstly, to allow State and Territory regulatory authorities to link the prescribed fees that are payable to the consumer price index. These fees are payable to State or Territory regulatory authorities where they perform a registration function on behalf of the Common- wealth. Secondly, another amendment will strengthen the prosecution provision of the Act by ensuring that corporations, and their directors, agents and employees are subject to adequate sanctions where an offence is committed under the Act. Finally, further amendment will allow on-the-spot fines for mass limit-overloading-offences as an alternative to prosecution to reduce the administrative burden placed on the court system.
Navigation Act

The Bill will make several amendments to the Navigation Act 1912. Two of the amendments implement changes agreed with the States and the Northern Territory on jurisdiction over maritime matters. The first will allow a trading ship under State-Territory jurisdiction to be brought under Federal jurisdiction should its owner wish it. This will be of particular value to the owner of a ship that operates a mixture of intrastate and interstate voyages-the ship will not have to move backwards and forwards between jurisdictions according to the particular voyage it is on. The procedure already works well with offshore industry support vessels. The second will implement revised, more flexible, arrangements on jurisdiction for enforcement of collision regulations.

The Marine Council is empowered to determine that the character or conduct of a person is such that the person is unsuitable for engagement as a seafarer. Such a determination is subject to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal but as the Act currently stands, the lodgment of an appeal automatically defers operation of the determination. This automatic deferral is to be removed and deferral to be left in the hands of the Tribunal according to the facts of the individual case. The current provisions relating to courts of marine inquiry are to be replaced by a more modern and flexible system of casualty investigation. The Bill will provide for the necessary power for this to be done in the regulations. Finally, the various statutory committees provided for in the Navigation Act are to be rationalised by combining the various functions, such as that carried out by the crew accommodation committee, into the Marine Council.
Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983

The Bill corrects a drafting deficiency relating to the discharge of garbage from ships in the vicinity of offshore platforms and will enable Australian ratification of Annex v of the International Convention for Prevention of Pollution from Ships.
Telecommunications and Postal Legislation

The Bill makes minor amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1989 and miscellaneous telecommunications and postal legislation to correct drafting errors. The most significant of these amendments will ensure that the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation is able to continue to supply basic telecommunications services between external territories and other places within Australia. This amendment does not preclude Telecom Australia from continuing to supply these same services. Another amendment will extend an existing provision preventing the sale without notice of equipment for which there is no permit to the supply of such equipment otherwise than by sale, such as by lease.
Other Portfolio Legislation

The Bill also makes minor technical amendments to the Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Act 1988 and the Navigation Amendment Act 1980. All amendments are revenue-neutral except the amendments to the Broadcasting Act 1942 and the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987. In relation to the amendments to the Broadcasting Act 1942, the estimated cost of setting up a charging scheme for the investigation of interference to the reception of radio and television programs is $100,000. The estimated net savings in the financial year 1989-90 will be approximately $350,000.

In respect of the amendments to the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987, the extension of the grants scheme to 1997 is expected to involve a net cost to revenue of $52m. Savings in the form of increased industry efficiency of $80m will accrue to industry over the three years from 1989 and annual savings of $50m are expected thereafter. The cost to revenue of the grants for modification is expected to be about $2.4m. The savings from the amendment to prevent excessive claims is estimated at $13m.
I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sharp) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1989 amends the taxation laws in a number of respects. It contains the measures announced in the 1989-90 Budget for a new tax collection system for companies, complying superannuation funds, complying approved deposits funds and pooled superannuation trusts, in conjunction with a move to full self-assessment. The changes also apply to trustees of unit trusts that are taxed as companies. Other Budget announcements that the Bill deals with extend income tax deductions for fees paid to professional tax advisers and for deductions incurred by life assurance companies in gaining the investment component of certain premium income. Another Budget measure recognises the nature of certain share-based financing arrangements as loans rather than as equity investments for tax purposes. The Bill also proposes amendments on the subjects of superannuation tax, approved deposits funds, the gift provisions and the prescribed payment system. Minor amendments as a consequence of earlier changes to the Social Security Act, and of the reduction in the top marginal rate of personal income tax on 1 January 1990, are also included.

Since the Budget, detailed consideration has been given to the most appropriate arrangements for the new payment of tax by companies and superannuation funds. In this process, the Government has considered representations from many sources, and discussions have been held with professional bodies. In the light of these further deliberations, the details of the system that I will shortly describe differ in several respects from those outlined in the Budget Paper. These differences address concerns expressed about the original proposal. I turn now to the details.
Collection of Tax

The new system will first apply to assessments in respect of income of the year of income ending on 30 June 1990. An initial payment of tax is to be due by the fifteenth day of the first month after the end of the income year-generally 15 July-equal to 85 per cent of the notional tax amount; that is, broadly, the tax payable on income of the preceding year at the current year rate, or 85 per cent of the taxpayer's estimate of the actual tax liability. Payment of the balance of tax due for the relevant year is to be made by the fifteenth day of the ninth month after the end of that year-generally 15 March. For early balancing companies and funds, payments are to be due on equivalent dates after the end of the substituted accounting period, but no initial payment will be due earlier than 15 January following the end of an accounting period. There will be no liability to make an initial payment of tax where the notional tax or estimated total tax is less than $1,000. Companies and funds in this situation will pay their total tax liability by the fifteenth day of the ninth month following the end of the income year, or substituted accounting period of early balancers.

Following the deliberations I referred to, the Government has decided to extend these collection arrangements to non-complying superannuation and approved deposit funds and to modify them in two significant ways. Firstly, late balancing companies and funds will be placed on the same relative footing as all other entities that are subject to the measures. Specifically, the dates for their initial and final payments of tax will now be determined on the basis of their substituted accounting period, but in all cases final payment being required not later than 15 June of the year of payment. The second major change benefits companies and funds with a notional tax in the range of $1,000 to $20,000, or that have a notional tax of $20,000 or more but estimate their actual liability to be within that range. They will be given an option either to make two payments under the arrangements announced, or to pay their total liability on the fifteenth day of the sixth month after the year of income, or substituted accounting period. The gain to revenue from the new system of collecting tax is estimated at $880m in 1989-90 and $150m in 1990-91.
Self-Assessment

Under self-assessment of income tax returns, which has operated since 1986, taxpayers lodge a return which is not generally subject to technical scrutiny and determine their taxable income. The Commissioner of Taxation calculates the tax payable and issues an assessment. The changes announced in the Budget merely take the present arrangements one step further for companies and funds under the new collection arrangements. These entities will calculate their own tax payable and pay this amount to the Commissioner, in an instalment, if applicable, and a balancing payment with their return of income. An assessment, which will retain all existing rights of objection or appeal, will be deemed to be made on the day the return is lodged. To facilitate this change, the Bill makes provision for the self-determination of foreign tax credits, and the offset of franking deficit tax against company tax liability. These are not significant changes to the existing self-assessment system, but they do present an opportunity for other major improvements, to which I now turn.
Amendment of Assessments

In debate over self-assessment, calls have been made for a review of the concept of `full and true disclosure' which exists in the present rules for amendment of assessments. The Government accepts that this concept has reduced relevance in the context of a system of self-assessment, and has decided to remove it from the amendment rules for all taxpayers. The Bill will give effect to this decision and will alter to four years in all cases the limitation period applying generally to amendments increasing a taxpayer's liability, other than in cases of fraud or evasion or other special provisions where the right to amend at any time is retained. The Commissioner will be able to seek an extension of this new four-year statutory limit from the Federal Court of Australia, or by agreement of the taxpayer. Consistent with this change, the period in which an amendment may be made to reduce a taxpayer's liability is to be increased from three to four years.
Keeping of Records

In line with the changes to the time limits for amending assessments, records relating to tax information will be required to be kept for only five years, instead of the present seven years. This period will be extended where the period for amendment is extended by the Court or under agreement with the taxpayer. The rules for the keeping of records are also being modified to require companies and funds subject to the new collection and self-assessment arrangements to retain for subsequent review documents used to calculate their taxable income and tax payable that they do not have to provide in simplified returns.
Other Changes

Some related matters raised by the new system are under review. Of particular importance are reviews being undertaken by the Commissioner of Taxation in relation to the information currently required to be furnished with returns generally, the tax agents' lodgment program, and the operation of present arrangements for the remission of penalties. Under existing arrangements, a taxpayer in doubt about the proper tax treatment of a particular matter may request advice from the Commissioner. The Commissioner is also reviewing the question of providing an avenue-by means of the remission of interest payable where an assessment is amended-to encourage entities subject to the new self-assessment system to lodge these requests ahead of their returns, and will release further information on this matter as soon as possible. Some other issues which have been raised in the context of self-assessment are nearing settlement. Honourable members will be aware that the professional bodies have been working closely with the Commissioner on audit guidelines and an access to accountants' audit papers. The Commissioner expects these guidelines to be released soon.
Tax Advice

Hand in hand with these arrangements goes the Budget proposal to allow tax deductability for the management and administration of a taxpayer's income tax affairs, which also will be given effect in this Bill. Examples of expenditure that will be an allowable deduction are fees paid to a recognised professional tax adviser for income tax advice, costs of disputing an assessment such as tribunal fees and court costs, and costs associated with an audit of a taxpayer's affairs by the Taxation Office.

Deductions will not be allowed for capital expenditure but depreciation of items, such as a computer, used in connection with the management or administration of a taxpayer's income tax affairs will be allowable. No deduction will be allowed for expenditure incurred in relation to an offence under a law of the Commonwealth, a State or Territory or a foreign country.

A related amendment will permit taxpayers to have amounts paid for professional advice concerning the impact of taxes on the acquisition or disposal of an asset included in the cost base used to calculate the taxpayer's capital gain or loss on the asset. These changes will apply to expenditure incurred on or after 1 July 1989 and the cost to revenue is estimated to be $40m per annum, commencing in 1990-91.
Life Assurance Companies

As announced in the Budget life assurance companies are to be allowed a taxation deduction for expenditure incurred on or after 1 January 1990 in gaining the investment component of life insurance premium income. This measure will put life assurance companies on an equal footing with other investment mediums but it does not extend to friendly societies and other registered organisations which benefit from a lower tax rate. The revenue costs of this proposal are estimated at $30m in 1991-92 and $125m in 1992-93.
Share-Based Financing Arrangements

Share-based financing arrangements entered into to obtain finance are more appropriately regarded as lending arrangements than as investments of share capital. It follows that dividends paid under such arrangements ought to be treated in an equivalent manner to payments of interest on loans. Consistent with that concept, and as announced in the Budget, the dividend imputation system is to be modified so that all dividends paid in respect of shares issued under share-based financing arrangements carry no entitlement to imputation credits or the intercorporate dividend rebate. This measure will apply to dividends paid on shares issued on or after 16 August 1989 or under finance arrangements entered into on or after that date, and will prevent losses of revenue the potential size of which cannot be quantified but could have become substantial.
Tax Exemptions for Approved Deposit Funds

The Bill also gives effect to a measure, announced on 26 June 1989, to enable more people to take advantage of the special tax exemption given to qualifying fixed interest approved deposit funds under the May 1988 changes to the tax arrangements for superannuation. The amount of exempt income of a qualifying approved deposit fund is calculated by reference to balances that remain from time to time of amounts that were on deposit for eligible depositors at 25 May 1988. To assist people who may have withdrawn amounts from an approved deposit fund after 25 May 1988 before the special exemption was announced, the existing law treats withdrawn amounts that were redeposited in the same approved deposit fund before 1 July 1989 as though they were on deposit on 25 May 1988. An amendment in this Bill extends the 1 July 1989 deadline for redepositing such moneys to 1 September 1989. As details of people who took advantage of this extension are unavailable it is not possible to estimate the revenue effect of this measure.
Taxable Contributions to Superannuation Funds

The Bill will also correct a technical deficiency in the superannuation tax provisions. The amendment, announced on 16 October 1989, will ensure that fully funded complying superannuation funds cannot avoid tax on contributions by exploiting the tax exemption intended to cover cases where an employer does not fund benefits until retirement. Under the exemption, the fund is not assessed on the contributions and the benefits paid are treated as `untaxed' benefits and subject to a higher rate of tax. This aspect of the law was drawn to the Government's attention because of concerns at the potential effect on the superannuation industry. The intention of the law in this area has always been clear, and the amendment to the Bill is therefore to apply from the commencement of the new arrangement for superannuation funds on 1 July 1988.
Gifts

An amendment to the gift provisions of the income tax law is proposed by the Bill to allow gifts of the value of $2 or more made on or after 7 April 1989 to funds that provide money for the acquisition, construction or maintenance of hostels for school students from rural areas. The proposal is part of the Government's $637m education and training strategy for rural Australia announced in April by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). The revenue cost of the proposal is estimated to be less than $500,000 in a full financial year.
Owner Builders

Finally, the Bill will modify the prescribed payment system provisions of the law to ensure that a householder will not be treated as an owner-builder if the actual work on a major part of a domestic construction project is actually carried out by a builder or by others on his or her part.
I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sharp) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I am pleased to introduce this Bill, which will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of comprehensive double taxation agreements between Australia and Papua New Guinea, and Australia and Thailand. The Bill will also provide legislative authority for the entry into force of protocols to amend Australia's existing comprehensive double taxation agreements with France and Singapore.

The Papua New Guinea and Thailand agreements, which were signed on 24 May 1989 and 31 August 1989 respectively, deal with all substantial forms of income flowing between Australia and the other two countries. The agreements substantially accord with other comprehensive taxation agreements concluded by Australia in recent years. The Government believes the agreements will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade, investment, and wider relationships between Australia and these two countries.

A feature of the agreements is that they each provide for tax sparing credit relief to be extended by Australia for `tax forgone' by Papua New Guinea and Thailand under specified development incentives for the encouragement of foreign investment. Where income derived by an Australian resident taxpayer has benefited from one of the nominated development incentives, each agreement calls for the tax credit to be allowed by Australia to include the foreign tax forgone. By this means, the development incentives will retain their attractions for Australian investors and allow them to compete on favourable terms with investors from other countries as they will not be negated by the imposition of Australian tax. I note here that the agreements were negotiated on the basis of the existing income tax laws of the respective countries.

The Government recognises that aspects of proposed changes to Australia's general foreign tax credit system, which have been foreshadowed as applying from the beginning of the 1990-91 income year, could affect the practical operation of the tax credit provisions of the agreements, including the tax sparing mechanism. For example, proposed income tax exemptions under our domestic law for certain dividend payments and branch profits derived by Australian companies from comparable tax countries are likely to provide at least as great relief from Australian tax, and would operate in relation to such income from foreign countries including those with which tax treaties have been concluded.

The protocols to Australia's double taxation agreements with France and Singapore will amend these agreements in a number of respects in relation to the prevention of double taxation and the removal of possible avenues of tax avoidance. The protocols will generally update those agreements in line with Australia's more recently concluded comprehensive tax treaties. The French protocol, signed on 19 June 1989, will amend the agreement to provide that government service pensions will only be taxed by the country paying the pension, except where the recipient is a citizen or national of the other country. As announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) when the protocol was signed, this measure will partially restore an arrangement previously applicable under the French agreement for retirement pensions derived before 1 July 1987. It will have effect in relation to government source pensions derived from that date.

Other pensions will continue to be taxable only in the country of residence of the recipient. As a related measure, the protocol allows contributions to a recognised pension fund in one country to qualify for a purchase price offset against pension income that is taxed in the other country. Of other measures of some significance, one will assist each country to apply its current domestic law provisions relating to international profit shifting arrangements and another will bring the definition of royalties more into line with Australia's income tax law and modern comprehensive taxation agreements.

The Singapore protocol was signed on 16 October 1989. It will operate to delete a provision of the existing agreement with Singapore under which Australia is required to provide a rebate of tax for dividends paid to a resident Australian company by a Singapore company in which the Australian company has at least a 10 per cent interest. That provision is incompatible with Australia's general income tax law now that the intercorporate dividend rebate in relation to foreign dividends derived by an Australian company has been withdrawn. The deletion of that provision will be effective in respect of dividends paid after 11 March 1988, being the date of an announcement by the Treasurer which foreshadowed this change.

Another measure gives tax sparing relief for income which Singapore exempts, or taxes at a reduced rate, under special incentive measures to promote economic development in Singapore. An exchange of notes which took place at the time the protocol was signed will extend to 30 June 1987 the operation of earlier tax sparing provisions in the agreement with Singapore, after which the amendments contained in the protocol will bring new tax sparing arrangements into operation in relation to certain designated development incentives currently provided by Singapore.

Other amendments to be made by the protocol will modify the existing agreement in relation to taxing rights over royalties, business profits, dealings between associated enterprises, airline and shipping profits, and income or gains from property. Each of the agreements and protocols will enter into force when all necessary constitutional processes are completed both by Australia and the other contracting countries. The enactment of this Bill will complete the processes required of Australia. The agreements and protocols will help facilitate trading relationships with the other countries but it is not possible to predict the eventual effect on the revenue. I table the explanatory memorandum on the Bill, and I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sharp) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

As foreshadowed in the Budget, this Bill is to establish the Industry Commission. The Bill sets out the scope of the Commission, its functions and policy guidelines, the constraints on government changes to industry assistance without a Commission report, and composition and procedures. It also proposes repeal and transition provisions with respect to the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 and the Inter-State Commission Act 1975.

On Budget night, the Government announced that the Industries Assistance Commission is to be restructured and renamed the Industry Commission, which will become the Government's major review and inquiry body in industry matters. Since that time, the Government has attached a high priority to the introduction of legislation enabling the establishment of the Industry Commission. That priority has reflected the Government's assessment of the need to continue the process of structural reform in this nation. The Industry Commission will be central to that. Through its advice to the Government, the Industry Commission will play a key role in helping industry to become more efficient, more productive and more internationally competitive. And that is central to ensuring better growth prospects and better economic conditions in this nation over the years and decades ahead. Promoting efficiency is about promoting a better economic environment where growth and employment can be sustained.

Since coming to office, this Government has undertaken structural reform over a wide area of industry and business activity. Too quickly, people forget the fundamental nature of the financial market deregulation-including the freeing-up of capital movements and the floating of the exchange rate-that has fully brought Australia into the international economy. As a result, Australian industry has been forced to face squarely the imperatives of doing business in an international environment-and it is only in that environment that Australia will be able to provide the basis for sustained and rising living standards. Structural reform has also been embodied in the fundamental reviews of taxation announced in 1985 and since. We have moved to a situation where Australia has a fairer and more efficient taxation system. That has been conducive to creation of a healthier business environment where firms and individuals are rewarded more for enterprise and hard work and less for their ability to secure unfair advantages through a distorted tax regime. Equally, the Government has instituted major programs of reductions in tariff and other assistance to industries.

As announced in May 1988, tariff protection is being progressively reduced, bringing Australia more into line with the sort of competitive pressures that our trading partners face. More recently, the Government has begun a process of major reform on the waterfront. This will be, of course, a progressive process, building on the understanding already achieved, and which will continue to draw on the commitment and patience of all relevant parties. In stark contrast, our predecessors were too apt to put the problem in the too hard basket. The reforms of the waterfront and coastal shipping will provide a sound basis for achieving greater efficiencies in the movement and distribution of our goods. Employment prospects at large will be enhanced as the benefits of that greater efficiency flow through the economy.

Moreover, the Government has not shied away from the fundamental reforms required in the labour market. Together with the trade union movement and employers, the Government is working towards the development of a system that will promote greater productivity and modernisation of labour and management practices. That reform has gone hand in hand with seeking moderation in wages growth consistent with the requirements of the macro-economic situation. Substantial employment growth in the economy has already been achieved. These labour reforms offer the prospect of generating still more jobs and, through more productive and competitive industries, creating greater job security in the future.

All these reforms are bringing and will continue to bring real benefits to the Australian economy. They have also been part and parcel of a more sophisticated appreciation in Australia of the economic realities facing this nation. Those realities include the need to be more competitive and the need to be more hard-nosed about the use of Government resources. That debate is to be warmly welcomed-and the establishment of the Industry Commission and the transfer of the functions of the Inter-State Commission to that body will allow the Commonwealth to continue to play its major role in the development of sound industry policy in this nation.

The formation of the Industry Commission represents a new phase in the Government's ongoing strategy of structural adjustment. It is evidence of the Government's commitment to respond to the more sophisticated debate throughout the community on industry development and of the consequent greater requirements for information on policies of industry assistance and development. The Industry Commission will be better placed to participate fully in these developments and we must not waste any time in facilitating that process.

In that regard, the Industry Commission will further the important role that the Industries Assistance Commission has played in the structural adjustment process in Australia. It will build on the Industries Assistance Commission's earlier work which was instrumental in awakening the community to the costs of many industry assistance policies. As an institution, the Industries Assistance Commission has been an important force in economic policy in Australia, building community awareness of the need for Australian industry to be outward looking and internationally competitive. But the Industry Commission will have a broader charter and, with new guidelines attuned to the challenge ahead, will be an important stimulus for reform.

By providing independent and expert advice to the Government and through its public inquiry processes, the Industry Commission will facilitate the ongoing structural change that is needed in the economy. The Industry Commission will work to involve a wide range of groups in its inquiries as part of the process of building community awareness. Consistent with that broader charter, all references on transport matters will in the future be sent to the Industry Commission rather than to the Inter-State Commission. The staff and functions of the Inter-State Commission will be absorbed by the Industry Commission. This is particularly timely. We are all fully aware of the need to continue to address vigorously the transport issues confronting Australia. They go right to the heart of the question of how we in Australia can move our goods across vast distances at the lowest cost with due regard to the broader needs of safety and possible alternative uses of existing transport systems.

The Inter-State Commission has been at the forefront of inquiry and analysis of transport issues. It has been a dispassionate, objective and expert source of analysis in this area and has established a high quality network on transport issues which can be integrated into the Industry Commission. That expertise and experience must be fully brought to bear in the broader charter of the Industry Commission. In this enlarged body, the resources of the Inter-State Commission will have a key role in the identification and analysis of the interrelationships between all sectors of the economy and the transport sector. The ISC's expertise needs to be brought out in the wider economic perspective provided by the Industry Commission.

For a start, sound policy development should be based on a full appreciation of the facts. For instance, we should be aware of the extent to which subsidising railways for passenger operation is a cost to the Australian community; and we should be aware of the need to build on the recent reforms in coastal shipping and the need to improve rail freight operations in order to ease the burdens on our roads. All these aspects are interlinked. And that is the essence of what the Industry Commission is about: namely, the identification of economic interrelationships and the specification of the costs and benefits involved in these relationships. It is only with this sort of information that the Commonwealth government-and, indeed, the State governments-can make sensible and considered choices as to future policy, choices that will ensure better and more sustained growth prospects for all Australians.

The Government has also decided to establish an Office of Business Regulation as an administrative unit within the Industry Commission to absorb the functions of the Business Regulation Review Unit. That Office will have a very important role. It will be dealing with matters that go to the heart of productivity in this economy. Inordinate and unnecessary regulation has a cost-just like any other barrier to efficient operation of business-and that cost is ultimately borne by the community.

Impediments to efficient operation of business and industry through regulation require as much attention as impediments flowing from other forms of industry regulation and assistance. It is therefore fully consistent with the charter of the Industry Commission that the functions of the Business Regulation Review Unit should be absorbed into this body. It will, apart from anything else, allow the Business Regulation Review Unit to gain the benefit of the economy-wide perspective that will flow from the broader operations of the Industry Commission.

In all of this, the Government sees the establishment of the Industry Commission as providing an opportunity for a renewed and reinvigorated role for the States in the consideration of industry assistance matters in this nation. The States, of course, have responsibilities in many sectors of the economy-in intrastate transport, port authorities and electricity generation-which can impact significantly on the efficiency and competitiveness of industry. The Government will therefore be looking to cooperate closely with the States in the future on structural reform of the government sector in Australia.

In particular, the Government would welcome the States' positive and full participation in the Industry Commission's process of public inquiries. With that in mind, the Commonwealth will be approaching the States for their assistance in drafting the terms of reference for three inquiries that cover matters relating to State government responsibilities. As announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) earlier this month, those matters relate to railways, the operation of statutory marketing arrangements and the generation and distribution of power. We will be inviting the States' full participation in these and all other relevant inquiries. We trust that the States will grasp the opportunity in using the Industry Commission as a source of analysis and information on matters relating to the Australian economy in general-not just those matters falling within the purview of the Commonwealth Government.

This then is the context. I turn now to the key features of the Bill. It should be noted that the Bill draws largely on the provisions of the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973, but also draws on appropriate provisions of the Inter-State Commission Act 1975. Except for an aspect of the repeal of the ISC Act, the Bill proposes that the commencement date of the Act would be by proclamation, or six months from royal assent, whichever is the sooner.

The definitions clauses include a broad definition of industry, which is intended to reflect the broadened charter for the Commission and the widest possible scope for its inquiries relating to industry. Definitions also include `subject of Commonwealth power' which follows the provisions of the Constitution. This is relevant to the scope of matters on which the Commission can require evidence and information relevant to an inquiry.

The principal functions of the Commission are to hold inquiries and make reports on industry matters referred to it by the Minister. Bearing in mind that the Commission is to contribute to the process of structural change as described generally in policy guidelines for the Commission, the Commission's functions also allow it to do anything incidental to its functions. The Government intends that, as part of analysis and advice on micro-economic reform issues, the Commission will give advice on business regulation, and prepare occasional research and information papers that contribute to enhancing community understanding of issues relating to structural reform.
The Bill sets out general policy guidelines to which the Commission must have regard in the performance of its functions. These are:
to encourage the development and growth of Australian industries that are efficient in their use of resources, self-reliant, enterprising, innovative and internationally competitive;
to facilitate adjustment to structural changes in the economy and to ease social and economic hardships arising from those changes;
to reduce regulation of industry, including regulation by the States and Territories, where this is consistent with the social and economic goals of the Commonwealth Government; and
to recognise the interests of industries, consumers, and of the community likely to be affected by measures proposed by the Commission.

The Commission must also have regard to any other matters notified by the Minister. For example, as in recent inquiries sent to the IAC, the Commission may be asked to have regard to the Government's environmental objectives in relevant inquiries. Reports resulting from an inquiry process will be required to be tabled by the Minister within 25 sitting days after receipt. There is a provision for delay recommended by the Commission; for example, where the Commission is made aware of governmental trade negotiations that might be disturbed by the timing of publication of a report.

The Bill contains provisions similar to those in the current IAC Act which constrain a Commonwealth Minister from taking certain prescribed actions unless a report by the Commission has been received within the previous 12 months. Allowance is made for a delay in the receipt of a Commission report. Prescribed matters follow those in the IAC Act 1973 and concern changes in import duties and restrictions, and changes in financial assistance to an industry for more than two years. Financial assistance and an industry are defined. Exemptions to prescribed matters are also set out. Principally these include:
payments to Commonwealth corporations;
the imposition, increase or reduction of a tax (other than customs duty);
changes in customs duties that are only made to match corresponding changes in excise duties;
maintaining the level of customs duty previously applying where a decision by a tribunal or court on a tariff classification has had the effect of altering the duty;
