the making of a commercial tariff concessional order or a by-law under the Customs Act 1901; and
action concerning international trade agreements and developing country tariff preferences.

The conduct of inquiries into matters referred to the Commission by the Government is intended to provide, as in the Industries Assistance Commission Act, for the fullest possible participation by all interested parties. The Commission is given wide discretion into how inquiries are to be conducted, and will not be overly bound by formal legal procedure, although there are appropriately strong protections and penalties for breaches with respect to a range of inquiry procedures. The Commission will widely publicise the existence and the nature of inquiries.

The Government does not consider it necessary to restrict the flexibility of the Commission by overly prescribing the Commission's procedures. There are therefore no standing provisions requiring draft reports to be prepared pursuant to inquiries, or for the Commission to present a range of options in making recommendations to government. These procedures may be left to the discretion of the Commission, it being understood that, as is the case with the IAC, the Commission will usually produce a draft report pursuant to an inquiry, thereby facilitating community debate, and will usually present a range of options in its recommendations to the Government. The Minister, in referring a matter to the Commission, will be able to require the publication of a draft report or the development of options in any particular case. In order to make clear the Government's intention in respect of these matters, the Government has decided it is worthwhile to bring forward an amendment to the Bill during the course of its consideration to provide explicitly for possible requirement of a draft report and options in recommendations.

The Commission will have powers to obtain relevant information and documents for the purposes of an inquiry and the power to hold hearings, which will be held in public unless confidential material is involved. The Commission will also have power to summon persons to attend hearings and to answer questions or produce documents. The Bill provides that the Commission is not to be given false or misleading evidence or information, and is not to be taken in contempt. In order to contribute to widest possible community debate and understanding of the issues of an inquiry, the Bill provides for documents, statements and submissions received in the course of an inquiry to be made public. Nonetheless, there are provisions for information to be held as confidential where a person objects and the Commission considers the evidence should be protected. The Bill maintains the protection of witnesses to an inquiry, and people making submissions to an inquiry, that are in the IAC Act. In particular, the Bill provides for penalties on persons who prejudice another person's employment because of their participation in an inquiry process. The Bill specifies that the exercise of the Commission's powers for the purposes of an inquiry, for example to obtain information and documents from any person, including a State, is limited to the extent that the subject matter relates to a subject of Commonwealth power. The definition of `subject of Commonwealth power' is given in terms of constitutional provisions.

As for the IAC, the Commission will have a chairperson and from four to eight full time commissioners, these being statutory appointments by the Governor-General for up to five years. To supplement the Commission's resources and expertise from time to time, there is provision for the appointment of associate commissioners by the Minister. There is a range of procedural provisions concerning commissioners, which follow those of the IAC Act and other Acts providing for statutory appointments.

The Bill contains a separate part dealing with repeals and transitional arrangements. The Bill provides for the IAC Act 1973 to be repealed. It also provides for the repeal at the same time of all but specified sections of the ISC Act, which remain as long as there is a holder of the office of Commissioner of the ISC. The Bill makes separate provision for the repeal by separate procla- mation of those remaining parts of the ISC Act relating to commissioners should there no longer be a holder of that office. These repeal provisions are based on advice of the Solicitor-General in order to be consistent with provisions in the Constitution relating to the ISC.

The Bill provides for moneys and staff of the IAC and ISC to be transferred to the Commission. Similarly, current inquiries by the IAC are to be transferred and completed by the Commission. There are provisions protecting the terms and conditions of appointment of ISC and IAC commissioners who become commissioners of the new body. Transitional provisions protecting prior records and witnesses are also included.

Finally, miscellaneous provisions of the Bill include a requirement that the Commission prepares an annual report which is to be tabled within 15 sitting days of its receipt. The annual report is to address the economic performance of industry and the effects of assistance and regulation on industry and on the economy generally. The Government sees this report as an important component of the Commission's role in increasing community understanding of issues concerning structural change. Indeed a key contribution to the transparency of industry policy is to be made by the publication and tabling in Parliament of annual reports of the Commission. With a broader charter, the Commission's annual report will continue and expand the benefits that have flowed from the IAC's annual reports.

Earlier today, the IAC's annual report was tabled. That report ranges widely in its discussion of the benefits of micro-economic reform. It puts forward robust views and analysis of current industry policy issues, including a critique of strategic trade theories. It provides a stocktake of sectoral assistance measures. There have been times when sectional interests, and even governments, have been uncomfortable with the perspective the IAC has brought to structural reform. No doubt this will also be the case with the most recent annual report. It will no doubt continue to be the case with the Industry Commission's annual reports-and it will continue to be an inescapable part of promoting transparency, vigorous community debate and broader understanding of industry issues.

To conclude, the establishment of the Industry Commission represents the Government's continued commitment to that transparency and full community debate in the development of policies relating to industry. The Commission is intended to make a major contribution to further structural reform in Australia. It will be a catalyst for productivity and efficiency gains, and thereby lay the groundwork for income and employment growth and security. It will build on, and broaden, the strengths of the IAC and the ISC which it succeeds.

The Commission's economy-wide perspective, its broad charter and public inquiry process will play a key role in promoting policies at both government and business levels to improve the competitiveness and dynamism of Australian industry. This Bill provides for an effective and broad ranging institution to serve the needs of parliament, the people and government. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sharp) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STAGE 2 DEVELOPMENT, HMAS STIRLING, GARDEN ISLAND, WESTERN AUSTRALIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WEST
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Stage 2 Development, including new Submarine School, HMAS Stirling, Garden Island, Western Australia.

HMAS Stirling is located on Garden Island in Cockburn Sound, about 60 kilometres by road south of Perth. The original development of HMAS Stirling was largely completed in 1978 and the base currently has seven surface ships and one submarine home ported there. It is also a site of the submarine escape training facility, which is one of the most advanced facilities of its type in the world. As part of the Government's commitment to update Australia's defence capability through the establishment of the two-ocean navy concept endorsed in the 1987 defence White Paper, a staged build-up of the facilities at HMAS Stirling is necessary. Two stages of development, between 1989 and the year 2000, are proposed to enhance progressively and expand the operational and support capabilities of the base to provide eventually for about half the Royal Australian Navy's major fleet units being home ported or based at Stirling.

The proposal now before the House is for the stage 2 works covering the base development from 1989 to 1996. The role of HMAS Stirling is to provide maintenance, supply and operational support for ships, as well as port berthing and shipside services. The proposed stage 2 facilities will enhance these services and allow the home porting of additional ships and submarines. This stage 2 proposal consists of over 30 individual projects. These range from additional accommodation and recreational facilities to new workshops' and technical service facilities and wharf facilities.

Included in this proposal is a new submarine school which is required as part of the new submarine project. The school is to be built to train qualified submarine personnel to operate and maintain the fleet of new type 471 submarines. There is insufficient space in the existing Oberon class training school at Sydney's HMAS Platypus and there are operational and training advantages in having the training school near the submarine west coast home port at Stirling. The new submarine school will provide classrooms, simulators and demonstration equipment for 40 staff and from 50 to 120 students undertaking specialist training for up to six months prior to posting to a submarine.
The estimated cost of these proposed stage 2 works, including the new submarine school, is $135.6m at April 1989 prices, which updates to $138.4 at September 1989 prices.

In conjunction with the proposed base expansion further housing will be required. The Defence Housing Authority currently provides 571 houses for naval personnel within the community adjacent to the Stirling base. Expansion of the base will require a further 272 houses by 1994 with another 222 being required by the year 2000. Present strategy of the Defence Housing Authority proposes to meet this need through a mixture of project home construction and spot purchase on the local market.

It is intended that Navy families be integrated to the greatest extent possible within the community at large. The Committee, in its report, has noted the concern expressed by the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses as to provision of community facilities and housing and the Committee suggests that the group be briefed on those issues as soon as possible. This is being arranged.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that mean?
—It means that they will be briefed on what is to happen at Stirling. Can the honourable member not hear me? Can he not read? I gave him a copy of the speech some time ago.
—Order! The Minister will ignore and not invite interjections.

—Let me repeat it. The Committee-that is, the Public Works Committee-in its report, has noted the concern expressed by the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses as to the provision of community facilities and housing for them and suggests-that is, the Committee suggests-that this group be briefed on the issue as soon as possible, and this is being arranged.
—Let me repeat: what does that mean?
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will heed the Chair.

—I have told the honourable member that 272 houses will be acquired close to Stirling to provide housing and facilities for people who will work at this base in future and it is for that reason that the Defence Housing Authority is in existence.

SPEECH.PARA: The project has received clearance under the Environment Protection Act 1974. The Committee, in its report, however, has expressed the belief that, contrary to what occurred on this project, environmental clearance should be completed prior to referral of the project for examination by the Committee. On most projects submitted to the Committee by the Department, the required environmental clearance is obtained prior to referral. There can be occasions when the environmental review process becomes extended and would cause delay to a project if referral were deferred. If that should occur in the future, the matter will be discussed with the Public Works Committee prior to any referral action. I have ordered that that take place.

It is intended that tenders will be called for some components of the stage 2 development immediately following parliamentary approval to proceed. The bulk of the works will be constructed in separate contract packages, with completion of the works due by 1996. Construction of the project will provide full time employment for approximately 120 construction personnel on site plus substantial opportunities for local contracts and material suppliers.

The increased housing that will be required for Navy families, which was just discussed at some length, will provide further economic stimulation within the adjacent suburban communities. As I said earlier, the planned stage 3 development will provide additional facilities to meet the further progressive increase in basing and operations at Stirling between 1996 and the year 2000. I thank the Public Works Committee for its support of this major defence proposal, and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to return to the position that I occupied in 1985 when I responded to the then Minister for Housing and Construction, the present Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), on various motions that came before the House. I appreciate very much the progress that the Minister has made since 1985. I remind him that, in 1985 when I spoke to these motions, I said, first of all, that the private sector should be involved in the design of these various projects. At that time the Minister said that there was no way in the world that he would ever see the private sector involved in the design of those facilities. By the end of 1985 and the early part of 1986, the Minister had come around to that. Then I said to the Minister that he really ought to consider the private sector becoming involved in the construction of those various facilities. He started out by saying that there was no way in the world that he would see the private sector involved in the construction of those works. He came around to that, too.

SPEECH.PARA: I tried to talk to the Minister about contracting out. To start with, the Minister would have nothing to do with contracting out. Recently in this House, the Minister was proudly proclaiming the progress that he had made on the contracting out of government operations. He even has his foot in the door now on privatisation, to which he and his faction are implacably opposed--

TALK.START.PARA: —Get to the point.

—I am on the point of saying that the Government, slowly but surely, is adopting the policies that the Opposition has been proposing since 1985. I am right back on the point. In fact, the Minister is now saying that there is even some chance that he would go along with some marginal degree of privatisation. He has already agreed to that inside the Cabinet. The Minister knows about Cabinet solidarity, but I am not sure that his colleague at the table, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), has entirely got the message yet. The Minister has certainly gone along with the partial privatisation of the Australian Industry Development Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is nice to be back in this position. I hope that it is not too long before our positions at the table are reversed so that I can remind the Minister of the way in which the Opposition has brought him along and remind him of the Opposition's ability to ensure that the direction of policy in this country is dictated by the coalition--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J. D. M. Dobie) Order! I call the honourable member for Deakin to order. Perhaps he might care to get back to the matter before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to respond to the motion by saying that the coalition does not oppose it. We recognise that the Australian Defence Force should have a credible capability on both sides of our continent, that is, both in the Pacific Ocean and in the Indian Ocean. The move that the Minister has foreshadowed to HMAS Stirling needs to be understood in the broader context of Australian defence policy and the chosen method of military strategy. The Opposition acknowledges also that is is an important part of the role of the Defence Force and that it will be necessary to integrate what is happening in Western Australia with what is happening with total Australian Defence Force capabilities for the defence of Australia and its security interests.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) unveiled the coalition's defence policy. Another reason that we support the Minister's proposal is that it is entirely consistent with the coalition's defence policy. We have some problems with what the Government is proposing on defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got problems all right.
—If the Minister thinks we have got problems, what about the Government's problems with the pilots dispute?
—Order!
—The Minister could not even get the words right; he was way off beam.
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will listen to the Chair when it calls for order, and so will the two Ministers sitting on the front bench to my right.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I wonder whether the member could get to the point that he is supposed to be discussing.

—If the Minister had been listening to the Chair, instead of interjecting, he would have heard me ask the honourable member for Deakin to do just that. The Minister will resume his seat and maintain silence.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I point out to you and to the Minister that the Opposition, in not opposing the motion, does so in the context of our reservations about what the Labor Government is doing about Australia's defence, in that the motion is insufficiently related to other arms of policy, particularly foreign affairs, trade and economic policy, which affect significantly our regional relationships. The Government is too complacent about the time scale within which threats could develop, and there is too much emphasis on reaction rather than deterrence. The motion fails to define Australia's role in maintaining peace and stability in the region.

SPEECH.PARA: Although not opposing the motion, I point out that it is inconsistent with major initiatives in the coalition's defence policy, which was launched by my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar today. Firstly, it proposes a new framework for the development and implementation of a national security strategy; secondly, there is a shift in defence strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—You would be well advised to listen to this, because when you are in opposition and we are on the government side-that will not be many months away-you will have to listen to a decent defence policy as distinct from the defence policy--

—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will address his remarks to the Chair, not across the chamber. The remarks were taken by the Chair to refer to him. I ask the honourable member to remain close to the motion before the House.

—In talking to the motion, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am saying that the motion is consistent with our policy, which includes a shift in defence strategy and force structure, to enable a more rapid and flexible response to events occurring at short notice within Australia's territorial boundaries or beyond. That is part of the rationale for having Defence Force capabilities on both sides of the continent. The motion relates, thirdly, to reform of the organisational structure and management processes of the defence organisation; fourthly, to stability in defence funding with maintenance of existing levels of funding in real terms; and, finally, to maintenance of extensive industry participation in defence supply and servicing.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing, I say that the Minister, in referring to consultation with representatives of the defence forces and their families, has completely missed the point in terms of the complete anger and irritation that they feel towards the Government. The Government has concentrated on projects, not people; and on hardware, not the software associated with our Defence Force personnel. I believe that one factor that will lead to the defeat of the Government in the next election is its inability to relate to our Defence Force personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just told you about all the houses that we are going to supply.
—The Minister said that he was--

—Order! There will be no conversation across the table. The honourable member will restrict his remarks to the motion before the House and ignore the interjections from the Minister, who is out of order.
—The coalition does not oppose the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

In moving the motion, I remind the Committee-because of the arrangement with the Opposition, I will need to be brief-that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill have been returned from the Senate. The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) will address the Bills on behalf of the Opposition, in the absence of the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), with whom I discussed the Bills prior to his leaving this place for other duties.

I would like to thank a number of people. I remind the House that it is nearly two years to the day since the legislation was first talked about in this place. I should like to place on the record my thanks to my departmental officers, some of whom are present in the chamber, from the portfolio and from the task force, who have worked tirelessly throughout that two years to bring about this legislation, which will change the shape of administration of Aboriginal affairs in this nation. It will fit in with wishes and desires of Aboriginal and Islander people as expressed in numerous reports over many years. As I said in December 1987, we wanted to get the legislation right. My door has always been open to people who had suggestions to improve the legislation, and the Senate has done just that through a committee review and a series of amendments to which the Government will agree.

We will accept the amendments that have been received from the Senate, but I express publicly my disappointment with one or two amendments-in particular, the amendment in relation to the preamble. History will show that the amendment is wrong and we are making a mistake, or missing an opportunity, but, given the situation in the Senate and the ability for that chamber to frustrate this House, the Government will accept the amendments.

In closing, I wish to say that yesterday we had a debate about people who are not able to defend themselves within the system. Much to-do was made about the rights of individuals who are not able to defend themselves in the chamber when a member of parliament attacks them. The same applies in the Senate. During the debate yesterday my mind floated back over the past two years to the large number of Aboriginal and Islander people who have been attacked under privilege over and over again. When we pick on people-whether they be Aboriginal, Islander, non-Aboriginal or non-Islander-I always remember the point made yesterday when I am on the side of the people who are being attacked. Yesterday no-one spared a single thought for the outrageous and wrongful accusations that have been made against people in the past two years. I do not want to prolong the debate, because I have made the point in earlier debates but it is worth making again.

The legislation will be funded properly by the Government, and if it is funded in the future it will bring about the sorts of changes that Aboriginal people have been seeking from the Government for many years. I commend the amendments from the Senate and commend the legislation to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a few brief comments because we are really debating an issue in its last stages. Some people could say that it is the end of a saga of Australian legislative history because the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) Bill is the second most amended piece of legislation in this Parliament since Federation, and there has been extensive debate about it. In fact, it is the most amended piece of legislation by an opposition in the Parliament's history; so it is a significant piece of legislation. I do not believe that the saga of ATSIC is over by any means. It is unfortunate that we have not been able to come to an agreement as a parliament with regard to the re-organisation and administration of Aboriginal affairs. That is a great pity. It would have been great if there could have been a bipartisan approach to the administration in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to comment on the issues mentioned by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) just now. He commented that many people have been maligned in the debate over the last couple of years. The intention of the Opposition-this was very strictly the case as far as I was concerned-in its attack in the Parliament on the administration of Aboriginal Affairs was always directed to the administration by the Government and not to individual Aboriginal people. Our concern is that the moneys allocated to Aboriginal affairs should reach the people at the grassroots.

Secondly, I will comment about the fact that the Minister pointed out a minute ago that the ATSIC Bill is concerned with giving management to the Aboriginal people and that it is within their desires and wishes. These were the words he used. If one looks back over this period one finds that the head of the Aboriginal Development Commission really left because of this debate over the ATSIC Bill; she disagreed with it. The head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs for most of this period, Charlie Perkins, disagreed with this legislation. Another eminent person, Neville Bonner, also disagreed with it. There is still a large amount of controversy about it, and I believe that it would be wise for the Government not to rush into getting this legislation administratively in place prior to the next Federal election because there is a clear possibility that we will be in government. It is also clear that our intention with regard to the administration of Aboriginal affairs is markedly different from what this legislation proposes.

We have argued our case against this legislation long and hard, rationally, clearly and extensively. We have put forward our reasons opposing it and we have proposed a large number of amendments. The Bill has, in effect, just fallen over the line as legislation. We are entering into uncharted waters with this legislation, and it bears all the seeds of its own destruction.

I will make some final remarks about the people who have assisted on our side of the Parliament. If long and hard work has been required of the Government and its officers, it has certainly been a mammoth task for the Opposition with its lack of resources compared with the Government's resources. I particularly thank the senators who have been involved in coordinating debate on the legislation, particularly when I was the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, and the other backbenchers on our side of the Parliament and their staff for their extensive work in examining this legislation and putting together the amendments. In particular, I would like to thank a member of my staff, Stephen Wade, for his extensive work on this Bill and, of course, the shadow Minister and his staff. In the Senate, Senator Peter Baume carried the burden of this legislation and the extensive number of amendments on our behalf. It has been a team effort for the Opposition in the House of Representatives and the Senate. I believe this legislation is much better because of the 91 amendments that have gone into it, largely due to the extensive work of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say one thing in relation to the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) in terms of what the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) said about the use of privilege in the Senate. I remind the honourable member that yesterday, during a debate, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) made a number of statements, one of which was to accuse the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of attacking the man. He said, `He nailed the character of a citizen outside this place with no right to answer'. That is exactly the process that the Opposition parties adopted in the Senate. I suggest to the Leader of the Opposition that during meetings which the Opposition parties might have he address the issue of the abuse of privilege by certain senators in the other place. I will leave it at that because what has been said is on the record, including the Minister's statements. Those people have been maligned in a way which was totally unnecessary. One or two people in the other place continue to malign those people, undermine their characters and besmirch their personalities, and I do not think it is appropriate for any parliamentarian to abuse privilege in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that this Bill has been finally passed is a tribute to the dedication and commitment of the Minister. I suggest that some years hence when the history books are written they will see this piece of legislation as landmark legislation. I concur with the statements made by the Minister in relation to the preamble. We have lost an opportunity which ought not to have been lost. Unfortunately, that view was not accepted by the Opposition parties or the Australian Democrats in the Senate. This legislation is the poorer for its preamble being dropped. I suggest to honourable members in the House that they read the preamble and see what benefit it would have given the legislation had it been included.

I am in no doubt-speaking as a person who has worked with Aboriginal people for many years and whose electorate comprises a large number of Aboriginal people-that in relation to the comments made by the honourable member opposite in terms of the way in which the Opposition would seek to administer Aboriginal affairs if it were in government, it need not worry. While Aboriginal people have a vote they will never vote by a majority for the Opposition parties. The Opposition has made very plain indeed what it would choose to do in the area of Aboriginal affairs. Not only would it abolish, or try to get rid of, this legislation but also it would attempt to white ant the processes of Aboriginal self-determination and self-management. I commend this legislation again and pay a huge compliment to the Minister, his staff and his Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This moment is a landmark for the Australian Parliament. The years will pass and this will be seen as the turning point when Australia moved from a position of, firstly, contempt and ridicule of Aboriginal Australians; secondly, to a position of paternalism; and now to a period in which Aboriginal Australians are entitled to self-management, self-respect and self-determination. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has seen this Bill through this House under difficult circumstances, when members of this Parliament have seen fit to denigrate him personally and also those for whom this Bill is seeking to provide a framework for self-management and future development. He has seen it through with dignity and strength, and I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill is the last of the three Bills in a package that has been debated over a two-year period. It deals with the Institute, a very important part of Aboriginal affairs. The work that it does is recognised both nationally and internationally. The Government agreed to all of the amendments that were put forward by the Institute, interested persons and the Opposition parties in the Senate. We find no difficulty with accepting those proposals. As I said at the outset in 1987, good ideas will be welcomed by the Government, and the spirit of my long-held principle of working with people and trying to achieve the best situation is being upheld here yet again.

Let me say one last thing, because we are on the last of the big three. The Opposition spokesman said that the Government ought perhaps to hold off, and not proceed with legislation to put the Government's plans into place. I have news for him. After all the frustrations that have been put in the way of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC), it is now a fact. It will be a part of political life in this country. It will now be put into law. It will now become part of the scene in this nation. It will not be held off until some election some time in the future. It will commence. I remind honourable members on both sides to read this legislation, because to change it will require the numbers in both chambers. It is a very far-reaching piece of legislation, as I said. It will trip into place after the Governor-General stamps it and then it will be off and running.
The cuts to ATSIC as proposed by the Opposition in its recent economic statement are not worth the paper they are written on, because some of the funds that the Opposition plans to cut--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, cheat!
—No. In fact, some of the funds--

—Order! I ask the Minister to resume his seat for a moment. I remind the honourable member for Deakin that, if he wishes to gain the attention of the Chair, he will resume his own seat in the chamber and not shout out across the chamber.

—In conclusion, I was making the point that, from the day that ATSIC commences, certain funds will be expended. I think I am joined by the Opposition in what I am saying here. I have read the Hansard record of the Senate. Senator Peter Baume made the point that we should be striving to inform people and make sure everybody is fully aware of all the processes involved in ATSIC, and that will be done. The expenditure cuts that the Opposition is proposing would involve the funds that deal with that very point, that is, to let the people in the community know what their rights are and to set up the mechanisms to commence ATSIC.

SPEECH.PARA: We will be complying with the wishes of the Senate. I am sorry that that cuts across the Opposition, but we will comply with the wishes of the Senate and, most importantly, the wishes of the Aboriginal community. It is obvious from the comments in support of this concept from the former secretary, Lois O'Donohue, Shirley McPherson who, when she worked for the Aboriginal Development Commission, came and saw me, and all of people who have written and who have some knowledge of the area-people in every State and Territory of the nation-that ATSIC is a goer. I said that in December 1987, and now it will happen, right from today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to confine my remarks to the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies. I believe that the Institute is very beneficial. I am a member of its Council. I believe that the work it does in Australia is very worth while and that the people who work there are dedicated and committed. It is one of those institutes in Australia which, over the years, have been very beneficial and worth while. Because we have had such an institute, we have gained a reservoir of information about Aboriginal Australians and that has been very important for this country's heritage. I hope that honourable members have realised by now that Aboriginal people have a long cultural heritage, and that heritage is being kept by the Institute. No doubt its work will be enjoyed by generations of Australians in the future. I believe that the 17 amendments made to the legislation during its passage have improved it. Hopefully, the Institute will remain separate from other areas of government over many years.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

In moving this motion, as much as the Government did not wish to do so, it is desirable to make a few comments about why it has done so. I inform honourable members that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has had to go to a meeting with his United States counterpart, Mr Cheney. No government likes to move this sort of motion, but it is essential. We do so mainly because of the action of the Opposition in the other place which, in cahoots with the Australian Democrats, has imposed a deadline on the receipt of urgent legislation to be dealt with after 24 November. We have to have all our essential legislation in the other place by that date, if it is to be dealt with this year.

The Opposition regularly cries crocodile tears about the need to facilitate the business of the House, and that is the purpose of the motion that the Bills be declared urgent-to allow the smooth passage of remaining essential legislation in the Budget session. The other day the Manager of Opposition Business, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), referred to the sitting pattern this year. He suggested that we were sitting fewer days this year than in past years. While we are planning to sit for 55 days this year-and it could be more-that is more than the number of days of sitting in both 1980 and 1982. In both those years when the tories opposite were in government, the House sat for 51 and 53 days respectively. So much for their concern about this Government's action. I am making the simple factual point that, despite the rhetoric of those opposite, it is the case that the Fraser Government regularly used the guillotine and it is nonsense for them to object to the need to proceed expeditiously with this essential legislation. I am sure that the honourable member for Hume will agree with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FIFE
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Opposition Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is more in sorrow than in anger that I indicate to the House and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) that the Opposition is violently opposed to debate being limited on the 11 Bills about to be declared urgent. We will not be party to legislation being rushed through Parliament today, or on any other day, without it being properly considered. There are occasions, as the Minister has has pointed out, when the course of action being pursued by the Government this evening can be justified. In government, as the Minister had indicated, I have moved that the guillotine be applied to Bills before the House, and I have no doubt that I will do it again when we go back into government after the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the guillotine should be used only when Bills become urgent because of something occurring outside the control of government. These Bills, 11 of them, are urgent for one reason, and one reason only: the Government's mismanagement. If 10 of these 11 Bills must be passed by the House of Representatives this evening in order that the Senate will be able to deal with them before the Christmas recess, they should have been introduced weeks ago so that they could have been considered properly and debated fully by the House. Instead the Bills have been introduced late, probably because Ministers have not had the legislation drafted in time. Now the Government expects honourable members to debate 10 Bills during a period of approximately five hours. I say to the House, and particularly to the Minister at the table, that it is outrageous and strikes at the heart of parliamentary government. If it was an occasional occurrence our attitude would be different. However, this procedure has become part of a regular practice by the Hawke-Keating Government.

Under Labor rule the institution of parliament in Australia is losing its real function as a meaningful representative and legislative body. Increasingly, Parliament is nothing more than a formality that exists to keep the Government in power. The Government of the day controls Parliament. Under the Hawke-Keating Government sitting times have been drastically curtailed. I repeat for the information of the Minister: sitting times have been drastically curtailed by this Government. This has reduced opportunities for checking the Government's performance adequately, for scrutinising legislation and for the airing of public concerns on issues of the day. The House of Representatives will sit for only 27 days during this Budget session as against 36 in 1986, 34 in 1987 and 33 last year-progressively reducing the number of days available for this House to debate the issues of the day and to properly consider legislation brought before it by the Government. This is despite the fact that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), on his own admission, has said that we have a serious economic situation on our hands.

It is, as the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has said, a very pressed period of parliamentary sittings. Whilst the Minister at the table tonight has not been sufficiently straightforward and gracious to admit this, it has been admitted by the Leader of the House. However, there is plenty of scope for the Government to allow more time for its legislation to be considered in a proper and responsible manner.

One might also ask why so many important Government announcements are now being made outside Parliament when Parliament is not sitting. It is because the Government prefers to see debate on many major issues confined to the Sunday morning current affairs programs on television. If so, it can only be assumed that the motive is to limit examination of what the Government is putting up rather than face more careful analysis in Parliament. It is a further extension of legislation by press statement. For instance, why was the so-called world's greatest statement on the environment not made in Parliament? Or, for that matter, why was the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on multiculturalism not made in Parliament? The latter had nothing really new to offer, but why was it not made in Parliament? Parliament is the rightful forum where debates on such matters should take place and people can see that we as parliamentarians are fulfilling the proper legislative tasks that we were elected to perform.

Only by allowing more time to debate and examine legislation will the Parliament regain the meaningful role that it should have. In November last year, for instance, the Government declared 28 Bills urgent. That had the effect of limiting debate on some to less than 30 minutes. Surely the Minister at the table tonight does not agree that this is the way parliamentary business should be conducted. Over the past two years, more often than not, the Government has used the guillotine to push legislation through the Parliament at the end of sitting periods. In one instance last year the Government, with the use of the guillotine, pushed 28 Bills through the House of Representatives in three days. Already this year it has used the guillotine on 32 Bills. Now 11 more are to be added to make up a disgraceful total of 43 Bills in 1989.

Besides allowing sufficient time to consider important legislation, the Government should also make time to answer questions raised by the Opposition, which, in the public interest, should be answered before Parliament rises at the end of the month. For example, the Australian people want to know whether the Government intends to reduce the size of the public sector. Will it adopt our spending cuts and privatisation program? Will it commit itself to the discipline of forgoing the proceeds of bracket creep? How does the Government intend to liberalise the labour market and achieve long overdue productivity improvements? Where is the Government's policy on injecting foreign competition into coastal shipping? Will we see real action to clean up the waterfront? Where are the Government's policies on contracting out? The onus is squarely on the Government to answer these and many other questions before Parliament rises.

The list of Bills to be debated and voted upon between now and, I emphasise, 2.30 a.m. tomorrow, covers important and complex matters. They are to be rushed through this House late at night and in the early hours of tomorrow. Let us look at the Bills. There is the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Student Assistance Amendment Bill (No. 2), the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Bill, the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill, the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Bill and the University of Canberra Bill. They are not only very important education Bills but also many of them are complex pieces of legislation. About 55 minutes has been set aside for the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill, one of the Minister's own Bills, and 1 hour and 25 minutes only for the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4); and 40 minutes for the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill. The Opposition will vote against the use of the guillotine. The Government stands condemned for this act of parliamentary vandalism.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Kerin's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only do I want to support my colleague the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife) but also I want to draw the attention of the House to an extraordinary anomaly that exists in relation to this allotment of time for urgent Bills. According to the sheet that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has presented here tonight, the time allotted for the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill is due to expire at 2.30 a.m. tomorrow, Friday, 3 November, and the time allotted for debate on the remaining stages of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) is until 5 p.m. on Tuesday 21 November. We know that the House will resume at 2 p.m. on Tuesday, 21 November. Therefore, the implication is that, despite the extraordinary squeezing of time that is occurring with these other Bills, the time for debate on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4) will commence at 2.30 a.m. tomorrow and not conclude until 2 p.m. on Tuesday, 21 November.
—You are work shy!
—Order!

—I acknowledge that I have carriage of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 4), but I think the Government's attention ought to be drawn to the fact that the amount of time allocated for that Bill is considerably more than for a number of the other Bills that are to be debated between now and 2.30 a.m. tomorrow. SPEECH.PARA: I see that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is preparing to respond, and I am glad that he is able to do so to a full House, because it has been obvious from events that have taken place in the last three days that the Minister is busy developing his own constituency, namely, those in the mining industry, the rural industry and the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday's performance in this House by the Opposition was very shabby indeed. Honourable members opposite should ask their colleagues the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) why they moved to suspend Standing Orders for spurious and unnecessary reasons. TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a package of six Bills on education. This would normally be a wide-ranging debate but because of the absurd limitation of time imposed by the Government no reasonable debate can take place. This is typical of this Government on the subject of education. It is probably not a coincidence because the overbearing approach of the Hawke Government in the education area is paralleled by its attitude here. My comments were to be devoted primarily to the subject of the funding of the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education (CAE) but because of this grotesque limitation of time I will be able to say very little indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Thursday, 26 October, I raised the issue of funding of the Gold Coast CAE, or should I say the non-funding of its previously approved capital works program, and I had hoped to pursue this matter and related matters in my speech tonight. However, I can only refer honourable members to page 1952 of the House of Representatives Hansard and to questions that I posed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and comments that I made at the time. I have questions on notice which ask the Minister whether it is a consistent requirement that amalgamations take a certain form-the form, namely, that has been put on to the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education. I alleged in my speech and I believe it to be true that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Moncrieff should be aware that the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 has been passed by the House.

—One cannot have a cognate debate on a piece of legislation that has already been passed. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Speaker, for your guidance. The manner of funding tertiary education, in particular on the Gold Coast, is a matter of concern. We have only one public tertiary institution, the one I referred to earlier this evening; that is, the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education. We also have Bond University, which attracts some overseas students, but that is not material to the Government. The question of attracting students, including Aboriginal students, to the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education is very material. I previously pointed out in a speech to the House that the line the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has been taking on the capital funding of the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education is of great disadvantage to anybody who wants to attend that institution. It is a rapidly expanding one, with many future course plans. The Minister will not release the previously approved capital funding, which means it cannot proceed with expansion of its courses. This is forcing disadvantaged students, those who are not well heeled and cannot go to Brisbane, to forgo their further education.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I have posed the question about the expansion of education and availability on the Gold Coast to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I have put on notice the following questions:

(1) Has it been a consistent requirement of his that amalgamations of tertiary institutions must proceed to the stage of a Memorandum of Agreement between two institutions before Commonwealth funds for approved capital building programs are released; if not, in which cases have capital building funds been withheld from institutions which have given an undertaking to amalgamate but which have not yet signed a Memorandum of Agreement.

(2) Given that considerable progress has been made in negotiations to establish the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education as an affiliated university college of Griffith University, what action does he propose to take with respect to the funding of Stage 2 of the College's capital building program.

As I have previously said, the requirement to sign a finalised memorandum of agreement before release of funds for previously approved capital building programs appears to be a requirement unique to the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education. The Minister's answer to the question on notice would therefore be of particular significance to the issue of whether coercion as to forms of amalgamation is a factor in the actual process of amalgamation. Whilst the Minister has not publicly acknowledged these questions, much less answered them, I believe that subsequent to my speech last Thursday I got an answer of sorts from him.

That evening, the Minister-heavily, and I believe deliberately-shouldered me as our paths happened to cross not a trivial bump but a blow sufficient to knock me almost off my feet and cause me an injury such that 24 hours later I was still suffering considerable pain from it. The Minister did not even pause, much less apologise. He simply strode on, leaving me and the person with whom I had been conversing, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), to stand and watch his retreating back in amazement. My initial reaction was shock and bewilderment. My next reaction was dismay that an education Minister, of all people, could be- have so badly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Typical.

—It may be typical. I was not aware of that until last Thursday. I have had many thoughts about this behaviour since then, not least that such extraordinary behaviour could come from a Cabinet Minister in a Government which has initiated a national program on domestic violence, a program which has had my wholehearted public support to date. It is a matter of great concern that the Minister could behave in this way. My hopes for rational answers to my questions do not appear very good. The sadness is that many students on the Gold Coast and in that area will miss out on a tertiary education because the college is now unable to proceed with its building program for 1989 and its 1990 program also appears to be in jeopardy.

SPEECH.PARA: Today in the Gold Coast Bulletin, Senator Mal Colston attempted to respond to my speech of last week. He does not appear to have had the benefit of the questions I have posed because, whilst he makes certain generalisations in relation to the subject of amalgamation of tertiary institutions, he makes no reference to the fact that it appears that the Gold Coast College of Advanced Education has been singled out for particularly discriminatory, unwarranted and punitive action by the Minister. There is no reference in this letter, which was printed on the letters page today-and which I have no doubt was vetted by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training-to the questions I posed about discriminatory treatment. Senator Colston could refer only in general terms to the funding being available--

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to say quickly that it is important for the Opposition to point out to the House that the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill will cut off students, in particular Chinese students, who were saving funds to come to Australia for education. As we know, they have been haranguing our Embassy in China to try to get our Australian Labor Party Government to allow them to come to this country to further their studies. It is very important that the House understand that these people are being deprived of gaining a good education here. When most of us went to school we associated with students who came here under the Colombo Plan which helped overseas students to visit Australia and attend school here. I am sure that has been of great benefit to us as a nation, given the goodwill involved with those people having gone back to their countries but having been fortunate enough to have had a good education here, which in most cases was probably better than they would have received in their own countries. Their education will have done a great deal of good for those nations. Of course, many of those people have stayed on in Australia and become doctors, dentists or other professionals. Many of the doctors moved into the western areas of Queensland and have done a good job serving the communities throughout that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great deal of money is being spent these days on education, particularly on environmental education. It is interesting to note that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is at the table tonight. I take this opportunity to support his not necessarily outspoken but sensible statements in the past couple of days on environmental issues. The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Bill is very important to the long term education of Aboriginal students throughout this huge nation of ours. Many of them are involved in the land rights situation in their schooling in the Northern Territory, Queensland and other such areas. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has been very sensible, and I support him 100 per cent. It is a pity more of his Government colleagues will not support him. It was amazing that when he spoke on the matter of public importance today only one Government member came in to support him. That was disgraceful.
—Unbelievable.

—It was unbelievable, and is absolutely disgraceful. We have to continue to develop our resources to earn the income to educate our Aboriginal kids and our own children. I support him 100 per cent, as I said.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been a member of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs of this House since coming to Parliament in 1980. That Committee has put out a report on education. I very much support all we can do about education. I guess we have to educate the Aboriginal people in our English ways, although we are now starting to learn a lot from them about their ways of living. A lot of Aboriginal education is taking place at the primary and lower school levels. Aborigines are being employed to take students out into the bush to teach them their bush ways, and I think that cross-movement of cultures is very important for us. We can learn a lot from them, and this legislation allows the extra funding to help them learn how we tick.

It is important to understand that the biggest problem we have with Aboriginal education is actually getting Aboriginal children to attend school. Hamlets and small towns in electorates such as Maranoa and Wide Bay in Queensland and others in the Northern Territory, Western Australia and South Australia have reasonably large populations of Aborigines-there are not really many Aborigines in Australia, but 27 per cent of the Aboriginal population is in Queensland-and one of the problems is that the Labor Government distributes the funding not on a per capita basis but more on a political basis, and Queensland tends to miss out. Queensland does the best job of educating Aborigines in Australia. The programs and incentives within the schools are copied by the other States. It is important that we continue to--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a good record in Queensland.

—We have the best record for Aboriginal education, and we have the biggest number of graduates coming through our higher colleges and universities. We have much to be proud of in Queensland. Our policy has been to assimilate, where possible, and encourage Aborigines to move into the towns and attend the local state schools, rather than keep them separated.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) here today expounding and spitting at the mouth about South Africa and the way they rant and rave at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting for days on end. It is a pity he will not go to South Africa and see how well its people are educated and looked after. It is incredible just what a great job the South African nation does in looking after its indigenous people and all the people who go there from other parts of Africa-all the frontline states. It is amazing how they drift down to South Africa to get a decent education and standard of living in that part of the world.

I return to the Bill. Of course, we are very keen to encourage young Aboriginal students to attend school. As I said, this is the biggest problem we have. It is very sad to see the amount of petrol sniffing that still goes on, although we have established a special program to help the children. In many communities one can see young kids wandering around when they ought to be at school. In a lot of places only 30 per cent of Aboriginal kids attend school, which is very bad for us.

I have been a member of the Standing Committee for nine years now and I do not pretend to have the answers about our Aboriginal problem, because the more money we pour at them, the worse they seem to get. I am a bit like the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on the environment. I think probably the best thing one can do is to offer Aborigines the best education that we have available-and that is what we are doing-and to encourage the Aborigines who are educated to go back into the education system and help educate the kids that are coming along. We are doing that more and more. There are many Aboriginal assistant teachers. More money is being spent by the Government. This Bill, in particular, encourages more funds to be taken out of Consolidated Revenue and granted to the States. I do not believe that there is a need to set up a special Federal arm of education for Aborigines. It always seems to me to be a total waste of money.
