SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am very pleased to see you in the chair this evening. The Opposition supports the University of Canberra Bill 1989. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government should be condemned for the turmoil caused to Australia's higher education system by its use of financial blackmail, centralised control, bureaucratic administration and other heavy-handed tactics to implement its ill conceived education policies''.

Given that this Government is in such a state of chaos and confusion that it is unable to provide and ensure a proper time for the Parliament to debate this important Bill, I foreshadow two amendments: firstly, an amendment to the process by which persons become disqualified for membership of the council of the university; and, secondly, an amendment to enshrine in this Bill the important principle of freedom of association. There are third and fourth amendments, amendments from the Government, one of which we have initiated, to the composition of the council to increase the number of representatives nominated by the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Assembly to come into effect upon the withdrawal of the Monash University and its rights to membership of that council. The second amendment from the Government is a minor, technical amendment, but one that will ensure that existing graduates of the Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE) are entitled to vote for that one position on the new council. I will seek the incorporation of those amendments if, for reasons of time, the House does not go into committee to allow a consideration of these amendments in detail.

The purpose of this Bill is to establish a University of Canberra under the sponsorship of Monash University to replace the Canberra College of Advanced Education. In a sense, it really follows the end of the binary system, which I think is a policy for which the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) will be well remembered in tertiary education circles in this country. In 1988, in accordance with the proposals contained in the Government's ill-fated White Paper, the Government introduced legislation to effect an amalgamation of the three Canberra higher education institutions-the Australian National University (ANU), the Canberra College of Advanced Education and the Canberra Institute of the Arts (CITA). Of course, that ANU-CITA amalgamation is proceeding. The coalition and the Australian Democrats publicly indicated their intention to oppose the legislation and we have led the way in the opposition to that Government proposal. We have done so on the grounds that the Government failed dismally, when it put forward this proposal of amalgamation, by not providing any significant educational or financial benefits which would be derived from the merger. So there have been very strong objections and a strong campaign of protest from within the institutions, notably the ANU.

Following this opposition to the Bill and representations from the incoming Australian Capital Territory Government, the Federal Government deferred the consideration of the legislation and allowed the new Assembly to consider the implications for the Territory. Not surprisingly, the subsequent report opposed the inclusion of the CCAE in the proposed amalgamation and proposed its establishment as a separate university under ACT legislation. Of course, that separate status for the University of Canberra was its preferred position, one which had been put to one side by the Minister in his manic determination to create a united national system. So in that sense the preferred position of the CCAE people is about to be realised, but not until after a very long fight with the Government.

The CCAE has, and always has had, a very different mission from the ANU. Students have gone there specifically because it offers something unique in Canberra. I think they will continue to go to that institution for that reason. Clearly, Canberra has room for two higher education institutions, whether they are called universities or something else. Students should have an opportunity to choose between them and we are pleased to see, therefore, the legislation proceed.

Unfortunately for the CCAE, this whole amalgamation proposal has been a very timely and costly exercise. It says much of this Government's administration that after all the hullabaloo we ended up with its preferred position. The Minister ordained that to meet his arbitrary requirements for student numbers, which in turn determined the allocation of research funds, the CCAE would have to amalgamate under his plans. In typical fashion, he offered a bribe on this one as he has offered on others. In some cases it has been a straight-out threat. In this case it was an engineering school if the CCAE went ahead with the merger. He threatened the ANU with reduced funding if it continued to resist. We welcome his failure and this Bill encapsulates that situation.

Given the limited time tonight, I will make one further comment-that is, this university is being established under Federal legislation. All higher education institutions in this country, except the ANU, which has a unique role-a national role-are established under State legislation. It has been suggested that the only reason the CCAE has been kept within the Federal sphere, ignoring the community which it serves, is that the Federal Minister wants to keep alive-he reckons he is down but not out-the possibility of effecting a merger between the ANU and this new university at some time in the future. If that is not the case, tonight is the opportunity for the Minister to come in here and advise the House when he plans to move this new university through to the Territory's jurisdiction. We on this side of the House believe in devolving responsibility to local communities and regions. We have a strong policy position to see the ACT Assembly take control and immediate responsibility at an early stage upon the coalition taking office at the next election. So, in respect of the new university, we on this side welcome its creation and its new status. We wish it well for the future. We believe that it has every reason to be confident about the future, given the dedication of its staff and its student body.

I have moved a second reading amendment just to make some general comments about the Government's policy position-in particular, the very strong, determined push it has made for amalgamations around the country. It can be seen wherever one goes. Last night I referred to the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT) in Victoria. I say to the Minister that this push, this threat, against RMIT in my view is not in its best interests. I do not believe that it is reasonable for a Federal Minister to say to a great institution like RMIT, `If you do not do as you are required to do by me as the Federal Minister, then I will deny you university status and capital funds and put a ceiling on your student numbers'. The position that RMIT has adopted, if one reads its resolution, is a reasonable one. It says that it is not prepared to sacrifice the great efforts and tremendous reputation it has built up. It is prepared to cooperate but not to throw the baby out with the bath water. It does not say much for this Minister that he should call a meeting of the institutions and just lay down the law. He does not have a gun at their heads; he has a whole artillery barrage. Like the Clint Eastwood film, his line is, `Make my day'. That is no way to run tertiary education institutions in the country.

I have mentioned Victoria, but all the higher education institutions in South Australia face an uncertain future because they have not managed to agree to ludicrous proposals virtually devoid of any education or even economic rationale to amalgamate. In Western Australia, the Minister for Education, Dr Carmen Lawrence, is heavily on the Federal Minister's back railing against the centralist implications of his merger proposals. In Queensland there is continuing bitterness and division over the questions of amalgamations and the status of various instituations. I am afraid to say that, wherever one goes, our higher education institutions have suffered a very great distraction, a very great diversion of resources, as they have fought against this Minister's unfortunately successful attempts to undermine the institutional autonomy and financial independence of some of our great institutions. I fear that the ramifications of this Minister's policy position will be felt for many years.

I will suffer from the guillotine tonight but I want to say something about the importance of the principle of voluntary student unionism. I thought it was one of the most incredible policy positions that I have ever seen from a Federal Minister when last week this Minister announced his version of a bill of rights for universities. After lighting the fire, this Minister, the arsonist, arrived at the scene of the crime to say, `Behold, I think it is time we brought in the fire truck'. The Minister talked about this a couple of years ago in a green paper but no-one was terribly keen on it. It was not an issue and no-one talked about it. Reading between the lines, the Minister virtually admitted that, as a result of his own actions, he has found the necessity to put up a political defence to the widespread criticism of the way in which this Government has operated.

The Government has achieved its objective by pulling harder and harder on the purse strings. In so doing, it has attacked the financial independence and autonomy of our institutions. The Minister fails to understand that we ought to be able to look at a university and see there a place where learning can be undertaken and where the pursuit of knowledge is encouraged free from any political intervention or interference. Instead of that, we have the Minister's proposal now lying on the table to allow and encourage compulsory student unionism with all the vices, with all the waste and with the affront that that represents to basic rights, which ought to be a feature of our campuses. Given the Government's handling of business tonight, the fact that other speakers wish to speak on this Bill and the guillotine limit on time, I conclude by saying that we welcome and support the moves for the creation of the University of Canberra. We wish it well for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to hear the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) talking about a wide range of issues in relation to the University of Canberra Bill. I am pleased that he supports the Bill and supports the proposal for the University of Canberra. Unfortunately, he seems to have made a number of personal comments directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) which had very little basis in fact and which betrayed the total confusion of the Opposition on this whole issue of amalgamations. The Opposition does not know what it is doing or what it is on about when it comes to the amalgamation of tertiary institutions. This was illustrated in particular by the comments that the honourable member for Flinders made about the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT) and the proposed University of Technology.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Flinders has been going around Victoria trying to pretend that he is a great champion of the RMIT and suggesting that the Minister has been bullying the RMIT and pushing it around. He has used a number of other terms and descriptions in relation to the plan to amalgamate the three key institutes. The Opposition does not want to see a university in the western suburbs of Melbourne. That is the fundamental point. It has never supported the creation of tertiary institutions in that part of Melbourne. Until the election of the Labor Government, the Hawke Government, we did not see any tertiary institutions spring up in the working class areas or the poor areas of Melbourne, or Sydney, for that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a lot of rot you talk.

—The honourable member for Moreton would not know anything about it. He thinks that education is for the privileged. Let me make it perfectly clear: education is not for the privileged; education is for all Australians. The fact is that the honourable member for Flinders supported and gave succour to the narrow number of people on the RMIT council that opposed the amalgamation. It was not the academic staff of that institution-they supported the amalgamation-and was not the students of that institution, who, to their credit, although initially having some feelings of opposition about it, also supported the amalgamation when it was explained to them. The honourable member for Flinders encouraged certain reactionary elements in the RMIT council.
—Ha, ha!

—The honourable member laughs. The kinds of reasons given for the rejection of the amalgamation were an absolute and utter disgrace, and he knows it. They had to do with elitism; they had to do with the refusal to recognise the people living in the western suburbs and the north-western suburbs of Melbourne as having the right to tertiary education. By rejecting this proposal we are now put in an invidious position of having to try to create the university of the west without the RMIT. But it will proceed. The attempts of the honourable member for Flinders to undermine university education in the west will not succeed. A university of some kind will proceed in the west of Melbourne, irrespective of his attempts to scuttle that proposal.
—But why sacrifice the RMIT?

—The honourable member for Flinders has had his go. The fact is that the honourable member is trying to defend the totally indefensible. The position of the RMIT council is totally indefensible. The Minister has been very kind to it. Look at what the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) and I have to say about the RMIT council and its behaviour. The fact is that its reasons for rejecting the amalgamation were a disgrace in a civilised society, especially since its rejection was not in accordance with the determination of the academic staff, but contrary to the academic staff's determination. So what sort of show is being run at the RMIT?

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has said that the RMIT should rethink the position. Indeed, it should rethink its position and reconsider its obligations to all Australians, in particular to that disadvantaged group of people living in the western suburbs, and proceed with the amalgamation. It has been suggested that the Minister has tried to heavy them. What has the Minister done to heavy them? Nothing. The fact is that the Minister could have forced an amalgamation if he was of a mind to do so. He gave them the freedom to make a choice. What has happened? The RMIT made the wrong choice and has given the wrong reasons. I appeal to the whole body of the RMIT to reconsider its position and get back to a position where it decides to amalgamate, because the future of university education in Melbourne depends on this amalgamation succeeding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—It does, and the honourable member for Flinders knows that it does. The honourable member for Flinders made certain personal comments about the Minister's role in relation to the Australian National University and the college here in Canberra. He said that the Minister tried to force an amalgamation. If his comments are based on the sort of evidence which he has tried to put forward in relation to the amalgamation involving the RMIT, they must be equally fallacious because the Minister does not force amalgamations; he gives reasons and explanations. He speaks to the various bodies, but ultimately it is up to the bodies themselves. In the case of the University of Canberra, they decided not to proceed and the Minister has proceeded in accordance with that decision to establish this Bill. He has in fact stuck to his word.

SPEECH.PARA: So the suggestion of the honourable member for Flinders that the Minister is trying to heavy institutions into an amalgamation is completely and utterly wrong. But that is just par for the course for the honourable member for Flinders. He has got it wrong in relation to the University of Canberra and in relation to the RMIT and the University of Technology. As a result, he has put all of us in a very difficult position because he is giving support to these reactionary elements that are opposed to university education in the western suburbs of Melbourne. The honourable member for Flinders ought to be ashamed of the role he has played in this situation. The honourable member must not think that the role he has played in this matter is going to do him any good in the west and north-west of Melbourne when all this is exposed.

Let us also look at the honourable member's amendment that he is moving here, in which he is trying to suggest that students should not be required to be members of student union organisations. What is the position of the Government on this? The Minister has said that the Government will not put up with an attempt by State governments to interfere in this matter. We are not going to put up with State Government intervention. We have still allowed the institutions to make the determination about unionism and membership of student organisations. But we are not going to put up with State governments trying to bulldoze through legislation under which, after a determination has been made about student unionism by the university or college concerned, a government comes on top and tries to change that determination. That is the Minister's position, and it is a position which obviously should be supported.

We know about attempts to break the student movement in the universities in the past by reactionary governments, such as the Queensland Government. We know about that sort of behaviour. The fact is that this matter ought to be left to the students and the universities to determine and should not be determined by State governments such as the Queensland Government-a government, by the way, which has no future because it will be defeated in a few weeks time. Nevertheless, the Opposition's attempt to put this clause into the Bill is nothing more than an attempt to defend those who are trying to attack student unionism. There is no doubt that student unionism is under attack by a number of organisations and bodies. The Opposition is also trying to get behind this.

This is an absurd position. The Opposition is trying to attack student unionism because the unions will organise against the absurd scheme that it will bring into universities whereby people will be required to pay up-front fees of $1,200--

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Yes. The honourable member does not want the unions to organise against that, does he? The Opposition wants that all to be hidden away. The implications of that proposal-I will speak about it again at another time-in terms of equity are horrendous in that people in my area and in the poorer areas of Melbourne and Sydney going to university or college will have to find all the up-front fees. That is a totally unfair and iniquitous system. The Opposition wants to support that system by preventing student organisations from being effectively organised against such a proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: We reject this whole argument that members of the Opposition have put forward tonight. We reject, in particular, the comments that they have made in relation to amalgamations, especially the RMIT amalgamation. I repeat: the Minister has behaved honourably throughout this whole process. He has not tried to bulldoze anything through. He has allowed the institutions to make a decision on the basis of their own councils, et cetera. That does not mean that some of us, especially those who represent the areas concerned, are not concerned about the behaviour of the honourable member in going around and discouraging what should have been a very important amalgamation in the State of Victoria for the people of that region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) in his excellent comments on this legislation. I am pleased that the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) mentioned the Economic Action Plan of the coalition. Political historians will regard that as the turning point of a lead-in to the next Federal election, which the coalition will win. One key reason we will win the next Federal election is the Economic Action Plan and its contents. Unfortunately, due to the savage guillotine applied by this arrogant, out of touch and fading Government, I will not be able to develop that point any further. I want to discuss in a constructive way the University of Canberra Bill 1989 in supporting the honourable member for Flinders and his amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I refer to the preamble in the Bill. I invite the Minister to look at the exact wording of the preamble, because two points arise. It is rare indeed to have a qualified preamble. It is even rarer still to have such extraordinary contents in a preamble. I refer to the words:
. . . because it is desirable to establish a new university in the Australian Capital Territory to replace the Canberra College of Advanced Education:
and because Monash University has agreed to sponsor the new university:
be it enacted by the Queen, and the Senate and the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, as follows . . .
I went through at random Acts of the Parliament, Commonwealth of Australia, volume 3, 1987 and I looked at 64 different Acts of Parliament contained in that volume.

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you got anything better to do?

—I research my contributions to this House, as I know the Minister does, and he should allow me the credit for doing that. Not one of those pieces of legislation has a qualified preamble. It is very rare indeed to have, in a sense, the Federal Parliament acting at the behest of Monash University. I venture to suggest that this is the sort of thing that gets right up the nostrils of the members of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I will be very interested to see what its scarlet report on this Bill has to say with regard to that qualification in the preamble.

SPEECH.PARA: In a sense, it is not in the mainstream of legislation, and I will not dwell on this, but there is a second dimension to it. This relates not only to putting in a preamble of that form but to the statement `and because Monash University has agreed to sponsor the new university . . .'. This Parliament does not enact legislation at the behest of the Monash University, the Melbourne Football Club, the Victoria Racing Club, or anything else. Legislation is enacted on the basis of the votes of the House of Representatives and the Senate. This is the most curious drafting I have ever seen in the five years that I have been a member of Federal Parliament. I have endeavoured to make some inquiries in relation to this matter, and I understand that there is some precedent for this kind of approach to the drafting of legislation. However, I will be particularly interested to see what the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee has to say. I believe this could have been more carefully drafted.

The Charles Sturt University, which has emerged during the period of the original Australian National University (ANU) legislation, and now this University of Canberra Bill, is in an indirect way germane to the discussion on this Bill. By this Bill, the opportunity for the higher education facilities at Albury-Wodonga to link with the Australian National University evaporates-and the ANU might also have been amalgamated with the Canberra College of Advanced Education. I think the Minister would concede that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose fault is that?
—Time does not allow for me to comment in detail; in fact, it is no one person's fault.
—Don't blame me.

—I do not. I simply highlight the fact that, as a consequence of this final decision for the Canberra College of Advanced Education to become the University of Canberra, and to be linked with Monash University, effectively we have lost another opportunity to straighten out the provisions-

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Dawkins interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The debate seem to have degenerated into a conversation between the Minister and the honourable member for Farrer. I ask that the debate be directed through the Chair.

—I will happily do so. In fact, the Minister has agreed with my comments, that by this Bill that opportunity is lost. This is regrettable because we now have a second best option applying in Albury-Wodonga, with the Murray campus of Albury, which requires funding but which has been dropped from the list of Federal funding. It is linked with the Charles Sturt University, involving elements from Bath- urst, Wagga and Albury. The Charles Sturt University is a fledgling university. It is one that I wish well. It has a major challenge ahead of it. The pity is that on the other side of the border at Albury-Wodonga the higher education unit chooses not to be linked with the Charles Sturt University.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I do not blame the Minister, but I want the House and the nation to know that this crazy situation exists in this combined city of Albury-Wodonga of about 80,000 in population. The higher education facilities on the northern side of the border will have nothing to do with-and in some instances will duplicate-activities south of the border. An attempt was made to reach some conclusion on that, but the factors became very complex. In respect of Albury-Wodonga, I regard the outcome as the second best option. Sure, we must now make the best of it, and hopefully the Charles Sturt University will power forward from the commencement of its operations and ultimately those south of the border will see reason and link up in a way which will be to the positive advantage of all involved.

I might add that we often have these problems right on the border. This one relates to education; earlier in the day there was a problem in respect of the bypass route of the Hume Highway. Again, that is a border problem where project B, the Albury internal bypass, has been pushed to one side. It is a continuing battle, but I will not give up the fight, nor will my electors. Finally, in support of the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), I am very pleased that it is the national Parliament that is legislating on this Bill and not the Australian Capital Territory Assembly.

Clause 5 (Sponsored by Monash University).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 5, page 3, line 20, before subparagraph (3) (a) (i), insert the following subparagraph:
``(ia) `2' were omitted from paragraph (1) (c) and `3' were substituted; and''.

This amendment seeks to expand the membership of the council of the university, that is, those who are appointed on the nomination of the Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), at the time that the sponsorship arrangement with Monash University ceases. We believe that at the time of the cessation of the arrangement whereby during the sponsorship period two members of the council are nominated by the Monash University, it is appropriate to extend by one the number appointed from the ACT.

We think it is appropriate for this university to be established under Commonwealth legislation but, at the same time, we believe that it is important that this new university be quite firmly established and linked to the local community. Therefore, we have provided for some members of the council from its inception to be nominated by the Chief Minister. This provision will be extended once the sponsorship arrangements cease.

The important principle here is to ensure that in this university, as I believe in other universities around the country, the outside members of the council-that is, the members who are appointed either from the community or by cooption from the council itself-are in the majority in terms of the composition of the council. In other words, I do not believe that it is appropriate for the staff, the administration and the students to be in a majority on the governing council. I certainly believe that all those interests ought to be represented on the council, but I do not believe that they should be in the ascendancy at any point. Therefore, when the Monash nominees are removed from the council we should expand the membership of the outside members of the council, and this seems to be an appropriate way to do it. There will be three nominees from the Commonwealth and three nominees from the ACT Government. That will constitute, I think, a very balanced council and one that will help guide the course of this new university into what I hope will be a very exciting future.

Qualifications for membership
of Council
``12. (1) A person is not qualified to become or remain a member of the Council (other than the Vice-Chancellor) if the person:
(a) is under 18;

(b) is an undischarged bankrupt or a person in respect of whom there is in operation a composition, deed of arrangement or deed of assignment with the person's creditors under the law relating to bankruptcy; or

Proposed new clause 40a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 17, after clause 40 insert the following new clause:
Compulsory membership of associations etc. prohibited
``40a. Nothing in this Act shall be taken to empower the Council to make Statutes:
(a) that would make it compulsory for a student to be a member of an organisation of students;
(b) that would make it compulsory for a student to pay fees or other charges to an organisation of students unless the student voluntarily undertakes to be a member of the organisation; or

(c) that would make it compulsory for a student to pay fees or other charges in respect of the provision of amenities or services that are not of an academic nature except in relation to the actual use by the student of those amenities or services.''.

This important Opposition amendment seeks to insert a new clause 40a into this legislation. In recent years we have not, to my knowledge, had an amendment to instil in legislation a basic freedom, that is, the freedom of association. It is an area where there are very great differences between the Opposition and the Government. It is our view-and it is surprising that it needs to be stated-that compelling anyone to join an organisation is anathema to the fundamental principle to the freedom of association, to the spirit of free inquiry and interaction which lies at the heart of Western democracy and which should be upheld by all our higher education institutions and politicians alike.

At the birth of a new institution I could not move a more important amendment to this legislation than to enshrine this basic principle. If this new university starts off with that statement of principle as its foundation, then its future will be well secured. We have had a lot of nonsense from the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) about freedom of association. He failed to recognise that the proposition that we have here leaves it in the hands not of university councils, State governments or State parliaments but of the students themselves as to whether or not they should join such an organisation. We are not opposed to students running organisations. In fact, this principle endorses their right to form organisations as people in a democracy ought to be able to do. We are opposed to this Government requiring in an underhand way, as it will in legislation it is shortly to propose in this Parliament, people to join organisations against their will. It is not just a slight matter.

Recently the Victorian Equal Opportunity Board considered this issue. Mr Kenmar took his case to that Board in respect of compulsory student unionism. Mr Kenmar was required to join the Monash association of students. The Board found that the Monash association of students was a political organisation and, because of his political beliefs, Mr Kenmar had been treated less favourably than other students. On a philosophical level we object strongly to compulsory student unionism and on a practical level we will ensure in government that students in higher education institutions are able to exercise their freedom of choice and decide whether to join student unions. Voluntary student unionism is an important plank of our higher education policy. In government we will take the appropriate action to ensure that it is introduced around the nation. We congratulate Mr Kenmar on the strong, principled stand that he has taken. He has given a lead to other students and to our country as a whole on this vital principle. While the Government may not accept the amendment on this occasion, it will see the principle raised again in the future when we are in government, when we have the numbers on the treasury bench to ensure that this basic freedom can be seen in practice on each and every campus in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —To disappoint the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and to encourage the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who seems to be nodding off, I indicate that the Government intends to oppose the proposed new clause. The Opposition has a totally confused view on this, as on so many other issues. The Government's position is quite simply that it should be up to the governing body of an institution to provide for the provision of student facilities, student associations, and the collection fees necessary to support those facilities and associations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition wants to impose its particular ideological obsessions upon the governing bodies of institutions. We have a very clear view that governing bodies of higher education institutions ought to be autonomous and able to make their own decisions about the way in which they run their affairs. That is why we pay particular attention to the composition of those councils to ensure that they represent not only the university community, the staff, students and administration, but also the outside community. Once an appropriate composition for the council is established, it is then up to that council or governing body to determine the rules which operate within that institution. We are not requiring institutions to impose compulsory membership of student organisations. If the governing body decides that membership of a student organisation can be voluntary, so be it.
