DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 October, on motion by Mr Robert Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill 1989 is umbrella legislation to set up a framework to provide for research and development corporations to replace research councils. Such research and development corporations already exist for the meat industry and for horticulture. This legislation envisages initially four such corporations-grain, dairy, coal and energy. In the very brief time allotted to me, I will be talking about the primary industry sector of the legislation, and my colleague the shadow Minister for science and energy, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), will be talking about the coal and energy sections. The various organisations associated with primary industry, in particular the dairy and grain industries, such as the Grains Council of Australia, the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, the Australian Dairy Industry Conference and the National Farmers Federation, have shown considerable interest in this legislation because it is very important to them, particularly in view of the amount of money, which will be increasing, that their grower members now provide for research.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been considerable discussion on this legislation between the Opposition, the Government and the Australian Democrats, which is commendable; if we can improve this legislation by sensible amendments, we should do so. At this stage there is a positive feeling and attitude amongst all parties towards possible improvements to the legislation. There are definitely ways that this legislation can be improved. I will move a general amendment to the second reading of the Bill and I give notice that a number of amendments will be moved by the Opposition during the committee stage in the Senate. It is hoped that between now and then further discussion will take place between the parties to ensure that as many of those amendments as possible are accepted. I believe all of them should be accepted because none try to negate the legislation; they improve it in a number of technical ways. I move:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Bill should include provision for representative organisations of a primary industry (as defined in the Bill) or class of primary industry to receive direct voluntary contributions from commercial companies for research and development, and for the contributions to attract a matched Commonwealth contribution on the same basis that funds raised by way of industry levy will attract a Commonwealth contribution, provided that such contributions:
(1) are not also eligible for the 150% tax deduction or for any additional Commonwealth research and development incentive scheme; and
(2) are within agreed limits such as the 0.5% of the gross value of the product stipulated by the Commonwealth for matching contributions''.

The honourable member for Gippsland has duly signed the amendment. The reason we move that general amendment is that we are not allowed to move a more specific one. We are moving that general amendment as we have been advised that this is the most appropriate way to go. If the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) believes that it would be more acceptable to him to have the amendment changed in the Senate to specify the dairy industry, we will be happy to do so because it is to that industry that the importance of this amendment is obvious.

The dairy industry has a significant number of dairy cooperative factories and there is an opportunity for them to provide money for research. As the cooperatives are owned by dairy farmers, it is really dairy farmer money that is provided and we believe that any such contributions by those factories should be accepted as grower contributions up to the 0.5 per cent of the gross value of the product. There is a precedent for that with the horticultural corporation arrangements. We believe the same should be available for the dairy industry and I ask the Government to seriously consider that. We will be quite happy to make that amendment more specific if that is more appropriate.

As I said earlier, my colleague the shadow Minister for science and energy will move a significant amendment at the committee stage in relation to the coal sector. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a range of amendments that I have foreshadowed because I will have no time to go into them in detail in committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That is not possible. The honourable member cannot anticipate debate at the committee stage.
—I will seek leave for them to be incorporated at that stage.

SPEECH.PARA: While we have some concerns about aspects of this Bill, a particular point I want to raise is that these research and development corporations should not be forced to hold annual meetings. Annual meetings should be held only when the representative organisation requires it. I believe that in the view of the Government that is accommodated in this legislation, but we want to make sure that it is quite clear because none of the other primary industry organisations want the requirement of the Meat and Livestock Corporation or the Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation to hold expensive annual meetings.

Secondly, if a particular corporation ceases to exist, the industry funds should not be transferred to Consolidated Revenue but, rather, should be held in trust for the industry. That is only fair and equitable. Industry organisations and the Opposition are also concerned to ensure a close working relationship between the corporation and its representative organisation. While we believe that this should be possible in view of the fact that the selection committees which are nominated by the respective industry will appoint six out of the nine members of the corporation, we believe that copies of research and development plans, or variations to them, should be made available to the representative organisation as well as to the Minister. The Opposition and the primary producer organisations also believe that the research and development corporations should consult with, and have regard to the views of, the representative organisations in preparing plans of operation, including the initial one.

Another concern is that State governments may try to take advantage of the fact that research and development money in the new corporations can be used to extend the research results to producers, in other words, getting to extension which traditionally has been the role of State governments and State Departments of Agriculture. We would not want to see that happen. It has so often happened. When the Commonwealth moves in, the States back away from their own responsibilities. After giving serious consideration to an amendment to restrict that extension facility to only research which was financed by the particular research and development corporation, we decided that may be too restrictive and may prevent it from using related extension arrangements, or related research and development arrangements for extension purposes, where it was necessary to tie the two together. The corporations need to look carefully at proposals for extension projects to ensure that they are not just financing something previously financed by a State government.

The Grains Council is also concerned that the different levels of levy for the different grains, and the varying levels for the same grain-particularly barley-in the different States, that exist in research councils are not lost to those specific commodities. It is only right and equitable that anything there should be retained for them. That is the purpose of another amendment.

We support the major purpose of the Bill, because research and development is very important for the competitiveness of agriculture. One of the great things about Australian agriculture is that it is research oriented. That is one of the reasons, along with its capital intensity and the fact that it has to face international competition every day, why it is our most efficient industry, and is the one that is sustaining our export drive.

As an interesting example of the different attitudes of the Government to research assistance and assistance generally, this Government is giving Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd $12m or $13m a year because it earns $200m a year in export income. The dairy industry, which will be one of the research and development corporations initially established, will earn close to $700m in export income this year. The Government's contribution to it will be about $2m, on a dollar for dollar basis, for research. I would like to know how much Kodak is putting into research.

If we look at the grain industry, we see that the figure for exports is even greater and that for Government assistance is proportionately less. I can go right through all the rural industries, including the wool industry, which exported $6 billion worth of product last year and will export at least $4 billion worth this year. Total exports amounted to $48 1/2 billion and, of that, $25 billion will be lopped off in a couple of years. The point I make to the Minister and the Government is that these are sensible, pragmatic, technical amendments to improve the legislation, not to frustrate or negate it. I ask the Minister to consider these amendments seriously between now and the time that they are dealt with in the Senate. We are prepared to discuss these amendments further because I believe that they are all worthy of serious consideration. In general terms, the Opposition supports the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has said, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill 1989 is designed to remove some of the restrictions of the old methods of research and development in the rural industry sector. It allows joint ventures, the taking up of patents and licences by the corporations, and more scope for the corporations to attract funds. The Bill embodies a couple of research areas which are of current importance to my electorate, the Northern Territory. A natural resource research and development corporation will be created. This will include the water research and development program currently operating under the Australian Water Research Advisory Council.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Territory we face a massive problem of mimosa infestation in some major water systems, specifically the Alligator River system. Mimosa is a weed. Where it gets control, it excludes all other plants and animals. Initially, people in the pastoral industry were concerned about it because it prevents beasts from getting to water. Then they realised that it had the potential to severely reduce carrying capacity. People in the tourist industry now realise that mimosa has the potential to undermine their businesses. It means that access to wetlands becomes impossible. It means that wetland birds are squeezed out as mimosa allows no other animals or plants to coexist with it. Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) scientists have told me that people think it is exaggerating the problem-that is, until they see the situation for themselves. They then compare it with the prickly pear infestations of the 1920s and 1930s.

Currently, mimosa covers half of the Oenpelli flood plain and, by the end of the wet, it has the potential to cover the whole of the flood plain. In the Adelaide River area it doubled its infestation in a year. It produces masses of seeds, and seedlings can develop in huge densities. They are light and rapidly dispersed by water, which is why each wet causes a rapid expansion of the problem.

Mimosa represents a unique combination of attributes. It has a unique biology and it threatens primary production, conservation and Aboriginal land in a way that no other weed does. No other weed in Australia has the awesome biological attributes of mimosa. Even by weed standards, mimosa is a formidable plant. It grows quickly and can produce seeds when only six months old. It produces huge numbers of seeds. An isolated plant can produce 90,000 seeds per year. To make matters worse, the seeds can float, so it can spread very quickly across the flood plains that are its main home. If one kills the plants there are still 10,000 seeds that can last for years in every square metre of ground. The end result is that the area of mimosa infestation can roughly double in a year. If we did nothing, we would have eight times the area of mimosa in three years. There is no other weed in Australia with these awesome biological attributes.

Unlike other weeds, mimosa can transform a range of ecosystems. Flood plains, swamp forests, pastures and even billabongs are all prime mimosa habitat. Mimosa converts them all to a monotonous shrubland in which no other species can persist. Other weeds are merely contaminants of ecosystems. Mimosa transforms ecosystems into something completely different. Mimosa is the greatest threat to primary production in the tropics since the prickly pear. Mimosa is low in palatability and explodes in response to overgrazing. The proposed new buffalo industry in the Top End will, in the view of some, promote the expansion of mimosa, which in turn will eventually choke out the industry. It is practically impossible to muster animals from dense thickets of this weed which, even now acts as a reservoir of stock, hindering the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign (BTEC).

In northern Thailand, with an economy based on agricultural production, mimosa is far and away the worst weed problem. Indeed, the Thai Government has set up a special task force to tackle it. Irrigation canals, reservoirs and agricultural land are all being choked by this weed. Mimosa is none too choosy about where it lives. Mimosa has only just begun to expand its range in Australia. It can thrive anywhere in the tropics with a rainfall of more than 700 millimetres. Clearly, it threatens the pastoral and sugar cane regions of north Queensland. It is a mammoth problem.

Mimosa is the most pressing threat to Kakadu National Park. Kakadu's wetlands are regarded by the park's managers as being endangered by mimosa, to the extent that four people are employed full time to patrol the park looking for this noxious weed. Mimosa threatens Aboriginal lands. Mimosa has already invaded Arnhem Land and it poses a threat to traditional methods of food gathering. No native plants and animals can exist where mimosa has taken over. We can probably control this weed cheaply, with biological control, if we act with urgency.

The CSIRO has laid solid groundwork for biological control. It has been working on the plant for a number of years, at a cost of nearly $1m, and now it has a large number of insects and fungal pathogens awaiting quarantine testing, followed by the rearing of massive numbers of them for release in the field. The funds now received by the CSIRO are not sufficient to do this as quickly as it must. In other words, a further injection of funds is required. It has been found that natural enemies have attacked leaves, stems, flowers and seeds. Some species have already been released. The more insects that are released the better the chances of fighting it.

The most promising herbicide for mimosa as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who is at the table, said-is graslan which costs $110 per hectare. It has to be applied twice or more to kill an infestation of mimosa. With biological control, after the initial research, there are no further costs. Mimosa was the only weed mentioned by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his statement on the environment. It is that significant. I believe that mimosa represents a great chance to demonstrate the Federal Government's commitment to preventing further environmental degradation. It would seem to me that the councils which are being set up under this legislation provide the opportunity for an injection of funds to be made to an appropriate council to enable it to solve the problem of mimosa infestation and to contribute to and assist in the work that has already been done by the CSIRO and other agencies.

Another area of important research which needs examination as a matter of urgency is the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign as it affects the buffalo industry. The legislation provides for a research and development council to be formed within the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation. In my view, this would be an appropriate research body to fund so it can look at brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication as it pertains to the buffalo industry.

It is important to recognise that buffalo are not beef cattle and that the BTEC tests are, at best, known to be extremely unreliable in relation to buffalo. There is no clear proof that tuberculosis is transmittable from buffalo to beef. While I understand that there is a 1992 deadline for BTEC for the cattle industry, there is a clear case for the buffalo industry to be treated differently and perhaps for the Australian meat and live-stock research council, or the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation, to undertake the work into the buffalo industry, including the application of BTEC. The buffalo industry is a potentially burgeoning industry for northern Australia, but it has to be treated sensitively.

I have mentioned these two subjects-mimosa and buffalo-because they interrelate. We have a prime opportunity to see what sensitive research can be done for not only conservation purposes but also sustainable economic development. We see a marriage of interests in these areas of research which can be undertaken profitably by the research councils which will be set up under this legislation which will assist conservation and, most importantly, the economic development of northern Australia. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Distinct from the corporatisation programs envisaged for the rural industries, the Government also intends in the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill to corporatise the operations of the national energy research development and demonstration program-better known as NERDDP-which is currently overseen by the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council-better known as NERDDC. Currently NERDDC carries out research in regard to energy related matters as well as coal related research. Coal related research is funded primarily by way of a compulsory levy known as the coal production excise. This excise raises 5c per tonne of black coal produced, which gives a total income of about $7 million each year.

SPEECH.PARA: Funds spent by NERDDC on coal research beyond the amount of the industry levy are drawn from the coal industry trust fund, which is itself the product of accumulated coal industry excise contributions. NERDDC's other energy related research is funded by way of government appropriations. In other words, the coal aspects of NERDDC are funded by way of a compulsory levy and those sections of NERDDC that deal with renewable energy, sustainable energy and conservation research are funded largely or totally by government funding.

The corporatisation program contained in the legislation seeks to split NERDDC into two distinct corporate research and development corporations: the National Energy Research and Development Corporation, and the Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation. The National Energy Research and Development Corporation will be funded from appropriation in line with current levels of expenditure. In other words, that body, NERDDC, will continue research into energy conservation and alternative or renewable sources of energy-solar and wind, to take two examples. However, the Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation will be funded only by way of the continuation of the coal excise as well as by the transference of the Coal Research Trust Account to the Corporation as envisaged in the legislation. The Government has made allowance for a review of this funding arrangement after the close of the 1992-93 financial year. Specific funding arrangements are not dealt with in this legislation, which is of a generic umbrella type. Details will be subject to discussions which are continuing between the coal industry and government, and will be articulated in the regulations. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy, however, has confirmed repeatedly that no appropriations will be used to underwrite or contribute to the Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation.

The industry is opposed to the current practice of conducting coal research within NERDDC by way of a compulsory levy. It wishes to see the coal excise abolished and the industry moved towards in-house research. The coal industry also contends that the proposed Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation is a redundancy. So far as the corporation is established in order to carry out industry related research, and, unlike the rural corporations, attracts no matching funding, the industry cannot see the purpose of this proposed arrangement.

Given that industry money alone would be supporting the proposed corporation, there is no justification for government bureaucratic intrusion into the administration and conduct of the industry's research effort. The creation of the Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation adds nothing to the efficiencies of the industry. Nor does it meet the urgent need for deregulation of the coal industry. The industry is already subject to an excessive degree of Commonwealth intervention, which has undermined its capacity to boost production and to respond to market forces. The industry would prefer to conduct its own research, utilising its own recently restructured and commercially oriented Australian Coal Industry Research Laboratories, amongst other organisations.

By calling for the abolition of the excise, the coal industry is seeking to model its research effort on the model used by the mineral sector, which carries out an ambitious research program through the Australian Mineral Industry Research Association. The research is not subject to a compulsory industry levy. The Association acts as a broker for the mining and mineral sector and has facilitated an active research and development program. The mining and mineral sector's overall research and development program attests to what the best industry sectors can do when left to their own devices.

I remind the House of some of the industries' technological initiatives in recent times. Consider the smelting technologies industry has developed. The direct iron ore smelting technology, referred to as Hismelt, of CSR Ltd offers not only lower capital costs but also a vast potential in utilising a more diverse range of raw materials in the steel production process. Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd is moving, by way of a joint venture project, towards the commercialisation of this technology with the construction of a $102m pilot plant. Similarly, MIM Holdings Ltd has utilised Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation breakthroughs in treating low value raw material by adapting the Sirosmelt technology to lead and copper. The outcome has been the Isasmelt smelting process, used primarily in lead smelting operations. There has been an 8 per cent boost in lead production and the construction of a new smelting plant at a cost of $50m. The results of the introduction of these processes will be an increase in the levels of production, improvements on the environmental impact of the plants and a rise in the amount of value added product we exported. The minerals industry understands that openness to technological change, as well as shift into downstream processing, is critical to international competitiveness.

Keeping the example of the minerals industry in mind, the coal industry is adamant it can reach a suitably diverse and high level of research and development activity without a coercive excise. Our traditional export industries are long used to competing in overseas markets and they fully realise the necessity to embrace leading edge technology. The National Energy Research and Development Corporation will continue to underwrite energy related research of national significance, as it does through the national energy research development and demonstration program. The coalition's resources and energy policy supports the present national energy research development and demonstration program and it would therefore be consistent to support the new National Energy Research and Development Corporation.

In summary, the Opposition does not oppose the creation of the National Energy Research and Development Corporation. However, we do oppose the Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation. We will be moving amendments to the Bill to excise references to the Corporation. One of the great fears I have about the legislation is that it sets the standard form of the research and development corporations but says nothing of substance. Everything is left to regulation. Vast powers are delegated to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). Certainly, the regulations are disallowable by Parliament. Nonetheless, the reality is that the Minister is being given a tremendous amount of delegate power.

I understand from discussions with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy that the reason that the legislation is so generally drawn and so lacking in specifics is that it would take a very much longer time-about 18 months-to bring before the Parliament in separate pieces of legislation all proposed research and development corporations' dealings with not only the agricultural industries but also the coal industry. That is something of an indictment on somebody, perhaps even this Parliament. The fact that a department can very quickly shunt through the Parliament a massive piece of legislation covering a great many diverse fields says something about the legislative process. Again, sadly, time does not allow me to expand further on this concern. But I do note that we are being asked to take the Government on trust to a very large extent. I will have more to say about the Opposition's amendments regarding the excising of any reference to the Coal Industry Research and Development Corporation during the committee stage.
Friday, 3 November 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill is to establish research and development (R&) corporations and a Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation (RIRDC) to provide for the funding and administration of research and development into agricultural industries.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear the Australia's dependence on agricultural exports is going to continue for some time, so the nation's prosperity for the foreseeable future will remain intimately connected with its primary industries. Research and development has received much public attention in Australia in recent years. It is seen by many as a major way of developing new industries, of achieving structural change and growth in the economy and of increasing the productivity and efficiency of existing industries. By international standards the money that Australia spends on research and development is low. The private sector in Australia generally appears to give low priority to research and development spending.

Research carried out in Australia has made a vital contribution to the superb track record of farmers in improving the efficiency of production. For example, surveys show productivity growth of between 1.5 and 2.5 per cent a year over the past 30 years on Australian sheep farms. Overall agricultural productivity growth over the last 20 years has been 2.8 per cent per annum compared with 2 per cent for manufacturing and one per cent for the economy as a whole. Commodity-specific R& spending is a major component of the total research and development effort. The rural industry research funds are financed by producer levies matched in terms of expenditure by government subsidies. In 1988-89 research expenditure by the relevant rural industry research funds is around $41m for wool, $29m for meat and $8m for wheat.

The Government has recently altered administrative and accountability arrangements for commodity-specific R& by establishing research councils or corporations to develop plans and budgets and set R& priorities. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is the main organisation doing relatively long-term research for Australian rural industries, especially in developing new technologies and products and where problems or opportunities exist at a national level or across State boundaries. Its role is complementary to those of State government departments and universities with whom it collaborates. The Organisation's rural research programs, which absorb close to half its resources, are undergoing a shift in emphasis to align them more closely to the needs of farm based industries.

Improvements in productivity off-farm are at least as important as those on-farm. Both process and product innovations are important sources of improved productivity beyond the farm gate. A good example of product innovation is the development of a means of giving machine washability characteristics to wool. Examples of process innovations are computerised selling of livestock and improvements in the retailing and processing of food. These types of innovations, along with increased farm productivity, contribute significantly to reducing the real cost of food to consumers while also providing higher returns to farmers.

An important source of innovation is the farmers' own experimentation. In an environment radically different from Europe, Australian farmers developed local technology based on dry land pastures and extensive livestock and crop production. A good deal of the rural research undertaken in Australia is funded from commodity specific rural industry research funds. These funds are generally sourced from compulsory industry levies matched by government contributions on a dollar for dollar basis.

An increasingly difficult problem for research managers is deciding on the spread of research projects-whether to continue on a wide front spreading resources even more thinly or to contract to fewer, better resourced but more isolated lines of work. We have to take into account the need to retain key disciplinary skills that are needed to keep abreast of and to exploit advances occurring elsewhere in the world. Once lost, such skills cannot be easily replaced. Recently gene shear technology was lost to France because funds could not be found to keep development of the project in Australia. These are the sorts of things that must not be allowed to happen.

The debate on investment in research is intimately connected with the question of how much the market or industry should influence the nature and direction of the research. This Bill highlights the emphasis this Government places on ensuring that all possible assistance is provided to maintain high level of research and development in the primary industry area. This Government is committed to keeping the agricultural sector of our economy at the leading edge in world markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his address at the 1988 National Agricultural Outlook Conference on behalf of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Dr Donald summarised the need for research in the following way:

SPEECH.PARA: Our agriculture is fragile and we need a major research effort to overcome problems in our agricultural resource base if we are not to go backwards. Indeed, the enormous potential of agriculture will not be recognised without maintaining a strong base of appropriate and up-to-date research skills and a climate in which original ideas can flourish.

I think that summarises the need for maintaining a strong research effort in Australia, particularly in the agricultural area. Since this debate seems to have been truncated so much, I would like very quickly to look at three points in the agricultural research area. The first is the Government's poor record in supporting rural research in many specific areas. The second is the growing problem of the mismatch of funds for specific project funds to the core funding that maintains the basic research facilities and the personnel. The third is the growing desire of this Government to go into short term research and its effort to try to pick winners.
To support the first point, in a booklet entitled Today's Research-Australia's Future CSIRO stated:

In the five year period from 1983/84 to 1987/88, CSIRO's agricultural research effort declined by 13.5 per cent, while that in State departments declined by only four per cent. Complete figures are not available for tertiary institutions over this period, but in the four years from 1984-85 to 1987/88 their effort in agricultural research declined by three per cent.

In other words, in all areas there was a decline in agricultural research over that period-a period which is wholly covered by this Government's stewardship. I think that highlights at least in some areas, and in very important areas, where this Government has failed to support agricultural research. To reinforce that I refer honourable members to the CSIRO Division of Soils annual report for 1988. The Chief of the Division stated:
. . . it has now experienced a cumulative reduction in government funds over the past six years of close to 30%. As a result Treasury funded staff numbers have declined from 190 to 150.

In other words, soil scientists are being sacked at the same time as Federal and State governments are pushing the problems of soil degradation. It seems totally irreconcilable with the Government's claim that it is concerned about land degradation.

Another point that has to be made is that we have a growing problem in the mismatch of funds. As was pointed out in a recent report of the Victorian Government from the Australian Institute of Agricultural Science, there is a growing problem where research councils of various commodities are trying to get State and other research centres to do the research but, in many cases, there are insufficient personnel and resources in what we might call the core funding area of these research centres. Accordingly, in some cases their research efforts are falling short. This was also highlighted by Professor Lloyd when he did his rural economic study in 1985. He offered one option as to how this problem might be addressed, but it is something that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) ought to be looking at seriously because it is a growing problem. As I pointed out, the other problem is the difficulty in a government trying to pick winners.
I remind honourable members of the words of Sir Gustav Nossal, who is one of Australia's leading research directors in the medical area. In 1982 he stated:

Who, for example, addressing the future of medical science a scant decade ago, would have predicted the stunning impact that recombinant DNA research (i.e. genetic engineering) would have on virtually every facet of biomedical investigation.

Again, this highlights the problem of the Government trying to go for short term research and pick winners. The Opposition is very concerned at the Government's approach to research and the way it seems to be cutting back on funds for places like the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, although the other day it had no difficulty in providing at least $13m a year for the next 5 years for Kodak, an industry that is earning only a fraction of the amount of export income that rural industries are earning. Unfortunately, because of the short time available to me, I cannot expand on those points, but there are a couple of very serious points involved that I think the Minister ought to be addressing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond very quickly to the points made by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd); and I will refer specifically to his second reading amendment and some of the amendments he has foreshadowed. I also want to make a few points about the amendments that I will be moving in the committee stage. Also, if time permits I shall address the comments made by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). First, in respect of the second reading amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, this is a broad amendment and the honourable member was at pains to point out that principally it concerns the dairy industry. I think people in the honey industry have the same sort of view on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been approached by the Australian Dairy Farmers Association and I understand what they are on about. I must say that I see some reasons why this measure makes sense. One of the chief reasons is that when the 0.5 per cent contribution level is reached, after which the Government's matching funding ceases-not that the dairy industry is anywhere near that-this will be a way of getting ongoing funds. However, I have been uttering a few words lately about consistent policy, to try to get a consistent basis to policy. We have just had a strategic planning review of research organisations and we have been giving this whole question a lot of thought.

Basically, the reason why I finally came down on not accepting what the dairy industry was enjoining me to do was the definition of whether it is a primary or manufacturing industry. Even if we wipe out any possibility of double dipping, which the industry does not want to be part of-and the amendment makes that quite clear-there is a definitional problem of whether cereal manufacturers can therefore contribute to wheat growers' funds, whether they are manufacturers or not. There is going to be a problem that perhaps the fiscal fiends in this town will say that farmers will pull back if money can be obtained through the dairy co-operatives, or whatever. The basis of the reason why I have been able to get vastly increased funds for research is that primary industries are atomistic. There is a quarantining and scrutiny problem that goes along with the definitional problem, and there is a problem with dollars that have strings attached to particular research projects and whether some of the research projects would have strings and thereby only go back to the firm providing the funds.

On balance, the Government will have to reject the second reading amendment. I understand the arguments fully. As I said, it was a very split decision in my own mind once I had this approach. In terms of the amendments foreshadowed, I have indicated that the Government will accept two of those amendments. I think there were 16 originally, and I understand that the honourable member will move those in the committee stage. The reason for my accepting those two amendments is that basically what they are saying is that when the Minister has approved the annual operational plan and all the rest of it, someone lets those involved know, and I have no objection to that.

As to the rest of the committee stage amendments that the honourable member was going to move-and I anticipate that they will still be moved in the Senate-there is a lot of nit-picking. Many of these matters relate to line relationships in a way, and a lot reflect the views from the farming fraternity, where it appears that they still do not quite understand the whole nature of what I am trying to put in place here-namely, the development of strategic relationships. I am insisting on consultation, but I still believe that at the end of the day we have to leave it up to the boards of the various research and development corporations; otherwise, it can very rapidly come back to some mindless farmer control because they put up the funds or half the funds. I really am insistent that there be proper consultation.

I believe that, as long as the proper strategic relationships are struck and the concept of accountability sinks in a lot further, we can achieve what the honourable member desires through his amendments. I give the honourable member the assurance that I will give his amendments further consideration. There is one other amendment that I was nearly prepared to accept, but there was a problem with it. However, we may be able to reach an accommodation in the Senate on one other.

My amendments allow for the transfer of outstanding moneys owed by the Commonwealth to research and development corporations, R &D funds and research councils. The moneys are to be paid to R &D corporations and R &D funds following transfer of the relevant levies. Such outstanding payments usually arise because of the 30-day delay between the Commonwealth seeking levies and the payment by the Commonwealth taking effect. The amendments also allow for the Governor-General to consider the recommendations of industry representative organisations prior to determining that the Bill's provisions regarding annual general meetings will apply to a particular R &D corporation.

I believe that there is a case for direct accountability of stakeholders at annual general meetings as a principal means of accountability for a specific industry. However, I recognise that, as with other industries, accountability of executive organisations which represent stakeholders may be more appropriate. The Government will determine a particular accountability mechanism to apply to each R &D corporation in agreement with the relevant industry. The Government does not intend to impose annual general meetings on industries and the amendment will ensure that this is the case.

Finally, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) raised a question about the Coal Research and Development Corporation. Quite frankly, at this stage I give him the assurance that I will take the Industry's views into account, and the views that have been expressed by the industry and the honourable member will be assessed further. The key thing in respect of coal is the fact that it is the largest export industry in the world, and its future is critical to the Australian economy, but relative to its size it is only a small funder of research and development. I am trying to put the levy which will go on to 1992 into a research corporation. That will be under industry control and industry direction.

I hope that, by making the industry focus on the direction of those funds rather than having a bit of bureaucracy as is the case at present, it will engage in strategic research. It will be very much a testing base for the future as to whether or not there is an ongoing role for research in this very important industry. The alternative is to have it go back to the department. The industry points out, as did the honourable member for Gippsland, that the Government will not provide any money in this area. I point out-and this bears on some of the points made by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker)-that with the science and technology statement we are upgrading research in quite a few areas, one of which will be in the National Energy Research and Development Corporation. That, with the moneys for greenhouse research, for example, which has direct relevance to the coal industry, becomes a pivotal point because all that money comes from the Government.

So, we are trying to provide a higher profile for coal research and development. We are trying to provide greater financial flexibility and commercial powers. After 1992 the corporation and levy mechanism will be reviewed in consultation with the industry. It will place the control of R &D directions for the coal industry in the hands of the coal industry through representative organisation provisions, accountability provisions and selection arrangements.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Messages from the Governor-General recommending appropriations announced.
