SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is basically a housekeeping Bill. A number of my colleagues will make detailed comments about specific provisions in this Bill. Its principal purposes are the extension from 30 June 1991 to 30 June 1993 of the 150 per cent research and development deduction scheme and to 30 June 1995 of a reduced rate of 125 per cent, and a number of other minor changes relating to the concessional taxation treatment of research and development expenditure. In addition, there are modifications to the basis for calculating franking credits, provision for exemption from income tax for the pay and allowance of Defence Force personnel while in Namibia, amendments to the treatment of capital gains tax in relation to long term leases, provisions to allow tax deductions for expenditure incurred by those who stood for election to the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly, provisions for the termination of the 100 per cent deduction for certain subscription moneys paid into initial shares of licensed management and investment companies, modification of requirements for employees to substantiate eligible transport payments, and a number of minor changes.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of my colleagues will focus their comments on specific provisions of the Bill. I foreshadow that I will be moving a second reading amendment in two parts. The first part focuses on the Government's record of taxation, and the second part is in lieu of a committee stage amendment which this deplorable process of guillotining legislation does not really allow time for. I have incorporated that as the second part of my second reading amendment. I emphasise the fact that I think this guillotine process is absolutely appalling and shows the incapacity of this Government to manage its affairs and the affairs of this House in an appropriate manner. Yesterday it squandered several hours rather than taking on issues as they were raised in the House. Generally as a long-term phenomenon the Government has an appalling record of incompetence in terms of House management.

This Government's record on taxation is unequalled. It stands as the highest taxing government in the history of Australia, with total tax revenue in this year, 1989-90, forecast to be 25 per cent of gross domestic product, having been as high as 25.2 per cent of GDP two and three years ago. This is a pretty outstanding record for a Government that claims to be a tax reform government. It claims to have reduced the burden of tax on the average Australian. The fact is that only those who have incomes above $35,000 have gained much at all under this Government in terms of tax relief; there has been a very heavy concentration of any benefits-and they are not great benefits-at the upper end of the income scale. The maximum rate of tax today cuts in at $35,000, as it did in the early 1970s. That level is 11/4 times average weekly earnings; in the early 1970s it was five times average weekly earnings. It has deteriorated rapidly in recent years. For example, somebody who has an income of 80 per cent of average weekly earnings is today on a 39c marginal rate. When this Government came into office they were on a 30c marginal rate.

If we listened to the rhetoric of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) we would be inclined to believe that the Government has reduced tax burdens on average Australians and that he has given back all that he has raised by way of inflation and bracket creep in the form of tax cuts. That proposition which he has put in this Parliament on a number of occasions is totally without foundation. If we do the exercise correctly and go back to the tax scales that prevailed from November 1982 onwards and we index those, we find that there is a net tax increase of $131/2 billion cumulative over the life of this Government over and above the tax cuts that it has given. That is, instead of Budget revenues being today somewhere around the low $90 billion mark, they would be around $80 billion or less, a substantial rip-off from the average Australian, a substantial increase in Government revenue and in the size of the public sector. On a number of occasions since we released our Economic Action Plan, we have asked whether the Government was prepared to match our commitment to give back bracket creep on an annual basis; that is, in each Budget we will announce an estimate for bracket creep for the previous financial year and we will announce how it will be given back.

I do not see any such inclination on the part of the Government. Indeed, some of the answers which were given today by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in relation to his claim for a new wage-tax package to be brought down next year implied that the Government was going to rely very heavily on bracket creep. As I said, the bottom line has been a $13.5 billion net increase in tax revenue through bracket creep alone. The Government prides itself on its having given tax cuts from 1 July this year. What bracket creep means in this financial year alone, according to estimates by Access Economics, is that roughly 50 per cent of those 1 July tax cuts will be clawed back within this financial year and within two financial years they will be more than clawed back.

The key point I wanted to focus on in terms of the Government's record is this tendency to do wage-tax deals. It has now emerged as a central element of taxation in Australia that taxation policy is substantially predetermined by the senior members of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), in particular Bill Kelty and Simon Crean in recent days, through their role as de facto Cabinet Ministers under the Hawke-Keating Government. These wage-tax deals are supposed to provide the wherewithal for the control of inflation; they are supposed to provide the mechanism by which the Government can bring down inflation and keep it under control. I am fascinated that in the various manifestations of the accord over the last several years, the rate of inflation has basically stuck in there rock solid at its current level of 8 per cent over most of that period. It has eased a bit and then has accelerated away, depending on the nature of our economic circumstances. Basically, we do not see any prospect under this Government of that inflation rate falling much below 7 or 8 per cent. The centrepiece of that, the floor that exists under it, comes from the wage determination process, from the accord's support of the centralised wage fixing system which pays across the board wage increases that are totally unrelated to productivity. It is that particular system which the Government tries to peddle as the solution to our economic problems which is one of the fundamental reasons for the problems that Australia faces today.

This week we had the spectacle of the Minister for Social Security breaking ranks and foreshadowing the fact that the Government would be bringing down another wage-tax deal early next year of about the same order of magnitude as the one that was brought down this year, his figure being $5.8 billion. Today we had statements by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the Parliament and yesterday we had statements by Senator Button and Senator Walsh to the effect that no discussions have taken place, although it is not clear whether it is formal or informal discussions which have not taken place. Bill Kelty is quoted in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald as saying that these discussions have taken place; that it has been agreed that there is a wage-tax deal to take place next year; and that it seems that it is to be of about the same order of magnitude as the one this year. Today we had the spectacle of a press release from somebody else from the ACTU who seems to be of the view that a deal is in the offing. That is Errol Hodder, a good friend of the Prime Minister and General Secretary of the Australian Workers Union, who put out a press release under the heading, `AWU Says Howe Was Right'. In a key point, Mr Hodder said:

. . . Treasurer Paul Keating should support the statement by Social Security Minister Brian Howe that the Federal government was looking at repeating this year's $5.8 billion tax and family package next year.
He also said:
Rather than contradicting each other, Federal Cabinet Ministers must respond positively to the challenge of the Opposition's recently announced economic policy.
I could not agree more with Mr Hodder in that respect. He continued:

Since the Liberals announced their new policy, the Government has basically resorted to negative attacks. However, there are many aspects of the policy which will appeal to workers and their families.
That is a key point. He said:
There are many aspects of the policy which will appeal to workers and their families.

So, much as the Treasurer, the Prime Minister and others may seek to denigrate our Economic Action Plan, the people who stand to gain most under that plan, the average Australian workers, are out there expressing their point of view in a very blatant way and expressing substantial support for what we have done. Mr Hodder also said that workers had for many years accepted the need for wage restraint and were now looking for wage increases and interest rate relief. Of course, we know that the policies being pursued by the Hawke-Keating Government cannot deliver either in a sustainable sense. When there are wage increases, they are usually unrelated to productivity and are unsustainable. If there is any prospect of interest rate relief-we have not seen any evidence of that yet, at least through to the middle of next year, according to the Treasurer's latest prediction-it will not be sustainable relief either. Until wages are related more directly to productivity and moved more in line with productivity, the Government will not get inflation down. If it cannot get inflation down and keep it under control, it will not get interest rates down and keep them under control.

Our unit labour costs are roughly double those of our trading partners, which is reflected in the fact that our inflation rate is roughly double that of our trading partners, which in turn is reflected in the fact that our interest rates are roughly double the average of our trading partners, or a little more because of the increasing risk perceived to be associated with Australian dollar assets as reflected in the recent downgrading of our international credit rating by Standard and Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service. Mr Hodder went on to say:

Instead of pandering to the environment vote, the Prime Minister should be addressing the basic financial difficulties faced by ordinary Australians. The Government will only by re-elected for a fourth term if it acts positively on behalf of its natural constituency.

I do not agree with that comment. It does not have a hope of being re-elected for a fourth term, but he makes a very valid point about the financial difficulties being faced by ordinary Australians. I conclude with Mr Hodder's very interesting quote:
If our members are to accept the new wage system-
that is the most direct and blatant threat we have heard for some time-

they have to be assured that it will provide meaningful gains for them. It would also help if the Government was seen to be acting on behalf of workers and their families. At the moment, the Government seems to be drifting towards the next election without a clear programme of relief for the very tough times being faced by most Australians. They expect more from a Labor Government.

Of course, I could not agree more with that statement. The whole of Australia expects more of its government. Australian families and workers are in very difficult economic circumstances. This Government has no effective response. If we take the perspective of Mr Hodder, he is basically saying that his membership was duped a year ago. It was locked into a deal through the ACTU processes under the accord to hold earnings to 6 1/2 per cent, in the Treasurer's expectation as it was put out at Budget time that inflation would fall to 3 or 4 per cent by the middle of 1990. In the last Budget, the Treasurer came out and admitted that inflation was locked in at around 7 1/2 per cent to 8 per cent on his most optimistic forecasts, and there is very little prospect of that being brought under control in the foreseeable future. The Government thought it had locked in a real earnings increase but it had actually locked in a real earnings decline, which is the main reason we are seeing this sort of statement from Mr Hodder today, the main reason the ACTU took so long to accept the principles of the last wage decision and the main reason we are seeing lots of examples of pressure on the wage determination process.

I conclude with one specific comment on my foreshadowed motion. I want to draw attention to a particular deficiency in one of the clauses of the Bill relating to long term leases and, in particular, to urge the Government to consider allowing a full cost factor to be taken into account when determining capital gains tax liabilities in relation to subleasing. I move:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) deplores the Government's economic mismanagement and, in particular, its record as the highest taxing government in Australia's post-war history; and
(2) calls on the Government to allow a full cost factor to be taken into account in determining the capital gains tax liability of sub-leasing''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill covers a number of areas but I shall confine my remarks to one aspect tonight and that is the provision dealing with changes to the substantiation rules for travelling allowances paid under industrial awards, which have been increased since 29 October 1986. The law as it now stands provides that the income tax substantiation rules will not apply to claims by employees for fares, car expenses or other transport costs incurred in the course of their employment, so long as their claim is within the limits of an allowance paid to them under an industrial award that was in place on 29 October 1986 and providing that the allowance has not been increased since that date. If the amount of the allowance payable under the award has been increased after 29 October 1986, the employee is generally required to substantiate the whole claim, including the amount payable prior to 29 October 1986. Likewise, if the amount of the claim exceeds the amount of the allowance, then the whole claim is subject to substantiation requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments in the Bill propose to modify these requirements to enable employees to claim a deduction against travel allowance paid pursuant to an industrial award that was in place on 29 October 1989, whether or not that allowance has been increased, without being required to meet the substantiation rules. This will only apply to claims which are not in excess of the amount of the allowance that was payable under the award on 29 October 1986.

Employees wishing to claim a deduction for expenses above the amount of the allowance payable at that date will be required to substantiate additional payments above the amount of the allowance payable under that award. It is proposed that the amendment would apply to expenses incurred on or after 1 July 1988, and the cost is estimated at less than $100,000 per annum. The amendment will remove an artificial barrier which has restricted movement in the rate of transport allowances payable under industrial awards since 1986. I am sure that will be welcomed by the trade union movement, which has had some difficulty amending those awards. The proposed new rules will not apply to reimbursements of car expenses payable on a rate per kilometre basis as these payments will continue to be dealt with under the existing laws.

Further amendments in the Bill deal with certain matters concerning car records required for substantiation purposes. Under amendments made by the Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 4) 1988 taxpayers were required by the substantiation provisions of the income tax law to specify or nominate certain matters in their income tax returns. The matters that were required were those relating to claims for car expense deductions, including the business percentage of the claim and/or details of replacement cars, among other details. The 1988 amendments removed the need to put these details in the completed returns of income and, instead, provided that taxpayers kept that information in car records held in their possession.

Those amendments, though, contained two omissions which this Bill seeks to correct. First, a reference in subparagraph 82ktg (g) (iii) (a) which should have been altered to refer to car records held by the taxpayer was overlooked in the original amending legislation. This reference continued to refer to information specified in the taxpayer's return. Clauses 13 and 29 of this Bill provide a technical amendment which rectifies this matter. The rules relating to car records that were inserted by Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 4) 1988 also omitted to require that the car records be retained by the taxpayer for a specified period. This Bill proposes to require that taxpayers keep the car records for 3 1/2 years from the date the return for that year is lodged or seven years if the car was used to earn non-salary and wages income. The period that records for a particular year must be retained is further extended if the records are relevant to a later year.

If the car records are lost or destroyed they will be treated in the same way as other records that are lost or destroyed; that is, a replacement document may be acceptable. Transitional arrangements apply for people who may have disposed of their records prior to the introduction of this Bill. They will be able to use a copy of those records or a substitute record, as if they were original car records. It is proposed that the amendments have effect from the same date that the original rules dealing with car records applied-that is, 1 July 1986. Provisions in the Bill prevent taxpayers being disadvantaged by the amendment.

This Government is enhancing innovation through creating an environment conducive to investment and profitability. These measures include: taxation measures which foster investment and risk taking; promoting the formation of venture capital markets; and encouraging skill formation and an adequate supply of work force skills. Industrial research and development, and hence industry's capacity to innovate, will be enhanced if the private sector now takes up its part. The development of technology-based industries is expensive and of high risk. It is justified, however, by the potential returns and by the deleterious consequences of not participating in this development.

Future participation of Australian companies in wealth creation will be enhanced if the resources of the public sector are developed and used to bolster industrial capacity; Australia's many small companies are encouraged to grow; foreign companies play a more active and positive role in research and development in Australia and in the early acquisition of technology by Australian firms; and government agencies act to enhance the participation of Australian companies in global operations, including penetrating overseas markets and participation in international research and development programs.

This Bill, by extending the concessions and the other amendments it makes, will allow just such steps to be taken. This Government has taken the steps to make sure we are not left behind. It is now up to Australian industry to go the next step and show some faith in Australia and the research and development now taking place in this country to help keep it here for the benefit of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to touch upon a couple of specific measures in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 but, before I do, I remind the House that this Bill includes 14 separate adjustments to various Acts, including the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. If honourable members prefer to break up those measures, which I have counted as one, that will affect research and development deductions for taxation purposes, there are about 21 separate measures in this Bill which is being guillotined through. This Bill was brought before the Parliament on 31 May and has only now been brought before the House for discussion under the guillotine. I do not know whether anyone need go any further to indicate the legislative incompetence of the Government in the way it brings its legislation before the House. This Bill was introduced on 31 May and here we have it for discussion, under the guillotine, towards the end of the Budget session.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) might listen to this. I am not being critical of him, but I also want to refer, amongst other things, to substantiation requirements. I think what I have to say might help him in advising his constituents because, as he has rightly pointed out, one of the measures in this Bill involves changes to substantiation requirements. An exemption has hitherto applied to substantiation claims for deductable expenses against allowances in industrial awards nominated or known as transport allowances in those awards; that is, awarded allowances for travel to and from places of work did not have to be substantiated for tax deductability purposes.

The first and most important point of interest about the administration of the principal Act in this connection is that this exemption did not apply to any other sectors of the work force. The cost of travelling to and from work generally is not deductable for tax purposes. Only the privileged few who were lucky enough to be covered by an award which designated the cost of travelling to and from work as an entitlement have had their travelling expenses deemed deductable. In political terms, that discrimination against the bulk of the taxpaying work force and in favour of a minority of unionists is a pay-off-nothing more and nothing less-to the lords and masters of this Labor Government in the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).

However dodgy and however deplorable, that might just have been another example of this Government's abuse of power. I say `might' because public perceptions of the standards of propriety expected under Labor governments, State and Federal, have fallen in line with the very standards set by those governments. Regrettably, there is even more to it than that. The present discrimination is not written into the Act. The Government did not make an up-front decision and, with courage, state publicly and for all to see that it would treat awarded transport allowances in a way which conferred privilege on a comparative few. It did not do so, presumably, because that would have been too straightforward and honest.

How did it go about it? What craven device was employed to get the result the Government had to deliver at the behest of its ACTU masters? It got the Australian Commissioner of Taxation to do its dirty work once again. What else? Never mind that such allowances paid by employers to employees are included in the definition of salary and wages in section 26 (e) of the principal Act and are therefore subject to tax and tax instalment deductions. A way had to be found around that and, of course, the Commissioner obliged. The means by which the Commissioner obliged was not too difficult to find, although it is usually used to persecute taxpayers rather than provide tax relief-albeit the narrow, selective tax relief in this case.

Surprise surprise: the Commissioner drew on his vast discretionary powers, this time those granted in section 221d. Section 221d of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 gives the Commissioner the right to vary the amounts to be deducted from the salary or wages of an employee or class of employees. To give this discretionary right a format, guidelines are issued. However, the guidelines issued by the Commissioner are issued by none other than the Commissioner himself-the relevant ones in this case being IT2487 and IT2488. Subparagraphs 4 (c) in the first and 5 (c) in the latter stipulate that variations may be granted upon a request being made by an organisation or association, or by individuals. It was as a consequence of variation requests to alter the general rules laid down in the Act that the discrimination to which I have referred arose.

In this Bill it is intended to amend the principal Act relating to award transport allowances. The favoured few will not lose an exclusive benefit, although entitlements are to be modified. Section 82kz (8a) is to be changed so that substantiation rules will no longer be a matter decided at the discretion of the Commissioner. In future, substantiation rules will not apply to claims for tax deductable expenses against an award transport allowance as that allowance stood at 29 October 1986, even if the allowance has been subsequently increased. To give an illustration, building trades awards provided a fares and travelling allowance of $7.60 a day as at 29 October 1986. It is intended that a building worker taxpayer will not be required to substantiate claims of up to $7.60 a day, even though the daily award allowance has since been increased to at least $8.70 the last time I looked, and maybe more. However, if a building worker in future claims in excess of the $7.60 daily allowance, that taxpayer will have to substantiate all deductions claimed against that allowance.

This is the point I want to bring to the attention of the honourable member for Oxley because he might find that he will have a few complaints. For example, if a building worker taxpayer were to claim the present allowance of $8.70 a day as fully deductable, the same taxpayer would have to substantiate the entire $8.70 and not just $1.10 as might be expected. With the passage of this amendment an ambush will be in place for the unwary worker taxpayer who, out of ignorance, does as in the past and claims the entire award transport allowance. He or she will be bound to substantiate the lot. The chances of any worker having kept the necessary records will be very remote indeed when the not so friendly tax man confronts the affected taxpayer. The chances are that most will be required to pay tax on the full allowance at the appropriate marginal rate.

At the same time, employers will presumably have to deduct pay as you earn instalments on, in the example given, the $1.10 a day difference between the October 1986 award transport allowance and the one currently being paid. That is a dog's dinner of an arrangement if ever there was one-and all in the name of what? It is in the name of favoured treatment demanded by the ACTU and cravenly accepted by this Treasurer (Mr Keating).

Another provision in the Bill under consideration is a requirement that copies of employment declaration forms be retained by employers for a year after the details declared have ceased to have any relevance. Until now, after the end of a financial year when new forms are received for the current year, the old ones could be discarded. That is quite sensible because old forms and the information contained in them are useless and superseded in the hands of employers. To keep them for another year would involve unnecessary and wasteful administration costs.

After all, Australian taxation offices (ATOs) were, and are still to be, provided with the original of those forms. The ATOs already have them. Given reasonable efficiency and information retrieval systems, the ATOs could extract declared information if such was required about any employee. In future, with tax file number legislation in place and promised efficiency permeating all ATOs, such efficiency should be there for the asking-at the press of a button, so to speak. That is not to be. It is wishful thinking, I am afraid.

The wonderful progress we were led to believe tax file number law represented cannot even address access to information as fundamental and readily available as that given to ATOs in employment declaration forms. Not to worry, the Treasurer is not one to let his own lack of administrative excellence lead him to require the Commissioner to improve his game. As so often is the case, the solution is to foist the responsibility on to his unpaid tax collectors who are the long suffering employers. Never mind that hitherto, in pre-tax file number days, and in future, employers were and will be bound to collect and file with the ATOs declaration forms for each and every employee under pain of considerable penalty for an employer's non-compliance.

The Commissioner's operatives cannot be expected to dig up this information if the need arises. If his sleuths need it or use the new requirement in the course of an investigation of the premises of an employer to harass that employer because the need is unlikely to be known, given past practices, another obscure imposition becomes another bargaining chip in the hands of the ATO and its delegates.

It is reasonable to conjecture in this way. It is reasonable, if only because there is not one single word or sentence in either the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) or the explanatory memorandum which tells us why employers across the country should keep, for another year, millions upon millions of employment declaration forms in storage on their premises, presumably so some incompetent can demand that one or all of them be produced on some whim or pretext. The Government tells us clearly enough what must be done in future but not why. What is the big secret? One would think that if it is worth doing it is worth giving reasons which can be debated and discussed.

The Treasurer is ever happy enough to have the wool pulled over his eyes when it comes to administration of tax Acts, for which he alone is ultimately responsible. He has in the past shown a disregard for the niceties by failing to lodge his personal return within the statutory limit and getting off scot-free-although that is another story-along with claiming an unlivable house as his principal place of residence in order to claim tax-free travel allowance even though he lives with his family in Canberra. It does show he has the ability to take advantage of his privileged position. It also demonstrates that he has the wit, but not the inclination, to see fair play in the administration of the tax collection process. The Treasurer's ready compliance with what is asked of him by the Commissioner of Taxation or his bureaucrats, without question and without giving reasons to the Parliament, can only be due to either his ignorance or his arrogance. Either way, it is not a pretty picture. It is indicative of a laxity on the part of the pre-eminent fiscal fiend in the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset in this debate, which is concerned with the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), I would like to put on the record once again the fact that the whingeing we have heard from those on the Opposition side about the guillotine being applied would not have occurred had the Opposition not wasted hours and hours of the Parliament's time over the last couple of days with absolute nonsense, spurious motions and decisions to try to suspend standing orders and just waste the time of people having to come in here and vote on those sorts of issues. A number of the aspects of the taxation laws in this legislation will go to the continuing drive of this Government to clean up the tax system. It makes it fairer; it makes it more operable; it cuts out all the rorts in the taxation system; and it goes to the very heart of some of the real concerns out there in the community. Tonight I will dwell on one or two of those.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that the shadow spokesman on science and energy, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), is here. I have no doubt that in his contribution he will refer to the research and development activities and the fact that in this legislation the dispensation for the 150 per cent deduction scheme will be extended to 30 June 1993 and the 125 per cent deduction scheme will operate until 30 June 1995. Clearly, one of the things that have been an impediment to this country's continued development has been the inability of Australian companies, once they have developed a level of expertise in industry, to market it.

I will give some examples. There is a technology corporation at the University of Wollongong. It was started with an injection of funds by the Commonwealth Government under the steel regions assistance program. It is now operating successfully as an opportunity for incubator industries to develop and to get involved in research, technology and development initiatives for Australia. Recently one such program was so successful that unfortunately the university could not afford to carry it any longer. It had to seek capital from another source in the economy-in this case, the State Bank in New South Wales, which purchased a majority shareholding in that particular company. As a result of that, it has recently provided an immediate injection of further funds, not only to establish the company in a much bigger entity, with quite a number of additional staff being employed, but also for research and development.

Under this legislation they will get the taxation benefit, but what they are doing is providing state of the art technology, research and development, in electronic document transfer. That is where it is going to be in that particular area in the future. It is a very important step. So I would certainly say that, as part of the Government's science statement put out in May of this year, this particular part of the legislation, which does give the accelerated tax deductability, will be found to be an extremely important component in extending the ability of Australian companies to get involved in research and development activities. We can no longer afford to have technology developed by Australian companies within this university setting, within the research and development capabilities of companies themselves, being taken offshore simply because there is a lack of finance, a lack of forethought or a lack of ability of companies to meet commitments. I think that this accelerated tax deductability, as I have said, will go some way to looking after it.

I want to talk very briefly about another couple of issues; firstly, the piece of the legislation that goes to election expenses. Of course, what we are doing is simply tidying up the system in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) as it applies to the rest of Australia. We are making available and claimable here deductions by candidates seeking election to the Legislative Assembly for the ACT. This is again extending a piece of the legislation which is extremely significant. It should apply in the Australian Capital Territory, particularly now that the ACT has moved to a system of self-government. Candidates, whether for the Sun-Ripened Warm Tomato Party, the Party! Party! Party! Party, the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party, the Residents Rally, or whoever it might be to stand for election in this Territory, can rightly now claim those election expenses incurred while seeking election.

Finally in the short time that is being made available to me tonight, I would like to go to the issue of the tax file number. What we are doing here is amending the Bill so that it will now be a requirement that a copy of an employment declaration be retained by an employer until the close of the income year after the income year during which the declaration ceases to have effect. Amendments are also being made to ensure that the tax file numbers are recorded on group certificates and tax check sheets issued for eligible termination payments where the numbers are quoted to the payer on a form provided for that purpose. There will be a negligible effect on revenue as far as the Government is concerned, so any of those nonsensical comments about highest taxing, biggest spending government in Australia's history certainly do not apply in this case. Tidying up the tax file number system, which has clearly been one of the major advances put forward by this Government, to clamp down on the abuse of the taxation system, is going again to prove to be a boon to the taxation administration.

Finally, I would like to say-and a thought just came to me-that the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) in his contribution on this legislation being put forward by this Government to tidy up the tax system, to make it fairer, to stamp out the rorts and eliminate the tax cheats in the system again put forward this catchcry of the Opposition that the Commissioner of Taxation and his officers are in some way the bully boys of the Government, going out there and forever chasing down the last dollar. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has spoken at length in this place about the numerous attempts to bludgeon the public servants of this country that are doing their jobs on behalf of a government elected by the people of this country and who will continue doing their jobs whatever government happens to be in power after the next election. I fully believe that those continual attacks on the propriety of public servants in this country, those in the Australian Taxation Office and the Tax Commissioner in particular, are to be deplored. They are nothing short of appalling. The legislation will make an appropriate continuing attack in the process of tidying up the tax system. It will make the system fairer and a much better system. The legislation certainly deserves the support of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inter alia, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1989 seeks changes to the 150 per cent tax deduction scheme for company research and development. The scheme has been in place since July 1985 and the Bill before the House this morning intends to extend the scheme's life and broaden the grounds for deductability for appropriate expenditure incurred after 20 November 1987. The extension of the tax concession will have a massive financial impact in regard to revenue forgone by the Commonwealth. The extension of the deduction in the manner I have described will cost the Commonwealth $200m in each of the years 1992 to 1993 and $120m in each of the years 1994 to 1995 and 1995 to 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: All up, the extension of the research and development tax concession scheme will cost $640m. The decision by the Government to extend the research and development tax concession is not a matter to be taken lightly by this Parliament. Financial commitments of this magnitude require closer scrutiny by the Parliament. If one calculates the sum of the revenue forgone over the life of the scheme from 1985 to 1995-96, it amounts to well over $1 billion. In fact, the sum of anticipated natural forgone revenue associated with the scheme over its life will be about $1.2 billion, the period 1985 to 1988 having cost $510m, while it is anticipated that the amount forgone for the period 1989 to 1995 will be $640m.

With a financial impact of this magnitude it is vital that the community and those supporters of the scheme in particular understand that the Opposition is duty bound to scrutinise closely the public benefit involved in the extension of the concession. While it is tempting indeed to join with the Government in accepting the legislation as it is in respect of the research and development tax scheme, the Opposition's own policy position adopts a more responsible position by far.

In accepting the need for the scheme to continue until at least June of 1991 we will, when in government, carry out a thorough and objective review of the concessional treatment of research and development before committing ourselves to its further extension. As this House will know, the scheme's early administration was seriously questioned by the Auditor-General as well as by the Industry Research and Development Board. The Auditor-General found that the scheme was open to abuse by those creative accountants seeking tax avoidance measures. Amongst the Auditor-General's specific concern was that syndicates buying into research and development were seeking eligibility for the concession on very spurious grounds indeed. Some of these syndicates were investing significant sums of money in areas of technological innovation which actually entail very little risk indeed but broadly met the eligibility criteria for the tax concession.

I am pleased to find that recently the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) proposed amendments to the legislation governing the 150 per cent tax scheme which seek to close off avenues through which syndicated research and development can divest itself of risk taking in relation to the concessional scheme. I am curious to know how extensive the misuse of the incentive scheme was over the years between the inception of the scheme and the rulings on eligibility. Such abuses which have led to these actions having been taken have not served the Parliament's confidence in the scheme at all well. Such confidence also took a beating from the Industry Research and Development Board's own report of the operation of the scheme. In that report of last March, the Board questioned, on pages 6 and 14, the capacity of our industry within the context of its present level of infrastructure to successfully commercialise those innovations which do emerge from the industry research and development process.

The volume of management skills and the amounts of venture capital available within the Australian economy have served to undermine the effectiveness of the tax concession scheme. Scepticism has also been rife amongst our scientific community, which is concerned by the hard evidence regarding the scheme's track record in creating jobs and projects in their fields of research. I consider this to be fair comment by the scientific community. As the science statement of 8 May 1989 was predicated on the extension of the 150 per cent tax concession scheme, the scientists have every right to see the scheme have a significant job project return.

The Minister capped this debate when it first broke out as a result of the concerns of Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) divisional chiefs, but since then the debate has run through the pages of the science-orientated press. One such study published in June this year seriously questioned the claims by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce that the scheme had created 12,500 new and real jobs in science. The divisional chiefs of CSIRO contended that this figure was blown out by the tendency of the Government to count existing jobs which had been redefined to meet the deductability criteria for the scheme. The study, as published in the June edition of Search, contended that there was little empirical evidence that the scheme itself had been responsible for job growth in science.

One could contend that such expanded opportunities as there were for scientists might well have come about just as readily if the tax concession scheme had not been in place. My point is that we need to judge the effectiveness of the scheme more thoroughly before the coalition commits itself to a costly extension of the concession into the mid-1990s. The central problem facing Parliament on the matter of the extension of the scheme is the extent to which the 150 per cent tax concession is in itself actually making a dramatic change to the rates of R &D being carried out by industry and whether or not the results of this R &D are being commercialised to a degree which warrants the massive outlays associated with its extension.

These are complex issues requiring close evaluation. I remind the House of the size of the number that we are dealing with here. In the period 1985-88, private sector R &D rose from $646m in 1984-85 to $1.07 billion in 1986-87. This was a net increase of $423m in investment in R &D in the two years to the end of 1986-87. This was achieved at a cost to the Government of $310m. Assuming that the R &D result for business over this period was a direct result of the concessional scheme, for an outlay of $310m we got $423m in increased business R &D. I consider that only a slight achievement at best and one well worth examining further in order to ascertain the full effect of any possible multiplier.

To be sure, there have been modest increases off a small base in industry R &D in recent years. We are slowly rebuilding our industry R &D rates back to where they were in the 1960s, following the slump of the past 20 years, which saw our R &D effort reduced by more than half. On the most recent statistics for the period 1987-88, business now carries out R &D at a rate equivalent to 0.45 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). This is a continuation of the upward trend since 1984-85, when the corresponding figure was 0.34 per cent of GDP. Though moving off these shallow bases, the average real rates of increase in business R &D for 1984-85 to 1986-87 was about 19 per cent. Owing to the October 1987 stock market collapse this rate collapsed in the year 1987-88 to only 5.6 per cent. The average real growth rate for private sector R &D over the period 1985-88 is therefore 14.9 per cent, on Australian Bureau of Statistics figures.

Though we have been able to sustain some moderate growth in our business enterprise R &D, it is difficult to do any more than correlate these trends with the existence of the 150 per cent tax scheme. This is especially so when we note that business enterprise R &D was already on a reasonably healthy road to recovery in the period before the introduction of the scheme. In 1984-85 the annual real growth rate had reached almost 18 per cent in an unassisted environment. Even allowing for some of the anomalies in this figure, a comparatively substantial private sector R &D push was in evidence before the scheme took effect.

Incidentally, these rates of real growth might seem impressive but they are a good distance from the compounding 25 per cent annual real growth rates which the report of the Australian Science and Technology Council (AUSTEC) entitled Improving Australia's competitiveness through industrial R &D claimed must be maintained into the 1990s if we were just to meet the 1987 level of comparable Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) nations. We needed a 25 per cent annual real growth rate. What we need then is an evaluation of the effect of the 150 per cent tax scheme which provides clear lines of casual connection.

Business R &D was already on an upward trend in the early to mid-1980s, so it is tempting to dissociate the continuation of that trend from the possible catalytic effect of the scheme, but even more questions need to be asked of our overall approach to R &D. Can our present industry infrastructure and levels of structural change sustain even the rates of R &D that ASTEC claimed were essential, just to reach a point of comparable competitiveness? Why is it possible for unassisted business R &D rates in 1968-69 to be higher than they are now if it were not for the changed economic climate?

Ought we to be grafting our R &D policies to areas of the economy such as the primary sector which have the cash flow to engender a substantial and tangible R &D effort? It is my understanding that European countries facing similar problems in regard to establishing a greater private sector led R &D effort have pursued this approach with some success. We need to know whether targeting of this type is superior to across-the-board industry concession such as the tax concession here under consideration by the House.

In drawing to a conclusion, I point out that as a result of these outstanding concerns, and before throwing its lot in with the Government's plans to extend the 150 per cent research and development tax scheme out of the mid-1990s, the Opposition will seek to undertake a review of that scheme. This is especially necessary in the context of the recent admission by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce that his industry policy has failed and he does not know what to do next.

It might well be timely for the coalition, when in government, to reconsider innovative measures for effecting real change to the way industry responds to opportunities for research and development. Moreover, the community must be guaranteed that the huge sums of money involved in the tax concession actually return a suitable public worth, and there are no better ways of targeting the scheme at hand. As I have said, I think the very existence of the scheme is a testament to the failings of the Government's economic policies.

If it were not a fact that Australian companies were paying higher interest rates by far than our regional competitors-20 per cent plus here compared with between 3 and 6 per cent regionally- and if it were not for the fact that industry laboured under high rates of inflation and low levels of productivity the very problems the scheme is seeking to correct would not exist. The incentive for industry to invest in its own future is not provided in the legislation before the House tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow such a determined bulldog as the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). I suggest that next time one of his staffers writes a speech he should read it before he gets in here. The honourable member for Gippsland suggested that the Opposition was very concerned about leakage of revenue through this scheme. The Government believes that a platform needs to be put under research and development. It is the launching pad for restructuring Australia's economy. This legislation is an essential arm of that. I accept the causal relationships mentioned by the honourable member in his speech but, whether or not they are the case, it is clear that this is a policy structure which is readily endorsed by those involved in research and development and it is certainly something that I would support.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Opposition's approach and what will it do? The ubiquitous review. That is the Opposition's solution. If the Opposition came into government, and God forbid that it should happen, we would have the ubiquitous review. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) rabbited on about how the Government was the captive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and therefore substantiation in some areas was not applied equally across the board. Of course, he is a recipient of the advantages of substantiation as a member of this place. So is there not a small degree of hypocrisy in that cry from the honourable member? His suggestion that substantiation be removed is an indication of the fiscal discipline which the Opposition is able to apply when it comes to taxation revenue. Clearly, while he may parrot the assertion in respect of the Government and its relationship with the union movement, it would be fair for us to say that there is the possibility of significant leakage of revenue for those who are friends of the Opposition.

I do not wish to repeat the debate about the capital gains tax. I mentioned it first in this House last week. However, it is clear that the Opposition's policy on the capital gains tax is an embarrassment to it because it has not really been well thought through. I have not heard one Opposition member defend the philosophical background of that change in this place. The Opposition says in its Economic Action Plan:
This should particularly help smaller business-
I accept that that may be the case-
and encourage longer term investment and savings.

I refute that suggestion but if it is the case I plead with the Opposition to tell me how the retrospective nature of that tax will affect that aim. Simply, it cannot. Those decisions which were made up to five years ago cannot in any way be affected in the long term by the retrospective nature with which the Opposition intends to introduce this taxation measure. That is very clear to those of us on this side of the House. I will not put it any more simply than this: many friends of the Opposition, the one per cent of taxpayers who will pay capital gains tax, will benefit from this decision. There are many, amongst them John Elliott, who will benefit from the decision who had a say in its making.

The capital gains tax has become part of the landscape of taxation in this country. It is an issue which is accepted by many of us in this place and by the general population. It provides equity. I am sure the honourable member for Curtin would understand one of the old adages in respect of taxation: income is income is income. Whether it is income from rent, from wages, from interest, from profits, or from dividends, it should be treated in the same way. If one makes a real profit on a capital gain over time, it is income at the time it is realised and it should be treated as such. I do not think there is any shying away from that aspect of the proposal that the Opposition has put forward. It will create inefficiencies. It will open up the possibility for the tax avoidance industry to thrive as it previously did.

There are a number of other elements in the legislation which go to improving and tightening the area of revenue collection for the Government. There are proposals in respect of the tax file number and substantiation, which I believe most of us in this place would support. I notice also that there is a provision to provide an exemption from paying income tax on the pay and allowances earned by Defence Force personnel while allotted for duty in Namibia. On Sunday I will be attending the War Veterans' Home's remembrance services in my electorate. I have no doubt that many of those who live in that home in Menora will believe that this is something they would agree to. Surely those who are serving this country in Namibia deserve some consideration and extra benefits. There is provision within this legislation for exemption of taxation on income tax for pay and allowances of those who are serving in Namibia. The shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), would endorse this position. I know that he has spoken many times in this place for the veterans whom he purports to represent.

Finally, while the legislation represents an omnibus piece of government policy a whole number of areas are being reduced. We regret the late hour at which it is now being debated. We regret the curtailing of the debate that has become necessary. It needs to be understood by those who are listening-the galleries are not full-that yesterday in this place we had 24 divisions, taking up four minutes each. Hours of debating time was wasted on Opposition shenanigans. Those people who sit on the other side in unction and humbug and suggest that it is the Government's fault that we are here now should look at themselves and the way in which they have behaved over the last few days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) which was brought into the House last May. We are debating it under a guillotine. This is a reflection on the way in which this Government manages its business. It is a Bill which when all is said and done is fiddling around the edges of the whole taxation situation. There are a couple of important components but it does not in any way address the point which is made in the amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). He drew attention to the fact that he deplored the Government's economic mismanagement and, in particular, its record as the highest taxing government in Australia's postwar history.

SPEECH.PARA: We have only to look at the figures. If we compare 1982-83, the last year of the Fraser Government, with the projected 1989-90 estimates we will find that revenue has gone up from $44.4 billion in total to $97 billion. That is a massive 123 per cent increase over that period in which the rise in the price index will be in the vicinity of 85 per cent. There has been a tremendous exploitation of Australian taxpayers under the Labor Government. It is very interesting to note the massive increase in the wholesale sales tax to which the shadow Treasurer referred, which has gone up from $3.5 billion in 1982-83 to an estimated $10.6 billion in 1989-90. That is a 200 per cent increase. Much of it has occurred since 1985 when the Treasurer sought to implement a broad-based consumption tax. That increase in the wholesale sales tax of something over 200 per cent, mainly concentrated in that period, shows the contempt of this Government for the average Australian taxpayer. If the Treasurer's broad-based consumption tax had been implemented it would have afforded some relief and compensation to those Australians worst affected. But, no! That source of revenue has been developed by stealth. The massive increase in the wholesale sales tax of some 200 per cent was concentrated mostly on goods in the 30 per cent area and is a very regressive tax. This source of revenue has increased to something like 11.5 per cent of the total revenue, whereas in 1983 it was 5 to 6 per cent of revenue. Many Australians would be concerned about additional indirect taxation of this nature; they need to realise that the Government is doing it by stealth.

The shadow Treasurer said that he deplores the Government's economic mismanagement. That shows up, as we are all aware, in the vast overseas debt that has accumulated under this Government. It has increased in gross terms to $140 billion, nearly a fivefold increase over the period of this Government. It increases relentlessly, minute by minute, hour by hour, and day by day. In August, the current account deficit, and the likely increase in debt of $2.6 billion, means an increase in debt of something like $100m every day. It is absolutely crucial that Government economic management be directed at this problem and what is basically causing it. The first cause is excessive spending, especially by the Government. In other words, we must save more and spend less. The second cause is endemically high inflation. Australia consistently has a higher inflation rate than Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, varying in recent years from a factor of four times the average of our trading partners to twice that average. As the third cause, I stress stagnant national productivity, which has a lot to do with the taxation regime of this Government and has adversely affected incentives. Indeed, stagnant national productivity over the period would be the single most important performance and policy failure under the Government.

To solve the problem, we must first address inflation. There can be no doubt that the Government is soft on inflation. Why? The answer is that it relates directly to the taxation matters that we are discussing tonight, because continually high inflation feeds the coffers of this rapacious Government through bracket creep. Do we get any reaction from the Government to our proposal in the Economic Action Plan to return at the end of each financial year the effects of bracket creep? The amount will be identified and will be returned to taxpayers. The Government, however, does not give any recognition to that proposal. It immediately enters into plans, as revealed by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) this week to match that largess in terms of receipts with largess in spending. There can be no doubt that the Government is very soft on inflation. There has to be a concerted policy to combat it involving very taut monetary and fiscal policies, particularly monetary policies.

We hear about tight monetary policy. We have had very high interest rates but to August last year a 30 per cent increase in the money supply. One can turn to the back of any issue of the Economist and look at the changes in the money supply. Australia is way in front with an increase of about 30 per cent. The United Kingdom is probably second with about 16 per cent. Germany, the United States of America and Japan have figures of 5 or 6 per cent. So our figure of 30 per cent compares with theirs of 5 or 6 per cent. Is it any wonder, with a floor from our centralised wage system and with that sort of slack in money, that we have continuing inflation? We have to concentrate on combating inflation and really mean it. We have to increase productivity and national production, including more investment in and production of export goods to replace imports. That is absolutely essential. I must stress more national saving; we must save more and spend less. We must kill inflation and increase productivity.

Our Economic Action Plan is a dynamic program to achieve that. It embraces a variety of initiatives such as phasing down the centralised wage system and freeing up the labour market to foster an enterprise based industrial relations system, linking increased wages to higher productivity, combating restrictive work practices and encouraging improved practices and changed attitudes and performance by Australian management, increased productivity in the transport industries, the wharves and so on and the privatisation of publicly owned enterprises for greater efficiency.

Tax policy is of very great importance in all these matters and I make a passing reference to our family tax package in the Economic Action Plan. I take this opportunity to stress that our economic and tax policies represent a comprehensive and integrated package to restore the Australian economy and thereby benefit all Australians. Rather than being the country with the third largest overseas bank debt in the world after Brazil and Mexico, we will begin to stabilise that and ensure that we can again stand proud in the international community of nations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this wonderful world in which we live at the moment, what a wonderful thing an amendment to the motion for the second reading of a Bill is because it allows people such as the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), who has just spoken, to wander far and wide in the debate on a specific piece of taxation legislation. But the one thing that the Australian community will realise, for all that our good friend and colleague has said, is that, were there any possibility of a coalition government, we would see a return to the use of unemployment as an economic tool. People well remember the Fraser-Howard years when the coalition government used that very miserable of all tools to regulate the economy in its ham-fisted way.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Berowra talked about a wages policy that a coalition government would somehow have in concert with its tax policy. The Australian public will also remember the coalition's record in recent national wage cases. In about 18 of the last 20 national wage cases, what has been the coalition's position? It has been for no increase. Australians will remember that simple fact when they eventually go to the polls. The coalition's record on wages is abysmal. It has sat by and tried to put the lid well and truly on wage growth, which has a great effect on people's standard of living. I was going to say something about the research and development aspects of this legislation and take business to task for its inability to react to the generous way in which this Government has allowed a host of concessions--

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 7, page 5, lines 16 and 17, omit from proposed subsection (3a):
``this section and sections 73c and 73d apply as if the partnership were an eligible company.''
and substitute
``the following paragraphs have effect:

(c) each partner is to be taken for the purposes of this section and sections 73c and 73d to have incurred so much (if any) of the expenditure as was incurred out of money contributed by the partner (otherwise than by way of loan), whether in the year of income in which the expenditure was incurred or a previous year of income;

(d) if the partnership has, whether before or after the commencement of this subsection, received, or become entitled to receive, a recoupment of, or a grant in respect of, the whole or any part of the expenditure, each partner is to be taken for the purposes of this section and sections 73c and 73d to have received, or become entitled to receive, so much (if any) of the recoupment or grant as is calculated in accordance with the formula:
amount of recoupment
or grant X partner's contribution
total contribution;
where:

`partner's contribution' means the total contribution made (otherwise than by way of loan) by the partner to the funds of the partnership as at the time when the recoupment or grant was received or the entitlement to the recoupment or grant arose, as the case may be;

`total contribution' means the total of the contributions made (otherwise than by way of loan) by all the partners to the funds of the partnership as at the time when the recoupment or grant was received or the entitlement to the recoupment or grant arose, as the case may be;

(e) any expenditure that a partner is to be so taken to have incurred, and any recoupment or grant that a partner is to be so taken to have received or become entitled to receive, is not to be taken into account in determining the net income of the partnership or any partnership loss, as the case may be, of the year of income; and

(f) subject to paragraph (c), (d) and (e), this section and sections 73c and 73d apply in relation to each such partner that is an eligible company as if that partner, and not the partnership, were, or had been, carrying on the relevant project and activities, but so apply with such modifications to those sections as are appropriate having regard to the partner's interest in the partnership.''.
(2) Clause 8, page 7, line 29, after ``1987'', insert ``and in respect of which this section applies to the company.''.

The amendments will address two matters affecting application of the research and development concession. The first concerns partners in a partnership of otherwise eligible companies in a research and development project. It is intended that a company partner be entitled to a deduction directly related to the contributions the company makes to the expenditure of the partnership, and that any different basis of distribution of profits and losses provided by any partnership agreement between the partners would not apply.

The proposed amendment will ensure that the deduction allowed to a partner company will be calculated by reference to the amount of expenditure that was incurred out of money contributed by the partner in the year of income, or contributed in a previous year but not then utilised. Where a partnership receives or becomes entitled to receive a recoupment or grant in respect of expenditure, each partner's share of the amount is to be calculated by reference to the proportion which the partner's contribution to the partnership funds bears to the total contributed to those funds by all of the partners.

The amendment also makes clear that it is the partners, and not the partnership, which are to be taken to have incurred expenditure or to have received or become entitled to receive a grant or recoupment. One effect of this amendment will be that a partner company will be required to meet the expenditure thresholds provided by the research and development provisions. The second matter concerns all companies to which the research and development provisions apply. The amendment now proposed will correct a provision in the Bill which could arguably negate the intended operation of the present research and development provision, section 73b, from its commencement in 1986 to 20 November 1987. We are here at this hour because of the decision of the Opposition--
