DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1989

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, I table the explanatory memorandum for the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Bill 1989.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 October, on motion by Mr Hand:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today we debated the Senate's amendments to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill-a Bill which was rushed through this House under the guillotine in May 1989. Here we are again faced with a Bill which was brought into the Parliament only two days ago and which also is under the guillotine. I believe that it is significant that legislation regarding Australia's Aboriginal folk is nearly always debated in this place after midnight. It is an absolute disgrace that tonight we are debating a Bill which has been rushed into the Parliament-a Bill which deals with excisions of land to try to get land for needy people in Australia-under the guillotine. The coalition is committed to utilising the coming two-week break to consult with parties that want to express views on the Bill. Already, Senator Grant Tambling from the Northern Territory has identified a number of matters of concern in the Bill. I seek leave to table and incorporate in Hansard a letter from Senator Tambling to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand).
—I do not think the Minister has seen it. He will come back to me.

—The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1989 purports to give effect to the so-called historic agreement outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 7 September this year. The Prime Minister's statement dealt only with those amendments necessary to provide the Aboriginal community with living areas on pastoral properties. On the whole, that agreement was hailed by most as an agreement for commonsense. It had long been a contentious issue that required some compromise by all involved: the Aboriginal people who had been displaced from the land of their ancestors; the white pastoralists whose hardy pioneering ancestors had also had claim to the land; the powerful Northern Territory land councils which laid claim to all stock routes and reserves in the Northern Territory; and the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory governments which had become enmeshed in a legal wrangle. The tragic bottom line is that, for as long as compromise was delayed, the Aboriginal communities living either on pastoral properties or on stock routes and reserves-some 5,000 to 6,000-were denied the infrastructure and services required to lift them out of their Third World living conditions. Without title to land, neither the Northern Territory Government nor the Commonwealth could provide services such as housing and water to these communities.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue has a long history; it goes back to 1982 when the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), as a Minister, was trying to achieve this for the Aboriginal people. Of course, this Government has been in power for seven years now and, in that time, it has made no progress on this matter. Some progress was thought to have been made as far back as 1984 when an agreement was struck between the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs who is now the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding), the Northern Territory Government and the Northern Territory cattlemen. They agreed to cooperate in the provision of Aboriginal community living areas on pastoral properties under Northern Territory title so long as traditional land claims to stock routes and stock reserves were dropped. In announcing the amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill in 1986, Mr Holding said:
The proposal in section 50 to remove from claims stock routes and stock reserves would remove a significant concern of the Northern Territory Government and the pastoral industry.
He went on to say:
In many cases, to grant such a claim would result in the splitting of a pastoral lease, since stock routes often traversed pastoral properties.

Until now nothing has happened. The current Minister did not honour the Commonwealth's undertaking. He did not proclaim the agreed amendments to section 50 of the above Act. The result is that, since the initiation of the excisions program commenced, progress in providing community living areas has been abysmally slow. Only 21 titles have been issued for Aboriginal living areas under Northern Territory title. Seventeen offers of territory title have been made and a further 12 offers of living areas are now ready to be made which are subject to the proclamation of the amendment to section 50 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. The failure of the Minister to proclaim section 50 of the Act allowed land councils to claim all stock routes and stock reserves and demand Commonwealth title for excisions on pastoral properties.

This-the land councils' blanket claim on all stock routes and reserves-has always been the stumbling block. It was the main reason the Northern Territory Government and the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association (NTCA) suspended negotiations with the Federal Government and the land councils in 1986. Land councils, in effect, denied Aboriginal groups the opportunity to accept freehold titles which were immediately available because they were to be under Territory title, not Commonwealth title. The provision of basic services to these communities was impaired.

International attention was focused on this issue on 4 August this year when the Arrente people moved onto the Yambah pastoral lease featured in a Four Corners program of July. The issue was finally brought to a head on 21 August this year when the Chief Minister drew the Prime Minister into the fray by outlining his concerns in a letter to him. When the Prime Minister failed to answer the Chief Minister's concerns, Mr Perron threatened a snap election. A flurry of activity followed, as that election-phobic government rediscovered consultation. After consultation the agreement was signed. The heart of that agreement provided that a small portion of stock routes and reserves would be scheduled where no agreement had been possible on pastoral excisions and that pastoral excisions would happen under freehold territory title on the basis of need.

The amendments announced in the Bill we are debating this morning go beyond the grant of excisions from pastoral properties for Aboriginal living areas. They amend the Act in various other ways, mostly in respect of mining arrangements which are apparently non-contentious and which do not directly affect the excisions matter. The Bill is the result of the September agreement which envisaged complementary legislation by the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory. Essentially, the grant of title to excised areas was to be Territory legislation and by means of Territory title, while the grant of claims over stock routes and reserves was to be under the Commonwealth Act. The Northern Territory has passed legislation-the Miscellaneous Acts Amendment (Aboriginal Community Living Areas) Act 1989. The Bill before us gives effect to the undertaking by the Commonwealth in the memorandum of 7 September which states:

The Commonwealth will amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1975, as a matter of priority, to provide for the grant, by way of inclusion in a Schedule to the Act, of certain parts of existing stock routes and reserve claims. The actual areas to be included in the new parts 2 and 3 of schedule 1 are alleged by the Minister to have been discussed by the Northern Territory and Commonwealth governments.

The Northern Territory Government disputes that. Its position was formally put to the Prime Minister by the Chief Minister on 25 September and Territory officers continued to provide information to the Commonwealth on the areas being considered and to respond to Commonwealth requests. On 25 October, Commonwealth officers advised that they were unable to provide the information sought. To my knowledge, the Territory still has not received any information on these undertakings except to read the references in the Minister's second reading speech which my colleague the honourable member for Bass (Mr Warwick Smith) faxed to the Northern Territory immediately after that reading. Nor has the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association been adequately consulted. All that it has seen is a list of properties which might or might not be scheduled. All requests for detailed and definite information have been brushed aside.

On 30 October the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association faxed a letter to the Prime Minister pointing out that it had not been consulted about the areas to be scheduled. The answer was the Minister's decision to push the Bill through all stages in the House of Representatives this week. That is why the consultation could not take place. It is an old saga. We hear it all the time. The consultation has failed in this area of administration under this Government. This is the typical manner in which this Minister undertakes consultation. Throughout this process the Minister has endeavoured to stretch the principles of the memorandum to the limit-to piggy-back other issues onto an agreement which had been made between Marshall Perron and the Prime Minister. It has taken the personal intervention of the Prime Minister on several occasions to keep the process on the rails.

In his speech the Minister does not mention these proposed amendments that he has dropped from the Amendment Bill. He had endeavoured, in a totally underhand fashion, to piggy-back some controversial amendments, mostly related to the mining provisions of the Act. These would have affected mining and exploration activity in the Territory and further entrenched the position and power of the land councils. At the formal request of the Northern Territory Chief Minister, these amendments have been dropped for the time being. While the coalition supports this legislation there are some technical concerns-now subject to legal analysis-which may require amendment in the Senate. There are other concerns. The first relates to the total area to be granted. The 7 September memorandum said:
The Commonwealth undertook that, in providing Aboriginals with living areas on stock routes and stock reserves, the following principles will apply:
it will schedule only a small proportion of the land subject to existing claims . . .
The total area to be granted is 2,312 square kilometres or 26 per cent of the land claimed. Considering that the claims were ambit ones to start with, the land councils have done quite well.

The second point relates to undertakings by Aboriginal claimants. According to the Minister, the grant of certain of these areas is subject to undertakings by Aboriginal claimants, designed presumably to remove or reduce the detriment that pastoralists or others might otherwise suffer. What are these undertakings? Will the Minister provide documented evidence of the particular undertakings that have been made? Will the Minister provide documented evidence of the way in which these undertakings were made known to lessees of pastoral properties in the area of the claim? Already the shadow Minister's office has had representations from solicitors who claim that their clients will be adversely affected.
The third point concerns areas to be granted by scheduling. The Minister said:
. . . the selection of the areas has been determined after consultation with the Northern Territory.

It should be noted, however, that the final decision does rest with the Commonwealth. As I have already mentioned, the Northern Territory Government is still trying to find out what is in the schedules and the NTCA has not been consulted at all.

The fourth point concerns the descriptions of areas to be scheduled. Clause 16-proposed section 77C-allows the Minister to make regulations to `modify' the descriptions of the areas to be inserted in parts: parts 2 and 3 of schedule 1. Such modification could result in the areas being enlarged or, indeed, reduced from those originally approved by the Parliament. We will be watching this matter carefully.

The fifth point concerns future claims over stock routes. There is nothing in the present amendments which guarantees the proclamation of the 1987 amendment to section 50 of the Act, which would prevent any further Aboriginal claims over stock routes and reserves. When the present amendments have been passed and assented to, subsection 50 (2d) and paragraph 50 (2e) (a) will continue to have no effect unless and until they have been proclaimed. Only the words in the 7 September memorandum provide a modicum of assurance. The memorandum states:
Upon enactment of the scheduling legislation, the Commonwealth will then proclaim the June 1987 amendments . . .

The Government thus continues the present uncertainty which we have had for the entire period of this Parliament. This thing could have been settled back in 1987 but it had not been proclaimed even though the legislation went through Parliament. It leaves it to ministerial discretion to determine when and, as a matter of law, whether the original repeal will take effect.

The sixth point relates to access to Aboriginal land. This appears to be unusual in that a person-that is, any member of the public, whether Aboriginal or not-will be required to negotiate with the land council access to Aboriginal land across non-Aboriginal land. Generally, if one wants to go across someone's land one negotiates with the owner, not the owner of the place one wants to get to. However, it is recognised that Aboriginal owners do need to be able to travel to and from that land. Why this is included in the Commonwealth Act is uncertain. The Northern Territory Lands Acquisition Act requires the Minister to acquire the relevant land, including, where necessary, an easement for reasonable access to the land.

I understand that there are three amendments to be moved to this legislation. I again point out to this Parliament that having had the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill go through this place-it was amended 92 times-a new piece of legislation is now coming into the House, but it is still not complete. At five o'clock this afternoon I got an amendment and at five to 12 I got another one; there was another change. This is not the way to bring legislation into this Parliament. It would not be so bad if we had not had so many amendments in the last piece of legislation relating to Aboriginal affairs. This Minister brings half-baked legislation into this House; the work has not been done.

It is about time we got the administration of Aboriginal affairs on the rails so that when legislation comes in here it is complete. The coalition does not oppose the passage of this legislation, but over the next few weeks we will seek to consult with the parties who want to express a view on the Bill and we will address any proposed amendments in the Senate. We want these people to have the opportunity of title to these parts of lands. They are a group of people who for years and years have not been able to get infrastructure into their communities. There is a great need for that. It is a great tragedy that for seven years this Government has failed to address that problem effectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —I advise the honourable member for Braddon that leave has been granted for the letter to be tabled but the letter does not meet the guidelines for incorporation in Hansard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has to be one of the most patronising, gratuitous contributions I have heard since I have been a member of this Parliament. This person, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), who masquerades as a spokesman for Aboriginal affairs on behalf of the shadow Minister, has come into this place and trotted out a speech which has no doubt been written by someone in the Northern Territory Government. In my view, it has demonstrated a complete lack of understanding or appreciation of the concerns of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. He is someone who wanted to be a Minister. It just so happens that the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill has been close to my heart for some time. Prior to coming to this place I worked for the Central Land Council, and I am proud to say that. In 1986 these proposals were put forward but they were not accepted by the Northern Territory Government or by the pastoralists. Why were they not accepted? Because they were not prepared to compromise.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Braddon has the hide to walk into this place and make accusations about Aboriginal people and their ability to put it over the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth Government. He said that this agreement is regarded as one of commonsense. If it is regarded as one of commonsense now, why was it not regarded as one of commonsense in 1986? Why? Because his friends in the Northern Territory Government, who refused to recognise the concerns of Aboriginal people, were not prepared to see the commonsense in these proposals which have been put forward.

There is not enough time available to allow me to go through the scope of this legislation. I wanted to explain to the House the situation in which some Aboriginal people live-those whom no doubt the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) would try to oppress; those whom no doubt the honourable member for Parkes and the honourable member for Braddon would like to deny rights to. In 1971 the Gibb Committee, formed under a conservative government, made recommendations on the matter of excisions. Six thousand Aboriginal people remained landless, despite the Aboriginal Land Rights Act passed in this House in 1976. They now have an opportunity to get somewhere secure to live. These are people who have attracted the focus of the international community because of their atrocious Third World living conditions. They are conditions which could have been rectified by the Northern Territory Government since the day it got powers of self-government in 1978. It has refused to do so.

What does the honourable member for Braddon say about that? The Northern Territory Government has had it within its power to pass community living areas legislation since that time and has not done so. What is the excuse of the honourable member for Braddon? There is not one. He is someone who masquerades as having knowledge, but he has none. I would invite the honourable member for Braddon and the honourable member for Parkes, as I already have done this evening, to come to the Northern Territory. I will escort them around, and let us talk to some of the people who are going to be disadvantaged by this situation. The stock routes and reserves are the remnants of a bygone era when droving was the go. They are not part of pasture leases, as some people would have us believe, although many pastoralists talk as if they are. They continue to use them. They are vacant Crown land and, as such, claimable under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act.

The agreement which has been reached between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory is indeed historic. I must pay some compliments to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I also compliment the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory for having the gumption to come down and at least settle this situation. We will wait to see what legislation passes through the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly and how it will be used within the Northern Territory. The honourable member for Braddon was keen to say that 26 per cent of the stock routes and reserves are going to be transferred to Aboriginal people. What he omitted to say was that the remainder will be available for being absorbed into pastoral leases. So pastoralists stand to gain approximately 6,580 square metres.

I conclude by giving a couple of examples of people who will be advantaged by this process. The people of Yambah: in August 1984 the Lynch, Turner and Palmer families, amongst others, decided to leave the grog and other problems of the Alice Springs fringe camps and take their families back to their traditional land at Yambah. They set up camp at McGrath's dam stock reserve: tents at first and later some tin shacks. But they still had no basic services. Ever since they have moved home they have been carting water from Alice Springs. For the first few years it was in recycled 44-gallon drums on the back of a truck. Since 1987 they have been able to hire the use of a water truck from one of the Aboriginal organisations in town. Their water is still stored in recycled fuel drums-no doubt something that the honourable member for Parkes is proud of. The families organised a chucking system with people chucking in a part of their pension cheques each week to buy water-something which indeed the honourable member for Parkes would promote. At one time they were paying 275 times what Alice Springs residents paid for water. Today it is approximately 30 times the cost of town water. Some camps still have to store water in 44-gallon drums. With secure title, a proper water supply can be found.

They are the sort of people who will be advantaged by this legislation. That is something that could have happened as far back as 1978, should have happened in 1986 and is at last happening. As I say, it is indeed a compliment to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who is at the table, and this Government that this has now happened. As I said previously, I pay some compliment to the Northern Territory Government for at last having the fortitude to accept the challenge and reach an agreement with the Commonwealth. But we will wait and see what happens and make sure that they live up to their agreement.

I would like to spend a lot more time on this debate because there are a lot of issues that need canvassing and a lot of history that needs to be read into the Hansard in relation to this matter. But I will say that the efforts of the land councils on behalf of their clients, the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory, have deserved great credit.

Apart from the derogatory comments which have been made by the Opposition members in previous debates in this place and again tonight about the role of land councils in looking after the interests of Aboriginal people, the councils have shown by their dedication, their professionalism and by example that they have acted as Aboriginal people have expected. As a former employee of a land council I can say that there was not one occasion when the Central Land Council, for which I worked, operated without the direct instructions of the Aboriginal people who were its clients and its bosses. On not one occasion did the Council go to government without the direct instructions of its clients and without acting for the benefit of its clients. I commend this legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a ridiculously early hour of the morning, and it is disappointing that we have had to put up with the sour delivery of the previous speaker, the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). We are here at this early hour to debate the amending of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. The main thrust of the legislation, as the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) has said, is to put in place the 6 and 7 September agreements between the Northern Territory Chief Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) relating to the grant of excisions of land from pastoral properties for Aboriginal living areas. That will amount in total to 2,312 square kilometres, which is 0.17 per cent of the Northern Territory. I understand that it takes in about 27 areas, including 6 per cent of stock routes. If enacted, it will give security of title to Aboriginal people who wish to live in these areas and because the security will be there money will be spent with confidence on building up an infrastructure for them so that they will have better living conditions than they have had to put up with in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say that this is a free country and people are entitled to live anywhere they so wish. But I do not enthusiastically endorse setting up excision areas for Aborigines to live on carte blanche because there is a high cost involved in setting them up and even with the high cost they still have fairly frugal facilities. If they are in isolated areas the children often grow up with little prospect of getting jobs. In some instances I believe that it leads to perpetuating unemployment. I think the future for Aboriginal people, particularly the children, lies in giving them a good education and prospects for jobs at the end of the day.

This legislation has some detrimental aspects. It is absolutely vital to the Northern Territory people. It has been debated there for many years, particularly over the last couple of decades. Now it is to be rushed through the House after 35 minutes of debate at this hour of the morning. I think that is regrettable. As the honourable member for Braddon said, it has been done with little consultation with the Northern Territory Government. The consultation which did take place was usually instigated by the Northern Territory Government. There has been no effective consultation at all with the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association. To some extent, it affects the cattlemen's livelihood. It reminds me of the recent Kakadu decision with Coronation Hill. Just before the decision was made the Prime Minister spoke for 90 minutes to Phillip Toyne of the Australian Conservation Foundation. Sir Arvi Parbo rang up and he did not even get a hearing even though he had a guarantee in writing that the project would go ahead and had spent $12m as a result. I believe that this sort of cynical expediency will only lead to certain defeat at the polls.

Another interesting aspect of the legislation is that Commonwealth title will be granted, as I understand it from my reading of the legislation, for stock routes and stock reserves, but Territory title, which is a special freehold title, will be used for the pastoral excisions. I cannot see why that would not have sufficed for all the land that is to be encompassed in this Bill. It contains a host of inadequacies and deficiencies. When it is debated in the Senate, no doubt a number of amendments will be moved by the Opposition to improve the Bill.

Section 77c states that the Minister will be given the power to make regulations to modify the size of the areas granted. It seems strange to me that, if that is taken to its logical extension, these areas could be enlarged to a considerable extent without the matter coming back before Parliament. I believe that this needs to be tightened up. I was disappointed to see an article in Vanguard, the Communist Party of Australia's newsletter that is sent around to all members. The article in the 9 August edition could almost have been written by the previous speaker opposite. It talks about:

. . . the mining and pastoral monopolies carrying on the tradition of gross oppression and exploitation of this continent's original inhabitants, a tradition founded by British colonialism's invasion of Australia and attempted genocide of Aboriginal people.
It further states:
The cattlemen's association represents the most reactionary, extremist, racist wing of the pastoral monopolies . . .
The paper also refers to:
`the greed of the pastoralists' and to the `pigheadedness of the Northern Territory Government'.

It is sad when language such as that is used in this country. In conclusion-as time is running out-I say that this legislation is flawed, as is so much of the legislation brought into Parliament that relates to Aboriginal affairs. Hopefully, when the Bill is finally agreed to by this House and the Senate it will have been amended into a better form, for the benefit of both pastoralists and the Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take up only a few minutes. I want to respond to the honourable member who has just resumed his seat, the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb). I refer to what was said some 120 years ago by the Australian Catholic bishops, who wrote to the Australian Catholic Church about the ill-treatment of Aborigines. In part, the letter stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We have dispossessed the Aboriginals of the soil . . . In natural justice then we are held to compensation. It is shocking to think of what has in fact been done. With very little, with short lived exception, injustice, neglect, cruelty . . . have branded the annals of white man.

In fact, that is what this legislation is all about. It is a small attempt-but a valuable contribution-to make the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 more effective in meeting the needs of Aboriginal people in the Territory, especially those living on stock routes and pastoral properties. The issue of Aboriginal communities living on stock routes and on pastoral properties is one which demands more time than is available to me tonight. I appreciate that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), wishes to add a few words before the debate is concluded. So, with those very few words, I will resume my seat.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Time is against us, but I want to respond to a couple of things. I found that the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) who substituted tonight for the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), has not improved on his normal degree of dishonesty in the way he has approached the debate. I do regret that the shadow Minister is not here.
—The Minister should withdraw the word `dishonesty'.

—I withdraw it. However, I ask people to read his speech and to compare his comments with the facts. I am disappointed with the debate on the Bill tonight. Following a conversation with my office and the shadow Minister, I was under the clear impression that at a meeting of the shadow Ministry the Opposition had decided to support the proposals. This followed a briefing in my office for the shadow Minister and his staff and, unfortunately, the individual sitting opposite. I was contacted by the shadow Minister and told that he would be supporting the proposals. I find it extremely disappointing that the speech made by the honourable member opposite contained the comments that it did. Many of them were simply not true and they obviously arose out of a misunderstanding of what has been proposed. I have met with the Northern Territory Government on numerous occasions, as have my officers. I have met with the Chief Minister four or five times.
—Order! The time allocated for the second reading stage of the Bill has expired. The question is: That the Bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2, lines 16 and 17, omit paragraph (d) of the proposed definition of ``exploration licence''.
(2) Clause 3, page 2, lines 27-39, omit paragraph (a) of the proposed definition of ``intending miner''.
(3) Clause 9, omit the clause.

These amendments are an example of the sort of consultation that has been entered into by not only me but also my officers and officers of the Northern Territory Government. I find it amazing that the Opposition's representative can come in here tonight and make the sorts of claims that he did. I point out that the original proposal was included in the group of amendments at the request of the Northern Territory Government. It now has a difficulty with the amendment and I immediately agreed this evening to withdraw it.

Following the honourable member's speech I do not know whether he intends to oppose or support the amendments. It is an extraordinary situation. We received an approach from the Northern Territory Government to address this issue. My officers and Northern Territory Government officers worked on this proposal and it was included in the amendments. We now find that the Northern Territory Government still has a problem with it and, in the spirit of the agreement between the Chief Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), I have immediately withdrawn it because it now becomes controversial. I do not believe one can play the game any more fairly than that. To get the scheduled items up in these areas of land that we all want to see passed across to the Aboriginal people, they must be attached to some amendments, and that is why we are moving them. The rest of the amendments are non-controversial.

The honourable member raised a number of points and referred to a letter from Senator Tambling, and that will be addressed. I say to the honourable member and to the Opposition that I find it extraordinary that the shadow Minister has telephoned me to say that the shadow Ministry has met and that it supports this proposal, yet the honourable member comes in here and makes the accusations and comments that he has made. I think that is an astounding way to perform. If honourable members opposite had not held up the business of this place yesterday we would have had more time to discuss this matter. It was put in tonight because of the commitment the Prime Minister and I made to Marshal Perron that we would introduce this measure in October, pass it as quickly as possible in this place and get it across to the Senate. We are fulfilling our commitment. People have required this land for a long time and we are acting on their requests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the committee stage has expired. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Primary Industries and Energy: Newspapers and Magazines

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Are officers of the Minister's Department regularly supplied with newspapers or magazines; if so, (a) which officer classifications are entitled to this facility, (b) what is each officer's entitlement, (c) which newspapers and magazines are supplied, (d) what was the cost of providing this facility in (i) 1983-84, (ii) 1984-85, (iii) 1985-86, (iv) 1986-87, (v) 1987-88 and (vi) 1988-89, (e) who supplies the newspapers and magazines to the Department, (f) if tenders were called for the supply of the newspapers and magazines, how was the successful tenderer selected and (g) if tenders were not called for why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Newspapers and magazines are regularly purchased for use by Departmental staff:
(a) Purchases are made on a needs basis only. No officers are entitled to obtain any item because of their position/classification
(c) A range of daily/weekly/monthly newspapers and magazines suitable to the needs of the Department

(d) (i) Answer cannot be provided as records are held in outposted archives, in formats from which it is difficult to extract the information sought and there are insufficient resources available to retrieve the information

(iv) ACT $19,000; in respect of other States the records are archived in formats from which it is difficult to extract the information sought and there are insufficient resources available to retrieve the information
(e) Newspapers are supplied by local newsagents and magazines by various publishers
(g) Business was conducted according to Newsagency Association agreements for market areas.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Committee of Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 30 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of (a) running the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers' meeting held in Canberra in August this year and (b) travel assistance to each person attending.
(2) Upon what basis was it decided who would attend and who would not.
(3) Why was not a wider range of opinions canvassed from other advisers such as Helen Suzman and Chief Buthelezi.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The cost of running the Commonwealth Committee of Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa (CFMSA) meeting in August this year was $113,703; (b) The Australian Government did not provide any travel assistance to persons attending the Canberra CFMSA meeting. Ministers however are eligible to claim the cost of their airfares from the CFMSA budget administered by the Commonwealth Secretariat and to which Australia has pledged an amount of up to $200,000 over two years for meetings and related special studies. The South African `witnesses' attending the meeting also had their airfares and a per diem allowance paid from the Commonwealth Secretariat's CFMSA budget.

(2) The Committee of Commonwealth Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa was established in 1987 at the CHOGM in Vancouver to provide high level guidance on Commonwealth initiatives to bring about the eradication of apartheid in South Africa by peaceful means. The Committee consists of the Foreign Ministers of Australia, Canada, Guyana, India, Nigeria, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe. The Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, Mr Joe Clark, is Chairman of the Committee.

The Canberra CFMSA meeting in August was the fourth meeting of the Committee and, as with the three preceding meetings, was attended by the eight Foreign Ministers on the Committee and accompanying officials. In addition, the Foreign Minister of Malaysia, Dato' Abu Hassan, was invited by the Canadian Chairman to attend the meeting in recognition of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting to follow shortly after in Kuala Lumpur. At his request, New Zealand Foreign Minister Russell Marshall was also invited by the Canadian Chairman to address the Committee on arrangements for the Commonwealth Games to be held in Auckland next year.

(3) Those invited from South Africa to provide expert testimony at the CFMSA meeting were selected by the Canadian Chairman of the Committee. The selection of a church leader, a union representative and a member of the human rights movement in South Africa, as well as a representative of each of the African National Congress and Pan Africanist Congress of Azania, ensured that Ministers were exposed to a wide-ranging, representative group of those opposed to apartheid within South Africa. It would have been an even more representative group had the South African Government at the last minute not decided to deny a passport to Mr Azhar Cachalia, Treasurer of the United Democratic Front, who had also been invited to appear as a witness at the Canberra meeting.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 6 September 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) During the morning of 28 April 1989 did the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) Inspection Branch receive a query and complaint by telephone from the Member for Farrer in relation to the condition of the runway at Whittingham Aerodrome, which services Singleton, NSW.
(2) Was an inspection of the aerodrome carried out by the CAA on (a) 28 April 1989, (b) 1 May 1989, (c) 2 May 1989 or (d) 3 May 1989.

(3) If an inspection was not carried out before 3 May 1989, did the CAA telephone the operator and owner of the aerodrome beforehand; if so, (a) on how many occasions, (b) did the call or calls alert the operator to a forthcoming inspection and (c) was the timing of the inspection canvassed with the operator.

(4) Did the CAA inform her that (a) on or about 5 July 1989 a Navajo aircraft operated by a commuter airline and carrying passengers became bogged on the runway proper, near the taxiway, when landing at the aerodrome and (b) the runway was closed twice during autumn and winter of 1989 because of a lack of serviceability; if so, was either item of information placed before her before she signed a letter dated 10 August 1989 to the Member for Farrer.
(5) Have the runway works identified by the CAA on 22 March and 7 June 1989, and referred to in a CAA letter of 14 August 1989, been completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mr Warren Gengos, Assistant General Manager, Safety Regulation received a telephone complaint from the Member for Farrer concerning the condition of the runway at Whittingham Aerodrome on the morning of 28 April 1989. Mr Blackall, Manager, Airport Inspection telephoned the Member for Farrer that afternoon for further details.
(2) An inspection of Whittingham Aerodrome was carried out by the CAA on 3 May 1989.
(3a) The operator of the Aerodrome was telephoned once on 28 April 1989.

(5) Not all the runway works identified by the CAA in a letter dated 14 August 1989 were completed. This contributed to the Instrument of Authorisation, which allowed operations at Whittingham Aerodrome, being withdrawn by the CAA on 8 September.
